HEADLINE: SUNDAY, May 1, 1994;
Help Wanted: Actors

 BODY:
Who better to coach the unemployed than actors, who are always out of work? The idea may seem perverse, but that's what the New York State Department of Labor and the Actors' Work Program are doing with the Theater of the Employed.
Gail Parker, an actor, led a recent workshop in this program in the garment district of Manhattan. "For better or worse, actors are pros at rejection," she said. Parker has also been a "certified fitness instructor," "trainer" and "communications professional." 
 Among the participants in her workshop were several lawyers, two money managers, an interior designer, a research technician and one man who said: "What am I? Anything I guess. I don't know. Economist."
Parker provided unwavering support during two hours of mock interviews and breathing exercises as the job seekers learned to correct their posture, investigate potential employers and practice projecting their voices to unsuspecting strangers at fruit markets. She didn't expect them all to return for the follow-up a week later. Some, presumably, would have already found dramatically new roles.

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
Arthur Miller Still Holds to His Moral Vision

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby 

 BODY:
TIME HASN'T HAD A STOP, BUT it's doing a graceful pause at the Booth Theater, where "Broken Glass," Arthur Miller's small, intense, deceptively prosy new drama, has set up shop. It was just a half-century ago that Mr. Miller made his Broadway debut with "The Man Who Had All the Luck," which closed after four performances, to begin a career that in 1949 was to include "Death of a Salesman," a modern classic and the work by which everything he has since written continues to be judged. In a metier where people burn out fast, he's still remarkable for the acuity and scope of his moral vision.
It's this vision, as well as the Miller voice, which remains as strong and unrelenting as a prophet's, that distinguish "Broken Glass" and give it a poignance so rare these days that it's almost new-fashioned. The play is ostensibly about a failed marriage, but the failure Mr. Miller examines has less to do with connubial relations than with one man's warped perception of the American way. Like Willy Loman in "Death of a Salesman," the hero of "Broken Glass" hasn't misread society's signals so much as he has blindly accepted them. 
 The time is 1938, the year of the Anschluss, when Hitler walked into Austria and announced, "It's mine," and of Kristallnacht (the night of broken glass), when rioting against the Jews in Germany suddenly alerted the rest of the world to everything that was to come. Phillip Gellburg (Ron Rifkin) is the head of the mortgage department of the Brooklyn Guarantee & Trust Company. In fact, he's the only Jew ever hired by the company and proud of it. He's also proud of his son, who has graduated from West Point and is making a career in the Army, largely, it seems, to prove Phillip's point that Jews don't always have to be lawyers, doctors or businessmen.
Phillip is a small man but he's a gigantic mess. Half of him is as anti-Semitic as Stanton Case (George N. Martin), the white Anglo-Saxon Protestant head of Brooklyn Guarantee. The other, only vaguely recognized half is the bewildered son of immigrants, a first-generation Jewish American trying to assimilate. As his life falls apart in the course of the play, Phillip remembers the joy he experienced many years before, walking down Orchard Street with his then-young beautiful bride, Sylvia (Amy Irving). "I felt so at home and happy there," he says, "a street full of Jews, one Moses after another. But they all turned to watch her go by, those fakers." Something you forget about Mr. Miller is that he can write dialogue with the best of them: wonderfully vivid, funny, ironic and economical. He doesn't waste words but, because he favors prosaic locutions, his gift for language is not often recognized.
It's Sylvia who forces Phillip to examine his once perfectly buttoned-up life. When the play opens, he's consulting his neighborhood doctor, Harry Hyman (David Dukes), about Sylvia who, nine days before, developed an inability to walk, stand up or move her legs, something that has just been diagnosed as hysterical paralysis. In every other way, she seems fine, though she has also become obsessed by the news from Germany. This especially irritates Phillip, who blames the sensation-mongering newspapers. He's also worried about Germany, he tells the doctor, but, after all, it's 3,000 miles away. Among other things, he's afraid Hitler will give fancy new ideas to American anti-Semites.
Phillip is desperately conflicted, the sort of passive-aggressive who, in a more conventional drama, would be a supporting character, which is the role he would assign himself. In his black suits, black ties, black shoes and white shirts, he doesn't want to call attention to himself. Mr. Miller places him at stage center and, with the awful gentleness of a surgeon operating without anesthesia, skins him alive. In Mr. Rifkin's richly detailed performance, the spectacle fascinates, though always at a somewhat chilly remove. Mr. Miller doesn't invite easy sentiment.
Sylvia is a far more nebulous character, a woman who gave up a promising business career of her own to become a good Jewish wife and mother, only to realize, too late, that she had married half a man. Now, in a barren middle age, she has caught a glimpse of the void and panicked. Ms. Irving, looking wafer-thin and beautiful, initially seems too young for the role, but she surprises. As she demonstrated in "Heartbreak House" some years ago, she's an actress of substance, intelligence and style. Hers is a most felicitous performance.
The other performances are good, especially those by Mr. Dukes (as the doctor) and Mr. Martin (as Phillip's boss). Yet no matter how their characters are disguised, they exist principally to make the plot function.
"Broken Glass" unfolds in 10 scenes with a gathering, Ibsen-like force as the doctor attempts to uncover the roots of Sylvia's illness. The play is meticulously constructed. This is evident in the way that Mr. Miller eventually reconciles Sylvia's preoccupation with events in Germany, which initially seems associated with some kind of atavistic memory, with what has (or hasn't) been going on in her bedroom. The craft may be meticulous but it is not entirely satisfactory. The ultimate revelations simply confirm the audience's suspicions, instead of somehow turning them upside down.
The production is efficiently directed by John Tillinger in Santo Loquasto's handsome, sleek, if overly complicated turntable set, which revolves to reveal the doctor's office, Phillip and Sylvia's bedroom and the executive suite at Brooklyn Guarantee. The shared visual motif of all three: a pattern of white tiles of the sort you'd find in the shower room of a large, impersonal institution.
 
'Picnic'
 There may be life in "Picnic," William Inge's 1953 Pulitzer Prize winner, but you won't find it in the astonishingly superficial revival by the Roundabout Theater Company at the Criterion Center. For all intents and purposes, the play, now set in the Depressed 1930's, looks deader than a doornail. Who's at fault? It's difficult to say.
I have fond memories of the original Joshua Logan production with a marvelous cast headed by Ralph Meeker, Kim Stanley, Eileen Heckart and Paul Newman, all members of the Actors Studio, and Janice Rule, who later joined the Studio. Yet, when I read the text shortly before going to the Roundabout revival, it seemed almost hopelessly dated: a romantic 1950's reverie about a small group of women in a small Kansas prairie town, and how their lives are changed by the appearance of a none-too-bright young macho drifter. None-too-bright young macho drifters were once the icons of a certain kind of poetic Broadway drama. In the context of today's less inhibited theater, these fellows tend to be flabby, potbellied theatrical devices, even when they spring from the imagination of Tennessee Williams.
"Picnic" contains some funny lines but most of the dialogue is written in a commonplace, faux-naif idiom that demands the talents of an absolutely first-rate cast guided by a director who can find the truth within all of the inarticulate malarkey. Scott Ellis, the director of the splendid revival of "She Loves Me," seems to have got nowhere near any such truth in this production. Even Tony Walton's elaborate set goes to waste. Uninhabited by any strong performances, it's a parched evocation of a small town that could be on Cape Cod or the moon.
It takes actors to make the scenery as well as the text work. As Hal Carter, the drifter, Kyle Chandler looks as if he had just flown home from law school, when he's supposed to have jumped off a freight. He speaks the lines clearly, but that's about all. Ashley Judd plays Madge, identified more than once as the prettiest girl in town, the lonely, lost, inhibited young woman who falls heedlessly in love with Hal. Though the actress is strikingly pretty, she never successfully plays that prettiness, so that by the end of the performance, she's just more scenery.
The high point of the original production, as well as of Logan's 1956 movie version, was the erotic dance by which Hal, the shirtless life force, seduces Madge's Main Street madonna in the twilight of a blistering hot Labor Day, under the watchful eyes of her family and friends. It should be a sure-fire theatrical moment: to the music of a radio, Hal and Madge begin dancing chastely enough but, as they go on, their heat rises. By the time they finish, Hal has forever unleashed forces within Madge that neither of them can comprehend. It's the make-or-break moment of the entire play. In this version, Hal and Madge could be playing horseshoes.
Debra Monk and Larry Bryggman give decent accounts of themselves as an aging schoolteacher and her longtime beau. Most of the other actors behave as if they had never been properly introduced to their characters. They seem to float alongside them, speaking their lines and doing their business without ever making the big leap to get inside them. Exceptional is Anne Pitoniak, who plays the old lady next door. I don't know what she does or how she does it, but the minute Ms. Pitoniak comes on stage, this "Picnic" suddenly finds a center. It's not the right one, but something's better than nothing.
 
'Amphigorey'
 "Amphigorey," at the Perry Street Theater, is officially described as a musicale, but that's just one of the jokes in this classy show, which has the kind of unstoppable zest I associate with the old Shoestring Revues and the revues that Julius Monk once staged at the Plaza. Not since those days have I seen a small cast of such spirited young dancer-singer-actors knock themselves out with such verve simply to please an audience hungry for wit, high spirits and irreverent, literate humor.
There is a difference though. "Amphigorey," based on the writings and drawings of Edward Gorey, is perhaps only fully enjoyed by people who have had a long and loving relationship with Mr. Gorey's surreal work. For others, including me, who know him only through his stylish titles for the PBS "Mystery!" series, "Amphigorey" is often more mysterious than it should be. His is a most special world, a darkly eccentric, contemporary Victorian age, a place that might be imagined by a Lewis Carroll on acid, peopled by voracious opera stars, warring children and other innocents, most of whom come to very bad ends.
When Mr. Gorey's words are sung by a cast as gifted as this one, it's sometimes hard to make them out, even to distinguish the nonsense proper names (Splaytova, Studge, Sergissipov) from the lower-case nouns, verbs, adjectives and adverbs that seldom are sung (or spoken) in familiar conjunction. It's a little like going to the Comedie Francaise without having taken a French refresher course first.
Not always, however. "Q.R.V.," the big opening number featuring the entire cast, is an ecstatic paean to the multiple beneficial effects of Q.R.V., which can settle the nerves, be thrown like a grenade, used to clean drains or dabbed under the arms to act as a love potion. Many of the sketches are obviously based on material so familiar to some members of the audience that they can anticipate the fun. But even I could appreciate a reference in "The Enraged Telephone" (about a telephone at the end of its patience) to the Byword Home for Distracted Menials.
Among the titles of the sketches: "The Admonitory Hippopotamus," "The Inanimate Tragedy" and (my favorite) "The Deranged Cousins," which sounds like a long-lost Nouveau Vague classic but isn't. There's a valuable imagination at work here.
Joyce Sozen appears as Mrs. Regera Dowdy, introduced as one of the "shy and reclusive" Mr. Gorey's "less timid alter egos." She's very funny as the show's alternately raffish and imperial emcee.
Mr. Gorey wrote and designed "Amphigorey." Peter Golub composed the music and Daniel Levans is responsible for the direction and choreography. Everything works with the sort of precision you expect on Broadway. But, be warned: read at least some of the Gorey books first, or take along someone who has.
 
BROKEN GLASS Arthur Miller uses vivid, economical dialogue in a meticulously constructed tale that is not entirely satisfactory.
 
PICNIC Who's at fault? It's difficult to say. Certainly not Anne Pitoniak, in an exceptional performance that grounds Inge's 1953 play.
 
AMPHIGOREY Edward Gorey's classy musicale has a young, spirited cast and unstoppable zest.

HEADLINE: CHOICE TABLES;
Tastes Swing Back To Flavors of Naples

BYLINE: By MAUREEN B. FANT; MAUREEN B. FANT is the author of "Eat Like the Romans: The Visitor's Food Guide" (Alphabyte, Rome).

 BODY:
AMERICANS' love affair with Italian food began with the sunny tastes of the south, and the Bay of Naples in particular -- spaghetti with rich, red tomato sauce, linguine with clams, thick-crusted pizza with oregano. Now, tiring of radicchio and carpaccio, many Italian-food eaters on both sides of the Atlantic are admitting to nostalgia for the flavors of the fertile slopes of Vesuvius. Fortunately, travelers to the Naples area today can have it both ways -- robust ingredients handled in a sophisticated modern way.
If you stay away from bus groups and mandolin players, the restaurant scene is pretty good. During a couple of brief trips last month to Naples and the Sorrento Peninsula, I tried a few of many wonderful places to eat and, just for fun, picked the ones where I would send the Clintons, were I an advisor, when they attend the meeting of the seven largest industrialized countries in Naples this coming July.
 
La Sacrestia
We'd first gone to top-rated La Sacrestia a few years ago and been enchanted. We'd been enchanted by the view of the bay, the whimsical medieval-ecclesiastical decor (the name means sacristy) and lace doilies, and the food. But this time many dishes listed on the menu were not available, and our waiter recited some unlisted dishes that were ex-trendy and banal (fillet with green peppercorns, for example). The quality of the food, as well as the variety, had fallen a bit too. 
 Our appetizer of fried anchovies stuffed with mozzarella was overdone, while our eggplant-stuffed ravioli were underdone, a pity, as the dish was otherwise a symphony of southern tastes.
We suspected what was the matter, and gossip we heard later confirmed it: La Sacrestia has suffered from the Tangentopoli scandals. The politicians who were the backbone of the restaurant's clientele are lying low, and half of the restaurant's 90 seats were empty on a Friday evening. In general, the recent political and economic chaos in Italy has meant only good news for the average diner. Forced to reconstruct their customer bases, most restaurants are doing so with friendlier service and fairer pricing, and indeed we found La Sacrestia's prices a bit lower.
I'm convinced that La Sacrestia's malaise is temporary. The trolley of fresh local cheeses, including the region's pride, mozzarella di bufala, is as attractive as the trolley of classic Neapolitan desserts, including pastiera napolitana (a ricotta cake with orange rind), feather-light baba, and, in mid-March, zeppola di San Giuseppe (whose feast day is March 19), a sweet bun filled with custard and black cherry.
The tranquil, otherworldly setting high above the chaos of Naples makes La Sacrestia worth a visit. Skip the antipasto misto, which is all deep fried, and have something like the shrimp with artichokes. We tried pasta with vegetable-based sauces -- the eggplant ravioli and a subtle bucatini with fresh onions and basil. In the past we had seafood, as did most of the other diners, like spaghetti with tomato and the tender white flesh of the scorfano, scorpion fish. For the main course, my companion's pezzogna (a local white fish) with unsalted green olives was quite good and unusual, although my fillet of sole under a mountain of slivered artichokes smacked of hotel food.
Most of the Campanian white wines listed were unavailable, but our fragrant, dry Villa Matilde Falanghina was our first choice anyway.
 
Ciro a Santa Brigida
A night at the opera -- specifically, at Naples's celebrated Teatro San Carlo -- or a morning of museum going, ending at the Castel Nuovo, could happily finish nearby at one of the city's most respected downtown restaurant-pizzerias. The restaurant seems so cozy I was surprised to find out later it seats 180.
As everywhere around Naples, vegetables and seafood were more enticing than meat. We eschewed the boring antipasti (shrimp cocktail, prosciutto) and chose our starters from the vegetable list with happy results. The carciofo (artichoke) alla siciliana -- with black olives, capers and crushed small tomatoes -- was an explosion of southern flavors, perhaps too explosive for the delicate artichoke.
The zucchini alla scapece -- thin-sliced zucchini, fried golden, with lots of garlic and vinegar -- was a fine execution of a classic.
Tubettoni con le cozze, large-bore short pasta in a very light tomato sauce with mussels, tasted of the sea. Truly memorable were the rotelli con peperoncini verdi, wheel-shaped pasta with a sauce of tomato and small green peppers.
As a main course, we chose polipi alla Ciro -- small whole octopi cooked in an earthenware dish in a sauce much like that of the artichoke -- and the restaurant's famous fish soup, pignatiello 'e Vavella -- a baking dish filled with tomatoes, clams, shrimp, tiny octopi and tiny squid and toast to soak up the liquid.
The standard baba is embellished (successfully) with custard and tiny strawberries, and the pastiera was excellent.
 
Mimi alla Ferrovia
The descriptions of Mimi we'd heard and read had led us to expect great home cooking in squalid surroundings near the station. I was afraid I couldn't possibly send the Clintons there, but in fact it is a very large, comfortable restaurant that seats 140, though after dark I would certainly arrive and depart by taxi.
When I saw standard fare like scaloppine al marsala and cotoletta alla milanese on the menu, however, I wondered whether we'd come to the right place. We eased into the meal with antipasto Mimi -- mozzarella di bufala, involtino di peperoni (roasted pepper wrapped around a rich filling of bread and cheese) fried mozzarella, squash blossoms, and more. The loud southern accent of the exquisite antipasto dispelled any doubt; it was clearly going to be a question of convincing the waiter we were serious.
In the theater that is Naples, you have to know your lines. A food expert in Rome, I announced, told us to come to Mimi for the real Neapolitan cooking (which was true). Our waiter, Roberto, took his cue, nodded gravely, and said "pasta e ceci." We were off and running. He brought us tasting portions of a creamy chickpea soup with fresh pasta and one of pasta e fagioli -- beans -- and then a few tiny fried squid. That was followed by a shared linguine alla Mimi -- pasta with scampi, shrimp and clams in a sauce of crushed small tomatoes.
We stuck with fish and ordered grilled squid and a pair of large red mullets in fresh tomato sauce.
The inevitable baba and pastiera for dessert were accompanied by the house limoncello, the refreshing lemon liqueur of the region.
On a Saturday afternoon, we left Naples and drove about 35 miles around to the other side of the bay to the tip of the Sorrento Peninsula. Both the restaurants we visited have decorous rooms, so there is no need to challenge the Amalfi Drive after dinner.
 
Don Alfonso 1890
One of Italy's top restaurants, with celebrated wine cellar to match, is in the little town of Sant'Agata sui Due Golfi, overlooking the Bay of Naples and the Gulf of Salerno. But you don't go to Sant'Agata for the view. You go for Don Alfonso.
The pink-and-green floral decor is perfect, the setting intimate (seats 40), and the service relaxed enough to suit southern Italy but professional enough for a president. Livia Iaccarino, a co-owner, is the gracious hostess; her husband, Alfonso (grandson of the original Don Alfonso), is the chef. There are two tasting menus, one traditional and one creative, both served only to entire tables, but we could not resist the variety of the regular menu. All the choices celebrate local ingredients -- many, including the olive oil, grown and produced on the Iaccarinos' nearby farm.
Our appetizers were "zeppole" (the traditional bun, usually filled with custard) filled with lobster and garnished with julienne vegetables in a light sweet and sour sauce -- one of those dishes you remember for years -- and the delicate "treccia di pesce azzurro in carpione," daintily braided fish fillets in a light marinade. Also on the antipasto menu were "foam" of tuna with polenta and sweet peppers, raw shrimp with white beans and mint, and cotechino sausage wrapped in Savoy cabbage with puree of cauliflower.
We passed up risotto with oysters and asparagus and whole-wheat pasta with artichoke and sausage, and chose paccheri di Gragnano, a traditional large tubular pasta specific to the peninsula, with oregano, black olives, salt cod and tomatoes; and potato gnocchetti with pomodorini (small tomatoes) and smoked provola cheese, both superb.
The main dishes, which included fish, meat and game, were slightly more traditional. We had the delicate boccadoro (a local white fish) diced and sauteed quickly, and spezzatino (stew) of tiny cubes of wild boar, with pieces of sweet pepper, zucchini, and pear, in a sauce of unsweetened chocolate (not whimsy, but quite orthodox with game in classic Italian cooking). Those were accompanied by a glass of the house red wine, since our excellent Falerno del Massico (Villa Matilde again) was white.
The dessert menu was a list of confections of unbelievable fantasy. My delizia di zucca -- a sweet puree of winter squash with pistachio marzipan and ricotta -- was delicate and delicious. On another visit, we'll try the pasticcio di melanzane e cioccolato (eggplant and chocolate dessert), a traditional combination in the Amalfi area.
The tufa cellar, stocked with French, Australian and Californian wines, and the finest Italians, was supposedly first excavated by Etruscans. Guests may visit and buy the house wine, olive oil and other products. Don Alfonso has fixed up three charming mini-apartments for the express purpose of letting guests enjoy the famous wine list without smashing their cars afterward.
 
 Taverna del Capitano
On the beach at the very tip of the peninsula six miles from the town of Massa Lubrense are a number of seafood restaurants, of which this must be the best, and I'm only sorry it will probably be too out of the way for the Clintons. Our first impression was of a typical seaside establishment that must prepare 800 plates of spaghetti alle vongole a day during high season, but we quickly found out that the captain doesn't run that kind of ship. Rather, the restaurant seats only 50 and the captain's wife and chef, Grazia Casa, strikes just the right balance between traditional respect for the finest, freshest local foods and a rather refined attention to presentation and and combination of ingredients.
Settled in by a huge picture window from which we saw only water, my enthusiastic companion attempted to construct his own antipasto misto from the menu. The captain would have none of it. The house misto, he explained, was "balanced." To ease our wait the captain's daughter, the extremely knowledgeable sommelier, served us a stuzzichino (a little goody to stimulate the appetite) of torta rustica with artichoke, ricotta and mozzarella, with the white Falanghina dei Campi Flegrei she helped us choose from a number of interesting regional wines. Everything is homemade, including the interesting breads and the lightly smoked and marinated salmon that graced our unusual and most wonderful antipasto misto, along with shrimp mousse, pesce bandiera (scabbard fish) with sesame sauce, smoked swordfish, marinated anchovies with sauce of crushed mint and parsley, mussels, cannolicchi (razor clams) and cuttlefish with pinto beans. By this point we had placed ourselves in the hands of the captain, who let us taste fish-stuffed ravioli in a delicate sauce of diced small tomatoes, black and white tagliatelle (a marine version of paglia e fieno) with scorfano and tomato, and cannelloni with shrimp stuffing and a sauce of cozze and vongole.
He then wheeled over a trolley of the most beautiful fish for us to interview. My companion chose a magnificent, bright-red scorfano, to be cooked whole in fresh tomato. I took the triglie (red mullets), designated di scoglio, the more highly prized ones that hang around rocks, not sand. Those were filleted then baked, covered with "scales" of thin-sliced potato. In addition to the inevitable baba and pastiera, the homemade desserts included tegola (tile) di cioccolato (chocolate) and the shell-shaped pastry known as sfogliatella filled with custard and black cherry instead of the usual ricotta and candied fruit.
 
 
 
WHERE TO EAT
 I have specified Campanian wine because in most cases I mean modestly priced but very good wines chosen from a wine list.
Since these wines do not come from very far away, they tend to have the best prices.
Prices include antipasto, first course, main course, dessert, and service, which is usually a 12 to 14 percent charge.
La Sacrestia, 116 Via Orazio, Naples; (081) 664186, (081) 7611051. Closed Monday.
A meal for two with a bottle of Campanian wine costs about $98.
Ciro a Santa Brigida, 73 Via Santa Brigida, Naples; (081) 5534072. Closed Sunday.
A meal for two with a carafe of house wine costs about $65.
Mimi alla Ferrovia, 21 Via Alfonso d'Aragona, Naples; (081) 5538525. Closed Sunday.
A meal for two with a carafe of house wine costs about $67.
Don Alfonso 1890, 11 Piazza Sant' Agata, Sant'Agata sui Due Golfi (Naples); (081) 8780026, fax 5330226.
Closed Sunday evening through Tuesday, and from June 1 to Sept. 30 closed only on Monday.
Tasting menus about $46 and $58 a person, not including wine. Meal for two a la carte with bottle of Campanian wine, about $122 to $153. ( If you dine a la carte, everything will turn up on your bill exceptfor the bite of pate offered at the beginning of the meal.)
Taverna del Capitano, 10/11 Piazza delle Sirene, 80068 Nerano (Naples); (081) 8081028, fax (081) 8081892. Closed Monday.
A meal for two with bottle of Campanian wine about $61.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 4; Styles of The Times 

LENGTH: 2175 words

HEADLINE: Such a Nice Zealot

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
In the past, animal-rights advertisements sought to shock and shame, with images of furry creatures caught in leg-hold traps, or veal calves confined to narrow stalls. The grim ads fired up the naturally indignant, but many found it just as easy to turn the page.
Try, though, to look away from this: Christy Turlington, her bottom bared, reclining like an odalisque on a 14-by-48-foot billboard above Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles. The slogan? "I'd rather go naked than wear fur." 
 "We have bad news to tell the world, but we have to sugarcoat it," said Dan Mathews, who conceived the ad, which appeared earlier this year. "We've learned people are more attracted to a glossy, glamorous image than a grotesque one."
Mr. Mathews, the director of international campaigns and chief strategist for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, or PETA (with long "E"), has given the tired and frumpy anti-fur movement a make-over, transforming it into the fashion industry's sexiest cause.
PETA partisans, led by Mr. Mathews, spray-painted anti-fur graffiti in the offices of Calvin Klein and Vogue magazine last winter, attracting wide publicity. The targets of the protests denounced the tactics, but PETA was able to show it didn't lack for supporters among the cream of fashionville. Besides Ms. Turlington, other uber-models like Naomi Campbell and Tatjana Patiz disrobed for ads in the "naked" series, as did the ex-model Kim Basinger.
The true impact of anti-fur sentiment -- a decade-old movement that has already courted a backlash -- is debatable. Fur sales were up this winter for the second year in a row. But there's no denying that the animal-rights bandwagon is a gaudy and attractive vehicle now rolling down Seventh Avenue. The British magazine Time Out calls it the No. 1 "hip cause," eclipsing even AIDS.
Mr. Mathews, a 29-year-old former model, is an activist in the body of a 6-foot-5 hunk, a zealot who's not too busy to follow trendlets in fashion and the club scene. His ability to ingratiate himself with the runway crowd and his flair for publicity have had much to do with PETA's success.
"I always thought if Dan were a P.R. person, he'd be a millionaire," said Kate Pierson, the vocalist for the B-52's, who took part in the Vogue raid. "He comes up with genius campaigns. I wish he'd be the P.R. person for our next album."
His detractors say it's not genius, just old-fashioned grandstanding. "It's 1994 already, and it's standard operating procedure for anybody who wants to get press that you just go out and make yourself thoroughly obnoxious," said Stephan Weiss, a partner in Donna Karan New York, a recent PETA target.
Mr. Mathews promises a new round of protests when fur designers introduce their latest lines, beginning May 16.
Recently, he came to town from Rockville, Md., where PETA is based, to gather support. He visited Jason Weinberg, a publicist who represents models and actresses, to listen to him pitch clients who might disrobe for PETA. Thanks to Mr. Mathews, the prospect of joining the company of PETA spokeswomen represents not only a statement of principles, but also a smart career move.
"Somebody who'd be fantastic because she's so outspoken and an interesting story is Kristen McMenamy," Mr. Weinberg said to Mr. Mathews, naming a top model who's previously been known for plucking her eyebrows.
"We love her," Mr. Mathews said.
"She's got long red hair now," said Mr. Weinberg, explaining that Ms. McMenamy had just given birth, "and she's a little more" -- he clucked his tongue -- "endowed. I can see Kristen doing something really funky, with her new baby under her arm."
Mr. Mathews said that was great because the next "naked" campaign would feature families and couples.
"I've got Molly Ringwald in Paris right now," Mr. Weinberg said, seated on a couch beside Mr. Mathews. "I can see her getting on the anti-fur thing."
He was interrupted by an associate who stuck her head in the office to say: "We have Ivana Trump footloose and fancy free. Are there any parties she can go to?"
Mr. Mathews pricked up his ears. He recalled that Ms. Trump had told Vanity Fair she'd stopped wearing furs from animals trapped in the wild and wore only ranched furs. Mr. Mathews said he'd love to get PETA literature into her hands concerning fur-ranch conditions.
"I'll talk to her in the morning," Mr. Weinberg promised. He crossed one wool pant leg over the other. "Oh my God. You know who would be so awesome? You'd get lots of exposure. Shannen Doherty."
This has been the season the fur flew. Manufacturers fired the first barrage, loosing a $1.25 million ad campaign that showed young women on the beach draped in fur. The subtext was clear: fur wearers could come out of the closet again and embrace the luxury of their garments without embarrassment.
The campaign built on a sales surge after the bust, when fur sales plunged from a high of $1.8 billion in 1987 to just $1 billion in 1991. Furriers insist the drop tracked the national recession and a series of mild winters. It had nothing -- repeat, nothing -- to do with the stigmatization of fur, they say.
"The fact sales are up 20 percent in two years says more about what's happening in the fur industry than half a dozen people on the street parading around naked," said Karen Handel, a spokeswoman for the Fur Information Council, a trade group.
Yet, anti-fur sentiment is undeniable. Designers who have banished fur include Giorgio Armani, Bill Blass, Ralph Lauren, Isaac Mizrahi and Todd Oldham. Since the early 1980's, anti-fur activists have picketed Fred the Furrier outlets, dragged mink stoles down Fifth Avenue and confronted fur-wearing women on the street with snide remarks or even spray paint. As a result, many consumers now view fur as a faux pas. Half of those surveyed in a Los Angeles Times poll last year opposed the wearing of fur.
But the tactics have also alienated people. Many women who continue to wear fur have developed barb-proof skins and are immune to street-level protests.
So this year PETA, the largest and most flamboyant animal-rights group, with 500,000 members worldwide, took the crusade to a higher plane, targeting designers directly.
Calvin Klein was first. After a handful of members defaced the designer's 39th Street offices in January, Mr. Klein agreed to meet with PETA. He viewed a four-minute videotape that showed a beaver drowning in an underwater trap and a farm-raised chinchilla being electrocuted. "He told us he'd never seen the footage before and was shocked," Mr. Mathews said.
Within a week Mr. Klein announced that he was getting out of the fur business because of his "reflections on the humane treatment of animals" and because fur no longer fit with his "corporate philosophy."
What seems most remarkable in the affair Calvin is that the designer agreed at all to sit down with the people who had vandalized his office. A spokeswoman for the company said the meeting was Mr. Klein's idea. But Mr. Mathews said it was set up only because he made contact with a sympathetic executive in the company, whom he was led to by an ally in the press.
Mr. Mathews cited these backdoor maneuverings as crucial to PETA's effectiveness. The goal of this year's campaign was to "cause a shakeout in the fashion industry," he said. "And we're really pleased with the results. To get the Big Three in one winter was beyond our wildest dreams."
The Big Three in question are Calvin Klein, Anne Klein and Donna Karan, all of whom made it known in a five-week period that they were dropping fur.
But Mr. Mathews is probably too eager to take credit, especially for the withdrawals of the Anne Klein and Donna Karan companies. Stephan Weiss, Ms. Karan's partner and husband, said ethical considerations played no part. "The amount of revenues from it was hardly worth the effort to design them," he said.
In the case of Anne Klein, Mr. Mathews wrote to Richard Tyler, the firm's new designer, after hearing from K. D. Lang, the singer and PETA supporter, that Mr. Tyler intended to let the house's fur license expire. Mr. Mathews wrote that PETA had readied a poster of a coyote with a boot to its throat and the slogan "Where does Anne Klein Stand on Fur?" He promised to call off the campaign if he got written confirmation that Anne Klein was banning fur.
Frank R. Mori, an owner of the Anne Klein Companies, attacked Mr. Mathews's "extortionate manner" and his "self-aggrandizing publicity stunts" in a written reply. He said a decision to drop the company's fur license had been made before PETA came on the scene "for business reasons."
In the end, Mr. Mathews won't quibble. Do top designers like Oscar de la Renta and Karl Lagerfeld still love fur? To Mr. Mathews, it doesn't matter. "Most of their customers," he said, in an unkind reference to the fact that fur buyers are generally older, "will be dead soon." PETA wants the hearts and minds of the young, and from many indications it is winning. Half the models managed by Elite indicate "no fur" on their resume cards, which circulate to clients.
The anti-fur bandwagon has come on so fast that some who have jumped aboard are in danger of whiplash. The same month that Christy Turlington donated her time to pose for her anti-fur billboard, she appeared in an ad in French Vogue holding a shearling suede coat with a fox-fur trim. The ad had been shot a few months earlier.
There is a gulf between some fashion types who espouse a trendy anti-fur sentiment and the broad animal-rights movement, which is far more radical.
PETA opposes not just fur, but leather, shearling, silk (because the silkworms are boiled) and wool (sheep get nicked when they're sheared). It campaigns against animals used in circuses, movies and for medical research, including AIDS and cancer. Mr. Mathews glosses over these issues, but others in PETA admit that fur is just the wedge issue leading a broad agenda.
Mr. Mathews is a bit of a surprise himself. On the one hand, he's a true believer, a militant vegetarian who finds it cruel that cows are "exploited" to provide milk for people and that trout are "tortured" by fishermen. He perceives horrible animal suffering everywhere. Yet, he has none of the dour humorlessness of the zealot.
On the contrary, he is charming and extroverted, with an unexpectedly shy laugh. He attended his first animal-rights protest while in high school in Orange County, Calif. In the early 80's he moved to Rome for two years and supported himself modeling for avant-garde designers and acting in Fiat commercials and even a spaghetti western, "Arapaho."
Much of PETA's success is due to his ability to win the trust of celebrities. It probably doesn't hurt that in a world where looks are everything, he is tall, blue-eyed and square-jawed.
"Dan is very strong, forward, and he's got so much energy and confidence," said Fabienne Terwinghe, a model who posed for the "naked" campaign. She described him as "a cute boy" and said the fact he was at ease in her world -- they met in Paris through the efforts of Paul McCartney, the former Beatle -- increased her comfort over disrobing.
Mr. Mathews has a way of becoming friends with his celebrity supporters, welcomed into their homes. He stays with his "soul mate" Chrissie Hynde in London, and with Elvira, the horror diva, in Los Angeles.
"He's very good with celebrities," said K. D. Lang, who once lent him one of her Armani men's suits to wear to a meeting.
Mr. Mathews ran into Ms. Lang in New York during the fall collections recently, at the show for the Cuban-born designer Manolo. After embracing, they admired each other's "cruelty-free" outfits: Ms. Lang's black rubber coat, which Donna Karan had given her, and Mr. Mathews's sea-green canvas suit, designed for him by Manolo himself.
Mr. Mathews had come to the show, which was held in a church on Central Park West, to continue his courtship of the fashion world. He was throughly in his element.
"Chris-Ann!" he said, greeting a friend of Ms. Lang's, as he hobnobbed among the V.I.P.'s in the front row.
"Hi, Dan Mathews, you little PETA freak," she said, as they kiss-kissed.
He was introduced to Ingrid Sischy, the editor of Interview magazine, and mentioned that earlier in the day he'd met with her publisher, Sandra Brant, to pitch a story about celebrities sharing a vegetarian Thanksgiving.
Shortly before the models took to the catwalk, Mr. Mathews tapped the shoulder of a woman in the pew in front of him: Bjork, the Icelandic rock star and budding model. She had once performed at a PETA benefit. "You look like you were just in the sun," he said.
"Yes."
"How's your kid? Everyone seems to be having kids these days."
Mr. Mathews unfurled a poster of the latest models to pose naked for PETA. A friend seated beside Bjork asked the singer, who has crossed over to become a fashion diva, dressed by young London designers, "Would you do that?"
Bjork took a long look at the poster. She seemed to be thinking it over.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Should a School Pay Taxes on Faculty Housing?

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
IN the latest development in a case being watched closely by private schools and local governments around the state, the Town of Windsor has appealed a State Superior Court ruling exempting 25 faculty houses on the Loomis Chaffee School campus from town taxes.
The appeal, filed April 22 in the Appellate Court in Hartford, argues that the houses are not used for educational purposes, as the school successfully contended. 
 The ruling being appealed, issued by Judge Frances Allen in Hartford on March 30, also directed the town to refund $130,000 collected from the century-old school since 1992 when it began taxing the homes and some undeveloped land on the 350-acre campus.
"If the decision had gone against us, we would have appealed," said Dr. John Ratte, headmaster of Loomis Chaffee. "Although we are disappointed that this issue remains unresolved, requiring additional time and expense, and diverting funds that might be better used, it's appropriate to seek confirmation from a higher court."
He indicated that the issue had widespread implications for other independent and private schools, colleges and universities. The suit is expected to go straight to the State Supreme Court.
"In the meantime the schools are under no obligation to keep up payments," said William Narwold of the Hartford office of Cummings & Lockwood, the law firm that represents the school. No new taxes will be billed, nor will any refunds be made, pending the outcome of the appeal. The case is not expected to be resolved until late 1994 or 1995.
The dispute arose when the Town of Windsor levied a $65,000 annual property tax against the faculty houses and two vacant parcels, contending that they were not used strictly for educational purposes as required for tax exemption under Connecticut law.
The school sued the town, asserting its compliance with state tax exemption requirements and with its charter, granted by special act of the General Assembly in 1874 to James and Abigail Chaffee Loomis, founders of the school. The charter guarantees exemption from taxes and it is immunized from legislative repeals or amendments without the consent of the school trustees.
Judge Allen agreed with the school that the undeveloped land was used for the educational purposes of bird-watching and sports, and that faculty members occupying the houses served educational purposes outside the classroom. They act as counselors, entertain students, put up visitors, help out in the dormitories and are on call around the clock for emergencies.
Efforts to overturn tax exemptions are not unusual during economic downturns.
"When money is tight," said Kevin Maloney, spokesman for the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, "towns are concerned about the degree of tax-exempt property within their borders and how it diminishes their ability to get the revenues they need without increasing the burden on taxpaying households and businesses."
Mr. Maloney noted that town services received by tax-exempt school properties -- fire and police protection and public school education of faculty members' children, for example -- invariably came under scrutiny in these situations.
The conference, with its membership of 129 of the state's 169 towns and cities, has been approached by Mr. Morrison to file a friend-of-the-court brief on behalf of the Town of Windsor, which is represented in its appeal by Francis H. Morrison 3d of Day, Berry & Howard, Hartford lawyers.
WHILE some schools actually pay property taxes on faculty housing, others strive to maintain goodwill by providing services to the towns, and in many cases they contribute large annual sums, or gifts, to the local general fund.
Loomis Chaffee does not make cash contributions, but, Dr. Ratte said, "we have worked hard to be a good citizen, providing education for a number of town children who would otherwise attend the public high school at taxpayer expense."
School and town officials are treading softly, unwilling to upset the delicate balance of their relationships.
"We have been fortunate for many years," said Barbara Johnson, Assessor for the Town of Washington, which has three private boarding schools. "Under agreements made years ago, The Gunnery pays us the equivalent of their faculty housing tax -- $21,143 this year," she said. "They do not get a bill. They just send the money."
Rumsey Hall paid the Town of Washington $7,269, and Devereux-Glenholme paid $12,500.
The Gunnery opens its skating rink to the town and Rumsey Hall makes its indoor tennis courts available to the public, both for fees "well below regular rates," said Ms. Johnson. She said she was surprised that the judge had ruled against the Town of Windsor.
Westminster School in the Town of Simsbury has been paying around $44,000 in annual taxes on faculty homes since the 1960's. "My sense of things," said Thomas Earl, business manager for the school, "is that the trustees are happy with the arrangement, and we would do nothing to change it until the outcome of the appeal is known."
Nor will Clarence King, the Town Assessor, remove the taxes pending the appeal. He said that he, too, had been surprised to hear that Windsor had been turned down.
In the Town of Salisbury, 43 children of faculty members of Hotchkiss, Salisbury and Indian Mountain schools are in the public school system, "using $300,000 of taxpayer funds," according to First Selectman Bud Trotta. His attempt in 1992 to obtain permission to tax noneducational buildings did not get out of the state legislature's Planning and Development Committee.
Lauren Elliott, the Salisbury Assessor, said she was not inclined to disturb long-standing arrangements with the schools. Hotchkiss alone contributes $50,000 a year "as a gift," said its business manager, Robert Griesemer. "And I don't think that will change," he said. "The money we contribute goes to the police and fire departments."
KENT SCHOOL and South Kent School pay taxes on faculty housing and have done so for about two decades, according to Patty Braislin, the Kent Assessor, while the Taft School in Watertown contributes up to $70,000 a year in gifts. "We feel a responsibility to continue and we have no plans to change anything," said David A. Mitchell, Taft's business manager.
Mr. Morrison, who represents Windsor, argues that the Superior Court ruling on Loomis Chaffee "applied a standard for faculty houses to be tax exempt which is not the law of Connecticut."
"The houses are not used exclusively for education within the meaning of Connecticut law," he said. "Their primary use is personal. Some husbands, wives and children living in them have no connection with the school."
In addition, he said, "the school takes the position that its charter grants tax exemption to the institution rather than its individual properties, so they can do what they want as long as they continue to provide a free and gratuitous education to boys and girls, as the charter requires. In fact, the school did provide free education until 1970, when it began charging tuition." Dr. Ratte said that the school had begun charging tuition sometime in the early '60's, although before then the school, which is primarily residential, charged for room and board.
"Whatever the wisdom of the legislature was in 1874," he said, "the world has changed."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. John Ratte, headmaster at the Loomis Chaffee School in Windsor, with faculty housing behind him. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 5; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2450 words

HEADLINE: Rises in Mortgage Rates Nudge Buyers

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
THESE should be the best of times for the residential real estate world in the New York area. Sales are on the upswing in much of the region. Sale prices are increasing for most types of homes. Even the long-dormant home-building industry is slowly returning to life.
But uncertainty looms over the rebounding housing market. Rising interest rates, particularly the sharp ascent that began three months ago, have prompted buyers, sellers, brokers and builders to ponder a plethora of questions: How much will rates climb? Will higher rates choke the long-awaited real estate recovery? Does refinancing still make sense? 
 So far, the anxiety over rates has sparked a surge of sales among those who had been cautiously considering buying a home but who feared that rates might rise higher and make doing so less affordable.
"We expect a very strong second quarter of home sales followed by modest declines in the second half of this year, as the rate increases start to take effect," said Rob Rosenblatt, director of surveys and statistics for the Mortgage Bankers Association, a trade group based in Washington.
David Michonski, a manager with the Greenwich, Conn., office of Coldwell Banker Schlott, a real estate brokerage firm, said that most of the recent activity had been among buyers sensitive to mortgage-rate swings. "We have had a tremendous number of buyers at that end of the market," he said.
Sheralyn and Bennet Goodman, for example, bought a four-bedroom colonial-style home in Yorktown, N.Y., last month for $217,850. "We really weren't prepared to do it this soon," Mrs. Goodman said. "But because we had heard a lot of talk about interest rates going up, we decided to do it sooner rather than later."
But for some potential buyers the run-up in rates -- the average fixed-rate 30-year mortgage in the New York metropolitan area increased to 8.55 on April 22 from a 25-year low of 6.87 percent on Oct. 15 -- means they cannot borrow as much money as they intended and thus may not qualify for the home they had planned to buy.
Indeed, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association, about 250,000 families in the nation were priced out of the home market in the last six months because of the rising interest rates. The Impact of higher rates on these borrowers, though, has been mitigated by a liberal lending environment and a wide variety of loans available today. "We're not in a tight-money market at all," Mr. Michonski said. "People want to lend and they are finding ways to do it, even with higher rates."
Nationally, sales of previously owned homes rose 5.7 percent in March over the previous month, as buyers rushed to lock in rates in case mortgage rates moved higher, according to the National Association of Realtors, a trade group in Washington. Sales, however, were still lower than in the fourth quarter, when they were running at their highest levels in years.
In most parts of the New York region, brokers said their sales were on the upswing, partly because of the rise in rates and partly because of the pent-up demand following an unusually cold winter. "March was one if the busiest Marches I have ever seen," said Savo Fries, manager of Caldwell Banker Schlott office in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., and president of the Westchester County Multiple Listing Service. "We quadrupled what we had in January and February, and we doubled what we had last March."
THE increased activity has not been felt across the market, according to some brokers. Rising interest rates have negatively affected some wealthy home buyers, said Mr. Michonski, the Greenwhich broker. Many of these prospective buyers are not sensitive to changes in mortgage rates, but they are dissuaded from making large purchases when higher interest rates depress the stock and bond markets.
"There is tremendous nervousness in that end of the market and a sudden reluctance to commit," Mr. Michonski said. "This is the portfolio-sensitive end of the market, and these people look at the value of their portfolio to help them decide whether they are going to feel good. And a lot of these people are not feeling good these days."
The most significant impact of the higher rates has probably been on refinancings, which were popular in 1992 and 1993 when rates were, for the most part, falling. "Refinancings generally end when rates go up," said Keith Gumbinger, an analyst at HSH Associates, an interest rate research company in Butler, N.J. "And recently we have seen a very big decline in refinance applications. Refinancings were representing about half of the mortgage volume. Now it is about 26 percent."
Thad M. McGarr, for instance, wanted to refinance the 9 percent $110,000 mortgage on his town house in the Chelsea section of Manhattan to a 7 percent 30-year fixed-rate loan. But by the time he found a loan in late February 7 percent was no longer available, even with additional points. (A point is a fee charged by the lender equal to 1 percent of the loan.)
"At first, I thought I'd just pay the extra points to get it down to 7 percent," Mr. McGarr said. "Then it went to 7 1/4 and suddenly it jumped over 8 percent. It wasn't worth my time to refinance from 9 percent to 8 percent. Two points lower was economically feasible, but not one."
Homeowners with adjustable-rate mortgages -- which generally adjust on a loan's anniversary date -- have also been affected by higher rates. Their monthly mortgage payments are likely to increase. About 27 percent of all home loans have rates that adjust, most of them annually, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association.
BORROWERS who took out adjustable loans during the last year or so, though, will still be faring better, at least in the early years of their loans, than those who are currently taking out fixed-rate mortgages. That's because adjustable-rate loans usually have a low "teaser" rate for the first year, an annual 2-percentage-point cap and a 6-percentage-point cap over the life of the loan. So borrowers who last year took out adjustables at rates like 3.75 percent may incur increases only up to 5.75 this year and up to 7.75 in 1995.
Interest on adjustable-rate mortgages is computed by adding a lender mark-up, often 2.75 percent, to the weekly average yield on the one-year Treasury bond. Don't bother, though, looking for an adjustable-rate loan that still has a "teaser" rate at last year's best rates, which bottomed out at about 3 percent. The average initial rate on a one-year adjustable in the New York area rose to 4.93 at midday last Thursday -- the last day for which figures for this article were available -- compared with the low of 4.15 percent last Oct. 29, according to HSH Associates.
But some lenders are more aggressive.
"You can still find some in the 3's, and the low 4's are still widespread, with points, of course," Mr. Gumbinger said.
He added that adjustable-rate mortgages remained popular partly because borrowers, particularly first-time buyers, found it easier to qualify for them because the initial monthly payments were lower. "It is cheaper to get into them than a fixed-rate mortgage," he said. Mr. Gumbinger also said that adjustables could be better long-term buys than fixed-rate loans even if rates continued to rise.
"If you are interested in an adjustable and shop the market aggressively -- because you can still find some at around 4 percent -- then they can make terrific sense," he said. "Your worst-case cap on that kind of loan is going to be 9 1/2 or 10 percent."
Mr. Gumbinger added that on both fixed-rate mortgages and adjustables it was generally not the actual interest rate but the perceived direction that persuaded home shoppers to buy or not to buy.
Mrs. Goodman, for example, said that she believed rates would "just keep going up until they hit 9 percent."
Mr. Rosenblatt noted that rates on most mortgages were currently where they were at the beginning of 1993, when they were the lowest rates since the 1970's.
"Rates are still attractive and near 20-year lows except for last year," he said.
Mr. Gumbinger pointed out that mortgage rates, particularly adjustables, were volatile, varying from region to region and from day to day. For example, the average rate for both 30-year fixed mortgages and adjustable-rate loans as of last Thursday was lower than the rates for the week ended April 22. (Mortgage rates to buy co-op apartments are also higher than for homes and condominiums.)
Mr. Gumbinger also noted that although rates had been generally rising for the last eight months, the amount of the increase had not significantly changed most monthly mortgage payments. He said that the monthly payment on the average 30-year fixed-rate $150,000 mortgage in the New York area increased only $155.75, to $1,140.64, as of last Thursday, when interest rates averaged 8.38 percent, from its low last fall of $984.89 when interest rates averaged 6.87 percent.
The difference in monthly payments is even smaller for adjustable-rate mortgages. Last October, when the first-year rate bottomed at 4.15 percent, the monthly mortgage payment on a $150,000 loan would have been $729.15. Last Thursday, with the average adjustable-rate mortgage rate at 4.93, the payment would have been $798.83.
Borrowers have been unusually keen to ask about locking in rates when they apply for a mortgage these days. They fear not only that increased rates will mean increased mortgage payments and make qualifying more difficult, but also that higher rates may force them to take out longer loans or pay extra points to keep the rate lower.
The Goodmans, for example, locked in their 7.25 percent rate on a 15-year mortgage on April 11. If they had waited a few hours longer, the rate would have increased to 7.5 percent, and the monthly payments on their 2-point loan would have increased by $18.40, to $1,205.12, from $1,186.72. If they had waited a week, the rate would have increased to 7.75 percent, and their payments would have increased by $36.94, to $1,223.66.
THE amounts did not endanger their ability to qualify for a loan. But the higher rates did make it difficult to qualify for the type of loan they preferred. "Had we not been able to lock in 7.25 or lower, we would not have been in a position to get a 15-year mortgage, which in our mind was primary," said Mrs. Goodman, a lawyer.
Most mortgages have free optional 60-day lock-ins guarding against rate increases while a mortgage is in the application process. But the time span for lock-ins can vary from as little as 30 days to as much as 90 days. Some also require a small fee to be paid in advance, and typically that money is credited to the borrower at closing. Should a rate decrease, some loans have provisions for buydowns or relocks, that, for a fee, enable the borrower to take the lower rate.
"People want to lock in a rate at application for 60 to 90 days," said Bruce Lublin, president of Homerica Inc., a mortgage broker in Harrison, N.Y. "It is all dependent on the prevailing direction of interest rates. When rates are stable or declining, people want to float. And when rates appear to be rising, people want to lock in."
Home builders, particularly small developers, are also concerned about the rate rise. Though many are expecting a good year in 1994, some are seeing investors pull out of development deals because they fear higher rates will lead to higher home building costs and fewer buyers able to afford homes.
"It looks like investors are slightly more hesitant than before," said Dave Heller, a contractor with Toll Gate Land Improvement in Massapequa, L.I. "We had a few deals that we were eager to do, now it seems like they are on the shelf."
The National Association of Home Builders, a trade organization in Washington, has projected an 8 percent rise in home construction nationally in 1994 over last year and a 4 percent rise in 1995 -- but only if 30-year mortgage rates are under 8 percent.
"If we stay at these levels or go higher, then we have to revise this forecast," said David F. Seiders, the association's chief economist. Should interest rates climb much further, home construction, which is just now starting to recover after a devastating five-year-long recession in the Northeast, could start to weaken again.
"Obviously, the builders in those parts of the country where the recovery has been slow are chagrined by the rising interest rates, since they are just getting started," Mr. Seiders said. "In the Northeast, we haven't been looking for a strong resurgence, because there is nothing to support it in terms of job growth or household formation, and in some places it is still overbuilt to some degree. So we're looking for a modest increase in the Northeast in construction. But any rate rise will likely keep things flat."
As for the future direction of interest rates, David Lereah, chief economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, forecasts that -- because of a strengthening economy, rising inflation and further tightening of short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve -- they will continue to increase slowly during 1994, possibly to as much as 8.9 percent by the end of the year and 9.15 percent in 1995.
He further projected that existing home sales would rise by 5 percent in 1994 over 1993 and new homes sales would rise by 6 percent, with a bulk of the increase coming in April, May and June of this year. "The market is peaking and will contract next year as long as rates continue along this road," he said. "There will still be a heck of a lot of people buying homes, but the growth will stop."
BUT others are more optimistic about rates. Peter Mosca, executive director of the New Jersey Association of Realtors, for example, predicted that the rate on 30-year mortgage would fall to 6.8 percent by the end of the year. He added, though, that he did not expect interest rates to have much impact on sales figures for 1994; he projects that sales in New Jersey will be flat or increase slightly over last year, in large part because of low sales figures from the first quarter of this year, which was plagued by unusually bad weather.
Most real estate analysts expect that prices in most parts of the Northeast will appreciate at or slightly above the current inflation rate, which is about 3 percent.
Should inflation pick up, though, home appreciation is likely to be higher.
"There are not a lot of investment vehicles out there right now, and owning one's home is one of the best they can have," Mr. Michonski said, "because real estate is coming out of a period of four dark years, it's leveraged, inflation is rising and there is tremendous up-side potential."

HEADLINE: He Who Once Rebuilt New Haven

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
IN the 50's and 60's, when many older American cities were crumbling, Mayor Dick Lee of New Haven knew what to do. During eight consecutive two-year terms from 1953 to 1969, he established a national reputation as a visionary of urban renewal, with a Midas touch to back it up. He was the man who could go down to Washington, on a first-name basis with John F. Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson, and return with thick bundles of Federal money for projects he had dreamed up for New Haven, mostly involving tearing down old buildings and getting someone in the private sector to put up new ones.
He supervised the building of two new public high schools and a dozen elementary schools and was an early proponent of putting up cluster housing that low-income families could buy rather than rent. 
 Mr. Lee also cemented his image as a master of Irish charm; a self-educated man who once headed the Yale News Bureau, although he had never spent a day in college; the man to get as a speaker, because he could enrapture an audience with dozens of stories and the timing of a vaudevillian.
 
A Call From Johnson
 Today, Dick Lee -- practically no one has ever used his formal name, Richard C. -- is 78 and retired from two additional careers, as an executive of United Way and then of a bank. He has not changed much. He still has the gift of gab and the telling punch line, sometimes two.
"In 1966, I was the first mayor in the country to come out against the Vietnam War, and I knew I'd hear from Lyndon," he said. "One night, we're sitting down at supper, and the phone rings. And my son David, who was a little kid then, answers it, and we could hear him say: 'This is dinner hour, and Mommy doesn't allow us to talk on the phone at dinner hour. You'll have to call back.' His mother asked who it was, and he said it was the President who wanted to talk to Daddy."
Within seconds, the phone rang again. It was Lyndon Johnson again. He was unhappy, not about being hung up on by a child but about the audacity of the child's father. "I see you have the only city in the United States with its own foreign policy," the President said.
Mr. Lee saw nothing wrong with that, he said. He still doesn't. To him, New Haven has always been a special place and should be entitled to a foreign policy or two.
He has never considered moving anywhere else, he said. He and his wife, Ellen, still live in the graceful stucco home with the sunken living room he purchased 30 years ago for $42,000 in Westville, one of the city's best sections.
 
City's Problems Hit Home
 But Mr. Lee is very conscious that his city has been in decline since the great age of redevelopment. Its center has been devastated by businesses moving out, and New Haven is afflicted by high crime rates and fear that are not limited to the poor neighborhoods. Several weeks ago, Ellen Lee was mugged and her purse stolen -- in her backyard, just after she had driven her car into the garage.
What has happened to New Haven reflects the migrations in America during the past two decades, Mr. Lee said. Poor people, mostly black and Hispanic, move into the city because they have nowhere else to go, while the white middle class flees to suburbia. When he was Mayor, New Haven was predominately a white city. That is no longer true. "It's a different city today," he said, noting that the public-school population is about 85 percent nonwhite.
But that doesn't bother him, said Mr. Lee, who was always known as a colorblind politician. "I went to grammar school in what was the city's black neighborhood then," he said.
In the summer of 1967, New Haven was added to the list of cities that had experienced the agony of riots. This one disturbance, although it came long after many other cities had succumbed to violence, shook Mr. Lee badly.
The New York Times sympathized with him in an editorial: "To a bitter minority of New Haveners, their city is still no model. But their lawless actions do not mean the city's efforts have been a failure, much less that it is pointless to extend them." Despite the city's troubles, the editorial said, "New Haven and its Mayor are still a model for the nation."
Although New Haven is far from a model city today, Mr. Lee said he was confident that it would somehow find its way again.
"Cities have been surviving since the Roman Empire," he said. "They are bastions of civilizations, the depositories of great books and museums that cannot ever be found in suburbs. And they have great universities like Yale and Harvard. The Peabody Museum here, children flock to it. This city has to survive."
But turning the city around is going to be difficult and take time, he said. "The problems we have here are not going to disappear overnight," he said. "They'll take 25 years, maybe longer, to correct."
The perilous situation of the state's cities has been building for 25 years, Mr. Lee said, since the Federal Government started to reduce its aid in the late 1960's. "What has happened since is years of retrogression on the national level in the effort to reclaim cities and their residents," he said.
Help for all Connecticut cities must come from some sort of regional governmental structures involving the core cities and their suburbs, Mr. Lee said. Coming from the elder statesman of the cities, that is almost revolutionary talk, and he admitted that he probably would not have felt that way 25 years ago.
In retrospect, the abandonment of county government in Connecticut in 1958 "was a grave error," he said. The counties offered frameworks for regional government, "and we had a golden opportunity to press for it while the suburbs, in term of political power, were relatively weak," he said. "We need something like it today. We have to adjust. We have to make hard decisions."
Mr. Lee said he was fully aware that the idea of regional government was not usually applauded in Connecticut, where town lines are regarded as sacrosanct, and relations between cities and suburbs have sometimes been full of hostility. But he noted that two major American cities, Atlanta and Indianapolis, became stronger by absorbing the suburbs around them.
And he said he was confident that some sort of regional approach would emerge in Connecticut when the cities' crime and economic problems reach deeper into the suburbs. "It will occur when everyone recognizes that the crisis now viewed as urban becomes part of all areas surrounding the cities," he said.
While staying out of politics, Mr. Lee keeps working to preserve his city. He is also one of the five proprietors of the Common and Undivided Lands in New Haven, a position established by the General Assembly of the Colony of Connecticut in 1646 to protect the 18-acre New Haven Central Green. The green remains an enduring symbol of New Haven. And so does Dick Lee.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/The Race for High-Tech Media Space;
Communicators Opt for Manhattan

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
TELECOMMUTING, video conferencing, computer networking, mobile fax machines, all are frequently invoked reasons for why the office of the future need not be an office at all. Yet the same communications companies whose magazines and television shows are trumpeting the death of offices are gobbling up Manhattan office space as though it were on fire sale.
"There's just been an explosion of space acquisition by communications companies in New York," said Mitchell Konsker, executive managing director of the real estate firm Galbreath Riverbank. 
 Not all buildings can handle communications companies, with their voracious appetite for power and air-conditioning, their many visitors and their need for round-the-clock access to their space. And those without high, uncluttered roofs that can accommodate transmission equipment are out of the running, at least for radio and television.
But for modern high-tech buildings, or those that can be retrofitted as such, the space race is on. And it is not just for the Viacoms and other well-known companies. It is for the myriad startups as well.
"There's an extraordinary number of new ventures, and even more being planned," said Peter Nelson, an executive director of the real estate firm Cushman & Wakefield.
Indeed, the Washington-based National Cable Television Association says that in 1970 there were 2,490 cable systems in this country; by last year, there were 11,395. And all of those systems require programming, much of which is being done in New York.
"My communications clients collectively have leased hundreds of thousands of square feet of Manhattan production space in the last 12 months," said Michael Laginestra, executive managing director at the Edward S. Gordon Company brokerage.
Examples, and not just from Mr. Laginestra's files, are rife. The Lifetime Network, which has studios in Queens, last year took 75,000 square feet at 825 Eighth Avenue -- Worldwide Plaza, on 50th Street. The Comedy Channel opened up in about 40,000 square feet at 1775 Broadway, at 58th Street, last year, and is looking to expand. Discovery Network has 31,000 square feet at 641 Lexington Avenue, at 54th Street, and is ready to take more.
Magazines, too, are gaining in numbers. The New York-based Magazine Publishers of America notes that last year 789 new magazines -- a record number -- were started. And, the association notes, nearly all major magazines are headquartered in New York.
Existing publishers, in fact, are on the move. In the last 12 months, New York Law Publishing took 75,000 square feet at 345 Park Avenue South, at 26th Street; Thomas Publishing took 52,000 square feet at 5 Penn Plaza, on Eighth Avenue and 34th Street; Parade Magazine took 73,000 square feet at 711 Third Avenue, at 44th Street.
Last month General Media Entertainment, which publishes Penthouse, Omni and other magazines, sold its headquarters building, 1965 Broadway at 66th Street, to Millennium Partners and is now looking for space.
Many of the publishing moves are being driven by technology.
"For decades, publishing companies kept renewing their leases in older, low-rent buildings," said Mary Ann Tighe, a senior managing director at Edward S. Gordon, who counts Newsweek, General Media and Tribune Company among her clients. "Now they need space that can accommodate their computers and fax machines and satellite dishes."
Newsweek recently left 444 Madison Avenue, the 49th Street building that was its headquarters for 34 years, for 251 West 57th Street, which can better accommodate the electronic mail system and other technologies the company wants to install.
GENERAL MEDIA is looking for about 60,000 square feet that it will use quite differently from the 80,000 it now occupies. Gone will be the huge reference library and morgue, replaced by data on compact disks. Gone, too, will be large or luxurious offices for anyone. In their place will be a video conference room, so editors or artists in different cities can work together. And there will be huge amounts of computer and communications equipment.
"Our offices will be designed for efficiency, not show," said Kathy Keeton, General Media's president. "The money we don't spend on decorating will go into technology."
But with all that technology, are offices necessary at all?
"Sure, our people can interact by computer, but human nature is such that people still want their bit of space," Ms. Keeton said.
For Ms. Keeton, who lives in New York, leaving the city was not an option. But not all publishers may feel so constrained -- a fact that does not escape New York's officials.
"We have to recognize that the technological barriers to starting new publications elsewhere are gone," said Adam Friedman, director of economic development for Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, whose office is now finishing a report that discusses how best to retain New York's status as publishing capital of the world.
The city does have things in its favor. A summary that the Magazine Publishers group prepared for Ms. Messinger's staff notes that New York is where the advertising agencies are, and that, with all the job switching magazine people seem to do, employers who want to catch the best ones in transit had best be in Manhattan.
"There's a perception that if you are out of New York, you are out of the ball game," said Edward J. Ziek, president of the Manhattan consulting firm Savant Communications.
For TV shows, it may not just be perception. Unlike the print media, television reporters and producers cannot rely heavily on telephone interviews. And many news sources are here. Even Cable News Network, based in Atlanta, produces its business shows in New York, most at 5 Penn Plaza, because most financial newsmakers are here.
"New York is the food capital of the world," said Reese W. Schonfeld, a co-founder of CNN and now president of the Television Food Network, which in January started up in about 20,000 feet of space at 1177 Avenue of the Americas, near 45th Street. "We have live shows, and we need to be someplace guests can easily come to."
Whittle Communications' Medical News Network, which is beamed to doctors' offices, is produced in 19,000 square feet of concourse space at 1251 Avenue of the Americas, at 50th Street. The show is interactive, in that doctors can request via computer more information on, say, a featured drug.
"The doctors may be all over, but this is where the pharmaceutical companies are," said Mr. Konsker, who brokered the deal.
OF course, New York doesn't have a hammerlock on media companies. Maurice Solomon, a vice chairman of the Julien J. Studley real estate firm, recently moved Broadcasting Partners, which owns six radio stations, from 10,000 square feet at 1700 Broadway, at 53d Street, to 15,000 square feet at Newport Office Tower in Jersey City. It was a good deal, Mr. Solomon said, with a great location for a rooftop antenna. USA Network also took space at Newport Tower -- although it has also expanded at 1230 Avenue of the Americas, on 48th Street.
But Manhattan offers some bargains of its own, particularly for companies that do not insist on Class A midtown space. There is a lot of industrial and studio space, with skyhigh ceilings, loading docks for handling props and parking space for news vans, that are easily converted to television use.
Time Warner's New York City News Channel -- known to almost everyone as Channel 1 -- is operating out of 27,000 square feet in a converted industrial building at 460 West 42d Street. Mr. Nelson, their broker, says they first wanted space downtown, to be near City Hall and Brooklyn, or midtown, to be near Time Warner executives. Most of the space they looked at was prettier; but the West 42d street space worked better -- and, at about $15 a square foot a year, was a lot cheaper.
"The timing, the price, the ceiling height, everything was right," Mr. Nelson said.
Once the newer midtown networks are more established, they may seek bargains as well. Television Food Network took a four-year lease, at the end of which Mr. Schonfeld fully expects to move to cheaper quarters.
"Once our guests feel it is important to them to be on our shows, they'll travel a bit more to reach us," Mr. Schonfeld said.
