HEADLINE: Disability Applicants Crowd Offices

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH WISSNER-GROSS 

 BODY:
A VISITOR to the crowded Social Security office in Mineola on a Monday morning might imagine that there is a retirement boom in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The timing coincides with the graying of a generation that moved to the suburbs after World War II, as well as the shrinking and relocation of corporations, particularly military contractors.
But Social Security Administration statistics indicate that the steady increase in the number of retirees is not the major cause of the bustle at branch offices. The change stems largely from a sharp increase in people who are seeking disability benefits, according to a regional spokesman for Social Security, John Clark, and that mirrors a national trend. 
 Applications for benefits have been increasing significantly nationally, Mr. Clark said. That does not mean that Americans are becoming more accident prone. The Social Security Administration attributes much of the increase to high unemployment rates along with cutbacks at large companies. The agency has seen a "tie-in to the state of the economy," Mr. Clark said.
 
Nontransferable Skills
 "More people come in and file for disability benefits when the economy is slower and more people are out of work," Mr. Clark said. "Individuals who a few years ago might have been able to go out to the labor market to give it a try now apply for disability benefits to get some money coming into the household."
On Long Island many workers have been unable to transfer their specialized skills to other industries. "People are grasping for straws to bring some money into the household," Mr. Clark said.
Workers who lose their jobs at banking institutions on the Island are more likely to have readily translatable skills, said a labor analyst, Gary Huth. Job hunting, he added, is more difficult for workers at military contractors, "where there are fewer comparable jobs for people to transfer to."
He said rapid technological changes in businesses could be barriers to older workers who may view themselves as less adaptable than their younger colleagues or whose companies may perceive them as less adaptable. An end result, Mr. Huth said, is that people are retiring earlier than they would have. Workers too young to retire are pursuing disability benefits more aggressively, Mr. Clark added.
 
Reflection of National Trend
 The Long Island statistics reflect anational trend, Mr. Clark said. Officials expect three million Americans to apply for disability benefits this year. That would be an 18 percent increase over 1993, which showed an increase of 23 percent over 1992.
Consistent with elsewhere the percentage of Long Islanders eligible for retirement benefits has been steadily increasing. According to the 1990 Census, 20.2 percent of Nassau County residents were over 60, compared to 1970, when the figure was 11.8 percent. Likewise, 14.2 percent were over 65 in 1990 compared to 7 percent in 1970, and 5.2 percent were over 75 in 1990, compared to 2.9 in 1970.
Nassau developed rapidly in the 40's, 50's and 60's. Western Suffolk saw major development largely in the 60's and 70's.
"Many people who came to Long Island at this time are at retirement," said Dr. Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Regional Planning Board. Dr. Kamer added that the business climate since the late 80's had encouraged many companies to reduce payrolls by offering early retirement packages, buyouts and other incentives.
The Social Security offices have seen their workloads soar as staffing has been cut. Nationally, the agency has 64,000 employees, compared to 80,000 in 1984.
On a recent Friday afternoon in Mineola 15 people waited for help. But the waiting time for people without appointments ranged from 10 minutes to two hours, depending on the help that they needed. A woman who said she had been waiting for almost two hours to inquire about disability benefits looked around nervously, wondering whether she had time to add coins to her parking meter before meeting a representative. The woman said she had been told not to leave the office, because she would be called soon. Eventually, someone behind the counter told her that she could run out to the meter.
Social Security officials said most inquiries arrived through toll-free telephone calls. The agency advises people to use the phone first, instead of going to offices to obtain information. For people seeking records of earnings or estimates of benefits, a toll-free number, (800) 772-1213, directs how to obtain the information, a process that can take two weeks by mail.
For people who want to speak to a representative, however, it is not unusual to be kept on hold for a long time. On a recent Thursday morning, the wait was approximately six minutes, a recording said. On a Tuesday morning a 20-minute wait lasted more than a half-hour. Most office visits are scheduled through appointments.

HEADLINE: Future Homemakers Meeting Draws 800

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN

 BODY:
THE Future Homemakers of America, a national nonprofit organization for middle and high school students enrolled in home economics, lets others argue the modern question of what constitutes a family. The organization, endorsed by the Office of Vocational and Adult Education of the United States Department of Education, begins where sociologists leave off -- preparing young people to live responsibly in their families and communities.
"We are the builders of homes, homes for America's future," reads the organization's creed. "We have the clear consciousness of seeking old and precious values." Nearly 800 young people chanted those words at the closing ceremony of the yearly New York State Future Homemakers of America Leadership Meeting, held recently at the Westchester Marriott here. The students, from communities across the state, had just concluded three days of workshops, competitions and socializing. 
 "I don't want to leave -- it's just so much fun," said Asia Dawson, an eighth grader at the Dr. Alfred M. Franko Middle School in Mount Vernon, who had helped keep events running smoothly in her volunteer role as a room monitor. "You get to stay in a hotel with your friends for three days! And you have a job."
 
'It's Sort of Corny'
 If the old values once included sewing one's own prom dress and learning to cook sensible dinners for two, then home economics today is not the course many Americans remember. Asia, for example, was excited about wearing a new store-bought purple-and-red party outfit to a dance sponsored by the Westchester Marriott on the second evening of the conference.
Cooking was not on the agenda at all, except for some tips about vegetarian cuisine offered during a workshop on the benefits of vegetarianism.
"It's not about cooking and sewing," said Kylie Yerka, an eighth grader from Verona in Oneida County. "You learn a lot of leadership things."
Her friend Corinne Wheeler added, "It's more about speaking."
Kylie said, "You do stuff in your community."
Corinne began to giggle. "It's sort of corny," she said.
Corny or not, the girls were serious about an event called Illustrated Talk, in which five winners of local competitions were competing on the state level. The talks ranged from understanding AIDS to Kylie's subject of racism. Each speaker was given points in areas like presentation style, visual aids and content. The winner would represent the state at the national meeting in Orlando, Fla., in July.
The talks took place in a conference room in front of a small audience and three judges. As in the other competitive events, in which students described businesses they had designed or demonstrated their knowledge of parliamentary procedure, the judges were drawn from the business community or were Future Homemakers of America officials.
 
Constructive Criticism
 Kylie, a thin blond girl with her straight hair parted in the middle, used black-and-white hand puppets in her talk about the importance of good communication in sensitive relationships. Words like "sender, receiver, message, feedback" were written on a poster she had placed on a easel, while a version of Rodney King's remark, "Why can't we just get along?" was written on a sign in front of her.
After the judges had finished evaluating her speech, one of them, Larry Nault, offered Kylie some constructive criticism. "Your body language and eye contact were excellent, and you will be a great performer someday," said Mr. Nault, an engineer for a consulting firm in Tarrytown. "But this is a controversial subject with four dimensions, and you only presented one dimension. It was pitched to the emotions. It was 'nice.' "
He suggested she seek a more complex understanding of her subject, just as he later told Carrie Kahanic, an eighth grader from Falconer in Chautauqua County, that her talk needed more substance. Carrie, in a well-rehearsed speech, spoke on the importance of reading to children, surrounded by picture books and a poster citing the benefits of reading.
 
Thinking and Leadership
 "Your visual aids were good," Mr. Nault said, after Carrie had read aloud from three of the books and exhorted young people to read to children in hospitals. "But here is a hint. What does it mean to be illiterate and not ever to read?"
Subjecting their efforts to such scrutiny helps build the students' character and hones their critical-thinking skills, Future Homemakers officials say. Other goals of the group, which is supported primarily by student membership dues and run largely by the students themselves, are focused on what the organization says are the leadership abilities needed in the home and workplace: planning, problem solving, decision making and interpersonal communication.
"We are helping kids work toward self-esteem and realize their potential at an earlier age," said Maryann Whitney, a home economics teacher from Falconer. Middle school isn't too soon, she said, "to start looking at the whole focus of having a family and having a career -- to integrate the two."
The language in the group's brochures is devoid of sexism, and about 20 percent of the members of Future Homemakers are boys. The organization hopes to attract more boys, said Peg Helt, a consultant to the group, since both boys and girls are required to take home economics courses in order to graduate.
 
Complexities of Modern Life
 But some issues are still outside the group's scope. There is that pesky question of what constitutes a family. And despite a demanding competition called Job Interview -- in which students write application letters, supply recommendations and are interviewed at the conference for a hypothetical job, after which they have about 15 minutes in which to compose a follow-up letter -- there was nothing on the agenda about child-care issues posed by working parents. Instead, a mist of hopefulness about adult life floated through the meeting.
"I definitely want kids and a family and a career in financial planning," said Carrie, whose mother is a home economics teacher. She added, however, that she hadn't thought about "how I will take care of my kids" if both she and her future mate worked outside the home.
Ms. Helt said individual chapters of Future Homemakers delved into the complexities of modern life differently. In the same way, individual students make varying uses of the opportunities offered by the group.
Jessica Hendrickson, for example, said she became confident enough with people to run a well-attended workshop on vegetarianism, complete with samples of soybeans, seaweed and blended fruit drinks. A 12th grader from Falconer who will attend the Culinary Institute of America next fall, Jessica said her five years in Future Homemakers had been invaluable. "It has made me grow up so much," she said. "I can speak in front of people."
Jessica, whose mother assisted her at the workshop and who explained the health aspects of a nonmeat diet, said her goal was to own a French gourmet restaurant.
Cooking with cream and butter and offering traditional recipes that included meat? "Yes, all that stuff," Jessica said.

HEADLINE: Washington Growing as a Financial Angel to Industry

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IMAGINE being able to place a drop of blood on a computer chip and get an instant analysis of its DNA structure. Then you could produce a device so simple that a family doctor could determine a person's genetic predisposition to cancer during a routine checkup.
Far-fetched? Not for the National Institute of Standards and Technology, the technology arm of the Commerce Department. It is giving a consortium that includes Beckman Instruments and the Baylor College of Medicine $9.2 million to develop just such a computer chip. 
 Those who think they have just stumbled onto a revolutionary new technology, one that seems so outlandish that no one will invest in it, now have a generous new patron: the Clinton Administration.
Fifteen months after President Clinton took office, the Government's research money -- currently $70 billion -- is increasingly being redirected from military projects aimed at national security toward commercial ventures intended to help industry.
That aggressive stance was dramatically demonstrated last week, when the Pentagon announced a $1 billion 10-year program to underwrite the development of a commercial industry to make flat-panel displays, the thin screens used in everything from aircraft cockpit displays to laptop computers to the goggles for virtual reality video games.
The flat-panel display industry is dominated by Japanese companies like Sharp, Toshiba and NEC. Citing the need for greater "economic security," the Pentagon plan calls for spurring the construction of four for-profit manufacturing plants. The support will come by offering the research money only to companies or consortiums that commit themselves to building factories.
But the flat-panel effort is only part of a larger shift.
While it is difficult to put a precise amount on the Administration's total budget for commercial technology ventures, the amount adds up to several billion dollars over the next few years. The Clinton Administration has said it would eventually like to channel as much as 20 percent of the $25 billion now spent by the Federal laboratories in commercial rather than military ventures. That would be up from about 5 percent under the Bush Administration.
The Pentagon, through its Advanced Projects Research Agency and through other groups, is shifting $473 million this year into research aimed at helping military contractors enter the civilian world. The National Institute of Standards and Technology, part of the Commerce Department, is spending $200 million this year on joint technology ventures with private companies, and that budget is slated to reach $750 million in 1997. The Energy Department is trying to shift work at the huge national laboratories to joint ventures with industry -- such as its program to work on a "clean car" with automobile companies.
Grants, usually awarded only to companies that match the Government's contribution with an equal amount of their own money, range from as little as $50,000 to many millions of dollars. Recipients range from start-ups to giants like I.B.M. and General Motors.
In Ann Arbor, Mich., the national institute has awarded a start-up company called Aastrom Biosciences Inc. a grant to develop a method for breeding human blood stem cells, the progenitor for all types of human blood cells. In California, a group led by the Hughes Aircraft Corporation received a $12.2 million award from the Pentagon this year to develop collision-avoidance systems for trucks.
The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the telecommunications company, received $15.8 million from the Pentagon to develop a network of medical data bases that hospitals could tap over long-distance lines. Bell Atlantic's grant came from the Pentagon's Technology Reinvestment Program, which was originally billed as a program to help military contractors adapt their technology to peacetime purposes.
The Commerce Department's research budget has been the greatest beneficiary of the Administration's new emphasis on commercial, as opposed to military, research. The department, through the National Institute of Standards and Technology, has been seeking to finance projects that have great commercial potential but little private investment. Last week, the institute spelled out five broad areas of technology that it would emphasize over the next several years.
Winnowed from 550 "white papers" submitted by industry, the winning areas include:
* DNA diagnostic technology (like the Beckman-Baylor venture);
* Manufacturing techniques for advanced composite materials;
* Modular software programs that can be connected like so many building blocks;
* Electronic information networks to improve the health-care system;
* Computer-guided systems for manufacturing in electronics.
"The whole idea is to do things that are just beyond the reach of the private R.&D. dollar," said Arati Prabhakar, director of the institute. "In every program, there's a glorious dream. But in every program, there is also a technical barrier that a company cannot overcome just with its own investment."
The Bush Administration, hewing to free-market theories, deplored such efforts as nonsensical. If a technology has great commercial promise, the argument goes, it should be able to attract private investment. If it can't attract investors, it may not have commercial value.
Dr. Prabhakar acknowledged the tension, but disputed the criticism of free-market advocates. "I don't think it's news there are things that are important for economic growth and that aren't addressed by private investment," she said. "I view what we are doing as an American experiment to explore the effective tools for government and industry to tackle problems together."
Economists have historically been skeptical about the ability of the Government to make decisions that are better than those of the private sector, and many critics worry that Federal money can easily be diverted to "pork barrel" projects advocated by well-connected companies and members of Congress.
Accusations of special-interest awards have already surfaced. Last year, the Advanced Research Projects Agency awarded $50 million to OIS Optical Imaging Systems Inc. of Troy, Mich., which plans to build a small plant for making flat-panel displays. Critics say the company received the award in part because of language written into an appropriations bill by a Democratic Congressman to suit the Michigan company. OIS executives have denied any special treatment.
But supporters of Administration policy say most of the new programs have remained clear of political cronyism. They also argue that the Administration has reduced its risk by demanding that companies match Federal money with their own and by identifying its own goals more specifically.

LENGTH: 1564 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: April 24-29

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
In a Changing Air-Travel Market, Delta Tries a Fresh Start
It was the latest admission that the business of air travel has changed -- for good. Back when a plane ticket was a luxury item, not a well-worn commodity like a pair of jeans, airlines used to make a lot of money. But then came rough-and-tumble upstarts like Southwest, and travelers discovered they could save money. Other airlines have attacked costs to some extent -- whether giving workers part ownership in return for concessions, or creating separate no-frills mini-airlines. But last week Delta -- which has few union workers -- said, in effect, that it was starting from scratch, announcing a drastic cutback of up to 15,000 workers, 20 percent of its force. The goal: cut costs by $2 billion a year -- to get its crucial cost for a "seat mile" way down from among the industry's highest. "It's extraordinary, unprecedented," said one analyst, a "fundamental recognition" that market changes are permanent. 

An About-Face for Prudential
As various recent events remind us, corporate America has its fair share of misdeeds. But it takes a brave underling to point them out to the boss, especially if they're big misdeeds, because the boss may not want to know -- and could lash out at the whistle-blower. When Mark Jorgensen, portfolio manager for two Prudential real estate funds, told his bosses the funds' values were being inflated, he was transferred and eventually dismissed. He filed suit, starting a six-month battle. But last week, after outside lawyers and auditors looked things over, Prudential suddenly said Mr. Jorgensen had been right after all, praised his "courage and conviction," offered him his job back (he declined) and said it would pay perhaps $50 million to make fund investors whole. It was a rare mea culpa.
 
A Philip Morris Nicotine Study
Philip Morris, which says smoking is not addictive, got some powerful evidence to the contrary a decade ago, then scrapped the research. That, at any rate, is what two of its former researchers told a House panel last week. They said they'd found another substance in cigarettes as addictive as nicotine, and that the two combined were powerfully addictive. Not only that, but they were on the trail of an artificial nicotine that was gentler on the heart. But Philip Morris, they said, ended the study abruptly in 1983 and swore them to silence. A company spokesman, though, called the hearing "shameful" and said it was full of "scientific sensationalism."
 
Auto Profits Soar! (Yawn.)
The nation's auto rebound is such a fact of life that even mighty profits evoke yawns. When two Detroit giants posted huge gains last week, nobody batted an eye. First General Motors said quarterly income was up 66 percent, and a day later came Ford's report: profits were up 58 percent. But G.M.'s stock actually fell at first before breaking even for the day, and Ford's was up a fraction. But how long can this last? When all those people who sputtered through the hard times finally get their new wheels, who'll do the buying?
 
A Lift for U.S. Technology
Flat-panel displays, now used mainly in laptop computers, represent what many see as hot items for the future -- they could turn up in car dashboards, airplane cockpits or portable maps. So America wants to stay on top of this technology. In the past it has simply paid contractors to build special factories -- and then faced the choice of paying high prices to those often inefficient factories, or buying abroad. But last week it came up with a new way: subsidize the industry with up to $1 billion in research grants. The hope is that this will prove cheaper in the long run, and will dispel any doubts about national security.
 
Soda and Schools: A Bad Mix?
Many new parents start out with lofty nutritional ideas: no junk, they vow, for my pure little darlings. Then reality starts seeping in -- as, say, children denied soda at home gleefully discover it in school vending machines. Now a Senator wants Washington to extend a parental hand. Patrick Leahy, the Vermont Democrat, introduced a bill last week that would urge schools to limit, even ban, the sale of soft drinks. If schools sell soda, said one supporter of the bill, it suggests that they're more interested in students' "dollars than their health." Coca-Cola, understandably miffed, mounted a lobbying counterattack, with a Coke spokesman insisting soda "can be part of a balanced diet." But Mr. Leahy says, "If Coke wins, children lose."
 
What Did the Teamsters Win?
The 23-day truckers' strike apparently ended last week when the Teamsters reached a tentative settlement with the trucking companies. Truckers claimed a partial victory, in blocking a move to allow part-time workers. But the flip side is that goods moved freely during the strike, whether on nonunion trucks or by rail, so the strike really underscored how the union's power has shrunk. The test: will union truckers get that business back?
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Pay Steady, but Spirits Up
Americans, it seems, don't need hefty raises to feel good about the economy. Last week came a report that average pay rose just 0.7 percent in the first three months of the year -- the smallest quarterly rise since 1986. Yet consumer confidence, as tracked by the Conference Board, surged in April to its highest level in four years. This mix of statistics could be a sign, right down at the paycheck level, that there's really no fear that inflation will erode salaries. Or it could be that these days just having a job is enough to make people feel good about the future; they realize fancy raises are not in the cards just now.
 
Slow Growth (With Footnotes)
On the surface, last week's main gauge of inflation seemed to show that the Federal Reserve is overly jittery in raising rates. After the gross domestic product grew at a fast 7 percent rate at the end of 1993, first-quarter growth came in at a tame 2.6 percent rate. But numbers rarely make an entrance these days without an entourage of footnotes, and this was no exception. Growth, it was quickly pointed out, was stunted by California's earthquake and everyone else's weather -- not to mention weak exports. And other numbers showed inflationary pressures -- like personal consumption, which grew at a brisk 3.8 percent rate even in winter's gloom. So a G.D.P. report that might have been cause for relaxation instead gave way to a new flurry of inflation fears.
 
So That's Where Mom Is All Day!
It was a busy week, with Take Our Daughters to Work Day hard on the heels of Take a Disgraced Ex-President Back Into Your Heart Day. Three million girls took part in this second annual pilgrimage (three times last year's level), and they spliced phone cable, mixed chemicals, designed video games, typed timeless prose on Mom's keyboard and made countless photocopies of their hands. The idea was to show girls age 9 to 15 (when they're said to start deferring to boys) that there's a place for women in the working world. But dissent nibbled at the event's edges. Some companies, like Chrysler, bowed out because boys were excluded. And in Ohio, a mother of six wanted her daughter to see how busy she was at home, but the school principal balked at first, saying homemaking was not an occupation. And one girl made an interesting point: if the next generation's attitudes are to be more enlightened, shouldn't boys witness women at work, too?
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Help for Mexico's Peso . . .
When the United States, Canada and Mexico had the sweeping vision of a North American Free Trade Agreement, they surely knew any currency disruption would throw things out of whack. But they probably didn't think trouble would arise so quickly. No sooner did the pact take effect on Jan. 1 than the peso started to crumble, battered by a peasant revolt and the killing of a top presidential candidate. So last week the three nations grabbed for a Band-Aid, setting up a $6.7 billion line of credit that Mexico's central bank can draw on to stabilize the peso. Of course, Band-Aids make sense only if there's healing going on below.
 
. . . and a Lid on the Yen
Up to a point, the United States loves a strong yen -- it makes Japanese products more expensive here, and less competitive. But currency speculators must have decided there can't be too much of that good thing, for they've sent the dollar near its lowest point against the yen since World War II. But too strong a yen could fuel inflation at home (costly or not, Japanese goods flow in), so last week the Fed intervened to prop up the dollar -- with Treasury Secretary Bentsen making the highly unusual move of announcing it.
 
American Tobacco Goes Home
At one time, the sun rarely set on American Tobacco. In 1902, with 90 percent of the American market, it formed B.A.T. Industries with a British partner. But American Tobacco, its B.A.T. stake long gone and now part of American Brands, became a minor player in an industry steadily shrinking in the face of health concerns. And last week, completing a cycle in a way, American Brands said it was selling American Tobacco to B.A.T., which already has its own small share of this nation's smoking market. So American Brands gets out of the antismoking glare, and B.A.T. becomes more of a force in the industry.

LENGTH: 1584 words

HEADLINE: Fiat Looks Beyond the Bad Old Days

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: TURIN, Italy

 BODY:
FIAT S.p.A., Italy's largest private company, is beginning to approach its businesses as if guided by the adage that the prospect of the gallows can do wonders to focus the mind.
The company is overhauling itself. It is in the midst of a $24 billion program to bring out 18 new models in the next two years. It is shedding some businesses. It is streamlining and strengthening its farm-equipment unit. It is bidding to supply high-speed trains in the United States. And it has changed the balance of power on its board in return for new investment. 
 Fiat's situation is familiar to most of Italy's big private corporations these days. They are under great pressure to reinvent themselves after several years of numbing recession and after jarring revelations of payments to politicians for favors.
Among the most visible changes at Fiat are in its automobile division. Some of the 18 new Fiat, Lancia and Alfa-Romeo models are large luxury cars, an effort to shed the image of a small-car maker and capitalize on the high margins that the bigger cars fetch. In recent months, Fiat has also brought out cars like the Punto, a compact, and a two-door coupe called the Coupe. Both have softer, less boxy lines than, say, the Uno, which the Punto replaced; the idea is to respond to the popular teardrop look of sharp new competitors like Renault's Twingo and Opel's redesigned Corsa.
The revamping conspicuously includes Alfa-Romeo, the maker of large luxury cars that Fiat acquired in 1987 but which many have said it neglected. This year, four new Alfas will be introduced, including two flashy sports models Fiat hopes will revive Alfa's sodden image.
There's also a wider use of safety features, like air bags, and engines have been redesigned for more power and fuel efficiency, especially in the bigger models, like the Alfa-Romeos.
Fiat is no longer pursuing a big auto merger, but it does seek profitable joint projects. Later this year, it will introduce two versions of a passenger van developed with Peugeot and manufactured initially at Peugeot factories in France.
The company has also shed baggage, selling units that make components like filters and spark plugs, and shifting its Rinascente department-store chain to a holding company controlled by the clan of Gianni Agnelli, Fiat's 73-year-old chairman.
But the biggest changes recently have come in farm machinery. Fiat has combined its farm-equipment division with that of New Holland, the farm-machinery business acquired from Ford in 1991. In the process, it has eliminated duplication and cut the combined unit's work force to 18,000 from 30,000, and strengthened marketing and distribution networks.
The New Holland acquisition represented a big step into the North American market. But except for that, Fiat, which stopped direct sales of Fiat models in North America more than a decade ago, says it has no further plans for the United States, where it also sells several thousand Alfa-Romeos through specialty-car dealers. Instead it is focusing its auto business on Eastern Europe, using a big car factory in Poland as a bridgehead, and Latin America, where it holds a 30 percent share of the Brazilian market.
Fiat's railway division, a leader in so-called tilting trains with roughly 70 percent of the European market, is part of a consortium with Morrison Knudsen of the United States that is bidding to supply high-speed trains for Amtrak's Boston-to-Washington line.
"I believe the real battle for the European market is coming later this decade, and we want to be equipped for it," said Giorgio Garuzzo, Fiat's 55-year-old chief operating officer. With automobiles now generating about 42 percent of group sales, Fiat's mix of cars and other products and services will remain "rather stable," he said.
THE gallows that focused Fiat's attention took the form of a brutal collapse of Europe's car market, with Fiat hardest hit. With recession squeezing hard, Fiat's car sales plummeted 20.6 percent last year, to 1.27 million cars. Most analysts attributed the big drop to a lack of model renewal. "The reason was largely an over-aged product line," said John Lawson, of DRI-McGraw Hill in London.
The drop came as a 1991 European accord allowed Japan's share of the Italian market to rise last year from 3 percent, to 4 percent; it is expected to reach 8 percent by the end of the century.
The recession bit deeply into Fiat's other businesses, like the Iveco truck and bus division, industrial products and machinery. With group sales down nearly 2 percent in 1993, to $32.5 billion, Fiat announced an estimated loss of $1.05 billion, its first since 1979.
Complicating matters, Fiat executives came under fire in connection with Italy's big kickback scandals. Mr. Agnelli acknowledged last year that the company had paid the equivalent of $33 million in kickbacks over 10 years. He said the amounts were paid in dribs and drabs, and he denied that senior executives gave approval.
Still, several senior managers, including Mr. Garuzzo, were held for questioning, though none have been charged. Mr. Garuzzo was questioned about reports of illegal payments made to politicians in Milan in return for purchases of Iveco buses for the city bus system.
All of this might have been manageable but for what had gone before. In the 1980's, Mr. Garuzzo said, Fiat was scissored between Italy's high inflation rate, which was ratcheted up by an indexation system linking wages to consumer price growth, and an overvalued lira, which was locked into Europe's monetary grid.
With labor costs soaring -- and with them the prices Fiat charged for its cars -- the inevitable occurred. Aggressive competitors like Ford Europe and Renault invaded Italy with popular models like the Renault Clio and Ford Fiesta, collapsing Fiat's share of the home market to 45 percent, from roughly 60 percent a decade earlier.
Worse, Fiat was essentially broke. And last July, Mr. Agnelli announced that Fiat's net debt would probably triple in the year, to about $7 billion.
Then, in September, the company resorted to a capital increase of $3 billion, providing the breather needed to pursue its investment program. The new money -- from French and German investors, led by the Alsthom Alcatel electronics group and the Deutsche Bank -- changed the nature of the company Mr. Agnelli's grandfather founded here in Turin in 1899.
The reason: in return for the injection of capital, Fiat's governing structure was shifted so that a seven-vote majority of its nine-member board, which sets long-term policy and appoints management, was now required for a decision. This meant that, for the first time, the two Agnelli family members on the board would be unable alone to command a decisive majority, effectively surrendering family control of Fiat.
AS testimony to Mr. Agnelli, the new investors requested that he and Cesare Romiti, the 70-year-old chief executive and Mr. Agnelli's right-hand man, forgo retirement until 1995.
Still, Fiat is no gerontocracy, and the heirs to power are men in their 40's and 50's like Mr. Garuzzo and Paolo Cantarella, 49, the head of the car division. But analysts generally credit Fiat management with the right steps to position themselves for that moment.
"They pulled in their horns in every respect except product development," said Steve Saxty, of Karl E. Ludvigsen Associates, an automobile consultancy in London. "That's very risky, and you have to give them credit for it."
Mr. Garuzzo acknowledged that relief had begun in 1992, when the collapse of the lira enabled the then Prime Minister, Giuliano Amato, to pull it out of the European grid, effectively devaluing the currency, and then to cajole labor leaders into ending wage indexation. With that, he said, Italy's labor costs have become more favorable.
Some of the decisions were obvious. Though producing large cars under its Fiat, Lancia and Alfa-Romeo brand names, Fiat has never quite shaken the image of the small-car maker, thus forfeiting margins enjoyed by luxury manufacturers like Mercedes-Benz. And the New Holland acquisition seemed made in heaven, because Fiat's farm machinery division focuses on mature markets like Italy, France and Spain, while New Holland offered access to the United States, northern Europe and Brazil.
With the revival in the United States, Fiat officials expect New Holland to be profitable this year, and other divisions, like Iveco, are also improving..
In a recent meeting with bankers, Fiat's chief financial officer, Francesco Paolo Mattioli, estimated that group sales would rise 13 percent in 1994 over last year, to $36 billion.
Mr. Cantarella of the car division said a lot will depend on Europe's automobile market. Fiat's car division had losses last year, and he said it is too early to say whether it will break even this year.
To bring this about, Fiat has a wish list for the new Government that the big winner in March's elections, Silvio Berlusconi, is forming. First of all, it wants special Government rebates to buyers who traded in older cars, similar to what France and Spain offer. Mr. Berlusconi's advisers are said to be favorable. Then, Fiat wants Government backing to freeze the Japanese share at present levels, at least until the recession lets up.
The prospect of help on the way prompted investors on the national stock market in Milan to push Fiat's share price up 33 percent in the month since the elections, to 6,900 lire on Friday.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Workers Are Starting To Win a Few

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
IT was almost 13 years ago when it became clear that labor unions had lost much of their clout. President Ronald Reagan broke the air traffic controllers' strike, and left the strikers unemployed.
In retrospect, that action seems to have set the tone for an era in which the power of workers to get "more," as Samuel Gompers is said to have put it when asked what organized labor wanted, had ended. 
 It was a time when the fear of inflation had grown to the extent that the public wanted something done, not just in the United States but around the world. In Britain, Margaret Thatcher was breaking the power of unions and in France a supposedly Socialist Government was imposing austerity.
The fear of inflation then is now only dimly remembered by many. Prices had begun climbing in the late 1960's, and inflation kept rising through price controls and through recessions. By 1981, almost everyone expected oil prices to top $100 a barrel within a few years. Interest rates were high and rising, and a few months after the controllers' strike was broken the Government sold an issue of 30-year bonds with a yield to maturity of 15.78 percent. There was disagreement about what government could do to bring inflation under control, but there was consensus that there would not be the political will to do it.
Now, the situation is reversed. Higher interest rates are being blamed on almost everything except concern about inflation. It is widely believed that labor costs cannot rise rapidly because there are too many people willing to do any given job, if not here, then in some other country.
But a funny thing happened when the nation's unionized trucking companies decided to save money -- and better compete with nonunion companies -- by replacing full-time workers with part timers. The teamsters' union struck, and won a partial victory.
There are similar stories to be told overseas. In France, the conservative Government decided to allow employers to pay less than the minimum wage to young workers, reasoning that would help to reduce unemployment. Students figured it just meant they would earn less, and took to the streets. The Government backed down.
In this country, the average worker has seen his weekly pay rise by 1.5 percent, after inflation, in the past year. That may not sound like much, but it comes after years of declines that coincided with falling inflation and weak unions. Change is again in the air.
None of this alters the fact that jobs can be exported. But it may be worth noting that the Clinton Administration, after establishing its free-trade credentials with Nafta, is sounding tough in trade talks with China and Japan. Protectionism, even if cloaked as retaliation for closed markets or righteous anger over human rights abuses, would be another inflationary force.
All of which may help to explain why long-term interest rates have climbed more than most people expected. Inflation is not going to accelerate tomorrow, but one trend that helped to depress it has lost power and may be reversing.

HEADLINE: Sound Bytes;
Assembling a New Whole

BYLINE: By Lawrence M. Fisher 

 BODY:
WHY build a company when it's faster to buy several and create a whole greater than the sum of its parts? That's been the mission of Michael Fields, a former executive of the Oracle Systems Corporation who set out to create the first comprehensive management tools, for tasks such as backing up data, security and archival storage, in the uncharted realm of client-server computing. While commonly available from large mainframe producers, such tools have been lacking in client-server set-ups, which split tasks among more than one computer on a network.
Armed with $35 million in capital from Warburg Pincus, a New York venture capital firm, Mr. Fields created the Open Visions Technologies Corporation by acquiring nine companies or divisionsof companies, such as the storage management division of the Control Data Corporation. Open Vision also acquired five products or product families from larger companies. Like the customers it hopes to serve, Open Vision is a "distributed" company, with headquarters in Pleasanton, Calif., and development centers in seven locations across the country, linked by a computer network. 
 Question: Why isn't systems management already provided by the sellers of operating systems or data base management software?
Answer: Whenever you move into a new paradigm, which is how I describe client-server, there are new requirements. Client-server lets users get close to actual production data, so you need expertise to manage it successfully. That's what Open Vision delivers in tools and services. These are all things the system software guys should do well, but the fact is they don't.
Q: What's different about Open Vision?
A: Open Vision is the first company to start by launching a major acquisition campaign to bring technologies and people together, not based on market share, but on how "integratable" they are. We walked away from a lot of companies with large market share but whose products did not meet our standards of integration. Buyers are looking for a suite of technologies that work together. The second criterion was that the engineers who built the products had to come along. If they didn't feel comfortable joining Open Vision it wouldn't matter if the owners gave the company to us.
Q: You were at Oracle for its dramatic rise, its fall in 1990, when it had to restate its earnings, and its rise again. What lessons did you learn from that experience?
A: I was appointed president of Oracle U.S.A. about one week after the debacle in 1990, and I had to face the investment community when they heard what had happened. The stock went from $18 to $4.50 in a week. I learned you have to manage your business not based on what you would like to do but on what you know you can do. You can't let growth get too far ahead of your ability to support it.
Q: You are active in Black Executives in Software Technology. What do you think can be done about the relative absence of African Americans in this industry?
A: In educational centers, they tend to teach the science of developing computer systems, which is for people who want to go on to develop hardware. That path scares away a lot of blacks and a lot of women. But the real opportunities are in application development, which is built much more on logic than on physics. I tell students to see the software industry as a major opportunity. Although there is no industry I consider color- or gender-blind, this is one where your abilities carry much more weight than your gender or color.
 
Michael S. Fields
 
 Born: Oct. 1, 1945; New York City.
 
 Noncomputer reading: "The Warburgs," by Ron Chernow.
 
 Ideal escape: Four days on Maui.
 
 Hobbies: Golf, pocket billiards, gadgets.
 
 Family: Wife, Sandra; daughters, Michelle, 26, and Tara, 22.
 
 Drives: 1990 BMW 750.
 
 Computers: Generic 486 DX2 66 mhz PC from CompUSA; a Macintosh Duo for traveling.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Putting Women on the Agenda

SERIES: First of two articles on a recent conference on progressive economics.

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE latest installment of Robert Skidelsky's biography of John Maynard Keynes indicates the eminent economist was not much interested in women, at least not until he met Lydia Lopokova, the ballerina who became the source and object of a grand passion Keynes had previously reserved for monetary theory. Irony therefore was especially delicious for some of the participants in an unusual gathering in mid-April at Oxford University. Under the very gaze of the dominant economic theorist of the 20th century -- his portrait hangs prominently in Magdalen College, where the group met -- they put the topic of women as an economic force on the table.
To be sure, the social democratic and progressive academics, trade unionists, think tank representatives and journalists from North America, Europe, Australia and Britain who gathered for the International Seminar on Growth and Unemployment weren't there only to be amused by juxtaposition. They were, for one thing, intent on restoring Keynes's reputation, sullied in the United States during 12 Republican years of rising deficits and tax breaks for the rich. "We were in the land of Keynes," said Jeff Faux, director of the Economic Policy Institute in Washington. "There was a fair amount of talk about how Keynes had been bastardized." 
 The participants, according to Mr. Faux and Linda Tarr-Whelan, director of the Center for Policy Alternatives in Washington, who reported back from the conference at a briefing in Washington in late April, were in a celebratory mood at what was apparently their first-ever chance to mull collectively over issues like the globalization of markets -- issues on which the better-financed right-of-center think tanks tend to have a louder voice. "The labor movement is just starting to see it's going to go international or it's doomed," Ms. Tarr-Whelan said.
It was Ms. Tarr-Whelan and her counterpart at the Fabian Society in London, Glenys Thornton, who insisted during the planning process on integrating women's issues into what was shaping up as a fairly traditional trade unionist-social democratic agenda, motivated by concern for "rising unemployment, widening inequality and escalating social distress," as the conference report eventually put it. The agenda did not reflect the more than two decades of changes in family structure and decline in male earning power that has propelled women into the labor force and transformed their social roles.
Ms. Tarr-Whelan offered certain implacable demographic facts about the United States in her presentation to the group:
* Women are 45.6 percent of the work force now, a figure expected to rise to 47 percent by 2005. They accounted for 60 percent of labor force growth between 1982 and 1992.
* Women make a significant contribution to family income. In 1991, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the median income of married-couple families with the wife working outside the home was $48,169. Families without the second salary had a median income of $30,075.
* Women are starting businesses at a faster pace than other groups -- five times faster than men. As the businesses mature, the women-owned business sector is growing in importance as an employer.
The notion that economic policy should be devised "with full recognition of the new realities of men and women at work," as Ms. Tarr-Whelan put it in her paper, is the founding principle of a powerful cabal of American women, from business, government, politics and feminism, who gathered for a "women's economic summit" shortly after Bill Clinton's election. They made their case with an eye to establishing a place in the raucous pan-interest group conversation of the first 100 days of the Clinton Administration.
The group, expanded and more diverse, met again in January in Leesburg, Va., to refine its positions. The participants still argued for the centrality of women's economic issues but also devised a three-tiered strategy encouraging entrepreneurial enterprise, strengthening the social safety net and balancing work and family.
Such an approach, the summit conference report argued, could be the bedrock of building a mass constituency of women. Women, of course, don't agree on everything, but research reported at the summit meeting by Celinda Lake, a Washington pollster, indicated a surprising consensus among women -- across political affiliation, region, race and class -- on "the interrelationship of work life, family life and community."
Ms. Tarr-Whelan took this approach, the "politics of the new economy," as she calls it, to Oxford. The traditional left tends to want to subsume women under the general category "worker," but, Ms. Tarr-Whelan said, there was no resistance from the group to thinking about women as independent economic actors. Her insistence that the think tanks send women helped. "It is one of the different things about having women at the table and women as planners," she said.
Talking about women also helped clarify an issue that many progressives tiptoe around for fear of pitting men and women against each other. "Women are pouring into the work force and men are losing their jobs," Ms. Tarr-Whelan said after the briefing. "There seems to be a relationship." She noted in her paper that women are still overwhelmingly in female-dominated occupations, citing 1988 figures indicating that only 9 percent of working women have nontraditional jobs. "Men and women are not holding the same jobs," she said. "It was a light bulb experience." Women figured prominently in the final conference report.
Any other resistance may have been leveled by the simple fact that Ms. Tarr-Whelan and her like-minded colleagues could brandish tantalizing election victories in the United States and Australia, where the women's vote helped carry Bill Clinton and the Labor Party, respectively, to victory.
One goal of the "politics of the new economy" is to keep economics up front and keep divisive social issues in the background. Ms. Tarr-Whelan favors the slogan "It's the economy, stupid," surely a sentiment with which Maynard Keynes -- and perhaps even his beloved Lopokova -- would have agreed.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Ways to Cope When Market Slides

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
THE long-anticipated stock market decline has left mutual fund investors wondering what to do to preserve what's left of their portfolios -- stay in the market or pull out?
Sit tight, say fund experts. Risk "is part of the package, and you can't panic when the market falls," said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc. 
 Investors have been doing just that. Although the Dow Jones industrial average fell almost 10 percent from its peak at the end of January to its recent low, money flowed out of stock funds just one week so far this year, the first week of April, when the market bottomed, AMG Data Services said.
Even so, investors should review their fund holdings, experts say. Possible actions: rethink the allocation to equities, shorten bond terms, buy shares as bargains appear.
Most important is to put the decline in perspective. The recent rout was the first time in more than three years that the market fell so far. Moreover, "declines of this magnitude are to be expected periodically after periods of overenthusiasm on the part of investors," said H. Bradlee Perry, senior partner of David L. Babson & Company in Boston, which sponsors the Jones & Babson group of funds.
The run-up in stock prices, Mr. Perry said, was mostly fueled by a strengthening economy and falling interest rates, which pushed bank savers into stock mutual funds. The steady upward march in equity prices built confidence and finally even euphoria, which burst, he said, when the Federal Reserve nudged up short-term interest rates.
His advice is simple. The current stock market decline "is a truly normal occurrence, and one that should be of little concern to investors who own shares of strong, growing companies."
The market has been so strong in recent years that this is the first tumble for many people who have just begun buying funds, so it makes sense to reassess risk tolerance.
"It's one thing to philosophize about loss, and another thing to live it," said Craig Litman, principal with Litman/Gregory, San Francisco-based investment advisers. "There may be some downside yet until the correction runs its course," he added.
Even so, long-term investors should avoid the temptation to bail out, said Sheldon Jacobs, who edits the No-Load Fund Investor. Although there can be prolonged down periods, the stock market tends to rise over time.
Mr. Jacobs conducted a study in which $2,000 was invested annually in stocks on the day the stock market hit its highest point of the year, starting on Jan. 11, 1973. While the 1973-1974 bear market yielded initial losses, the investment finally began growing. By the end of 1993, he said, the $42,000 invested over 21 years was worth $162,734.
What about hopping out of stocks until the market hits bottom and then moving back in? "The plain truth is that market timing doesn't work," said Gerald Perritt, who edits The Mutual Fund Letter.
Even so, there are some ways fund holders can protect themselves. One solution for the uneasy investor is to raise cash to minimize losses. Of course, the price of holding cash is potentially lower returns.
Also, the steady upward returns of recent years have lulled many investors into keeping too much money in common stocks or long-term bonds, Mr. Phillips said. Money needed in five years or less should be in less volatile investments like short-term bond or money market funds.
For long-term investors, the picture is different, and advisers urge them to put money into equities now.
Consider some particularly beat-up market sectors as good buy candidates, Mr. Litman said. He recommends putting a small portion in emerging markets debt, via the Fidelity Emerging Markets Income Fund. He also likes Harbor Capital Appreciation, which invests in established companies, and Brandywine, which looks for smaller, lesser-known companies and has a $25,000 minimum investment.
The highly regarded manager Michael Price sees so many opportunities now that he has reopened two funds that had been closed to new investors since 1989, Mutual Shares and Mutual Qualified.
Some funds actually posted gains in March when the market suffered its worst declines of the quarter, said Janet Brown, managing editor of No-Load Fund X. Among them were Southeastern Asset Management Value (up 1.7 percent) and Warburg Pincus Growth and Income (up 0.6 percent).
Bond fund investors might take a different tack than putting more money into the market. Because of the Federal Reserve's upward moves in short-term interest rates, long-term bonds are particularly vulnerable to price declines. So one good option is to shorten maturities, moving from a long-term to an intermediate- or short-term bond fund during rallies.
Bond investors who have substantial losses, especially in municipal bonds, might consider switching into comparable funds, locking in the loss for tax reasons while leaving their economic position unchanged, Mr. Litman said.
The bottom line: outpacing inflation over time requires a commitment to equities. To invest successfully, diversify, invest for the long term and minimize costs, Mr. Perritt said. Furthermore, realize that the stock market spends a lot of time in retreat; use market slumps to buy rather than sell, he said.

HEADLINE: The World;
A Nixon Legacy Devalued By a Cold War Standard

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN most of the obituaries and retrospectives about the life and times of President Richard M. Nixon, his foreign policy achievements were hailed as the centerpiece of his Presidency. But oddly, all of these eulogies either ignored, or mentioned only in passing, what may have been one of the most enduring of Mr. Nixon's foreign policy initiatives: his decision in 1971 to take the dollar off the gold standard and demolish the Bretton Woods monetary system -- bidding both farewell with that memorable line about the Italian currency: "I don't give a (bleep) about the lira."
Bretton Woods was the town in New Hampshire where, in July of 1944, American and British officials gathered to set up a monetary system that would restore global trade and economics after the war. The Bretton Woods system was based on the conviction that the world should not return to the laissez-faire chaos of the 1930's, when exchange rates were allowed to float and fluctuate wildly. The Bretton Woods agreement established that the dollar would be the fixed center of a new economic solar system. Each country would declare a value of its currency against the dollar, and it would be allowed to float only 1 percent up or down. The dollar would be linked to gold at a rate of $35 an ounce. Any country that piled up dollars could come to the teller window at Fort Knox and redeem them for gold at that fixed rate. 
 For about 25 years the system worked fine, until the Vietnam War and Great Society programs triggered serious inflation in the United States. As America's trade deficits with Europe and Japan grew, and dollars started piling up abroad, the Western allies rushed to redeem their dollars for gold before they were eroded by American inflation. President Nixon imposed wage and price controls to dampen inflation, but he also decided that he would devalue the dollar to make American exports cheaper and stimulate export-led growth. Since Bretton Woods barred such a devaluation, Mr. Nixon devalued Bretton Woods. He unilaterally abrogated the treaty, closed the gold window, and soon thereafter let the dollar float. In Japan, they called it the "Nixon Shocku."
"It fell to Nixon to seal the fate of the Bretton Woods system," said Richard N. Gardner, author of the standard history of Bretton Woods and now the American Ambassador to Spain. "While this may have been inevitable, to ignore its long-term impact would be a major historical oversight. Nixon moved us into a very different monetary universe of floating exchange rates, something we are still coping with today. That is a world of greatvolatility of currencies, which complicates international trade and investment and encourages speculation."
One major positive to come out of Nixon's move was that it forced the key industrial democracies to work together in a "Group of Seven" to coordinate interest rates, monetary and fiscal policies -- and even diplomacy -- to maintain a modicum of currency stability.
The reason this Nixon initiative gets short shrift is because news and history tend to be written in the context of a Super Story -- a large narrative drama that sets the broad context in which events are judged. The international Super Story of the Nixon era was the cold war; news was deemed significant or insignificant in relation to where it fit in that East-West drama. The opening to China and detente naturally assumed a high profile; economics was secondary. Most journalists and editors, having been suckled on the cold war, naturally gravitate to news about national security, not economic security.
"For the last 45 years we were in a war -- the cold war -- and everything was subordinated to the requirements of waging that war," said Michael Mandelbaum, an expert on cold war history at Johns Hopkins University. "In that context, the sorts of things that Richard Nixon cared about -- national security issues -- were defined as high politics, and the proper preoccupation of Presidents and journalists, while international economics was defined as low politics, and the proper preoccupation of faceless bureaucrats. People write histories about wars, not bookkeeping, and they run for President to be warlords, not accountants."
Now that the cold war is over, though, the Super Story may be changing. Regional crises -- like Bosnia and Haiti -- still grab headlines, but they must now compete with a new Super Story -- the one about a world that is becoming more and more economically intertwined. In that world, the President is as much Merchant in Chief as Commander in Chief. President Clinton's efforts to secure a global trade agreement -- known as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -- and the North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico and Canada have loomed very large in this new dollar drama, and it is a safe bet that neither will be overlooked in his obituary.

HEADLINE: If and When;
From the Pall of Sarajevo to the Shore of Who Knows Where

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If Somalia, why not Bosnia? If Bosnia, why not Rwanda? Or the Sudan? Or Haiti? Or Afghanistan?
Five years after the grand retreat of Communism, the list of plausible candidates for military intervention grows ever longer. Yet neither President Clinton nor other Western leaders have articulated a clear standard for distinguishing among victims of brutality and aggression. 
 The major post-cold war intervention, in the Persian Gulf, was not about Iraqi brutality (the Iraqi dictatorship had been brutal long before it invaded Kuwait), but about oil and alliances. Vital Western interests -- the old standard for intervention -- would have been at stake even if Iraq had scrupulously observed the Geneva Conventions.
And things were simpler in the cold war, when arguments over whether to commit forces to faraway conflicts were framed by the confrontation between Moscow and Washington. The world had no problem pragmatically averting its gaze from humanitarian catastrophes like Pol Pot's genocidal but diplomatically isolated regime in Cambodia.
But there is no oil in Haiti or Bosnia. There are no Communists in Rwanda. There is only murder and torture and genocide, without any meter of horrors that can calibrate one country's suffering against another's.
And where there are Western interests, they are subtle. Perhaps, for example, it is not Serbian atrocities that should motivate action in Bosnia, but issues of European stability.
Gone are the traditional hawks and doves. In their place stand the new globalists, who argue that the West has an overriding stake in encouraging international order and should do so as a coalition wherever the conflict, and, on the other side, the thinkers who oppose almost any intervention unless it can be justified by the familiar definitions of national interest.
If the search for high philosophical principles has yielded these appealingly coherent theories, there also remains an enormous middle ground where various flavors of political or policy experts are trying to improvise a practical way to guide America's use of power while recognizing its limits -- notably the needs for domestic consensus and reasonable prospects of success.
Here is a sampling of the schools of thought, signposts to the debate on how to use American power in an unfamiliar world:

Interventionism:
Acting to Stem Chaos
John Steinbruner, director of foreign policy studies at the Brookings Institution, is among the more forceful advocates of Western engagement. With the increasing interconnection of the world economy, he argues, the United States and its allies have a powerful interest in preventing the virus of chaos from infecting wider swaths of the globe.
"We live in an integrated world," Mr. Steinbruner said. "A serious infection that gets out of control in one place is threatening to the whole organism. If you live in the shoulder, and you've got gangrene of the feet, you'd better worry."
Intervention, Mr. Steinbruner contends, can be launched only by a coalition of forces from various nations, but he said the United States has a leading role. "If we don't undertake it," he said, "nobody else will."
He suggests a broad standard: That citizens of any country should be accorded basic human rights, which include the freedom from wholescale slaughter because their country's government has collapsed or because a group has unleashed an ethnic war (although, he adds, "I don't mean the right of a dissident to thumb his nose at a dictator.")
He acknowledges that such a standard, whether enforced through the United Nations or by the West, would have to be applied to every case, from Afghanistan to Rwanda.
"Once you espouse these doctrines," he said, "you have to apply them to places you aren't used to caring about, and that's why everyone shrinks away from it."
Mr. Steinbruner said that the world now lacks the rationale, the coalition and the military planning for such operations. And he said that the main emphasis should be on early prevention of conflicts, rather than military intervention.
But he said that ultimately, aggressors will be deterred only by credible threats of countervailing force.
"Massive breakdowns of the civil order are too dangerous for the entire system," he said. "We are very slow to get on to this. But ultimately we won't have a lot of choice. If we want to run a coherent society ourselves, we will have to defend legal order at the far reaches of the globe."

Non-Interventionism:
Avoiding Entanglements
Ted Galen Carpenter, director of foreign policy studies at the Cato Institute, sees few, if any, humanitarian tragedies that justify American military intervention.
"We can express moral outrage as citizens, or as a government," he argues, "but that cannot be a criterion for intervention."
He worries that intervention is a slippery slope and that deployment of American troops to countries like Somalia builds the pressure for wider commitments.
"There are so many potential arenas," he said, "that even if we pursued it multilaterally, the U.S. would be involved in a great many conflicts, incurring great costs and substantial risks. A global security system is impractical."
Mr. Carpenter has little use either for those who call for intervention to quell selected instances of humanitarian abuses, usually the most egregious.
American forces, he said, should be placed in harm's way only if this country's survival is at stake, or when the international order is threatened by something like Hitler's rise to power.
"Those who come down in the middle end up getting into a lot of different enterprises, peacekeeping operations, and then find out, as we did in Somalia, that the task is much more difficult than we anticipated," he said. "At that point, all but the most ardent lose interest, or go into opposition."
For him, Bosnia is the classic example of a place in which the United States has no real interests and no reason to meddle. "Serbia is a third-rate economic and military power," he asserts, "with no territorial ambitions beyond the borders of Yugoslavia."
"As tragic as the situation is -- and it is obviously horrible -- the best solution is probably to let the various factions fight it out. To intervene there raises the obvious question. If there, why not the Sudan, where more than a million have perished, or Angola, where the U.N. says 1,000 a day are perishing, or the chaos of Afghanistan?
"There are a lot of tragedies in the world," he added, "and we can't intervene in all of them."
Mr. Carpenter dismissed the notion that a strong stand in, say, Bosnia, might deter aggressors elsewhere.
"Most conflicts have local roots; they're due to local factors," he said. "Just because an aggressor is hammered halfway around the world doesn't mean that competing factions in another region will be intimidated."

Flexibility:
Indignation Case by Case
Zbigniew Brzezinski, who was President Carter's national security adviser, agrees it is impractical to intervene in every conflict. But he said the West cannot stand by when atrocities become as severe as the recent massacres in Rwanda, where as many as 200,000 people may have been killed, according to the U.N. Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali. The indifference to this staggering carnage, Mr. Brzezinski said, is a "total blemish on the international community and the international organizations."
America tends "to interfere as little as possible in foreign wars, civil wars," he said. "And that's the tendency of this President. Yet even he can't get away with it."
Mr. Brzezinski said it is a useless exercise to define when -- and for what reason -- foreign conflicts require intervention.
"It's not a mathematical question," he said. "It's a matter of common sense. At a certain point, disasters become something bigger, and people cannot stand aside.
"Is it a thousand people killed? A million?
"It depends somewhat on the traditions of the country. In a country like China, a million disappear, and this is taken rather stoically."

The Limits of Power:
Listening to the Voters
All of the people who call themselves pragmatists -- from the hawkish to the dovish -- say humanitarian interventions should be limited to those cases in which the West can make a difference at a reasonable cost.
But James R. Schlesinger, a former Director of Central Intelligence and Defense Secretary under Presidents Nixon and Ford, says this misses the point. Intervention implies a decision to, if necessary, use substantial force. That must be decided at the outset.
Are there cases of genocide where the United States and its allies should take action, even if no national interest is at stake? "Probably yes," Mr. Schlesinger says, "But it has to go over many hurdles."
Pressed on whether intervention ever becomes a moral imperative, he said:
"Those who would act on behalf of morality had better think through the entire moral fabric, including imposing those views on an indifferent body politic in America."
To Mr. Schlesinger, the most crucial hurdle is American public opinion.
"If people see enough horrors on TV, that can be enough," he said.
"This country is still the most democratic of democracies, in which foreign policies well up, to a large extent, from the general public. You can't do things as if you were the Imperial German Government. I don't believe you can go into a costly humanitarian operation solely as a result of ruminations by the executive branch."
He also cautioned against the notion of firing shots across the bow of an aggressor. "Don't do these little signals," he said. "That's an American illusion: 'If we only send a signal to Ho Chi Minh that his important assets are at risk, he will see that the rational thing to do is desist.' "

LENGTH: 848 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
And Landscape Architects Are Tilling the Soil

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Throughout American history, in voices as disparate as those of Thomas Jefferson, Henry David Thoreau and Country Joe and the Fish, many have rhapsodized about the rural life. In the country, lungs breathe clean, souls tune in to nature's rhythms and democracy grows its strongest roots. Yet in spite of those paeans to arcadian joys, Americans have deserted farms and small towns at such a startling pace that the 1990 census showed that less than one-fourth of the population was rural -- down from about half in 1920.
Even as the rural population dwindled, the trappings of country life followed Americans to the cities, pushed along by the modern-day environmental movement and shrewd marketing. Consumers bought rugged clothes from retailers like L. L. Bean and the western look from designers like Ralph Lauren, remodeled their kitchens to resemble weathered cupboards in Iowa farmhouses and drank beer said to be brewed from "pure mountain water." If the life in rural America could not be lived in earnest, it could, at least psychologically, be replicated. 
 Sue Halpern, a writer who lives the rustic life in New York's Adirondack Mountains, notes that polls of city and suburban dwellers often find them expressing a desire to live in small towns. "This is more than a little wistful," Ms. Halpern writes in her book, "Migrations to Solitude" (Vintage, 1992). "They'd probably rather own a Model T, but they're going to buy a Taurus."
Now comes new evidence that some Americans are acting on wistful sentiment and moving back to the land of big sky. But when they get there, they are finding that it no longer resembles the land of their dreams.
In a recent study, Kenneth Johnson of Loyola University-Chicago and Calvin Beale of the Department of Agriculture have confirmed their belief that the population of rural America is again on the rise as it was, briefly, during the short-lived "rural revival" of the 1970's.
 
Crowded Lakes
 Using annual estimates of population shifts compiled by the Census Bureau and state demographers, their report shows that 64 percent of the country's 2,277 non-metropolitan counties grew in the early 1990's, compared with only 46 percent of these counties during the 1980's. The number of people moving into rural areas outstripped the number moving out by 377,000 from 1990 through 1992, reversing the trend of the 1980's, when a net total of 928,000 people left rural counties.
If more Americans are headed to the country, the atmosphere they find -- and probably help to create -- may be far different from what they had imagined. Retirees may muse about spending long, lazy hours fishing on a quiet pond, but they are likely to find the local lake clogged with bass boats or waterskiers. Migrants to eastern Idaho or northwest Wyoming seeking the backwoods solitude of cross-country skiing might find their peace shattered by hordes of snowmobilers.
If they wander into L. L. Bean in Freeport, Me., they will find a shopping mall. Outside, they will already have encountered a strip of outlet stores selling everything from porcelain to designer apparel to vacation souvenirs (in case you were planning to have a dinner on fine china, looking like the ultimate in chic, next time you went camping).
But malls and their urban wares are not really the issue. It's not so much that paradise is being paved over. It's being landscaped into golf courses.
The growth in rural areas, according to Mr. Johnson and Mr. Beale, is strongest in counties with large retirement communities and recreational areas where residents can ski, sail, climb mountains or hike. While the migrants have brought about economic rebirth in many places, they have also profoundly transformed the local economy. Work is likely to mean waiting on tables, not tilling the land.
"There's so much of a tendency of urban people to regard rural America as a playground," Mr. Beale said. "This creates a lot of controversy in places like the West where many local people get resentful. They may want the business, but they realize that it may change the character of the place."
 
Vistas From Poolside
 The ideal of the country may have followed Americans' trek to the city. And as some of them trek back, they are bringing the amenities of the city in tow. But will the country still seem like the country when Main Street has espresso bars down the street from the general store?
Rick Bass, an environmentalist and writer, described in his book "Winter: Notes From Montana" (Seymour Lawrence/Houghton Mifflin, 1991) what he and his companion were looking for when they searched for a home in the country. In it, he summed up these contradictory impulses: "We wanted a place of ultimate wildness, with that first and last yardstick of privacy: a place where you could walk around naked if you wanted to, a place with a barn, field and stables for keeping horses, because Elizabeth loved to ride. And if there was an indoor swimming pool and maybe some tennis courts on the premises and a little garden, well, that would be all right too."
