HEADLINE: The Nation;
Good New Jobs, Same Old Salaries

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Each month the Labor Department announces the creation of tens of thousands of new jobs. And the announcements are greeted skeptically. They are mostly part-time jobs or temporary day work, the skepticism goes. Or they are low-wage jobs in fast-food restaurants and in health care. All of this was true. But lately the mix has got much richer. Now, a lot of the new jobs are higher status, with better pay and often with benefits.
These happy statistics, which are just now showing up clearly on government ledgers, give the Clinton Administration something to crow about. For many thousands of skilled people who sought work but could not find suitable jobs, opportunities are opening up. But for the nation as a whole, the standard of living is not likely to rise anytime soon. 
 Since last fall, new jobs have multiplied in such solid fields as medical technology, trucking, teaching, computer specialties, mortgage finance, accounting and factory work. But pay is a problem. Some of the jobs pay $40,000 or $50,000 a year, but the amounts for each occupation have remained roughly unchanged, rising each year by barely enough to offset inflation. And this stagnation shows no sign yet of lifting.
"Everyone has a sense of insecurity sitting in the back of their minds," said Lawrence Katz, the Labor Department's chief economist, referring to the layoffs and cutbacks that have characterized the 1990's, and have touched millions of Americans. "That sense of insecurity will probably dampen their wage demands for some unknown period of time."
The dampening is evident at the Whirlpool Corporation, for example, where more than 700 people have been hired to staff third shifts at Midwestern plants to meet a surge in demand for washers, dryers and refrigerators. But their wages for assembly work, now averaging $12.20 an hour, are rising by less than the current inflation rate of 3 percent a year -- the pay schedule being roughly pegged to a union contract that lasts until 1999. Many companies operate similarly.
"The labor movement's contribution to wage inflation is nonexistent," said Mark Roberts, an economist for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Whirlpool gives bonuses to workers who increase their productivity by assembling, say, five refrigerators an hour instead of three. The bonuses give the workers a share of the profit from the extra production, and without extra production and profit there are no bonuses.
In the past, companies like Whirlpool, forced to give wage increases even as workers continued to assemble only three refrigerators an hour, covered the extra labor cost by raising prices. These price increases contributed, in turn, to a rise in the national inflation rate. The Federal Reserve responded by raising interest rates to discourage borrowing and spending. That reduced the inflation rate, but it also slowed down the economy, and the hiring.
Now, the Federal Reserve is raising interest rates again, partly out of concern that the latest surge in hiring might become inflationary. Many economists disagree, including some in the Clinton Administration. They argue that an upturn in hiring is no longer a front-burner reason for the Fed to slow the economy, risking recession.
"You ask who feels insecure about their jobs and in every group, 80 percent of the hands go up," said Richard Freeman, a Harvard labor economist, describing some recent focus group sessions involving workers from supervisors to janitors. "That insecurity is the underlying reason for the lack of wage pressure today."
The job growth that is gaining strength today started quietly in February 1992, while George Bush was President. A recession had ended the previous March, but for nearly a year into the recovery employment contracted. When the turn finally came 26 months ago, the hiring was heavily at the low-wage end of the spectrum, according to the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.
During that first year, until February 1993 -- the Clinton Administration's first full month in office -- 1.5 million new jobs were created, after subtracting layoffs, forced retirements and other cutbacks from a much larger total. But while many of the lost jobs paid more than $10 an hour, nearly 60 percent of the new ones fell below that level.
They were in restaurants, at companies like Manpower Inc., which recruit and rent out tens of thousands of temporary workers, and in the health care industry, which mostly added nurse's aides and other attendants. The year was notable for cutbacks, or very weak hiring, in manufacturing, construction and finance -- industries that pay relatively well.
Part-time work represented about 19 percent of the new jobs in 1992, and that share has persisted through Mr. Clinton's months in office, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports. There the similarity with 1992 ends. "In just about all industries, 1993 was a better year than 1992," said Thomas Nardone, a bureau economist. "Even those industries that lost jobs in 1993, went down less than in 1992."
 
One Promise Kept
 In the 13 months through March, the nation's work force grew by 2.2 million. And 30 percent of that growth -- 684,000 jobs -- has come since January. As the economy and hiring have picked up, the Administration has been able to proclaim that it is meeting its goal of over 200,000 new jobs a month.
But quality is another issue. The bureau's findings are too general to show with precision the quality of the jobs, though they allow the general conclusion that it is rising. The bureau does not match jobs with wages, for example. The closest it gets is calculating average wages for the industries or occupations where jobs are being created, and from this inferences have to be made.
Temporary workers, averaging less than $10 an hour, represented nearly 21 percent of the job growth in 1992, and that fell to 14 percent last year. On the other hand, manufacturing, which kept losing jobs until last September, has added 88,000 since then, at companies that make autos, furniture, metals, electronics and machinery -- and pay on average more than $12 an hour.
Similarly in health care, no one knows how many of the new hires are technicians and registered nurses and how many are orderlies, nurse's aides and home-care workers. But the average wage of $11.32 an hour last year suggests that technicians and nurses are a rising proportion.
Across industries, the bureau also collects data on administrators and managers and on "management-related occupations." Both were areas of weak job growth or job decline in 1992 and strong job growth since then. These are broad categories that cover accountants, store buyers, personnel executives, public relations executives, funeral directors and the like. They are categories with average earnings of up to $35,000 a year.
"We are going through a sort of three-phased process and we are now in the second phase where employers don't offer higher wages, but do offer more full-time jobs as opposed to contract work or temporary and part-time work," said Frank Levy, a labor economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "If the recovery continues and many people, across many industries, offer these jobs, wages are likely to be bid up."
And when will that phase begin? Mr. Levy replied, "You can offer secure jobs for a long time before you have to offer higher pay."

HEADLINE: COLLEGE SENIORS FINDING MORE JOBS BUT MODEST PAY

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Del.

 BODY:
With the economy strong again, graduating college seniors are finding jobs easier to get after a four-year drought. But except for students with both solid work experience and widely sought skills, many students in the class of '94 are settling for jobs with modest salaries and no future while hoping for better work or saving for graduate school.
"It's real clear that in the 90's, people may find work but not work they're happy with," said Edgar J. Townsend, director of career services at the University of Delaware, which occupies a 1,100-acre campus of elms and Georgian brick buildings. 
 The university's student body reflects that of other major universities, and the fortunes of its graduates in finding jobs parallel national trends. Sixty-five percent of the university's 21,000 students, including 3,000 seniors, are from other states.
These days they are discovering that good grades and a grounding in Homer and history matter less than proficiency with computers, balance sheets and nursing. These skills give those who held jobs while attending college a considerable edge.
But the salaries that even these students receive have barely budged in two years, despite the rising profits of business. No one collects national figures of college graduates' average starting pay. But the College Placement Council in Bethlehem, Pa., says the starting salaries of business majors are a good example. Their average of $23,820 this year is 3 percent less than last year, the council said.
In his own annual poll of the University of Delaware's graduates, taken six months after they leave, Mr. Townsend found that the average starting salary fell last year for the first time in 15 years, to $24,385 from $24,761 in 1992. Moreover, when adjusted for inflation, starting salaries have been falling since the late 1980's. For the first time, too, the best-paid graduates last year were nurses, who started at an average of $32,858. They displaced engineers, who started at $32,298.
Delaware's seniors, like their peers nationwide, have also made a sobering discovery: "Fortune 500 companies are not available anymore," Mr. Townsend said, because so many are still cutting jobs.
The biggest company around, Du Pont in nearby Wilmington, once drew Delaware's top chemistry and engineering graduates and assured them lifetime employment. But Du Pont has been reducing its work force, and for the first time in decades it did not send recruiters.
Instead, retail store chains -- Kmart, J. C. Penney, the Gap, Liz Claiborne, Macy's, Caldor, Lord & Taylor, Herman's, Lady Foot Locker -- had representatives here. They offer modest salaries, $20,000 to $25,000, and have some job requirements that colleges do not teach. The Gap's recruiting form for a supervisory job at a distribution center seeks a bachelor's degree and an "ability to lift 50 pounds consistently."
Joanne Galasso, 21, recently came to the placement offices for an interview with Caldor, the discount chain. Ms. Galasso, a psychology major with a 3.4 grade-point average, was all business. Tall, trim, earnest-looking in tortoise-rimmed glasses, she had donned the uniform of the interviewee -- navy blue double-breasted suit, collarless white blouse and black, low-heeled shoes.
She started looking for work in January, hoping to use her psychology major to begin a career as a therapist. She found nothing. "I had realistic expectations about salaries," Ms. Galasso said. "But I was shocked that there's really not much there. I think a lot of us are accepting the fact of take what you can get."
In one respect, Mr. Townsend said, job opportunities have improved markedly in recent years. Employers seem to be adhering to equal opportunity laws, he said, noting that women and minority groups no longer complained of discrimination.
A 21-year-old psychology major, Chandra Stewart, who is black, is also expecting to take uninspiring work at a modest salary while saving for graduate school. Her goal is a job that pays about $25,000.
"Race is such a big issue," said Ms. Stewart, whose work experience includes an internship at the Social Security Administration. "It might even be to my advantage. People are consciously trying to get more minorities into their businesses."
 
A Decline in Opportunities
 In other respects, the changes in the job market seem permanent.
Vernicka Tyson, acting director of Career Development Placement Services at Michigan State University, which monitors job placement trends nationwide, said the changes seemed structural and thus unlikely to change as the economy improves. More employers are hiring now than last year, she said, but large companies that once planned recruiting visits three years in advance and hired thousands of graduates yearly now show up on a few weeks' notice.
Employers say today's hotly competitive job market demands that they be ready to respond to changes in their business and be cautious about hiring. Steve Marts, a recruiter from Caldor, said: "There's a lot of applicants to talk to. But to find quality ones to fold into an organization, that's a very selective process."
As a result, companies are increasingly offering contingent jobs -- part-time and temporary jobs or contract work under which a company takes on a candidate for a specific task for up to a year. That buys them more time to size up workers before offering full-time jobs.
Mr. Townsend said potential employers try to assuage students' fears of dismissal by assuring them that earlier layoffs have opened opportunities for them. But he said the students do not believe it because employers' recruiters seem fickle. Some companies interview students, flatter them with additional interviews, then write letters saying they are sorry but they do not have the job for which they were interviewing.
Students have devised defensive strategies of their own. They routinely agree to take jobs and renege when a better offer comes along. "If they're so willing to cut you, and something better comes along, why shouldn't you take it?" said Daniel Mumm, 23, who has accepted a $35,000-a-year job designing and maintaining computer systems.
Still, Mr. Mumm said he was ready to accept a hoped-for offer from a leading New York bank. "That's the one I really want," he said. "A lot of students are unaccepting one job to accept another. It seems the companies almost expect it."
 
Work and Grades Bring Jobs
 Success comes most quickly for students who have had the stamina to mix the toils of scholarship and real jobs. With three courses to complete until he graduates in September, Nino Toscano, 24, has just been promoted to senior analyst at a financial services company where he has worked for two years. His salary of about $40,000 puts him in the top rank of his class.
"All through college I've worked full time," said Mr. Toscano, an economics major. "The important thing is the work experience you accumulate in school. I know a lot of people who are smarter than me, but they're still looking for jobs."
Wendy Caputo, 20, a computer sciences major with a 3.5 grade-point average, sped through college in three years. Each summer, while taking courses, she worked as an intern at Giant Foods, a supermarket chain, in its operating systems department. She has accepted a job with a computer consulting company in Rockville, Md., starting at $29,000 a year.
David J. DiGiacoma, who was here recruiting accountants for a small company near Wilmington, said: "They don't need a work history, but in this market it's a good thing. The university has a lot of accounting majors with good grades. So how do you differentiate them? It has to be a factor."
Another recruiter, Joseph Puckett of Hermann's, the sporting goods chain, looks for recruits with work experience and a knack for making customers happy. "A while back," Mr. Puckett said, "it was, 'Give us the ones with the best grades, the best record of achievement, the president of 15 things.' Those are still pluses. But if you don't have the desire to run the business the way we want to run it, pretty soon we're going to be unhappy."
In this market, however, even good work experience and a good attitude confer little job security.
Todd Krieger, 23, graduated cum laude last year with a degree in chemical engineering. He has a good job, paying $35,000 a year, with a design engineering concern. But he has witnessed a spate of layoffs and, fearing he will be next, has returned to the placement office library to plot a new search for work. "I'm trying to dive off the ship before they push me off," Mr. Krieger said.

HEADLINE: Residents of S.I. Neighborhood See Schism

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The Clifton section of Staten Island, where a 22-year-old man died after a struggle with the police on Friday night, is itself a kind of island -- an outpost of minority residents that cleaves more toward the tastes of Brooklyn or Manhattan than it does toward those of its neighbors only a mile away.
Unlike most of Staten Island, Clifton is predominantly black and Hispanic. Many residents moved there from places like Harlem, East New York and West Africa, often hoping that by crossing the Narrows waterway to the borough's northern shore they would find refuge from economic hardship or crime. But lately, some of those troubles seem to have followed. 
 In interviews yesterday, the people of the Park Hill Apartments, site of the fatal confrontation between Ernest Sayon and the police, described their neighborhood as largely alienated from the rest of Staten Island. One resident, Mohamed Baro, an immigrant from Guinea who drives a commuter van, said the isolation reminded him of the former tribal homelands set up under apartheid in South Africa.
"The blacks live with the blacks and the whites live with the whites," said Mr. Baro, 50, who was one of dozens of residents milling around the patch of sidewalk still stained by what residents identified as Mr. Sayon's blood. "Relations between the blacks and whites do not exist at all on Staten Island. The whites are scared to come here. When they do drive through this area, they roll their windows up."
 
A Neighborhood Changes
 Two decades ago, the Park Hill Apartments, which are privately owned but government subsidized, were integrated. But in recent years many whites have left for other parts of Staten Island or for New Jersey, often replaced by black and Hispanic people moving in from other boroughs.
But newcomers like Michelle Haneiph often discover that shopping and entertainment on Staten Island are oriented toward whites. So they take the nearby ferry to Manhattan or drive over the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to Brooklyn -- which is what Ms. Haneiph said she did when she could not find a theater on Staten Island showing the Spike Lee film "Jungle Fever."
"People over here are linked more to Brooklyn than to the rest of Staten Island," said Ms. Haneiph, 27, a switchboard operator. "You have the bridge right here and the $1 vans going right to Manhattan."
While residents expressed little hostility toward white Staten Islanders, they said they resented being stereotyped. Some said they avoided telling whites that they lived in the "Hill," because the complex has a reputation for drugs and prostitution. And others said that when they went to stores in the borough's white areas, they were often watched closely.
"Don't get me wrong, I like Staten Island, but when I spend money, I don't like people to think that I am a potential criminal," said Anne Darius, 31, who works for the New York City Law Department. "When you live in the hill, you are immediately thought of as using drugs or being on welfare."
The schism on Staten Island is also reflected in Park Hill residents' views of the police. Some said they welcomed officers because they would do anything to rid their streets of increasingly aggressive drug dealers. Others said they saw the police as an occupying force charged with making sure the ills of Clifton do not spill over into white neighborhoods.
"Police officers would rather have us here than in the white sections," said Tislam Thompson, 13, who was watching as a friend of Mr. Sayon painted a memorial for him -- a red, yellow and green flag -- on a tree next to the spot where he struggled with the police.
But others said the community generally appreciated the police, maintaining that the only people criticizing officers' tactics were those selling drugs.
"Relations are only bad with the dealers," said a 50-year-old woman who gave her name as Dolores. "They just want to be able to stand out here and deal. The rest of the people are sick and tired of the drug dealers. Most of the people support the police and so do I. I don't know what happened to that boy last night, but I'm guessing that it was drug related."

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
In the Northeast, Even Smog Is Trapped in Gridlock

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
The urban summer smog that chokes asthmatics and confines the elderly to air-conditioned rooms will be gone by early in the next century -- or so Congress decreed in 1990.
But with the 12 states of the Northeast facing a cleanup bill that could run to tens of billions of dollars and with the deadline for explaining who will pay just months away, the diverse interests that influence air-pollution policies have not advanced much further than pointing fingers. 
 "It's almost like the Palestinian-Israeli talks," said David Hawkins, a senior lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private environmental group. "Nobody wants to be the first to compromise."
Failure to break this deadlock over enforcement of the Clean Air Act, business executives say, could be as threatening to the region's economic health as smog is to the public's health. "If air quality is not improved in a cost-effective way," said Bill Tell, an executive in charge of regulatory affairs at Texaco, "you are going to see an exodus of jobs" from the region.
 
Hearings on Tap This Week
 That is why both big business and environmental hard-liners (as well as the state officials caught in between) are pinning their hopes on a little constructive head-bashing by Washington. And with Environmental Protection Agency holding hearings in Hartford this week, there is good reason to hope that the agency will broker a deal.
Almost certainly, that deal will include a free market for trading emission rights among polluters and a system for easing compliance costs of coal-fired power plants.
The active ingredient in smog is ozone. And ozone is created near the ground by a host of reactions involving ultraviolet light, heat, nitrogen compounds and volatile organic compounds that include anything from raw gasoline to tree sap.
Until recently, efforts to contain ozone focused on cutting organic compounds from tailpipes, smokestacks and ventilators. But scientists now say that nitrogen compounds are a critical player in transforming life-sustaining oxygen into lung-searing ozone. Indeed, John Bachman of the Environmental Protection Agency says that in much of the Northeast cutting nitrogen compounds would be far more effective in reducing smog than further cuts in volatile organic compounds.
Spicing the recipe for conflict, there is now good evidence that both ozone and its chemical precursors travel long distances. Hence, compounds blown in from western Pennsylvania can combine with locally made ingredients to transform New York or Boston into smog central.
 
New Enthusiasms
 This explains the new enthusiasm for controlling nitrogen compounds from coal-burning power plants. It also explains why Congress created the Ozone Transport Commission, made up of representatives of 12 Northeastern states plus the District of Columbia who have the mandate to figure out strategies for controlling regionwide smog sources.
Some important anti-smog measures are already dictated by Federal law, and are thus uncomplicated by the push and shove of regional interests. For example, the region will benefit from tougher emissions standards to be applied to new cars nationwide.
But Eric Svenson of New Jersey's giant utility, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, argues that such measures "alone won't even come close" to helping the states meet ozone standards during the dog days of summer. That leaves it to the states to explain how they are going to reduce volatile organic compounds emissions 15 percent by 1996, plus cut both organic and nitrogen compounds by 3 percent annually.
The members of the Ozone Transport Commission made headlines in February by asking the Environmental Protection Agency to impose on the Northeast the same exceptionally stringent standards on new autos that will be required in smog-burdened California. But Delaware, New Hampshire, New Jersey and Virginia demurred, because of worries about the cost. And the American automobile industry is fighting back, offering to produce a vehicle that would be cleaner sooner, but would not meet the California standard.
Hardly anyone is claiming that the California vehicle standards alone would get the Northeast where it must go. Then what? Targeting nitrogen compounds, with heavy emphasis on power plants, which produce about half of the region's emissions. But the states are bitterly divided on how to proceed, and no wonder.
 
Smog in the Corridor
 The worst smog in the region is along the "Amtrak corridor" from Washington to Boston. But the bulk of the nitrogen compounds, notes John Elston, New Jersey's official in charge of air quality, comes from plants far to the west. And such areas have little motivation to pitch in because little of the benefit would go to their own ratepayers.
Adding sand to the wheels of negotiation, there is still much debate over allowing smog producers to pay rather than to play. A free market trading system already gives power plants broad discretion in controlling emissions that generate acid rain. A dirty plant can buy pollution rights from a clean plant, for example.
The Environmental Defense Fund, an advocacy group, has suggested that it would be cheaper to achieve the goals of the California car standards by creating a similar trading system for nitrogen and organic compounds, letting auto makers buy equivalent abatement from stationary sources like power plants or a dry-cleaning store or to buy and junk especially dirty vehicles. Indeed, some experts argue that opposition to the Ozone Transport Commission's proposal for car standards would evaporate if it were amended to include a trading system.
William Rosenberg, a former assistant administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, says that trading nitrogen compound rights among stationary sources is also critical to containing costs and softening opposition from coal-fired utilities. To comply, he reckons, most utilities would have to do little more than shift to natural gas in the summer -- or pay other plants to make the shift.
But the devil is in the details. Acid rain cumulatively damages lakes and soil over vast areas. A straightforward trading system for smog precursors, it is widely acknowledged, would be more problematic because ozone damage varies widely according to season, air temperature and wind patterns.
Daniel Dudek of the Environmental Defense Fund acknowledges that trading does not fit into an ozone solution as neatly as it did to acid rain, and many environmental groups question whether such trading will ever lead to cleaner air. But Mr. Dudek says the benefits of cutting compliance costs would far outweigh the risks of creating financial incentives to reduce emissions at the wrong place or time. Denying the legitimacy of market-based trading at this stage, he says, would only show that "we haven't learned anything since 1989," when trading rights were proposed for acid rain.
This brew of conflict and scientific uncertainty seems a recipe for political gridlock. But a solution is in the works.
For one thing, the penalties for states that fail to present serious plans by the deadline in November represent an incentive to compromise. While state officials might welcome a Federal takeover of the cleanup, they would not relish the consequences. Once the deadline is missed, a sanction clock starts ticking that would lead to a cutoff of highway funds and a moratorium on business growth within two years.
Some participants in the debate have sketched the outlines of a deal. One element would be the California tailpipe standard, softened by allowing auto makers to buy emissions rights from other sources. Mr. Dudek calculates that trading under these conditions would save the auto industry $5 billion from 1996 to 2004.
Another element would limit power plants' emissions of nitrogen compounds but let the plants trade emissions upwind. Thus a New Jersey utility could buy emissions rights from a plant in Pennsylvania, but not vice versa. The deal would be sweetened for Pennsylvania by setting exceptionally tough emissions standards for power producers along the Amtrak corridor, in effect requiring the east to subsidize nitrogen compound reduction in the west.

HEADLINE: Mood Swing Hits Tokyo

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 30

 BODY:
When Morihiro Hosokawa took office last summer promising to clean up rampant political corruption and open up the minutely regulated economy, he was greeted with almost giddy optimism. Nobody expected change overnight, but just placing it on the agenda after 39 years of one-party rule gave Mr. Hosokawa the highest approval ratings of any Prime Minister in the postwar era.
On Monday a close ally of Mr. Hosokawa's, Tsutomu Hata, became Prime Minister and pledged to continue the reforms, but the mood this time is a mixture of wary hopefulness and cynicism. 
 The realization that change can also mean instability has left the Japanese far more sober-minded about what lies ahead in the remarkable reform effort they have begun.
 
On a Knife's Edge
 The coming week is a holiday period known as Golden Week, and it will give Mr. Hata and his Cabinet some respite after the open bitterness of the succession battle. But once parliamentary business resumes, one fact is likely to dominate public perceptions and the political maneuvering: Mr. Hata is head of a minority Government that can be brought down any time the opposition chooses.
In short, his conservative Government will be operating on a knife's edge. The news media here have already declared that its lifespan may be measured in weeks, which means that the prospect of its producing strong policies on several pressing crises -- ending the recession, changing the tax structure and reducing the yawning trade surplus -- are slim.
"It is impossible to expect anything from the minority Hata Cabinet on big policy issues," Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's most respected daily business newspaper, said in an editorial. It added that a new election was likely, and soon.
That means Mr. Hata is unlikely to have the support to negotiate a broad trade agreement with the United States soon, despite his stated intention of opening the economy in ways that Washington has demanded.
That prospect is one reason the value of the yen soared against the dollar in New York on Friday, some traders said. Despite occasional assertions to the contrary, the Clinton Administration is believed to favor a strong yen as a weapon for attacking Japan's trade surplus. A strong yen makes exports more expensive in foreign markets, and boosts imports by reducing their cost to Japanese.
 
Traders Push Yen Higher
 So when trade frictions and the surplus grow, traders tend to push the yen higher, as they did on Friday.
Today Japan's largest-circulation newspaper, Yomiuri Shimbun, ran the results of an opinion poll capturing the ambiguous public mood. A surprisingly strong 56.8 percent of those polled said they supported the new minority Government, compared with 71.9 percent approval when Mr. Hosokawa took office.
But the public responded negatively to the way in which Mr. Hata had forged his six-party coalition Government. When the conservative parties in the coalition sought to band together and overpower the Socialists, the Socialists quit in anger. That left Mr. Hata with his minority Government.
In the Yomiuri poll, 57 percent said they thought Mr. Hata's methods for forming his coalition were "forcible." The feeling, even among some of those who disagree with the Socialists' policies, was that Mr. Hata's raw power play against the Socialists violated the old political rules.
As members of Mr. Hosokawa's Government, the Socialists proved unreliable partners. Some fought against bills reforming the electoral and campaign financing systems. But the public seems to have found them a buffer against the more rightward-leaning policies of Mr. Hata's core supporters.
 
Cabinet More Conservative
 Indeed, Mr. Hata's Cabinet is considerably more conservative than Mr. Hosokawa's, and even more conservative than some of the previous Liberal Democratic Governments.
For instance, for the first time in the postwar era, the Cabinet includes a retired general. Shigeto Nagano, 71, the Justice Minister, was the highest officer in the Ground Self-Defense Force, as the Japanese Army is known, before retiring and winning a seat in Parliament in the 1980's.
The Foreign Minister is Koji Kakizawa, 60, an articulate former Finance Ministry bureaucrat who has argued that Japan should end its postwar pacifism and allow its military to be used abroad in peacekeeping missions. That independent stance is anathema to Japan's leftists, and even to many older Liberal Democrats who remember World War II and distrust the ability of civilians to control the military.
"In international affairs we have to be open to collective security arrangements, to have shared responsibility in our security affairs," Mr. Kakizawa said in an interview. "I don't just mean financial responsibility, but shared risk-taking in maintaining the security of this region."
Ultimately, the question is whether the Government will last long enough for its security policies to be tested. Its first task will be to pass a long-delayed budget for the fiscal year that began on April 1. After that, the Government's existence could grow more precarious by the day.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says It Is Pleased Syrians Are Acting to Limit Terrorism

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, April 30

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher told Syrian officials today that the United States was pleased that Damascus has taken steps recently to curb terrorism, among them closing two training camps run by Abu Nidal, the prominent terrorist leader.
Mr. Christopher met late into the night with President Hafez al-Assad and other Syrian officials to discuss a new Israeli peace plan. In an earlier session with Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa, he said Damascus had made some progress on terrorism at a time when Syria hopes to be removed from Washington's list of countries that sponsor terrorism. 
 American and Israeli officials acknowledge that as Mr. Assad moves cautiously forward in peace talks with Israel, he is maneuvering for a big reward: improved political and economic ties with the United States. But American officials caution that this cannot happen until Syria is removed from both the terrorism list and the list of countries that do too little to fight drug trafficking.
 
Concern Over Arms Deal
 Mr. Christopher also told Mr. Sharaa of American concerns about a recent arms deal signed by Syria and Russia and about reports that a ring of counterfeiters based in Syria was producing high-quality $100 bills.
The Secretary of State flew from Israel to Damascus today to present a new Israeli peace plan to Mr. Assad in the hope that it would end the deadlock in peace talks between the two countries.
Israeli officials said the plan called for Israel to make a phased withdrawal from the Golan Heights, which it captured in 1967 and annexed in 1981. In return, Syria would grant full diplomatic relations to Israel and sign a peace accord. The plan also proposes demilitarizing the Golan Heights and establishing a multinational peace force to patrol the area.
State Department officials say Mr. Christopher may meet again with President Assad on Sunday, after Syrian officials study the Israeli plan. Later on Sunday, Mr. Christopher is scheduled to return to Israel to tell Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin about Mr. Assad's response.
Before Mr. Christopher met with President Assad, an Administration official said the Secretary of State would convey Washington's concerns about Syria's human rights performance and would seek to arrange a visit to Syria by a high-level American human rights official.
In Mr. Christopher's meetings on Friday with Israeli officials, the Israelis agreed with him that Syria had made some recent progress in combating terrorism, American officials said. Syria, which exercises considerable sway over Lebanon, recently shut down an camp run by Abu Nidal's organization, Fatah Revolutionary Council, near Beirut and another camp in the Bekaa region of Lebanon.
 
Party of God Detentions
 State Department officials said they found it encouraging that Syria had several leaders of the Iranian-backed Party of God arrested after they led a recent demonstration in southern Lebanon. Although the members of the group, which American officials say has carried out numerous assassinations and hostage-takings, were released, American officials said the arrests could be an important sign that Syria is trying to crack down on the Party of God.
But some Administration officials have said recently that the State Department, in its eagerness to push peace negotiations forward, might be too willing to recognize Syrian progress on terrorism.
State Department officials say it is too early to tell whether Syria will be removed from the list of countries that sponsor terrorism.
Mr. Christopher told Foreign Minister Sharaa of Washington's concerns that Damascus had not stopped the drug trade from flourishing in the Bekaa. American officials say Syria has eliminated some of the poppy cultivation in the region but has not done enough to stop the production and transshipment of drugs.
Regarding the deal on arms sales signed last week between Syria and Russia, American officials said Mr. Christopher would ask the Syrians what weapons systems would be sold.
"We're concerned that the memorandum of understanding they signed might call for some technology transfers from Russia," an Administration official said.

HEADLINE: Majority of Americans Say Cigarettes Spur Addiction

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

 BODY:
An overwhelming majority of Americans say that cigarettes are addictive and that tobacco companies do not tell the whole truth in acknowledging the health risks of smoking, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows.
The results indicated strong sentiments against smoking and tobacco companies at a time when cigarette company executives are defending themselves in Congress against charges that they are manipulating the levels of nicotine in cigarettes and have suppressed research showing the addictive effects of smoking. 
 Noteworthy in the survey was that smokers, about a quarter of the respondents, were nearly as critical of the tobacco industry as non-smokers. A substantial number of smokers -- 39 percent -- favored a ban on smoking in public places.
"I think they're lying to gain money, and I say that with all the conviction I can," Rita O'Brien, a 38-year-old kindergarten teacher in Philadelphia and a nonsmoker, said in a follow-up interview of tobacco company assertions that cigarettes are not addictive. She said that her husband had failed in his most recent attempt to quit smoking and that he now smokes more than ever, up to three packs of cigarettes a day.
"Since he started smoking again," she said, "he feels the same way I do."
The telephone survey of 1,215 adults was conducted April 21-23. The margin of sampling error is plus or minus three percentage points.
 
A Growing Antipathy
 The anti-smoking sentiments expressed in the survey reflected a growing antipathy against smoking in everyday life, as smokers face an increasing number of restrictions on where and when they can smoke. Two-thirds of those responding to the poll favored a smoking ban in all public places, compared with the 61 percent who expressed a similar opinion in a November 1991 poll by the Gallup Organization. And 42 percent said they favored legislation that would ban smoking altogether, compared with 34 percent who answered the same way in a January 1992 Harris poll.
"Most smokers would like to quit," said Susie Agerton, a 36-year-old writer from Meadville, Ala., who has been smoking a pack of cigarettes a day for 10 years. "But we've got to quit passing this on from generation to generation to generation. The buck has to stop with us so that maybe it will stop our children from smoking."
Among the issues facing the tobacco industry, the question of cigarette addiction through nicotine is attracting enormous attention. Dr. David A. Kessler, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, suggested earlier this year that cigarettes should be regulated like a drug because of nicotine. A House subcommittee is studying the issue.
On Thursday, two former scientists for Philip Morris, the country's largest cigarette maker, told the committee that the company suppressed research in which scientists found evidence of a substance in cigarettes that increases the addictive power of nicotine.
 
Beliefs on Addictiveness
 While the tobacco industry has steadfastly maintained that nicotine is not addictive, 91 percent of those surveyed said they believed that cigarettes are addictive. Among those with that view were 87 percent of those who said they smoke, 91 percent of those who said they used to smoke and 93 percent of those who said they never smoked.
Sam Deniso, a 65-year-old retired construction worker in Malden, Mass., and one of the smokers in the survey, said that he strongly believed that cigarettes are addictive. He cited his own experience as the reason.
A smoker for 50 years, who said he smoked three packs on the days he played poker and no more than two on other days, said in a follow-up interview that he had tried to quit "about 100 times" and succeeded eight times in the last 10 years. Now, he said, he is down to three or four cigarettes a day in an attempt to stop again.
"Sure, they're addictive," he said in an interview, adding that if the tobacco companies contend they are not, "That's a whole bunch of lies, as far as I'm concerned."
He also said that he believed companies added nicotine to maintain addiction.
 
A Role in Cancer?
 Another smoker, John Hampston, a 52-year-old former railroad worker in Duluth, Minn., said he has been smoking for 35 years, now down to one pack a day from four. After 29 cancer operations with the next one scheduled for late May, he said he feels as if he has been addicted to cigarettes for the last 15 years.
Asked if he felt smoking played some role in his illnesses, he bristled: "Not some role. All the role."
Sixty-one percent said they thought that tobacco companies encourage teen-agers to smoke.
Asked if they thought tobacco companies deliberately make cigarettes more addictive than they would be otherwise, 43 percent said they did while 30 percent disagreed. Nearly half the people who never smoked, 48 percent, were more inclined to think the companies manipulated their products, as against 41 percent of those who quit and 36 percent of current smokers.
Eight of 10 people polled, 84 percent, expressed skepticism over tobacco companies' truthfulness in talking about the health risks associated with smoking cigarettes. While health groups have long contended that smoking causes lung cancer, emphysema and other diseases, industry officials have only acknowledged a "link" between smoking and some illnesses.
Only 11 percent of those polled said they felt the companies told the entire truth about the health issues. Forty-five percent said they felt they were mostly truthful but were hiding something and 38 percent said the companies were mostly lying.
Among smokers, 77 percent said the companies were not completely truthful; 90 percent, among former smokers; and 84 percent, among those who never smoked.
More than 6 of 10 people felt that the tobacco companies encouraged teen-agers to smoke, a finding that belies another standard industry assertion. Tobacco executives, including those from R. J. Reynolds, which developed the Joe Camel cartoon character, steadfastly insist that young people are not targets of any marketing campaign.
But among smokers, only 46 percent felt that teen-agers were being targeted, compared with 67 percent among former smokers and those who never smoked.
The survey also revealed that smokers tended to make less money and have less education than nonsmokers. In the lowest economic group, people earning under $15,000 a year, 32 percent of the respondents said they smoked. Among those with annual incomes above $75,000, only 19 percent said they smoked. Among college graduates, 12 percent were smokers. Among those with no more than a high school education, 30 percent smoked.

HEADLINE: Exxon Trial On Oil Spill Starts Monday

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE, April 30

 BODY:
Five years after the Exxon Valdez oil spill off the Alaska coast, 10,000 fishermen, property owners and Alaskan natives will soon have a chance to argue their case against the Exxon Corporation.
In the civil trial, opening on Monday in Federal District Court here, the plaintiffs will seek to prove that the pollution damaged their culture and livelihoods. 
 Exxon, the world's largest corporation, refused to comment.
Brian O'Neill, the plaintiffs' lead lawyer, says the proceedings will captivate even people with no monetary interest because the history of the spill provides a cautionary tale of environmental disaster.
"If something's not done, it will happen in your backyard next," Mr. O'Neill said. "This is corporate indifference and arrogance at its worst."
This is the first civil trial resulting from the accident on March 24, 1989, when the tanker strayed from shipping lanes, ran aground on a charted reef and spilled almost 11 million gallons of North Slope crude into Prince William Sound.
Exxon has already paid substantial fines and cleanup fees. In 1990, accused of Federal environmental crimes, the company agreed to pay $100 million in restitution and $150 million in fines.
The next year, it paid $900 million to settle state and Federal civil claims over environmental damage.
The company has also spent an estimated $2 billion to clean beaches and inlets in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska and to restore the habitat for wildlife.
 
Money Can't Fix Harm
 The oil killed half a million birds outright and tainted an estimated 1,500 miles of coastline. Today, scientists still worry that oil trapped under hard-shell mussel beds will slowly leak and cause long-term chronic pollution.
"Money can't really correct all the harm done," said John Havelock, a former Alaska Attorney General who directed a state commission formed to examine the spill. "I guess you could say the trial will show that a million dollars in prevention would be better than a billion dollars in court fines.".
In the four-phase trial before Judge H. Russel Holland, jurors will decide any liability on Exxon's part, then separately determine any punitive or compensatory damages owed; the plaintiffs have asked for about $1.5 billion in compensation. A fourth phase will resolve miscellaneous claims, like those from miners claiming damage from the oil.
Lawyers on both sides predict the trial will last all summer and say it is the most complicated of its kind ever to be tried in the state.
Almost 600 witnesses are scheduled in a case that has amassed 2,000 depositions and five million pages of documents. Lawyers planned to manage the paperwork with an in-court computer that will retrieve evidence and automatically display it for the jury.
 
Suit by Mayors
 A second civil trial begins on June 6 in state Superior Court and involves seven towns whose mayors say they lost municipal services diverted to the spill. Other state plaintiffs include 13 corporation owned by Alaskan natives, which have claimed damage to lands and archaeological sites.
In pretrial motions, Judge Holland rejected Exxon's request to withhold financial data, including its total wealth, from jurors in the punitive damages stage. He also barred Alaskan natives from collecting for damage to their culture and way of life. They may, however, still sue for economic damage, like the loss of fish, wild game and plants that make up their traditional diet.
Exxon spokesmen declined to comment on the trial in two telephone interviews in the last two weeks, but a company lawyer has said Exxon's trial strategy will be to concentrate on marine science, fish abundance and whether there are any lingering effects from the accident.
Mr. O'Neill said the plaintiffs will focus on Exxon's employment of Joseph Hazelwood, who was tried and acquitted in state court in 1990 for operating a vessel while drunk. Mr. Hazelwood has appealed a misdemeanor conviction for negligently discharging oil.
 
Accusations About Drinking
 The 1990 Federal indictment filed against Exxon but never brought before a jury asserted that Exxon lawyers had heard accusations of drinking against Mr. Hazelwood 19 months before the accident.
Jurors will hear from the former captain in a plaintiffs' videotape lasting more than three hours.
"This is a big, powerful company that didn't care enough about its employee -- or the public -- to do anything about the employee's personal problems," Mr. O'Neill said of Exxon and its captain.

HEADLINE: I.R.S. Can't Explain a Slowdown in Tax Filing

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Tax returns have been coming in more slowly so far this year, but the Internal Revenue Service does not know why.
Through April 22, the agency received 103.6 million returns, down from 104.1 million through the comparable date a year earlier, the I.R.S. said on Friday. The number of requests for extensions filed dropped to 2.6 million from 3.6 million. 
 At the beginning of this year, the I.R.S. was expecting 117.5 million returns by year's end. It has scaled back the projection to 114.9 million and is considering reducing the projection again, said a spokesman, Frank Keith. Last year, 113.8 million returns were received.
Mr. Keith said officials believed that about 800,000 of the decline could be attributed to the agency's efforts to inform people who have been filing unnecessarily. The agency has also noticed fewer returns reporting only interest income, because declining interest rates have pushed some of those taxpayers below the filing threshold, he said.
But the General Accounting Office wants the I.R.S. to make sure the declining number of returns is not a reflection of a lapse in compliance.
"There is that concern," said David J. Attianese, the accounting office's assistant director for tax policy and administration. "If you go by the trends of the last several years, they should have had an increase, but they didn't. I think it's significant, but we're still trying to figure out why it's happening."
The decline in returns comes during an I.R.S. campaign to close the gap between what taxpayers actually pay and what they are supposed to pay. The compliance rate is about 80 percent, the agency estimates. Its goal is to push the rate to 90 percent by the year 2000.
Despite the overall decline in returns filed this year, the number of paperless returns continues to increase. The I.R.S. said 13.4 million returns were filed electronically by tax preparation services, up from 12.3 million last year.
 
Telephone Returns Are Up
 It said 519,000 returns were filed by telephone in the seven states where taxpayers could use that method, up from 149,000 last year, when only Ohio residents were eligible. The agency plans to announce its telephone filing plans for next year this summer.
By April 22, the I.R.S. had sent out 56 million refunds, down from 56.4 million last year. Refunds averaged $1,026 each, up from $979 last year.

HEADLINE: Mayor's Severance Plan Is Affecting Many of System's Younger Workers

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Faced with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's program offering severance payments, thousands of municipal workers have been considering whether to leave their jobs and take the lump-sum payments. Some made the decision easily, while others say they agonized over what to do.
Under the severance program, aimed at helping to close a $2.3 billion budget gap in the next fiscal year, workers who agree to give up their jobs can receive $3,500 to $15,000 based on length of service. On Friday the Mayor extended the deadline to the middle of next week in hopes of reaching the target of 7,600 workers; about 7,000 had taken the offer already. 
 Many who have decided to take the severance payment are only in their 20's or 30's and are now casting about for a new career -- some eagerly, some with regret.
 
Chilled by the Freeze

Marianne Paciulli has worked in the Department of City Planning's environmental assessment review division for five years. Ms. Paciulli, who is 32 years old and lives with her husband in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, said the decision to leave grew out of increasing dissatisfaction with her job.
"Unfortunately, my timing with the job was all wrong," she said. "When I came to the job there was a hiring freeze and so, at every turn, I was squashed in my efforts to get a raise or a promotion. After a while it got frustrating to be stuck in a situation I wasn't happy with."
When the Giuliani administration announced its severance plan, "I wasn't too keen on the idea," she said. "But then I realized that I wouldn't get too far in city government and that this fiscal problem is not going to be cleared up any time in the next year or so."
Nonetheless, she said, the decision to leave was not particularly easy. "It took a week to make the decision. It is a big step to walk away from a job without having another one." But she reasoned that with her husband in a secure position with the city, she had nothing to lose. "I'm debt free, and I get $7,500 that I can play with or use for school if I decide to go back to school. Besides, summer is a good time to be unemployed."
She wants to work with a nonprofit organization "to help people who are struggling with AIDS," she said. "It seemed like the time to make a change in my life. I figured, why not take the money and run?"
 
Wouldn't Risk Layoff
Peter A. Valiente, who performs environmental reviews for the city's planning department, said that when he heard that Mayor Giuliani might resort to layoffs to eliminate the $2.3 billion deficit in the next fiscal year, he wondered what it meant for him. "My boss called us in and told us to prepare for the worst," he said.
He read and heard about the severance package, "but no one could assure me that I wouldn't be on the list of people to be laid off," he said. "So, after agonizing, I decided that it would be better to take the money than to risk being laid off."
Mr. Valiente, who is 29 years old, lives in Chelsea and has worked for the city for 18 months, after leaving an engineering job in New Jersey. He said he will now "seriously upgrade my computer skills and take courses on data-base management. I want to add to my skills and make myself more marketable."
While he said he relishes the opportunity to use his $7,500 to take courses and seek new employment, he maintains some bitterness toward the city's severance program. "It seems to me, just from talking to other city workers I know, that the city is losing a lot of young people who are still enthusiastic about their jobs," he said.
"I would have liked to have done this job for a couple more years because I have enjoyed it. But mostly, I'm disappointed."
 
Moving to New Zone
 Gay M. Pinto has worked as a procurement manager for the Parks Department for more than 10 years. "I have loved my time with the city and I have made some good friends here," he said. "It was a tough decision for me, but I looked at it as an opportunity to do something I've always wanted to do."
Mr. Pinto, who is 40 and married, lives in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx and has lived in various parts of the city since moving from Trinidad as a child. He said he, his wife and their 2-year-old son would move to Florida "so that we can visit family, I can begin looking or a job and we can make the transition from being New Yorkers."
Mr. Pinto said that despite recent cuts to the budget of the Parks Department and a reduction in the agency's work force, he was not concerned about being laid off. "I have been here for 10 years and felt that my job was pretty secure," he said. "But I guess I took the severance package as a sign that, for me, it was time to move on. Things are changing in this city. Things haven't gotten any better and it doesn't seem like they will any time soon."
He has no idea, he said, what sort of work he will seek and acknowledges that he has concerned about the prospects for a 40-year-old man looking for work. "I plan to look for something in the same field, but I don't know what kind of work I'll be able to find there. But I feel it was something I had to do. No matter what happens, I won't look back."
 
'Incredibly Difficult'
 Laura Ruttenberg contends that he decision to take the severance package was one of the most difficult questions she has faced. For her, it represented a choice between an interesting job with questionable career advancement or taking time to make decisions about what she wanted to pursue for the remainder of her professional life.
"It was an incredibly difficult decision for me," said Ms. Ruttenberg, who is 27 and director of community relations for the Parks Department for Manhattan. "It was wrenching."
"It has been a great job, with interesting people and interesting aspects to the job," she said. "But I knew, because of the budget problems and the cutbacks, there was no next step at the Parks Department for me. I began to feel that I was at a dead end, professionally. But I didn't know what my next move should have been."
Ms. Ruttenberg, who has been with the parks system for more than three years, after graduating from Barnard College, said she viewed the severance package as a chance to compel herself to come up with a career strategy. "It's kind of like sky diving and having to push yourself out of the plane. I want to go into the special events and fund-raising area. I'm going to take some classes in conference planning, but I'm not certain what direction I'm going to go in."
She said the $7,500 payment from the severance package will enable her to pay rent for six months. "It was a tough decision. But I feel that I now have an opportunity to find out exactly what I want to do with my career. This is a golden opportunity that doesn't come along too often."
 
Heart in San Francisco

Sean L. Spear said he fell in love with the San Francisco Bay area some years ago and has since harbored the dream of living there. Now, Mr. Spear, a 27-year-old planner who lives and works in Brooklyn, will fulfill that dream.
"I will settle my affairs here in New York and then I will move to there and look for work," he said. "If I had a wife and kids I might have made a different decision because it's not easy to walk away from a job. But I've always wanted to expand my horizons, live somewhere else and have a new kind of life."
The decision to take the severance package was difficult, he said. "I have not been unhappy with my job. New York is my home town, I have a lot of friends here and ties to the city." Mr. Spear started working for the city immediately after graduating from Cornell University. "I thought that, after five years at the job, it was time to move up and I was torn about leaving because of the potential for promotion. But I figured that I am at an age in my life where I can find another job."
He said he plans to continue working in municipal planning. He, too, will receive $7,500 from the severance package. "I hope to save as much of that as I can. Hopefully, it won't take too long for me to find another job."
 
Fantastic Timing
 Paige Van Wirt, a Housing Department project manager in Brooklyn, received a job offer from Moody's Investors Service on the same day the Giuliani Administration announced the severance offer. That enabled her to receive a $7,500 payment and walk into her next job.
"It was a stroke of luck for me," she said. Still, she admitted, taking advantage of the severance offer was not an idea she embraced immediately. "It wasn't easy because I really enjoyed what I was doing," said Ms. Van Wirt, who is single and 26 years old. As a project manager, she supervised the development of housing initiatives in five areas of Brooklyn.
"It's a big decision to walk away from something you love doing. But I mulled it over and I took the severance package to be a nudge. It seemed to tell me that it was time to move into a new career path." In the meantime, she said, she must stay on for another three weeks to qualify for the severance package. "I have some vacation time coming," she said. "So I will use my vacation time to qualify for the severance, and start at my new job in that time period. Things have worked out kind of perfectly for me."

HEADLINE: SOCCER: WORLD CUP '94;
A Controversial World Cup Coach Keeps Them All Guessing

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MILAN, Italy, April 29

 BODY:
Arrigo Sacchi? The man is crazy, his critics are howling. Fire him now before all of Italy is humiliated. Only 50 days until the World Cup and Sacchi has still not named his team. The man can't make up his mind. He is a juggler, not a coach. He has called up 73 players to the national team in two and half years. Seventy-three! Guerin Sportivo, a soccer magazine, once ran pictures of all 73 and threw in mug shots of Pope John Paul II, Robin Williams as Popeye and Sylvester Stallone as Rambo to illustrate Sacchi's indecisiveness.
"Arrigo, have you forgotten anyone?" the headline snorted. 
 A familiar soccer panic has gripped this country like a hand around the throat. The prevailing mood is glum, the national hysteria proclaiming that the Azzurri, the Blues, cannot win in the United States. Sacchi has become an emotional dartboard for frustrated fans and journalists, the target for relentless criticism. It was bad enough that Italy lost "friendly" matches this year to France and Germany. It was unforgivable that the Azzurri suffered a 2-1 defeat recently at the hands of Pontedera, a team in Italy's fourth division, a minnow among soccer whales.
Gazzetta dello Sport, the largest of Italy's three all-sports newspapers, screamed in a front-page headline: "Let's send Pontedera to the World Cup."
 
They Call Him 'Crazy'
 America Oggi, an Italian-language newspaper published in New Jersey, went further and called for Sacchi's firing. "Sacchi must go now before it's too late," the newspaper demanded. Attilio Giovannini, a member of the Italian teams at the 1950 and '54 World Cups, dismissed Sacchi's conscription of so many players and called him "crazy."
This is nothing out of the ordinary, saner voices remind. Italy felt the same dread in 1982 and won the World Cup. Worry is to be expected as a national indulgence. Not everyone can play soccer, but everyone can panic.
"It's pretty normal," said the Italian star, Roberto Baggio, the world player of the year in 1993. "So much is expected."
"A typical Italian overreaction," said Germany's Jurgen Klinsmann, who has played in the Italian League with Inter of Milan. "They are still one of the favorites."
 
A Dream Job
 It is said that everyone is a coach in Italy, but Arrigo Sacchi is the coach. As he sat in his small, tidy apartment on a quiet Milan street the other day, he appeared to be calm at the center of this storm. The son of a shoemaker, Sacchi is 48, balding gracefully, a Renaissance man among coaches, an avid reader of politics and economics and the fiction of Steinbeck and Faulkner, his conversation volleying comfortably between English and Italian. Always, he said, he works with music on. He is a "dreamer" who would impose his disciplined system of attacking offense and pressing zone defense on independent-minded players and an unconvinced public.
The criticism doesn't eat at him, said Sacchi, who took over the national team in October 1991. He was not a great player, and he has climbed from the lowliest division of Italian soccer in his 20 years of coaching, so "I am accustomed to suffering and criticism." This is not a hard job, it is a dream job, Sacchi said, one that pays $800,000 a year. "Utopia." With a straight face, he said he not only reads the sports newspapers, he learns from them.
So passionate are the Italians for soccer that three sports dailies provide saturation coverage and a Sunday night program called "The 90th Minute," which provides highlights of the day's games, is among the most popular shows on television. At the AC Milan-Monaco game on Wednesday, a semifinal in the European Champions Cup tournament, 80,000 fans packed San Siro Stadium here, cheering, singing, bouncing like human popcorn and setting off Roman candles and flairs smuggled inside loaves of bread, clothing, and oversized flags.
Soccer interest permeates a top level of government. The designated Prime Minister of Italy's 53d Government since World War II, Silvio Berlusconi, owns the AC Milan team along with a media empire, and has even appropriated a popular soccer chant, Forza Italia, as the name of his nascent political party. Naturally, the national team coach is always under a microscope.
 
Sacchi's System
 When fame becomes burdensome, Sacchi retreats to his home in tiny Fusignano, outside of Bologna, and goes for long, solitary rides in the country on a mountain bike. Several days ago, Sacchi came upon a farmer hacking at the earth with a hoe, and said the man told him, "I follow the football because you are the coach. I root for you. You can win the cup. But if you don't win, you've done enough anyway."
Of course, Sacchi knows, not everyone feels this way. Only victory in the World Cup will satisfy impatient fans and journalists. They want to know why it takes so long to name a team. The World Cup begins June 17 and he will not select the final 22-man squad until May 12. Why does he experiment with so many players?
"It's a lot easier to win with 80 players than 11," Sacchi says, jokingly, then says no, he must give a serious answer.
It is because he believes in a system "that grows out of the head, not from the feet," a system that demands humility, altruism and professionalism, a system that values the team over the individual. It is a struggle. Italy is a country of egotists, Sacchi said, where a man is taught to think for himself.
One of his players once told him, "When I move without the ball, the television doesn't show me."
If he can find 22 players to fit his system, the coach said, "It will be an Italian record."
When he coached at AC Milan, people also doubted his tactics, Sacchi said, but he won an Italian League title and two European Cups. Soccer in Italy continues to evolve from a style of conservative defense and counterattack, where the only thing that mattered was not losing, toward "total soccer," where Sacchi wants versatility -- counterattacking, attacking as a tactical weapon, the long-ball attack, everything. He not only wants to win, he wants to win with an entertaining show.
"I believe in attacking soccer, where you have to create and do a lot of things," Sacchi said. "But anytime you risk defeat, nobody wants to attack. They want to withdraw."
 
Planned Confusion
 So he juggles his attackers and deflects the criticism. Why did it take Sacchi so long to move to the front Giusseppe Signori of Lazio, who has 21 goals in 23 league games, instead of Pierluigi Casiraghi, who has found the net only three times? Where will Baggio play? People are clamoring to know. Forward or midfield? To keep people guessing is precisely the idea, Sacchi said. His methods are not indecisive, he said, but planned confusion.
"I hope to have a team where it is difficult to know who will be forward, who will be midfield or defender," Sacchi said. "If it is clear, Italy will not play well."
While controversy swirls with tornado force, Sacchi appears not to be buffeted. If they are calling him names, at least they are calling him something. When he first coached in the Italian top division, Sacchi said journalists called him Mr. Nobody.
That's all right, a friend told him. Life is a big cake and everyone wants to sit at the big, round table and have a piece. Everyone is pushing for a seat.
Not you, Arrigo, the friend said. You don't have to push. You already have a seat. You already have your cake.

HEADLINE: Unwarranted Criticism of Japan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I must take issue with several points in your coverage of the Japanese bureaucracy. First, the caption with the photograph of Masamichi Kono distorts what is stated in the text -- that Mr. Kono and fellow bureaucrats did not inform bankers in advance about "an initiative for helping the banks write off bad loans to finance companies." The fact that Japanese bureaucrats are secretive about their intentions does not distinguish them from bureaucrats elsewhere. The caption twisted Mr. Kono's not advising the banks of his agency's intentions to imply that he "knows more about the bank crisis than the bankers." Does every bureaucracy that is secretive about its intentions know more about the industry it regulates than people in the industry? 
 Second, the article suggests that the people it describes "have good reason for their self-confidence" because "they are usually credited with spearheading Japan's impressive recovery from the ruins of World War II." But if the current generation of bureaucrats are self-confident or smug, it is not because they created Japan's postwar affluence but because they grew up in it.
 
JAMES R. BRECKENRIDGE
Manhattan, April 15
 
The writer is a lawyer in New York City.

HEADLINE: Journal;
An Inspector Calls

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
Everyone loves a thriller, and Broadway got a sensational one last week, with the arrival of Stephen Daldry's stunning production of "An Inspector Calls." Yet the most suspenseful drama unfolding around Times Square right now may be offstage, where real-life inspectors are infiltrating the shadowy Damon Runyonesque underworld of ticket scalping. At stake is not only consumer confidence in the Broadway theater but also an all-cash criminal economy generating millions of untaxed dollars in the heart of Rudolph Giuliani's budget-crunched New York.
The star of this production is the politically ambitious G. Oliver Koppell, who is filling out Robert Abrams's term as New York State Attorney General and is up for election this fall. Last month Mr. Koppell began filing suits against flagrant out-of-state brokers who scalp Madison Square Garden events like the Big East basketball tournament and Barbra Streisand concerts. Next thing he knew, Mr. Koppell says, "everyone from parking attendants to partners in Wall Street law firms" was cheering him on to widen his inquiry. Then "a number of people came forward as informants." 
 Now a task force involving two different divisions of the Attorney General's office is extending the investigation into Broadway's ticket distribution system. Mr. Koppell sees his constituency as the ordinary consumers who are infuriated by their inability to buy good seats legitimately, presumably because many of them are diverted to scalpers.
To see how large the problem is, two Times colleagues put themselves in the position of out-of-town tourists who wanted to plan a weekend trip to New York around a Broadway show. They tried to buy prime orchestra seats, fifth to tenth row center, by phone for a Friday or Saturday night -- any Friday or Saturday -- for five different plays. And failed each time.
At "The Phantom of the Opera," the Telecharge salesperson flatly said that on Saturdays "nothing is available in the center orchestra for the entire run of the show" -- despite the fact that the run is unlimited. But not even "Blood Brothers," an unprofitable production on its last legs, could fill the order. No wonder tourists turn to scalpers, or give up on Broadway altogether.
Mr. Koppell's job is to find out where all those tickets go, and how they get there. Few in the theater doubt that ice plays a major role. Ice is the industry's term -- derived from an old machine politicians' acronym for Incidental Campaign Expenses -- for bribes paid by scalpers for prime tickets at the box office. Since Broadway box offices -- and their phone extensions, like Telecharge -- are run by the theaters' owners, not the individual shows that are tenants, many producers are rooting for the Attorney General to help them at last gain control of their own ticket inventory. "Shows are hosts surrounded by parasites," says a producer; he believes one theater employee collected up to $15,000 tax-free a week in ice at one of his hits.
Meanwhile, fear reigns. Shortly after Mr. Koppell's investigation first leaked out in The New York Observer, the Shubert Organization, Broadway's largest theater owner, fired the manager and box-office staff of its Philadelphia touring outpost, the Forrest, but refuses to explain why to reporters. No producer I contacted would speak about ice for attribution; one refused to talk on the phone and instructed me to meet him instead in an anonymous midtown office.
This is a crucial moment for Broadway. The pre-Tony Awards boom is on. After an abominable winter, the street's marquees are alight again with big names -- Stephen Sondheim, Arthur Miller, Tommy Tune, Disney. But how many plays will survive Labor Day? For the first extended period in memory, not a single Broadway show, the big musicals included, is a consistent sellout.
Smart theater people know that high ticket prices compounded by scalping are driving away business when Broadway needs every customer it can get. Smart politicians know that ticket scandals are political windfalls: Louis Lefkowitz, the Attorney General who uncovered $10 million in Broadway ice in 1963, was on the front page for months. Smart New Yorkers know that Broadway's health is essential to the city's economy. With passions like these at play, who doubts that Mr. Koppell has the makings of a smash hit?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Children Without Mothers Are at Special Risk

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I have been disheartened to see that recent reports about the vulnerability of America's children ("Study Confirms Some Fears on U.S. Children," news article, April 12; "4 Million Children Said to Live in 'Distress,' " news article, April 25) omit any mention of a specific population at high risk for later troubles: motherless children. "Single-parent households" are almost routinely assumed to be female-headed, when in fact many thousands of children in this country are being raised by fathers or other relatives. 
 In 1988, the last year for which the Social Security Administration collected such data, 588,000 children under the age of 18 had lost their mothers to death -- a figure that doesn't even begin to include those families where mothers are absent due to divorce, abandonment, alcoholism, mental impairment and imprisonment. Yet because children in single-father households are more likely to be economically secure, and because acknowledging early mother loss makes us all just a little bit uncomfortable at the core, scores of motherless children are overlooked in America every day.
I can tell you, based on both personal experience and interviews with hundreds of motherless American women, that losing a mother at an early age is one of the most stressful life events a person can face. It completely rips apart the fabric of a child's life.
If a son or daughter who loses a mother never receives adequate substitute mothering, the loss can do long-term damage to his or her self-esteem, ability to relate to other people, overall feelings of security and ability to trust others.
Motherless women have also reported sexual abuse by fathers or stepbrothers after their mothers had died, difficulties maintaining relationships as adults, and debilitating post-partum depressions. Just as growing up in poverty has lifelong effects on a child, so does growing up without involved and consistent emotional care.
While it has been easy for us to overlook motherless children in recent years, the AIDS epidemic will soon make us unable to ignore their plight. We are headed for both a social and emotional crisis in this respect. In 1983, 255 American children under the age of 18 lost mothers to AIDS; by the year 2000, that figure is likely to surpass 80,000, a 300-fold increase.
About one-third of those children will be New York City residents. Not only will social service organizations have to provide for the care of thousands of motherless children, but someone will have to explain to each one why his or her mother is gone. If we can't do a better job of preventing and curing the causes of death -- such as AIDS, cancer and accidents -- that take young mothers away from their children, the least we can do is begin to acknowledge the difficulties they face.
 
HOPE EDELMAN
New York, April 26, 1994
The writer is the author of "Motherless Daughters."

HEADLINE: All-Volunteer Military Was a Highlight of Nixon's Presidency

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The individuals who were asked by the media for their recollections about Richard Nixon have, as best I can tell, wholly neglected his role in ending the draft and establishing the all-volunteer armed forces, which was so highly commended for its performance in the Persian Gulf War. 
 The economist J. Kenneth Galbraith wrote: "The draft survives principally as a device by which we use compulsion to get young men to serve at less than the market rate of pay. We shift the cost of military service from the well-to-do taxpayer who benefits by lower taxes to the impecunious young draftee." But so long as the takings were confined to a minority in the lower middle classes, Congress went along with the renewals of the draft authority.
When the fighting in Vietnam escalated in 1965 and 1966, accompanied by larger draft calls, students on the college campuses voiced their opposition. The Johnson Administration set up a Presidential commission headed by Burke Marshall that recommended that the Selective Service draft be replaced by a lottery. It helped, but students could still avoid being drafted by running to England, Sweden and Canada, or by securing medical deferments or employment in critical occupations.
In his run for the Presidency in 1960, Mr. Nixon said he would end the draft as soon as feasible. On Oct. 23, 1968, during his second run, he repeated this pledge when he said, "It is not so much the way they are selected that is wrong, it is the fact of selection."
Shortly after his inauguration Nixon established the President's Commission on the All Volunteer Force, headed by Thomas S. Gates. The Gates Commission report was presented to Nixon on Feb. 20, 1970.
The record of the Nixon years must include his role in ending compulsion and expanding freedom of choice. Thanks to his actions, the United States armed forces are stronger and more efficient.
 
WALTER Y. OI
Rochester, April 25, 1994
The writer was a senior staff economist on the Gates Commission.
