HEADLINE: Christopher Gets Syrian Response to Israeli Peace Plan

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, Syria, May 1

 BODY:
After meeting with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that peace talks between Syria and Israel had reached a "new, more substantive phase" and that Mr. Assad had presented new ideas in response to Israel's recent peace plan.
Mr. Christopher declined to describe the details of the Syrian response. But American officials appeared pleased that Mr. Assad had paid serious attention to the Israeli proposal, which Mr. Christopher presented to him in seven hours of talks this weekend. 
 The Israeli plan calls for Israel to withdraw from the Golan Heights over several years, in return for Syrian recognition of Israel and the signing of a peace accord.
Calling the talks with Mr. Assad "very serious and substantive," Mr. Christopher said at a news conference: "We have entered a new, more substantive phase of the negotiations. But it is clear there is a good deal of work to be done."
[After the talks between Mr. Christopher and President Assad, the Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk Sharaa, rejected the offer for a phased withdrawal and reiterated Syria's longstanding demand for a total withdrawal.]
 
Meeting With Rabin Next
 The Israeli plan and Mr. Christopher's visit seek to end the deadlock in the Syria-Israel peace talks. Mr. Christopher flew to Israel tonight to meet on Monday with Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin to describe the Syrian ideas. In an encouraging note, a senior official traveling with Mr. Christopher said, "They are discussing the full range of issues that have to be discussed."
One of Mr. Christopher's goals on his 10-day trip to the Middle East was to obtain firm dates to resume peace talks in Washington between Israel and Syria, Jordan and Lebanon. He said tonight that no dates had been set, adding that he needed to confer with Russia, which is co-sponsoring the talks, before setting a date.
One area in which Mr. Christopher reported progress was in his effort to persuade Mr. Assad to allow a high-level American official to examine human rights in Syria. Mr. Christopher said that it would be desirable for John Shattuck, the Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, to visit Syria, and that he had received some encouraging responses that such a visit might be arranged.
The stalemate in the Syria-Israel peace talks results from each side's wanting the other to take the first big step. For security reasons, Israel has refused to pull out of the Golan Heights, which it captured in 1967 and annexed in 1981, until Syria signs a peace agreement. Syria opposes a peace deal until Israel unilaterally withdraws from the Golan Heights.
The plan put together by Mr. Rabin seeks a comprehensive deal in which Israel would withdraw in phases from the heights in perhaps eight years. In return, Syria would establish diplomatic relations with Israel, sign a peace agreement and end its economic boycott of Israel.
Since Syria used to shell northern Israel from the Golan Heights, Israel is proposing security measures as part of the package. It is calling for demilitarization of the heights and also an international force of peacekeepers to serve as a buffer.
Neither Mr. Assad nor any other Syrian official made the sort of public, unmistakably positive response to the Israeli plan that Israel officials were hoping for. Israeli officials say that when Mr. Rabin met on Friday in Tel Aviv with Mr. Christopher, the Israeli leader said he was disappointed that Israel had not received any confidence-building measures from Syria after he had outlined a bold, politically risky peace plan.
There was a flurry of statements from Syrian officials in the news media today that welcomed progress toward peace but reiterated Damascus's demands, sometimes in a slightly tougher formulation than before.
Mr. Rabin has been subjected to severe fire from the Israeli right for saying he was willing to dismantle settlements in the Golan Heights in exchange for peace with Syria.
Some American officials say Mr. Assad is not inclined to make many concessions, since he believes that he has made many recent gestures to Washington, among them eradicating some poppy cultivation in the Bekaa region of Lebanon, closing two terrorist camps in that country and allowing an Arab member of the Israeli Parliament to visit Syria.
In the view of some Middle East commentators, Mr. Assad wants normalized relations with the United States even more than he wants peace with Israel and the return of the Golan Heights.
That is why American officials expected him to ask for some sizable carrots from the United States before he moves substantially forward in the talks with Israel. Among them is having Washington remove Syria from the American list of nations that sponsor terrorism and the list of nations that have failed to do enough to suppress drug trafficking.

President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has issued a counterproposal. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Clinton's Call for Pacific Harmony Meets a Chorus of Criticism From Asians

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, May 1

 BODY:
When President Clinton first described his vision of a new "Pacific community" last summer, in which the United States would engage Asia more vigorously and creatively than at any time since World War II, most of the region's leaders embraced the idea as a long-overdue shift from what they saw as Washington's Eurocentric view of the world.
But in recent months the enthusiastic talk of harmony, which reached a crescendo when Mr. Clinton gathered Asian leaders at a first-ever summit meeting in Seattle, has quickly given way to a broad chorus of criticism. On topics as diverse as trade policy with Japan, human rights and the possible caning of an American teen-ager in Singapore, leaders from Canberra to Tokyo are voicing similar critiques. They say Washington has been arrogant, that the "community" it envisions is built in America's image rather than in Asia's, and that it is chiefly interested in imposing its own rules.
 
Driven by Three Goals
 Many of the criticisms are self- interested, and some come from countries that insist the region needs a stabilizing American military presence, but reject Washington's political influence. But a result is that many Administration policies have been subtly undercut by some of its closest Asian allies. 
 "There has been a very sharp change of tone in recent months," a senior South Korean official who deals regularly with high-level Clinton Administration officials said recently. "There is a sense that America's approach to Asia has been very high-handed, too much preaching about human rights and too much of a Mickey Kantor approach on trade that may score a few points in the short term, but hurt the U.S. role in the Pacific for a long time."
Since the Seattle meeting, Mr. Clinton's Asian policy has been driven by three goals: opening Japan's markets, brandishing trade threats to force China to respect human rights and insisting that North Korea will never become a nuclear power. But its policies on Japan and China have been under daily attack in the region, one reason the Administration is being forced to rethink its strategy. A widespread reluctance to confront North Korea has created a particularly tense challenge for Washington at a moment when the North seems only days away from trying to harvest additional fuel from its reactors.
The most surprising opposition has come on trade. Almost every Pacific country professes sympathy with Mr. Clinton's complaints about Tokyo's trade surpluses and its slowness in opening its markets.
 
Australian Premier Opposed

 But in recent weeks country after country -- from Australia to Malaysia to South Korea -- has attacked the American insistence on "numerical targets" or "quantitative indicators" of American market penetration in Japan.
Some join the Japanese in complaining that such agreements undermine free market forces. But the real argument is that political pressure to buy American goods will make it harder for the rest of Asia to sell its wares to the Japanese.
Among the most outspoken critics of the Administration's approach is Australia's Prime Minister, Paul Keating, who has accused Washington of using a "heavy-headed sledgehammer number to crack the nut."
His Foreign Minister, Gareth Evans, said recently that he feared that Australian-made auto parts would be squeezed out of the Japanese market. South Koreans followed with the same complaint about their computer chips. European officials have joined in, saying their goods are suffering in Japan because of "Buy American" campaigns.
"They are right," a senior Japanese trade official said the other day, clearly enjoying the fact that Mr. Clinton has won few converts. "If we have a choice between buying an American product and one from elsewhere, political correctness says we should choose America." (In fact, that is not always the case: Five years after the United States pressed Japan to open its markets to imported beef, Australia sells more beef there than the United States does.)
But the recent evidence suggests that the Clinton Administration may be backing away, at least temporarily, from its high-pressure approach. A few months ago Mr. Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, dismissed arguments that Washington should not press Japan's fragile Government on opening its markets, saying nothing would get done for years if Washington waited for political stability to return to Tokyo.
Now, warned by the American Embassy in Tokyo that the new, minority Government of Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata is hardly in a position to negotiate, Administration officials are all but giving up hope of progress before the Group of Seven meeting this summer in Naples.
 
China Policy Under Attack
 Similarly, the Administration's strategy of linking preferential trade status to human rights in China is under broad attack. Since Secretary of State Warren Christopher traveled to Beijing to deliver a warning six weeks ago, leaders of Japan and South Korea have delivered very different messages.
Before his resignation last month, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa told the Chinese just what they wanted to hear: That Western concepts of human rights should not be "blindly applied" in Asia. South Korea's President, Kim Young Sam, never even raised the issue when he went there a few weeks later.
Last month, even as the Administration struggled to back away from its threat to revoke China's most-favored-nation status without appearing to abandon its human rights initiative, Singapore's former Prime Minister, Lee Kuan Yew, warned that Mr. Clinton was engaging in a "fruitless endeavor" in trying to pressure China. He warned that "the United States will find itself all alone in the Pacific" on the issue.
 
Singapore's Views Supported
 Mr. Lee's complaints about the imposition of American values on Asian countries are now familiar, and they have been reprised by the arguments over the caning sentence handed down by a Singapore court against an American teen-ager convicted of vandalism. The fundamental argument -- that the rights of the society come first, ahead of individual rights -- strikes a chord in many Asian countries. What has changed in recent months is that other Asian leaders have warmed to Mr. Lee's argument, often in the service of their own economic interests.
Japanese business executives, for example, often portray Japan as China's more reliable partner, saying their own country would never mix business and politics. That is a grim truth for American diplomats in Asia, who point out that Japan holds considerable sway as China's biggest provider of foreign aid, and now its second-largest trading partner.
"This is an issue that the Japanese see a lot differently than we do, and that's been true for some time," Walter F. Mondale, the American Ambassador to Japan, said recently.
Even Australia has spoken out against linking preferential trade benefits for China with human rights. While stressing the need to press "universal human rights" Mr. Evans said last month that denying the trade benefits to China "would have a very adverse economic impact on the region as a whole, particularly Hong Kong, with flow-on effects for Australia."
In Hong Kong the economic considerations have clearly won out, despite concern that China is moving to quell dissent before regaining the city in 1997. In Washington last week, Hong Kong's chief secretary, Anson Chan, told Vice President Al Gore and other officials that the territory's prosperity would be devastated by the withdrawal of trade privileges for China.
"We do not believe trade should be linked with human rights," she said, trying to speed the argument for separating the issues, which is already taking hold in Washington.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Shaper of Magazines Retires

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY 

 BODY:
Marshall Loeb, one of the most visible and influential editors in the magazine industry during his 38-year tenure at Time Inc., is to retire as managing editor of Fortune magazine after eight years in the job, the magazine will announce today.
Mr. Loeb will turn 65, the mandatory retirement age for Time Inc.'s managing editors, at the end of the month. He will become Fortune's editor at large and write a new column for the magazine. 
 He will be succeeded on May 20 by Walter Kiechel 3d, an executive editor at Fortune who joined the magazine in 1977 as a reporter-researcher. Mr. Kiechel, who is 47, will be the first managing editor in 40 years to be promoted from within the ranks of the magazine.
 
Similar Visions
 Mr. Loeb and Mr. Kiechel have worked together for several years and, by both their accounts, have similar visions for the magazine.
During Mr. Loeb's tenure, the "big story" that had always been Fortune's forte was made more explicit. In addition to standard fare about the economy, management and corporate strategy, Mr. Loeb introduced articles on executive life and on social problems that affect the business world. Homelessness and the plight of public schools were among the recurring themes.
He also expanded the use of graphs, lists and tables to illustrate major articles.
The change at Fortune comes as competition from television, newspapers and other business magazines is stronger than ever.
For instance, Biz, a monthly that focuses on small businesses, was started in March with an initial circulation of 500,000, as a joint venture between American City Business Journals Inc. and Dow Jones & Company. And the two monthlies that entered the field in 1992 have grown rapidly: Worth, which was started by Fidelity Investments, now has a circulation of more than 300,000, and Smart Money, started by Dow Jones and the Hearst Corporation, has a circulation of 449,000.
But the three magazines that continue to dominate are Business Week, Fortune and Forbes, despite their distinctly different thrusts. Business Week emphasizes news. Forbes, published every two weeks, focuses on how companies are managed and the people who manage them. And Fortune, also published every two weeks, is known for its in-depth articles.
The competition among the three for circulation and advertising is perhaps the fiercest in the magazine industry. "The last 10 years have been sort of nasty in the ways that Forbes and Fortune have gone at each other, with each trashing the other whenever they can," said Steve Klein, media director and partner at Kirshenbaum & Bond, an ad agency.
In North America, Business Week is the circulation leader at 883,718, followed by Fortune at 786,619 and Forbes at 770,008, according to the most recent figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulations. Fortune and Business Week also have international circulations -- Fortune at 136,753 and Business Week at 116,857.
Last year, Fortune saw a 10 percent increase in advertising pages, while Forbes had a gain of 1 percent and Business Week a decline of 2 percent. Through this March, Fortune's ad pages were up 8 percent, compared with the first quarter of 1993. Business Week was up 16 percent and Forbes was down 9 percent.
While Fortune officials decline to provide figures, they say the magazine's revenues are strong and profits are up. In 1993, circulation profits reached a record high, officials said.
Fortune has also prospered editorially under Mr. Loeb, who was previously managing editor of Money, a Time Inc. publication that emphasizes personal finance.
"I think Marshall really has a sense of the pulse of a magazine's readers, almost like no one I know," said Norman Pearlstine, a former executive editor of The Wall Street Journal and the president of Friday Holdings, a media investment group. "If you think of Money and Fortune, you see that he clearly positioned each of those publications just wonderfully."
A hurdle for Fortune was its image as the publication for the white-collar work force of Fortune 500 companies. With that audience shrinking, the trick was not only to keep the audience but also to build it.
Steven Swarz, editor of Smart Money, sees Fortune as a strong service publication for executives. "I think Fortune became must reading for people aspiring to higher corporate jobs and for people who wanted to know what those jobs were like," he said.
 
No Big Changes
 Mr. Kiechel said that while he was not contemplating a redesign or other big changes at the magazine, he would probably "rethink" some departments. He talked about adding more case studies and extracting lessons from them.
Long regarded as the heir apparent, Mr. Kiechel has overseen much of the magazine's coverage of managerial issues and, for 10 years, has written a column called Office Hours. He has also written many cover articles, including last year's "How We Will Work in the Year 2000."
He says the 1990's will be a defining time in economic history, comparable in importance to the industrial revolution in the 19th century.
"We are in a historic transformation of our economy," he said in an interview. "The core infrastructure is shifting from old industries like the auto industry to computers, telecommunications and the entertainment business. The old blue collar-white collar distinctions are going. The new workers are professional and technical workers who are going to be the dominant people in the work force."
The changes, of course, present new challenges to a business magazine. Mr. Kiechel even held out the possibility that the magazine might have to redefine its landmark Fortune 500 industrial list.
 
Continuing Themes
 Mr. Loeb said he would write about "forward-looking ideas" in his new column. He is also working on a book on personal finance and will continue to travel and give speeches around the world.
With his cheerful personality and relentless curiosity, Mr. Loeb has long had the air of a little boy who can't believe he is so lucky as to live the life he does. Brought up on Chicago's West Side, he served as a foreign correspondent in postwar Germany, became a reporter for The St. Louis Globe-Democrat and joined Time magazine in 1956, where he wrote or edited more than 130 cover articles in 24 years. He became managing editor of Money in 1980.
"He has been a major factor not only in business journalism but in the entire magazine industry," said Stephen B. Shepard, editor in chief of Business Week.

HEADLINE: Resentment Zone;
Officials' Courtship of Yankees Stirs Anger in the Bronx

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
Ted Davidson, public-housing resident, and George M. Steinbrenner 3d, public-stadium resident: two peas in a pod.
Both have been in the South Bronx a long time and are wary of the neighborhood. Both threaten to leave. "I'd move to Jersey," Mr. Davidson says, though he probably never will. And maybe his neighbor, Mr. Steinbrenner, six long blocks away, never will, either. 
 But the big difference Mr. Davidson sees between him and Mr. Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, is this: "Every time Steinbrenner threatens to move they give him more money to stay here. But we don't have anything here."
The longstanding tension between the residents of South Bronx and the Yankees is tightening again. The Giuliani administration is proposing to renovate the ballpark at a cost of about $275 million, while at the same time threatening to cancel construction a few blocks away of a $250 million police academy, envisioned as an economic sparkplug for the struggling neighborhood.
Money for the academy at 153d Street and Park Avenue was not in the financial plan that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani issued in February. Police officials have long argued that the existing academy near Gramercy Park in Manhattan is inadequate and needs to be replaced. But a Giuliani administration official, citing budget constraints, said on Saturday that it was unlikely money for the new building would be in the city's proposed capital budget to be released this week.
The distinction between the city's treatment of the stadium and the neighborhoods around it was drawn even more sharply two weeks ago. Mr. Giuliani and other city leaders announced that the city's application for a $100 million Federal grant to create an "empowerment zone" centered in Harlem would include a narrow swath of the South Bronx encompassing Yankee Stadium but not the adjacent poverty-stricken communities of Melrose and Mott Haven.
"How do you include the richest franchise in sports and not include, a few blocks away, the poorest of the poor?" said Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President. While Mr. Ferrer commended the Mayor for including a piece of the Bronx in the Federal application, he said he would work to have other poor neighborhoods included also.
 
Help for Everybody
 Joe Lhota, the chief of staff to Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson, said the administration hoped the Federal aid would both help the people in the stadium area and enhance the chances of the Yankees' remaining in the Bronx.
"The history of the Bronx in the 20th century and the history of the Yankees are intertwined," he said, adding that the administration, along with state officials, was determined to keep the team there.
Yankee Stadium has long skewed politics and money in the South Bronx. Well before Mr. Giuliani, a Yankee fan since childhood, the team found favor among politicians devoted to the lore of the Bronx Bombers and fearful of the disgrace their leaving would spread.
When the Yankees threatened to leave New York City in the 1970's, the cash-strapped city bought the stadium and renovated it. The construction bill went from $24 million to $100 million, and to save money the neighborhood-improvement component of the project was cut.
Now, 20 years later, officials and residents in the Bronx fear they are reliving that era. "We want to avoid that mistake, but the city seems to be running headlong into it," Mr. Ferrer said. "You can't just rebuild the stadium, you have to fortify the neighborhood."
Although many of the South Bronx neighborhoods have improved in the last 20 years, Maritza Owens, who organizes prenatal health programs in Mott Haven, said gunfire is a common nighttime sound near her home on the Grand Concourse, within easy walking distance of Borough Hall, Yankee Stadium and the police academy site. On a recent afternoon when the Yankees were at home, a homeless man was sprawled out asleep in Joyce Kilmer Park opposite Borough Hall on a rise from which fans in the stadium's crowded upper deck could be seen.
 
'Community Is Suffering'
 "How can you spend so much time and energy on Yankee Stadium when outside a whole community is suffering?" said Ms. Owens, standing near the police academy site, a sunken lot littered with rusted car parts and discarded appliances and furniture.
The proposed police academy, once expected to bring hundreds of new jobs and thousands of police officers and cadets to the area, was seen by Bronx leaders as a way to add spirit, security and economic heft to the South Bronx's attempt to erase its national reputation as a charred symbol of urban catastrophe.
The Police Department has been making the case for a new academy for eight years, and two mayors have advocated putting it in the South Bronx, although budget constraints delayed its progress in the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins. It became the spark for the Bronx Center Plan, a strategy for complementing 20 years of new housing in the area with jobs and educational opportunity.
The plan called for the construction of theme high schools, one connected with the police academy to prepare students for careers in law enforcement and another, near Yankee Stadium, for students interested in working in the sports business. It is unclear if those schools will be built.
Although there is no direct connection between the decision on the police academy and the plan to renovate Yankee Stadium, Bronx leaders see them as a message being sent by City Hall.
Richard Kahane, president of the Urban Assembly planning group and chairman of the Bronx Center Plan, said that the police academy would be a tremendous economic boon to the neighborhood, while Yankee Stadium's effects are limited.
 
Loyalties Questioned
 "This is a major generator of confidence and faith and a major generator of economic development in terms of jobs and a major generator of economic opportunity," he said. "Yankee Stadium is an important civic symbol, but it is none of the other things."
Mr. Kahane said Mr. Giuliani had a stronger political loyalty to the Yankees than to the neighborhoods around it. "Mr. Giuliani never ran on revitalizing this community," he said. "He did run on keeping the Yankees here."
But the Mayor and his aides hold fast to their contention that the decision on the academy is all about money.
"People arguing for this have to get real," Mr. Giuliani said in March. "The city simply can't afford it. This is not a question of what people want, but where we're going to get the money from."
The Mayor has softened his stance somewhat recently, saying he would consider other cuts in capital budget projects for the Bronx proposed by Mr. Ferrer to help pay for the police academy. But last week, Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers said finding the money for the police academy was "a tough case."
Instead, the administration plans a $69.8 million renovation of the current police academy. But that plan would simply overhaul the building's systems and do nothing to alleviate overcrowding, said Joseph Wuensch, the deputy police commissioner for management and budget.
He said that the academy was designed in the 1950's to hold classes of 600 cadets, but that classes now number 2,200 cadets, causing a shortage of everything from lockers and classrooms to showers and auditorium space.
Nonetheless, the Giuliani administration, which has strongly supported the Police Department and has protected it from other budget cuts, believes the needs of the police can be met without spending the money for a new academy, Mr. Powers said.
 
'Worth Every Nickel'
 By contrast, with Mr. Steinbrenner questioning the city's resolve to provide a safer, more lucrative and fan-friendly stadium, money seems no object in its effort to keep the Yankees.
"We don't know what it will cost," Mr. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, said when negotiations with the Yankees began in February. "It will be a lot of money but worth every nickel."

LENGTH: 2496 words

HEADLINE: Foundations Are Finding Wealth Is a Problem, Too

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH 

 BODY:
The nation's foundations are discovering prosperity has its perils.
As a group, their financial health has never been better. Their ranks keep growing: 35,765 foundations in 1993, with 11,000 of them created since 1980. A bullish stock market raised their combined assets to an all-time high of $177 billion last year. 
 And there is the glittering prospect that fresh converts to charity will appear in the coming decade, when economists predict trillions of dollars will pass from Americans now over 50 to their children and grandchildren -- the biggest intergenerational transfer of wealth in history.
But the foundations' very visible well-being has stirred uneasiness within their ranks, even as they come together for the 45th annual conference of the Council on Foundations, opening today in Manhattan.
 
Concern Over Image
 Some foundation leaders say they worry about their public image, objecting that they are portrayed as hoarding wealth while the country struggles under the burden of its social needs. They also express fear that a budget-driven Congress, in its search for revenues, could start pruning the lists of tax-exempt organizations; besides foundations, these include 25 categories of nonprofit groups as varied as pension funds and cemetery associations, farmers' cooperatives and professional football leagues.
Foundations in fact represent only 17 percent of all nonprofit organizations. Foundations are nonprofit organizations that give away money, and most of them are set up by individuals to or groups such as family members or businesses.
"Foundations must try harder to merit public trust or risk increased regulation by governments," the council's president, James A. Joseph, warned its 1,300 members recently. The question is not whether foundations do good. It is whether they should do more, by drawing down endowments if necessary and even spending themselves out of existence, as a few philanthropies have done.
By law, to retain their tax-exempt status, foundations are required to pay out the equivalent of at least 5 percent of their assets each year. Their combined giving last year exceeded $9 billion, spread out among thousands of nonprofit groups active in education, health and welfare services, the arts, environmental protection and foreign assistance.
"The notion that foundations are just sitting on money is frivolous and ignores all the good they do," said John E. Craig, executive vice president of the 75-year-old Commonwealth Fund, which is known for innovations in health-care policy.
 
Available Capital
 He is one of many foundation leaders who are quick to point out that their available capital for all these activities is modest compared with what governments are spending. "Even if all foundations were to take all their combined assets and blow them all in one year, the total would produce only a 9 percent increase in government and private spending for social welfare, education, cultural purposes and the environment," he said. "This would leave nothing for next year and the next year."
Many of the larger foundations say that preserving their endowments requires them to earn at least 10 to 12 percent on their investments to offset inflation and to cover the required 5 percent payout and an additional 1 to 2 percent excise tax set by Congress.
In years when the market soars and assets grow, foundations can increase their giving. But they have learned that they must prepare for the inevitable years when markets sour and they must dip into capital to meet their commitments. The Ford Foundation's assets of $3.7 billion melted to $1.7 billion over three years in the early 1970's. By 1992 they had rebounded to almost $6.5 billion.
By protecting their assets, foundations argue, they can continue to serve as testing grounds for innovative ideas. A successful project in training welfare mothers for jobs,for example, can have an influence on shaping government policy.
And President Clinton, meeting recently with leaders of 200 nonprofit organizations, praised a Carnegie Corporation analysis on the needs of very young children, saying the foundation offered his administration coherent recommendations for action.
 
'Thinking and Worrying'
 For foundations, the present climate of disquiet can be useful, said Peter C. Goldmark Jr., president of the Rockefeller Foundation.
"The foundation world is in a yeasty and creative period; its members are thinking and worrying," he said, arguing that these are cynical times when no organization is immune from scrutiny, including hospitals, universities and religious groups. "Like all American institutions, foundations are learning to give and receive criticism thoughtfully."
As bestowers of largess, foundations, in fact, are not likely to hear much critics, certainly not from the nonprofits who need their grants.
An exception is Pablo S. Eisenberg, executive director of the Center for Community Change in Washington, a nonprofit group supported by foundations. Assailing foundations as elitist, he said that while they have "added women and minority members to their governing boards, they have yet to appoint teachers, union members or community spokesmen."
"Their double standard," he said, "makes it tough for grass-roots community groups to get financial support while they gladly fund a third-rate museum or ballet."
Philanthropy is getting increased attention these days from research centers at universities. More evidence of the interest: researchers and grant seekers alike are using nearly 200 affiliated libraries in urban and rural communities that supply foundation data -- the Foundation Center at 79 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan drew 30,000 visitors last year.
Except for once-a-year messages in annual reports, foundation administrators seem inclined to operate quietly. "There aren't any publicly recognized role models like Andrew Carnegie who are articulating the value of philanthropy in today's world," said Dr. Elizabeth T. Boris, director of the Aspen Institute's Nonprofit Research Fund. She added that philanthropic leadership would be even more necessary to attract some of the $8 trillion that baby boomers will inherit over the next two decades.
 
Judging by the Record
 Franklin A. Thomas, president of the Ford Foundation, likes to say the foundation "should be judged on its record." That record, including creation of public television programming, production centers and satellite transmission, as well as widening community revitalization efforts, reflects Ford's national and international activities and a smaller but growing involvement in New York.
Ford, like Rockefeller in decades past, considered spending itself out of existence but its trustees concluded that it was more prudent to leave future generations a legacy, Mr. Thomas said. Among the major foundations, he said, there is a trend toward increasing collaboration and openness. "We have a sense we're learning from each other, without losing our identities."
To pay for this year's three-day meeting, 120 local foundations contributed $300,000 for events that will include a reception at the Metropolitan Museum of Art as well as bus trips to see neighborhood preservation efforts in Harlem and an employment training center and bilingual school in the South Bronx.
For the first time, a share of the money donated for hospitality will be put aside for distribution to local nonprofit groups.
"New York is a great laboratory for philanthropy but the sheer dimensions discourage outside foundations from working here," said Lorie A. Slutsky, president of the New York Community Trust. "We don't want to hide the city's problems but want foundations to see hopeful experiments, opportunities to work here in the city and models to take home."
The New York Community Trust, one of hundreds of community foundations around the country, serves as an administrator of 1,100 charitable funds, investing and distributing income from almost $1 billion in assets.
Many are multimillion-dollar funds, but there are smaller efforts like the Theresa E. Bernholz Fund, created 69 years ago by Rosebel G. Schiff to honor an inspiring school principal at Public School 9 in Manhattan. Mrs. Schiff left $1,000 asking that the income each year go to a single deserving student. This year, because the endowment has prospered, four pupils will share the Bernholz prize, each getting $50.
"Now that," Ms. Slutsky said, "is an endowment."

 1992 grants: $264 million

 New York-based private foundation . . . nation's largest by assets, with about $6.8 billion . . . established in 1936 by Henry and Edsel Ford . . . supporter of programs domestically and internationally to combat urban and rural poverty through community development . . . major contributor to low and moderate-income housing in United States, education efforts and leadership training among minorities . . . staff of 220 headed by Franklin A.  W. K. Kellogg Foundation
 1992 grants: $173 million
 Chief executive: Russell G. Mawby
 Based in Battle Creek, Mich. . . . established by the cereal developer in 1930 with declared purpose of "helping people to help themselves" . . . philanthropic support expanded from local concerns to include health and education activities and improvement of agriculture and rural life in Third World countries . . . nationally supports programs in childhood and higher education, youth and leadership training, health services, voluntarism . . . Pew, founder of the Sun Oil Company . . . initially Pew interests focused on Philadelphia but moved into national and then international field, supporting aid to emerging democratic institutions in Eastern Europe . . . current national interests include support for schools, the arts, research, environmental protection and training of urban ministers . . . HEADLINE: Legislators Toss Insults, But Can't Pass a Budget

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 1

 BODY:
It is frequently said that one reason the State Legislature is late in adopting a state budget -- it is now a month overdue -- is that no one has been hurt by the delay. The Legislature has kept the wheels of government greased, and state colleges, prisons and health-care services continue to operate as usual.
But the impasse has begun to cause some people pain, and their numbers are growing. School boards are preparing to ask voters to approve local property tax increases because they do not know how much state aid they will receive. Mayors are in the same bind as they present budget proposals to municipal councils. And scores of nonprofit organizations that depend on state grants are seeking bank loans to cover payrolls. 
 "This is blatant arrogance," said Mayor Shawn D. Hogan of Hornell, a city of 10,000 that is 60 miles southwest of Rochester. "People are sick and tired of this. And not just local government leaders, but also John Q. Public."
Yet legislative leaders are no closer to an agreement than they were last month. And today negotiations fell to an acrimonious low as the Assembly's Democratic Speaker vowed to pass a plan that is virtually certain to be rejected by the Republicans who control the Senate.
As early as Tuesday, the Assembly will begin passing budget bills based on a compromise plan released by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last week, said the Speaker, Sheldon Silver of Manhattan. The plan splits the differences between the two houses over state aid to schools and tax cuts.
Mr. Silver's move is something of a toothless tactic, since even many Democrats do not like Mr. Cuomo's proposal. More important, a budget accord is impossible without the assent of Senate Republicans.
But the threat indicates just how deep the stalemate has become. And it exemplifies a familiar Statehouse script in which one house passes meaningless legislation when real progress is unattainable, then accuses the other of inaction and obstinacy.
So it was today, as Mr. Silver charged, as he has in the past, that the Senate Republicans are holding up the budget to embarrass Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat who is seeking his fourth term this November.
"I have to think they have another agenda, that they don't want to give the Governor a budget because the Governor is the one who will pay in November," he said in an interview.
 
A One-House Bill?
 But even Mr. Cuomo rejected that notion, saying, "I wouldn't share his description of the Republican's motivations." And though Mr. Silver had praised Mr. Cuomo's compromise plan as a "useful blueprint" for an Assembly budget bill, Mr. Cuomo said he would rather reach a compromise with both houses than see his proposal memorialized in one.
Rounding out an afternoon of recriminations and ad hominem attacks, the leader of the Senate's Republican majority, Ralph J. Marino of Oyster Bay, accused Mr. Silver of being rigid, uncompromising and determined to win political points "to establish himself as new Speaker."
The dispute over the $33 billion budget for the fiscal year that began April 1 is ostensibly about splitting up an anticipated budget surplus of $1.5 billion. Two issues in particular have created roadblocks: how to allocate $410 million in tax cuts, most for businesses, and how to divide $400 million in additional aid to schools.
 
Splitting a Surplus
 The Senate has proposed reducing or eliminating several business taxes, including a 15 percent surcharge on corporate taxes, over the next two years. But Mr. Silver contends the Senate plan would worsen anticipated future budget gaps, and he has called for phasing in the tax cuts more slowly.
On school aid, Mr. Silver has insisted that New York City receive the biggest share of additional money because the city has 37 percent of the state's students but receives less than 35 percent of state school aid.
But Mr. Marino argues that Mr. Silver's plan would reduce aid to needy rural districts upstate, most of them Republican strongholds.
Mr. Cuomo's proposal, which has been criticized by lawmakers from both parties, would give all school districts at least a 3.5 percent increase in aid. But it would give additional money to growing districts, which would include New York City. The compromise plan also calls for spreading out many of the Senate's business tax cuts over four years instead of two.
The Legislature has insured that state agencies can continue operating by passing the portion of the budget that pays state workers' salaries. But it has not passed the portion that allocates grants to local governments, school districts and nonprofit organizations that provide social services.
 
Tax Increases Pending
 With little chance that a budget will be in place, voters will decide the fates of 155 school budgets on Tuesday. Dozens of those districts are facing property tax increases; but in some cases, tax increases might have been reduced or avoided if the state had granted larger-than-anticipated increases in aid, school officials said.
Hundreds of mayors must also seek approval of proposed budgets from municipal councils. Many are facing budget gaps that they do not know how to fill because they have not been told how much state assistance they will receive.
"It causes everybody a lot of anxiety that we are going to announce a budget when we won't know what our numbers are," said Mayor Anthony M. Masiello of Buffalo, who plans to announce a tax increase and layoffs this week to help close a $34 million deficit.
Officials with nonprofit organizations say dozens of groups that have contracts with the state to provide social services will begin suffering cash-flow problems this week because they have not been reimbursed in a month. Those groups provide services to a wide range of the needy, including the elderly, unemployed, mentally retarded and blind.
Kenneth H. Cowdery, executive director for a Buffalo-based service organization called the Clarkson Center, said he expects to seek a $45,000 bank loan this week to cover his payroll. To pay for the interest on that loan, his organization must seek additional grants and donations because the state will not cover it.

HEADLINE: Close Race To Succeed A Senator From Ohio

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARMA, Ohio, April 28

 BODY:
Joel Hyatt, who is running to replace his father-in-law, Howard M. Metzenbaum, in the Senate, worked his way through a shopping center, shaking hands in the final days before Tuesday's primary election.
The Democratic entrepreneur, who founded a national chain of low-cost legal clinics, repeatedly introduced himself, but he is so well known from his years promoting Hyatt Legal Services on television that most people seem to know him already. 
 But after he greeted Harry Cudilo, a 70-year-old retired accountant, Mr. Cudilo looked bemused. "I'm voting for Boyle," Mr. Cudilo said flatly of Mr. Hyatt's chief Democratic rival, Mary Boyle, as Mr. Hyatt walked away. "She's not as rich as he is."
Score one for Mrs. Boyle and her latest television assault, which has suddenly given shape to this down-to-the-wire election with the clarity of a bumper sticker: "The Senate doesn't need any more millionaire lawyers," she says to the camera. "What it needs is more moms."
 
Race Closely Watched
 The Senate race here, a state that has long served as a microcosm for national politics, is particularly significant. Ohio has a near balance of Republicans and Democrats. It also has a mix of urban and rural areas and an economic standing near the national average. Moreover, the race is being closely watched in Washington as one of a handful that together could imperil the Democrats' majority this fall.
Like voters in other states, people in Ohio are anxious about crime and health care. They express a deep cynicism toward Washington and a profound disaffection from government, and have approved term limits for their elected officials.
With so few issues dividing them in their respective primaries, the Democratic and Republican Senate candidates are trying to distinguish themselves by claiming to be the most ordinary candidate.
The "Mom versus Millionaire" advertisement, which is being broadcast statewide, deliberately echoes the successful 1992 Senate campaign of Patty Murray in Washington State, who converted a legislator's dismisal of her as "just a mom in tennis shoes" into a winning campaign slogan. Mrs. Boyle, the mother of four and a popular three-term Cayahoga County Commissioner has sought advice from Senator Murray.
Also on the Democratic side is Ralph Applegate, a business consultant who barely registers in the polls.
 
A Republican Doctor
 Among the Republican candidates is Dr. Bernadine Healy, a cardiologist who is a former director of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. At a recent debate she said voters often ask her why a doctor would run for the Senate. "Washington is sick," Dr. Healy said she replied. "It needs a doctor."
Later in an interview, Dr. Healy, who has raised over $2 million, more money than anyone else in the race, much of it from doctors, said: "The Senate needs someone from the real world. It has become a homogeneous ruling class."
Other Republican candidates include Lieut. Gov. Michael DeWine, a former Congressman who lost a Senate race to John Glenn in 1992; State Senator Eugene J. Watts, and George Rhodes, a businessman.
The Republican race has come down to a contest between Dr. Healy and Lieutenant Governor DeWine, who is ahead in the polls.
 
The Metzenbaum Legacy
 The 76-year-old Mr. Metzenbaum, one of the Senate's most liberal members, is leaving after 18 years. Although he stood to the left of mainstream Ohio voters, he earned their respect by fighting for the average consumer -- sometimes even against Ohio's important automobile industry, as when he backed higher gasoline mileage standards.
All of the Senate candidates suggest they would carry on his legacy as a fighter, even as they distance themselves from his liberal tradition. Mr. Hyatt, for instance, has staked out a tough position on crime, supporting the death penalty, while Mrs. Boyle does not.
Dr. Healy, whose husband is director of the Cleveland Clinic, has taken up the cudgel against President Clinton's health care proposals, warning that they will reduce Ohio's strong medical tradition to "socialized medicine."
David Sweet, dean of the Levin College of Urban Affairs at Cleveland State University, said he was "greatly troubled" as he watched the candidates on both sides "further their own interests by bashing Washington."
The race has provided a good example of how deep the anti-politician fervor really runs. "On both sides, you have experienced elected officials being challenged by outsiders," Mr. Sweet said. "When push comes to shove, will they vote for an outsider with no experience? Or will they come to the voting booth saying, 'I'm not happy, but I want someone who knows how to work within the system'?"
The opinion polls reflect that confusion, with a large percentage of voters still undecided.
At a shopping mall here, John Maziasz, a 46-year-old worker in a department store, said: "I haven't decided if I like Hyatt or Boyle. Her point about another millionaire in the Senate struck a chord with me. But I did go to Hyatt Legal Services to have my will made out."
Political analysts say the Hyatt-Boyle race is too close to call.
 
Themes of Class Warfare
 The television commercial, made by Austin/Sheinkopf Ltd., has crystalized the central conflict between Mr. Hyatt and Mrs. Boyle by hitting on class warfare themes that have historically played well here.
"It works on several levels," said John C. Green, director of the bipartisan Ray C. Bliss Institute of Applied Politics at the University of Akron. "It taps into the feelings of the ordinary person, the anti-incumbent, anti-establishment disgust with politicians. It brings in the gender issue. Mary Boyle is a pathbreaking woman, perhaps the first female Senator from Ohio, but she's also plain folk."
It also suggests, without stating it, another class subtext of the campaign: that Mr. Hyatt's father-in-law is handing him the Senate seat. Although Mr. Metzenbaum is strongly backing his son-in-law, the Senator has not been visible in the campaign or in commercials.
Still, a former chairman of the state Democratic Party, James Ruvolo, said voters were suspicious that Mr. Hyatt's first run for office was for his father-in-law's seat. "I told him that the only thing standing between him and the U.S. Senate is being the son-in-law," Mr. Ruvolo said in an interview.
For his part, Mr. Hyatt emphasizes that he "made the legal system more responsive" by starting legal clinics that were open on weekends and at night, conducted transactions in plain English and charged less than tonier firms. Railing to reporters against the "entrenched interests" in Washington, he said he wanted to make Government similarly responsive.
That theme puts Mr. Hyatt in the awkward position of running as an outsider, even though he has endorsements from the state Democratic Party and most of organized labor. Similarly, while calling for campaign finance reform, he acknowledged that he has accepted money from political action committees.
"If I'm going to fight entrenched interests, I have to get elected," he said. "The idea isn't to fall down on your spear and die; the idea is to win."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
For a Victim's Sister, Rifkin's Trial Is Part of a Troubled Journey

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., May 1

 BODY:
The trial of Joel Rifkin on the first of several charges of murdering young women has offered grisly testimony and sharp disagreement between the defense and prosecution over Mr. Rifkin's mental state, along with an unexpected look at how the defendant hoped to profit from his notoriety.
The proceedings, which began April 11 with jury selection, have moved quickly, but it has been a long, troubled journey for Margarita Gonzales, whose 23-year-old sister, Jenny Soto, was among Joel Rifkin's admitted victims. Ms. Gonzales, who lives with her mother in Brooklyn, has attended nearly every court proceeding since Mr. Rifkin made his 12-page confession on June 28. 
 But it was not until C. Thomas Capers, a senior investigator for the New York State Police, took the witness stand that she learned that her sister was Mr. Rifkin's 14th victim. Trooper Capers had taken Mr. Rifkin's confession.
"Until now I didn't know whether she was No. 13 or No. 14," said Miss Gonzales. She said she felt some relief that the trial was nearing an end. But she did not know whether Mr. Rifkin would ever come to trial in her sister's death.
Mr. Rifkin faces murder charges in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens and in Suffolk County. He is on trial in Nassau County Court only for the murder of Ms. Bresciani, but the other victims have become part of the testimony because of his insanity defense.
 
Sandwiches Are an Issue
 Mr. Rifkin grew more alert in court last week after a change in diet, his lawyer says.
Last Monday, as a state trooper was recalling how Mr. Rifkin had confessed to killing 17 women, Mr. Rifkin slipped down into his chair at the defense table, tilted his head back and fell asleep.
"It was the bologna sandwiches they gave him for lunch," said Mr. Rifkin's lawyer, John Lawrence, who said his client's allergic reaction to the nitrates in the bologna had made him drowsy.
The court officers gave Mr. Rifkin nitrate-free lunches for the rest of the week and the defendant stayed relatively alert. "He's feeling as well as can be expected," said Mr. Lawrence.
Mr. Rifkin, a 34-year-old unemployed landscaper, is on trial in the killing of Tiffany Bresciani, 22, of Manhattan, whose body was found in the back of his pickup truck June 28 after state troopers stopped him for a traffic violation. He later confessed to killing her and 16 other women over a four-year period.
 
Protecting 'Marketability'
 Mr. Rifkin had hoped to cash in on his notoriety by selling his story to the highest bidder. He talked of "book rights" and "marketability" in a letter he wrote last December to Mr. Lawrence.
"We need to act fast to sell before there is a public record of the rights to my pre-arrest story or the studios will buy the story from someone else," Mr. Rifkin wrote. He noted that at least two books might already be coming out and "when they do, our marketability is dead."
The contents of the Dec. 19 letter became available to the jurors late Friday, just before they were dismissed for the weekend. The prosecutor, Fred Klein, entered it as evidence, noting that it was among some documents turned over to a psychologist who had evaluated Mr. Rifkin.
In the same letter, Mr. Rifkin cautioned Mr. Lawrence against making too many documents available to new doctors entering his case. "I should decide what I want turned over," he wrote. "Some might be very damaging," he added, expressing concern that the documents might show "implied guilt."
"Guilt implies an understanding of wrongness and responsibility," Mr. Rifkin said, a comment the jury may yet hear again in Mr. Klein's closing comments before they begin considering their verdict.
Mr. Klein also left the jury on Friday pondering another letter, written by Mr. Rifkin to Mr. Lawrence on Aug. 13. In it Mr. Rifkin expressed doubts about the efforts of psychologists and psychiatrists hired by his first lawyer, Robert Sale, to develop an insanity defense.
"What Sale is looking for is classical psych evidence," Mr. Rifkin wrote. "But there is none, no barking at the moon, no personal conversations with God, no hallucinations, no manias. The problem is I am not in the book."
When the jury in Mr. Rifkin's murder trial returns to the courtroom Monday morning, the prosecution plans to call its star witness, Dr. Elliot Park Dietz, a forensic psychiatrist and expert on serial killers.
Dr. Dietz is expected to refute last week's testimony by Dr. Barbara R. Kirwin, a clinical psychologist and the only witness for the defense, who testified that Mr. Rifkin was legally insane and therefore not responsible for the 17 killings.
Dr. Dietz has previously written that serial killers usually have an intense desire for admiration and esteem, and no appropriate way to get it. When this is combined with a sexual perversion, intelligence and an ability to avoid being caught, there is a potential serial killer, he has said. Dr. Dietz is expected to argue that Mr. Rifkin fits such a pattern.

HEADLINE: Japanese Assail U.S. On Trade

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, May 2

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's decision last week to give the new Government of Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata time to get settled before applying pressure on trade issues has been received here with a palpable sense of relief.
But if the United States thought the bureaucrats who manage Japan's trade policy would also ease up, they will have to think again. The Ministry of International Trade and Industry publicly issued a blistering attack today on a recent Clinton Administration report assessing what the American report calls an array of unfair trading practices by Japan. 
 The Japanese reply, challenging nearly every assertion in the American report, suggests there is little room for compromise and thus sends a troubling signal: Finding a way to reduce Japan's huge trade surplus and give American companies better access to the Japanese market may be no easier under the new Government than it was under the old one.
If anything, the report demonstrates that Japan's bureaucracy is growing more combative in parrying American thrusts on trade.
 
40 Areas Cited in Report
 A wide-ranging series of trade negotiations between Tokyo and Washington broke down in February, and at the end of March the Clinton Administration issued what is called a national trade estimate, analyzing perceived barriers to American companies. The report cited more than 40 areas, from computers to glass, in which it said barriers existed in Japan.
With an American deadline for action rapidly approaching in two areas -- Government procurement of telecommunications and medical equipment -- the Clinton Administration has notified Japan that it will extend the talks. The easing was intended to give the weak minority Government of Mr. Hata, which was assembled on Thursday, more time to establish itself before having to deal with these questions.
But Japan's trade policy is controlled more by the permanent bureaucracy than by politicians, and the bureaucrats' tough stand was clear in the new report.
The report asserts, for instance, that Japan's trade surplus, $130 billion last year, does not prove the markets here are closed. It also asserts that tariffs in Japan are less than half the level of those in the United States and that in some areas, like Government purchases of medical equipment, Japan is actually more open than the United States.
 
Government Budget an Influence
 Economists agree with some of those assertions. Trade imbalances are generally described as the difference between how much a nation saves and how much it invests and spends. Whether a government's budget is in surplus or deficit can have a big influence on the figures.
In addition, some American trade officials have acknowledged that the American report included some areas where there has already been substantial progress or where the proof that barriers exist is slim.
But some trade experts say the Ministry of International Trade and Industry has deliberately offered misleading figures in some of its defenses.
When comparing American, European and Japanese trade patterns, for instance, the ministry arbitrarily eliminates the figures for trade between the United States and Canada and Mexico, and trade between neighboring European countries, on the theory that trade between neighbors is fundamentally different from trade between more widely separated countries. That reduces significantly the evidence of how much America and the European countries import, and thus puts Japan in a better light by comparison.
 
Argument Contradicted
 The ministry's position also contradicts another argument the Japanese have long made, that the world is growing essentially borderless and that trade should not be looked at in bilateral terms, because goods move so easily around the globe these days.
However the validity of the American and Japanese reports is assessed, they leave no doubt that the well of distrust between the world's two economic superpowers is deepening.
In some respects, the arguments sound a lot like those that took place between the United States and the Soviet Union a decade ago, except that instead of debating the arcana of warheads and missiles the two sides are arguing over the arcana of market-share measures.
"The whole point is to increase the foreign share of markets in Japan where real barriers exist," said one American trade official. "Instead, it's become a game of how close they can come to the letter but not the spirit of the agreements we've reached."
 
What Is a Foreign Product?
 Some of the toughest arguments are over how to measure the share of foreign products in various Japanese markets, or, indeed, over what constitutes a foreign product.
Japanese imports have soared over the last decade, but a growing percentage of those imports is made up of products made by Japanese companies in foreign factories.
Honda Accords manufactured in Ohio are now Japan's best-selling imported auto, for example. Does that demonstrate a more open market, or that it is cheaper to produce goods overseas?
Those are the kinds of questions that are likely to dog the relationship between the two countries for months.

HEADLINE: Foolishness, From A to Z

 BODY:
This week House members will decide whether to turn Capitol Hill into a carnival. They will decide whether the "A to Z" spending-cut plan, which a majority of them support, should come to the floor for a vote. Under the bill, the House would engage in a 56-hour orgy of votes on any amendments proposed by individual members that would lower the deficit by cutting spending (no tax hikes allowed).
Its sponsors say the bill would allow individual members to get a public vote on pork-barrel projects that sneak their way into law as part of massive appropriations bills and which the leadership thereafter insulates from review. Amendments would be debated for up to an hour and then voted on. But once the 56 hours are up, the bill calls for voting each remaining amendment up or down without debate. 
 A-to-Z would make for great theater, allowing members to strike out against programs they despise. Its sponsors say the process would root out wasteful programs, like $1 million studies on crossing streets and $200,000 birthday celebrations of Smokey Bear. But urban members could also gang up on farm programs and farm representatives could whack at Medicaid or enterprise zones. Worse yet, the free-for-all could try to overhaul health care, eliminate welfare or balance the budget by constitutional amendment -- momentous decisions that could be taken without debate.
Rapid-fire votes would be fun to watch. But the process would mock sane deliberation. Because amendments would be filed only a day before debate commenced, they would be reviewed by no committee, outside expert or the Congressional Budget Office to see if the promised savings were real or fanciful. The procedure would also be hideously unfair: Members could propose cutting Federal programs, which often target the needy, but they could not propose closing tax loopholes, which disproportionately benefit the rich.
A-to-Z misconceives what is driving up the deficit. It is not discretionary spending; that will, under the 1993 budget act, fall to its lowest level, as a percentage of economic output, in 30 years. Nor is it all entitlement programs, most of which will remain relatively constant. The problem is escalating costs in the two health-related entitlement programs, Medicare and Medicaid. And reforming them will take more than a thoughtless vote on a hastily proposed amendment.
No doubt some of the 232 House members who are backing A-to-Z figured that the leadership would keep the malicious bill off the floor. But under new House rules, all members will be asked this week to publicly declare whether or not the bill should emerge from committee. That will force the uneasy among the sponsors to choose between hypocrisy (by voting to bottle up a bill they themselves are supposedly proposing) or lunacy (by letting the wacky bill reach the floor).

HEADLINE: Fed Wants Us to Think It Fights Inflation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The notion that the Federal Reserve raises interest rates to control inflation has been repeated so often, with the Fed's encouragement, that it has come to be accepted as an economic truth. Raising interest rates may deter inflation slightly given the presence of certain economic circumstances, but that is a possible effect of Fed policy rather than its purpose. 
 Indeed, the specter of inflation is so remote at present that even the Fed cannot pretend its new interest rate rise as reported by you on April 15 is designed to combat visible inflation. The new pretense makes the target "future" inflation and pursuit of an economically "neutral" rather than "stimulative" policy.
To understand the Fed's real purpose in raising rates, one must recognize two things.
First, the Fed is the overseer and protector of the country's banks, deriving its power from how well it takes care to advance the banks' interests. Second, interest charges are prices, exactly like the prices paid for sausages or milk, but these are paid for money borrowed rather than for goods bought.
When the Fed raises its discount rate, it increases its price for the money it lends to the country's banks. When it raises the Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans, it is allowing banks that have surplus cash (because their lending opportunities are lagging behind those of more fortunate banks) to participate in the loan-demand surge being experienced by the better situated banks. And when the banks themselves raise rates, they become more profitable enterprises.
The Fed raises interest rates when the banks make clear that the demand for money is increasing. What the Fed is doing is enabling the banks to profit to the fullest extent that the "traffic will bear," and enabling itself to profit through the higher discount the banks must pay for money they borrow from the Fed to meet the heavier demand they are experiencing from their customers. In turn, the Fed has more money on hand to lend to the banks because of the higher discount rate the Fed itself is charging. The entire banking system, from the Fed on down, is the beneficiary of increased demand for loan funds.
Ultimately, one of two things happens. Either the demand for funds slacks off, or the economy becomes overextended. But only in the latter case does inflation ensue. Given the state of the American economy, that juncture is not visible on the horizon. The Fed delights in casting itself as our economic manager and savior, rather than as the board of directors for the country's money production enterprise -- interested in maximizing profits for the enterprise just like any other enterprise's board.
This sophistry cannot go unchallenged. Raising interest rates is itself inflationary, for interest rates are themselves prices. Moreover, allowing the Fed to perpetuate the myth of its anti-inflationary power and role offers the country false comfort; the Fed's arsenal of counterinflationary "weaponry" is far too limited to prevent the general price level from rising. The American economy is a vast and complex mechanism, whose oscillations cannot be controlled by money manipulation alone, and it is idle for the Fed to pretend otherwise.
 
SAMUEL M. GREENHOUSE
Boca Raton, Fla., April 25, 1994
 
The writer is a retired economist.

HEADLINE: Fed Wants Us to Think It Fights Inflation;
A Genuine Recovery?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your April 22 business section carries a brief article that gives added credence to the aphorism "there are lies, damn lies and statistics." Unless you can pierce the nuances to the raw figures, statistics can be dangerous to your economic health. 
 We are told the jobless rate has fallen to 6.5 percent from 6.8 percent the last few months. But an outplacement consulting firm found that most new jobs were either part-time or temporary positions. It discovered that the daily rate of reductions in the work force was up a whopping 19.9 percent in the first three months of the year compared with the last quarter of 1993, "leaving workers with a pervasive sense of insecurity about their jobs." Even comparing the rate with the rate of cutbacks in the same first quarter of 1993, it was up a significant 13 percent. Discretionary spending could be severely impacted.
Since both Keynesians and supply siders agree that two-thirds of our economy is powered by consumer spending, we may be experiencing a remission, not a genuine recovery. Further impeding a return to better times is the premature concern of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, about inflation, raising interest rates three times in two months. Although I do not question his motives, some respected economists feel higher interest rates are inflationary since a basic cost factor is increased.
 
HERBERT BARCHOFF
New York, April 23, 1994
 
The writer has served on the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

HEADLINE: Russia's Arms Makers Try Change

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: REUTOV, Russia

 BODY:
Inside the gates of a complex where the Soviet Union once developed cold war weapons like cruise missiles and spy satellites, Gerbert A. Yefremov is waging a different kind of battle.
With arms orders having all but disappeared, Mr. Yefremov is trying to reorient the enterprise toward conquering the markets for earth-imaging satellites, solar-power cells, food-preservation equipment, water-purification systems, tinted glass, sailboats -- virtually any commercial product its scientists and engineers can design and produce with their considerable technical skill. 
 At stake for the company he manages, Mashinostroyeniya, are its 6,500 remaining jobs, down from 9,000 a few years ago, in this city 10 miles east of Moscow.
For Russia, Mr. Yefremov's success or failure will be an early test of the country's ability to convert an economy that was largely directed at maintaining military strength into one that can support jobs and create wealth in a free market.
 
Battle for Survival
 "We have always had to compete," Mr. Yefremov said. "Now it's just a different kind of competition."
But even with aid from the West, some of which is on its way, it seems that no more than a handful of Russia's military enterprises can be transformed into makers of quality civilian products at a competitive price.
As a result, even a relatively small company like Mashinostroyeniya may be forced in the long run to slim down to a fraction of its former self. That means the transformation of the military industries will barely alleviate the pain and upheaval that the military-industrial complex seems destined to endure as Russia moves in fits and starts toward a market economy.
To try to ease Russia's conversion, an American program is just getting under way to encourage American companies to seek joint venture partners among Russian military contractors.
Mashinostroyeniya was selected recently by the United States Government to be one of four Russian military complexes to participate in the first round of the program to create and finance commercial joint ventures with American companies. Under the program, which was developed by Defense Secretary William J. Perry and is being managed by the Pentagon and the Commerce Department, the United States will provide a total of $20 million to joint ventures that it judges to be models for further deals.
The other three Russian companies chosen for the program are the State Scientific Research Institute of Aviations Systems and the Istok Electronics plant, both in the Moscow area, and the Leninets plant in St. Petersburg.
 
Benefits Are Cited
 "We would prefer that these factories produce commercial goods rather than weapons of mass destruction," said Barry Carter, an official who oversees the program for the Commerce Department. "These joint ventures help the economy of Russia, and they help the U.S. and the rest of the world through more trade and investment."
Although no precise figures are available, Russia's military industry, which encompasses not just weapons makers but nearly all technology enterprises and a portion of the nation's heavy industry as well, directly employs some five million people, down by more than 1.5 million during the last few years. The industry indirectly supports tens of millions more people in a country with a population of 150 million.
As they struggle to adapt, Mr. Yefremov and his colleagues have ideas aplenty. But money is a different story. Also lacking is experience in sales, distribution, marketing and quality control. Little or no help is available within Russia on those fronts.
So the company's fate may ultimately turn on its ability to convince American and other Western companies that Mashinostroyeniya is an attractive investment and joint venture partner.
 
Some High Hurdles
 The hurdles to attracting Western help are numerous. Among them are the same problems afflicting all foreign investors here, including the lack of an established commercial legal system and a political climate in which Westerners are increasingly branded as greedy carpetbaggers. There are also problems more specific to Russian military contractors, like the lack of patents for most technologies and the slow pace of privatization.
Mashinostroyeniya -- the Russian name means machine-building, short for the company's full title, Scientific Production Machine-Building Association -- has more of a fighting chance than most Russian military enterprises. Representatives of several dozen Western companies and consulting firms have trooped through its labs here during the last several years. Some of them, like the Loral Corporation, a big military contractor and builder of satellites, based in New York, have expressed interest in the Russian enterprise.
"Mashinostroyeniya will survive and thrive because of the excellence of their technology and their devotion to the economic applications of high technology," said Clark C. Abt, director of the Defense Technology Conversion Center at Boston University, who has visited the company several times.
Even outside the auspices of the United States Government's program, American and other Western companies are combing Russia these days for opportunities to do deals with the once-mighty military industry. Booz, Allen & Hamilton, the New York consulting firm, is working on a project financed by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to bring Western companies together with Russian radar and electronics producers to rebuild Russia's aging air-traffic control system.
 
Programs in the Works
 Dresser Industries of Dallas is considering making gas turbines with the Kirov military plant in St. Petersburg. Brown & Root, the oilfield services company based in Houston, is considering building offshore oil platforms and ships at the Severodvinsk shipyard, a center of nuclear submarine production that has fallen on hard times.
"These are state-of-the-art companies with no market," said Bill Hankinson, who heads Brown & Root's operation in the former Soviet Union.
But if the wreckage of the Soviet military machine holds promising business opportunities for Western companies, it is less clear whether any more than a relative handful of the most technologically advanced and entrepreneurial military enterprises can transform themselves into commercially viable companies, with or without American aid.
After all, an American executive here said, only a few big military contractors in the United States have managed to convert to large-scale commercial production, and they face a decline in military spending far less precipitous than that faced by their counterparts in Russia.
Western executives said most big military enterprises in Russia had only one or two technologies or product lines that could become viable commercial businesses. While some may need considerable numbers of production-line workers or engineers, many others will not. The Polaroid Corporation's joint venture making circuit boards at the Signal plant in Obninsk employs only 120 of the enterprise's 5,000 workers.
Mashinostroyeniya is using only 10 percent of its production capacity for Government orders and has only scattered commercial business, like assembling telephones for Siemens, the German company.
 
Glory Days Recalled
 Its current scramble for survival is a sharp contrast to Mashinostroyeniya's glory-filled past. Run for three decades by one of the Soviet Union's best-known engineers, Vladimir N. Chelomey, the enterprise had a hand in some of the nation's technological breakthroughs, including the development of the cruise missile, the design of the Salyut space station and the production of highly classified spy satellites. As leader of the Soviet Union during the 1950's, Nikita S. Khrushchev sent his son, Sergei, an engineer, to work there.
Mr. Yefremov, a genial engineer who has run the company since Mr. Chelomey's death in 1984, said he saw Mashinostroyeniya's future as a holding company overseeing a number of businesses based on some of the company's technological skills.
"We don't want to just build irons," he said. "Our wealth is not in money -- that's what we lack -- but we have real wealth in our people and our technology. That's where we start."
He said he was particularly hopeful about the company's abilities in designing and building satellites. Mr. Yefremov said he wanted to pursue a joint venture with Loral to design a telecommunications satellite at a lower cost than Western companies could achieve.
But Mr. Abt of Boston University said the enterprise's most impressive technology was based on its experience in reconnaissance satellites. He said that through its Almaz satellite program, the company had considerable skill in all-weather high-resolution radar imaging as well as in optical reconnaissance.
 
Technology's Commercial Use
 Such technologies -- which largely remain classified in the United States -- have a wide range of commercial uses, he said, including air-traffic control, pinpointing sources of pollution and agricultural forecasting. Mr. Yefremov said he was working with an American investment group to sell satellite images.
American companies have also shown considerable interest in the company's technology for solar batteries, which some experts say could be produced in Russia at far lower cost than in the West.
Mr. Yefremov said he was "100 percent optimistic" about the company's prospects. But, sounding like a far more experienced entrepreneur than he is, he said the process of conversion would be a difficult one.
"The world market existed for many years without us," he said. "Nobody was waiting for us, and nobody is going to make room for us."
