HEADLINE: A Bitter Debate Over Italy's Fininvest

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ROME, May 2

 BODY:
With Silvio Berlusconi set to become Italy's next Prime Minister, his future seems clear. What is perhaps less clear is the future of the company he owns, Fininvest S.p.A..
While Mr. Berlusconi struggles to assemble a cabinet, Fininvest is struggling with $2.3 billion of debt, amassed during its heady growth years in the 1980's. 
 While his political aides work to reinvent Italy, Fininvest, whose $7 billion in sales make it Italy's second-largest privately owned company, after Fiat, and Europe's second-largest media group, after Bertelsmann of Germany, is struggling to reinvent itself as a lean, professionally managed company. It aims to seize the day as Italy emerges from recession, and as Fininvest's main markets, notably television, transform themselves.
This has put Fininvest at the heart of a bitter debate. After all, Mr. Berlusconi's critics say, isn't his becoming Prime Minister a bit like Ted Turner's becoming President of the United States, and holding onto his television stations? The difference is that Fininvest, in addition to controlling roughly half of Italy's television market, also controls the publishing houses Mondadori and Einaudi, 34 magazines and a handful of daily papers, financial services companies, a department store chain called Standa with 15,000 employees, and champion soccer, hockey and handball teams.
To get Italy's economy purring again, Mr. Berlusconi, who stepped down as Fininvest's chairman to enter politics, has pledged to deregulate vast areas of business from telecommunications to financial services to retail trade. The problem is that these are all areas where his companies are strongest.
The potential of these markets illustrates the possible areas for conflict of interest imbedded in the dual role of Mr. Berlusconi, because his Government will have to fill in the legislative blanks required to regulate these new markets.
"There will always remain a shadow of suspicion on the decisions of this Government," said Antonio Pilati, the director of the Institute for the Economics of the Media in Milan.
Suspicion might be milder were Mr. Berlusconi's business empire in better shape. But the pinch of recession, plus management problems resulting from rapid growth in the fat years, have left Fininvest in financial straits. The critics of Mr. Berlusconi are already accusing him of extending political favors in exchange for new investment from Mediobanca, the Italian investment bank that holds the key to Italian financial markets.
On Thursday, Mr. Berlusconi named three legal scholars to draft a law against conflicts of interest. His opponents were unimpressed, contending that this was, in effect, the wolf appointing the shepherds.
Paradoxically, the largest problem facing Fininvest, whose shares are wholly owned by Mr. Berlusconi either directly or through fiduciary companies, may prove in the end to be the loss of Mr. Berlusconi himself.
Last January, when he resigned as chairman, he turned to Fedele Confalonieri, an old school friend, and Francesco Tato, a tough executive with a reputation as a turnaround artist, to clean up his company.
 
A Clash of Cultures
 Mr. Confalonieri, at 56, represents Fininvest's club of old boys who held tight to their seats while the group grew at dizzying rates. But that culture of size clashes with Mr. Tato's culture. He entered Fininvest from Mondadori six months ago, and his specialty is trimming fat and tightening management.
"It was all easier when he was here, than now that he's not here," Mr. Tato said of Mr. Berlusconi. "It leaves us with the problem of changes that are necessary, without his charismatic imprint."
The real doubts about Fininvest arose last year, when, according to Mr. Tato, Mr. Berlusconi decided someone had to sort out his company's jumbled holdings.
"For 12 years, we were expanding at all costs," Mr. Tato said, in an interview at Fininvest's Milan headquarters. "When you're in the rage of development, you tend to make mistakes. When you have 20 percent growth and cash flow, why bother?"
Even so, Mr. Tato added, "The company is extremely successful. It has stamina, it has culture."
 
High Marks on Investments
 Indeed, analysts give Mr. Berlusconi high marks for his investment choices. He moved aggressively into financial services like insurance and funds, when these markets were exploding in Italy. He bought into Standa and several strong advertising agencies just as Italian retailing began to transform itself away from mom-and-pop stores.
He moved with imagination and vigor, and some would say political cunning, to develop private television, and in 1991 paid $600 million for Mondadori's publishing empire.
"At the end of the day, they're a good group of companies at the individual level," said Dagmar Bottenbruch, a corporate finance specialist at Credit Suisse First Boston in Milan.
 
Assembled for Tax Purposes
 By the late 1980's, however, the advertising market was saturated, and recession was crimping consumer spending, and with it Fininvest's cash flow. Moreover, the tangled group of companies was largely assembled to dodge convoluted Italian tax laws. Thus, while debt was amassed at the top, taxes were paid at the operating level, meaning little cash percolated up to meet huge interest payments.
By 1992, the last year for which there are reliable figures, the problem was enormous. Fininvest declared $12 million in net earnings, but Mr. Tato acknowledged it could do so only by claiming extraordinary asset gains that amounted that year to about $142 million. He insists all the operating companies are now profitable, and lower interest rates have reduced debt service; still, the situation has not dramatically improved.
Indeed, six months ago few in Italy were betting on Mr. Berlusconi. Besides the debt, several company executives, including Mr. Berlusconi's brother Paolo, were under investigation in Italy's big payments-for-favors scandals. With national elections scheduled for this year, the country seemed headed toward a leftist-led government, promising a shake-up of private television, the linchpin of Mr. Berlusconi's business.
More significantly perhaps, Mr. Berlusconi's debt was concentrated at major Italian banks led by Mediobanca and its 86-year-old honorary chairman, Enrico Cuccia, the quiet godfather of Italian finance.
 
The Fall of Ferruzzi
 In the 1980's, only two Italian businessmen of size, Mr. Berlusconi and Raul Gardini, the head of the big Ferruzzi industrial group, remained aloof from the circle of industrialists around Mr. Cuccia. When Ferruzzi collapsed last year, dumping billions of dollars of debt onto the banks, and prompting Mr. Gardini's suicide, many believed Fininvest would be the next to go under.
But last October, Mr. Berlusconi called in Mr. Tato, 61, a veteran of the big Olivetti electronics group, which has long been considered one of Italy's best management schools.
A lean man with a bright smile, who negotiates as readily in English or German as his native Italian, Mr. Tato is called "Der Kaiser" for his success in turning around Germany's sleepy Kienzle computer company, after it was acquired in 1982 by the Mannesmann steel group, and Triumph-Adler, which Olivetti purchased in 1986 from Volkswagen.
Mr. Tato says his task is essentially twofold:
First, he intends to trim Fininvest to a financial holding company by transferring operating activities like administration and data processing, and much of the group debt, to the operating companies, and installing effective managers to create four large groups: publishing, financial products, retailing and television.
 
Taking Companies Public
 Once this is accomplished, he said, the idea is to take these companies public, reducing Fininvest's stake and broadening the shareholder base, while raising capital to reduce the debt. The first big step came last week, when Fininvest announced it was uniting its publishing interests in the Mondadori group, and floating a 53 percent stake on the stock market, which, Mr. Tato said, would net Fininvest between $467 million and $545 million.
The lead role of Mediobanca in placing the shares signaled the reconciliation of Mr. Berlusconi and Mr. Cuccia.
Analysts say Fininvest's overhaul assumes particular urgency because of the fast pace of change in Italian telecommunications, as illustrated by the deal announced last week by Bell Atlantic and another of Italy's telecommunications giants, Societa Telefonica per Azioni, or STET, to develop interactive telecommunications systems.
In Italy, as in the United States, advertisng revenues no longer suffice to finance the growth of television services, according to Mr. Pilati. Yet, with an obsolete television broadcasting system and no cable or satellite services, Italy will require a vast investment in pay television to raise the cash needed for new video services that link cable or phone lines and computers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: New Fininvest Team -- Italy's Prime Minister-designate Silvio Berlusconi, left (Associated Press), has stepped down as chairman of Fininvest, Italy's second largest private company, after Fiat, and turned over its management to Fedele Confalonieri, lower left (Gaetano di Filippo/Daylight), and Francesco Tato, below. HEADLINE: AGENCY OFFERING AN AID BLUEPRINT FOR PALESTINIANS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
The World Bank unveiled a three-year, $1.2 billion program today, worked out with the Palestine Liberation Organization, to quickly lay an economic foundation for Palestinian self-rule in the Gaza Strip and Jericho.
Last Oct. 1, the United States organized a meeting of 40 donor countries, which pledged $2.4 billion to support the new Palestinian authority in the former Israeli-occupied areas. 
 Since then, the World Bank and economic experts from the P.L.O. have been working on a program that would take these diverse and often vague pledges and forge them into a coherent, detailed plan for economic development -- identifying the major needs, specifying how the money should be spent, eliminating duplication and setting clear priorities.
This program is expected to begin almost immediately after the planned signing in Cairo Wednesday of the full Israeli-P.L.O. accord governing the transfer of Gaza and Jericho to Palestinian self-rule. The first steps in the economic program will involve the laying of sewers and construction of waste-disposal facilities in Gaza and Jericho.
Other projects -- for improving housing, roads, health centers, telecommunications and water -- will follow as soon as the engineering studies are completed.
"If the peace process has any hope of success, the Palestinians need to see improvements in their living conditions very quickly," said Caio Koch-Weser, the World Bank vice president for the Mideast and North Africa.
"The program and the funds behind it," he said, "are for the immediate needs of the Palestinians and will help create a new physical and social infrastructure, provided political stability can be maintained. But unless there is a visible improvement in social and economic conditions, in an equitable way, the very foundations of peace will be undermined."
The World Bank plan, released today, details how to spend half of the $2.4 billion over the next three years, and the rest later. The plan will be carried out by the P.L.O.'s Economic Council for Development and Reconstruction, based in Jericho, in cooperation with the World Bank, Israel and the donor nations.
World Bank officials caution that poverty will not be eliminated in Gaza and Jericho in one year, where the per-capita income is $1,275. But they have to start somewhere.
While these officials would not say so, the plan provides both a blueprint for Palestinian economic development and a straitjacket intended to prevent corruption or the creation of show projects that are not economically viable.
The P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, would have preferred a looser arrangement, under which the P.L.O. received money directly from donors to spend as it saw fit, and would have allowed Palestinian ministries to make deals with individual nations for projects. But such an approach can invite payoffs, kickbacks and the sort of uncontrolled development that has plagued other Mideast nations.
This plan stipulates that any contracts financed or co-financed by the World Bank must be put up for competitive bidding, and there are tight rules for maintaining accountability.
 
Meat and Muscle
 The connection between these projects and the Palestinian-Israeli economic agreement signed in Paris on Friday is this: the Paris accord basically established the rules in which the new Palestinian economy would operate -- what taxes can be collected, how many banks can open, what tariffs can be charged, from where oil is to be imported, and generally how the Palestinian administration will relate to Israel's economy. That was the skeleton for the Palestinian economy, and the World Bank program is the meat and muscle the Palestinians and the donor countries hope to put on that skeleton.
In its first three years, the Emergency Assistance Program for the Occupied Territories, as it is formally called, is made up of these elements:
*A total of $600 million will initially be spent on public investment in housing, transportation, sanitation, health, education, telecommunications, roads, electricity, agriculture and water projects. The West Bank will receive $366 million, and Gaza will get $234 million.
*A total of $225 million will be spent on start-up costs for the central government, police force and other public institutions in Gaza and Jericho, as well as support for non-governmental relief organizations working there. The Palestinians plan to create a central administration to take over functions of daily life now performed by the Israeli civil administration. They will need money to establish their own bureau of statistics, budget office and data collection.
*A total of $300 million will be spent to stimulate private investment in telecommunications, housing, agriculture and industry. This will involve financing to local credit institutions, developing a central Palestinian bank-supervisory agency and developing a uniform legal and regulatory framework to assure investors that property rights and contracts will be respected and enforced.
*About $75 million will go for technical advice, ranging from helping Palestinians devise certain political institutions to undertaking feasibility studies and project preparation for further economic development.
The underlying objective of all the projects is to stimulate job growth. A report issued today by the International Labor Organization said that at least a quarter of the labor force in the occupied territories is already out of work, and joblessness exceeds 40 percent in Gaza alone.
World Bank experts hope that the Palestinians will avoid some of the mistakes that Arab governments have made in economic development. Economists say the Palestinians have one advantage of being economically underdeveloped: They can start from scratch in many areas. The hope is that they can be induced to follow the model of the East Asian economies, with their emphasis on private investment, personal saving and education, rather than that of Syria, Jordan and Egypt, with their legacies of socialism, government intervention and dependence on aid.
This plan is intended to help foster a Palestinian economy in which the balance between public and private investment will be clearly tilted toward the private sector as the engine of economic growth, as is the case in East Asia. The plan assumes an economy with an open trading system and a non-protectionist approach to industrial development.

HEADLINE: White House Not Ruling Out Force in Haiti

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
President Clinton's national security advisers say they are reconsidering whether to use force to oust Haiti's military leaders, a threat that could satisfy mounting pressure from members of Congress and toughen the additional sanctions that the United Nations is expected to impose on Haiti this week.
A senior adviser to the President said today that no decision had been made about whether the United States would seek to remove the military government headed by Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras in order to restore the democratically elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, or how to do that. It is unclear whether there has been a change of heart by Administration officials who all but rejected the military option as recently as a few weeks ago. 
 White House officials who briefed members of Congress on the revised sanctions policy last week were surprised that lawmakers now consider tightening the embargo on Haiti to be an outdated approach.
Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, who attended the meeting, said he and others had advised Samuel I. Berger, the deputy national security adviser, and Strobe Talbott, the Deputy Secretary of State, not to close off military options.
 
Focus Primarily Diplomatic
 In an interview today, Senator Graham said he had told the officials: "I have come to conclude that if your objective is the restoration of Aristide, then that objective must be matched with the means to accomplish it. At this point, the only means is a credible threat and a willingness to use military action."
Administration officials, however, say they are focusing primarily on diplomacy, expanding sanctions, increasing aid to feed 1.2 million of Haiti's 6.4 million people and sending international and United Nations officials to monitor human rights.
Administration officials stressed that Mr. Clinton is still some distance away from deciding for or against the use of force. But Pentagon officials said they had begun some preliminary planning aimed primarily at signaling the Haitian military about the seriousness of United States intent.
Such a move would also let the White House show Mr. Clinton's domestic critics that it is serious about returning Father Aristide to power.
One sign that the United States still has not made up its mind is the absence of serious pressure on the Dominican Republic to stanch the flow of gasoline and oil over the border into Haiti.
The State Department had asked President Joaquin Balaguer of the Dominican Republic to comply, but one senior department official said that Mr. Balaguer had responded that "there is nothing to discuss" until after elections there on May 18.

HEADLINE: Clinton Makes No Progress With Beijing

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
With a month to go before he must decide whether to renew China's preferential trade status, President Clinton made no progress during a meeting today with a top Chinese official toward resolving differences between the two countries over human rights.
In a written statement, the White House said Mr. Clinton had reminded Deputy Prime Minister Zou Jiahua of his insistence that China do more to improve its human rights record by the June 3 deadline. But senior White House officials said later that Mr. Zou had simply reasserted Beijing's view that the United States should not interfere in its internal affairs. 
 "They sort of talked a little bit past each other," a senior White House official said after the 40-minute meeting in the Oval Office. Dee Dee Myers, the White House spokeswoman, described the session as "businesslike," but other American officials called it stiff and uncomfortable.
 
Follows Christopher's Visit
 The meeting was the first between Mr. Clinton and a top Chinese official since his discussions with President Jiang Zemin at an Asian summit meeting in November, and comes six weeks after Secretary of State Warren Christopher met with Chinese intransigence in four days of human rights talks in Beijing.
Administration officials said it would almost certainly be the last such meeting before Mr. Clinton must decide whether and under what terms to renew China's favored trade status, and they expressed disappointment that Mr. Zou had not been more conciliatory.
The officials described Mr. Zou as among the more hard-line members of the current Chinese leadership, and they expressed continued hope that Beijing would ultimately give the Administration the political cover it needed to extend China's most-favored-nation status, which entitles it to export its products to the United States at the lowest possible tariff rates.
With the Chinese economy growing faster than that of any other nation, Mr. Clinton and his aides have no appetite for choking off trade by withdrawing China's preferential trade status.
 
Discussions With Democrats
 In private, White House officials have said they now see the question as not whether the status should be renewed, but under what terms, and they have been consulting with Democratic advocates of a tough policy toward China about a compromise that would allow a considerable amount of trade to continue even if China fails to meet the Administration's human rights objectives.
Today, in a sign of their unwillingness to risk a new rupture in the fragile relationship, Administration officials declined to speak publicly about the Chinese position, and the White House did not permit reporters and photographers to question either Mr. Clinton or Mr. Zou.
That followed Mr. Clinton's decision on Saturday to postpone until June 30 a decision on whether to designate China as one of the world's worst pirates of American recordings and software, a step that could subject it to trade sanctions.
White House officials said the President had sided on Saturday afternoon with Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and others who warned against injecting new tensions in United States-Chinese relations.

HEADLINE: Puzzling Currency Move;
The Dollar Was Supposed to Rise. It Fell. The Answer May Lie in New Expectations.

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
The biggest question on the minds of many market analysts last week was this: How could it be that American interest rates were rising and yet the dollar was suddenly falling against both the Japanese yen and the German mark?
Normally, when American interest rates rise, the expectation is that the dollar will get stronger, because Germans and Japanese will want to buy dollars to put them in American banks or bonds to take advantage of the higher interest returns. But instead, it went the other way. 
 The answer to this puzzle may be an interesting lesson in the economics of expectations, and in today's global marketplace the hunch, the hope, the intuition and the expectation have a whole new meaning and impact. Why? Because when a few market leaders get a hunch and the herd follows, money managers and speculators can move so much capital so quickly in and out of markets in search of short-term gains that it can be highly destabilizing for any currency that finds itself under attack.
Despite the Clinton Administration's efforts to prop up the dollar on Friday, it continued to lose ground today. In New York, the dollar fell to 1.6491 marks, from 1.6540 on Friday, and slipped slightly to 101.67 yen from 101.70. [Page C17.]
Even though American interest rates have been rising, traders say that their expectation was that with both President Clinton and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen calling for a cap on further increases, American interest rates had probably peaked, or nearly so.
Meanwhile, other very different expectations were evolving regarding Japan and Germany. Last week, Japan finally got a new Government together under Prime Minister Tutsomu Hata, but it was a minority Government, put together with Scotch tape and filled with all sorts of factions, making it so fragile that many expect to count its life span in weeks, not years or even months.
The expectation created by that Government was that it would be a long time before Japan was able to meet even the minimum demands being put forward by the Clinton Administration for opening certain of its key markets. Therefore, trade tensions will continue between the two countries, and the United States will continue trying to force Japan to open markets by keeping the dollar weak and the yen strong.
When the dollar is cheap it means American exports are cheap and easier to penetrate the Japanese market; when the yen is strong it is much harder for the Japanese to sell abroad.
So while the higher American interest rates may have created the apparent expectation that the dollar would strengthen, the real expectation of the marketplace was that the trend of upward rates was probably approaching its limit and could therefore be discounted.
 
Shifts Termed Relative
 At the same time, the creation of a weak Japanese Government only reinforced and extended the expectation in the marketplace that the United States would tacitly support a weak dollar and strong yen. Therefore, even though American interest rates may be marginally higher than Japan's in nominal terms, the potential for making money in the currency markets from a stronger yen seemed to some to be far greater than what could be expected from any further increases in American interest rates.
One American official stressed that all these shifts in expectations were relative. They may apply at any one time to only some big investors, who may help push a currency up or down. But clearly, if everyone felt the same way, a currency would move much more sharply than the dollar did last week. Nevertheless, even subtle changes in expectations when married to huge amounts of money can have a big market impact.
That is why the Clinton Administration decided it had to break the psychology of expectations, by supporting the dollar. In its public statement, the Administration said that it was intervening in the markets because they had become "disorderly" -- meaning that the dollar was falling too far too quickly.
Officials said they wanted to signal the market unequivocally: the United States is not relying on a policy of further weakening the dollar to address its trade problems with Japan.
While most American officials considered this a big deal, some analysts and traders were not particularly impressed with the American intervention. They said they found it rather timid and tentative and they expected that the dollar could well be tested again very soon. The fact that the dollar inched down still further today certainly reinforced that view.
"If you are going to intervene to stabilize a currency, you have to do it massively, with a good deal of coordination with other major central banks, and in a way that really threatens market participants, otherwise they will test you again and again," said Henry Kaufman, the market analyst who runs his own investment firm. "You have to tell the market: 'If you are going to speculate, it is going to cost you.' You have to be ready to take away a good deal of the money that these speculators are ready to commit to this kind of activity. Instead, the only message was that the U.S. Government doesn't like disorder. There was a lack of conviction behind it."
The Federal Reserve has to be "ready to go for the jugular" of market speculators with the same ruthlessness as they are ready to attack a currency and ride a profit, Mr. Kaufman added, otherwise it will not be taken seriously in the long run.
As for the mark, the expectations of the marketplace seemed to have turned sharply there as well. Indeed, American officials said they had to prop up the dollar much more against the mark than against the yen. Several traders say that the conventional wisdom these days is that the German recession has clearly bottomed out. Germany is headed for growth this year of about 1.5 percent, with inflation either flat or heading down.
 
German Recovery Expected
 Reports from Germany today said corporate order books were filling up again, industry was working at higher capacity and companies were reporting sharp gains in profits and sales for the first quarter of the year. Finance Minister Theo Waigel told Parliament last week that another economic miracle was on the way, similar to Germany's soaring recovery after World War II.
As the market digested this information in the last week or so it produced a set of new relative expectations about the relationship between the mark and the dollar, and not surprisingly many investment funds were reported to be stocking up on German bonds and equities. In today's electronic global Monopoly game, the push of only a few buttons can suddenly set off a wave of dollar-selling and mark buying -- as it did last week.
The only good news in all this, one senior American official said, is that next week expectations can change back just as quickly in the dollar's favor, and the electronic herd will be sure to follow.

SUSPENDED DRIVER KILLS 3 IN A FAMILY

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Airport-Opening Delay Is a Jolt to Bondholders

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bondholders in Denver's new $3.2 billion airport were jolted yesterday with the announcement of yet another delay in the opening. The publicly traded revenue bonds that financed the construction dropped as much as one point in trading in the municipal bond market.
Analysts note that with each delay of the airport's opening the investment risks increase. 
 The opening has already been delayed three times, and a fourth delay is expected to prompt credit rating companies to cut their ratings on Denver airport bonds. Some investors yesterday sold the bonds amid concern the debt will slip to non-investment grade, or junk-bond, status, traders said.
Mayor Wellington Webb of Denver announced late yesterday that the airport's opening would be delayed indefinitely because the computerized baggage system did not meet the requirements of the city or the airlines.
While the "short-term consequences would be unpleasant at best," he said, a premature opening "would be disastrous."
The city's revenue director, Patricia Schwartzberg, said the cost of the delay was expected to create a shortfall of $16 million to $17 million a month for the city, but that United Airlines, the major hub operator there, has agreed to cover its full share of those costs, which will be about $8.8 million a month for three months. The other airlines that operate at Denver will be required to cover the rest of the costs, either before the airport opens or afterward, in the form of higher fees.
Yields on most of the airport's actively traded bonds rose as much as 10 basis points, said one trader. At Goldman, Sachs's trading desk a 6.75 percent Denver airport bond due in 2022 was off about 1/2, to 89 5/8, to yield 7.65 percent.
The same bond back in December 1992 was trading at 95 to yield 7.13 percent and in June 1993 it was at a price of 102 1/8 to yield 6.59 percent.
Mark Webber, a vice president and senior fixed-income analyst at Kemper Securities, said that when compared to the Bond Buyer index of 25 revenue bonds, the yield spread of the 6.75 percent bond was 60 basis points over the index in January. That spread has more than doubled since than and was 130 basis points over by the end of last month. The widening of this spread is a measure of how much the value of the bonds has dropped just because of the opening delays and other problems with the airport.
 
Delay in Opening Airport
 The last delay in opening the airport, which was then due to open March 9, prompted the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Moody's to warn that further delays would likely result in lower ratings on the airport's revenue bonds.
Standard & Poor's rates the bonds BBB, one notch up from its lowest investment grade. Ernie Perez, an analyst with S.& P., said that in addition to the cost of the delay in opening the airport, S.& P. was concerned about other future financial uncertainties if the airport did not meet projected operational measures, including passenger traffic. "This could negatively impact overall costs, which are capped by the airline agreement at $20 per plane passenger in 1990 dollars and future decisions by airlines to serve the airport," he said. He also said that S.& P.'s rating decision would be based on the course of action taken by the city.
Moody's Investors said yesterday that it was reviewing its conditional Baa-1 rating on Denver airport for a possible downgrade. A lower rating may be assigned as early as today, they said.
While large institutions were not trying to sell their Denver airport bonds, traders said, some individual investors and mutual funds did try. About $20 million of the bonds were offered for sale in the secondary market, with one fund offering $3 million of Denver airport bonds for sale, traders said.
Denver International originally was scheduled to open in October 1993. Construction delays and baggage system problems pushed the date to December, then March and finally May 15.
The construction of the airport, the first new one in the nation in 20 years, was financed mostly with revenue bonds. Bonds sold in 1985 were used for land acquisition and were followed by the first project bond sale in 1990 and then in 1992.
The bonds are expected to be repaid by revenue generated from fees from the airlines using the airport and its other revenues. The city is not obligated to repay the bonds should airport revenues fail to meet operating costs and debt service once the new airport is open.
 
Treasury Market
 Elsewhere, prices of Treasury securities sagged after the National Association of Purchasing Management index came in higher than expected. Traders and investors are still uneasy following the dollar's slide in the currency markets last week.
By late in the day the 30-year bond was down 10/32 , to 872/32 , or to 7.33 percent, from 7.30 percent on Friday.
James Hale, an analyst of fixed- income securities for MMS International, said: "The bond market extended its losses after the data, which was a mixed bag, with the N.A.P.M. employment figure rather impressive. But the slight decline in prices was something of a relief. As for construction spending, the headline figure for March was certainly below expectations, but most of the shortfall was in public construction, which unexpectedly fell 2.7 percent, while private construction was up a solid 2 percent."
The production index fell to 62.7 in April from 64 the prior month. The price component, which reflects inflationary pressures, fell slightly to 63.2 from 64.2.
The April rise in manufacturing employment in the N.A.P.M. data was the first increase in more than five years. That was bearish news for bonds as was the fact that new orders remained strong and the backlog of orders rose significantly, suggesting continued economic growth for the immediate future.
United States March construction spending rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, far less than the 1.2 percent gain forecast. February was revised slightly higher to a 1 percent decline from the 1.2 percent drop earlier reported.

HEADLINE: New York Agrees to Build Prison's Kitchen in Bronx

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Under pressure from a court order and state lawmakers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to add $128 million to New York City's capital budget to build a giant kitchen in the Bronx that would prepare food for prisoners on Rikers Island, mayoral aides said yesterday.
The new expenditure is part of nearly $500 million in budget additions and restorations that Mr. Giuliani will announce today in his proposed $18.8 billion capital spending plan for the next four years, the officials said. The new projects will not affect the city's debt payments, senior aides said, because of savings from bond refinancings. 
 By building the kitchen in the city, Mr. Giuliani would reverse the decision of Mayor David N. Dinkins, who argued it would be less expensive to buy frozen dinners instead from a state-run kitchen in Orangeburg, N.Y.
 
$20 Million for Food
 Complying with a court order to improve the food at the jail complex, the Dinkins administration had decided last November to pay the State Department of Mental Health about $20 million a year to provide food from its kitchen in Orangeburg, in Rockland County. As part of the agreement, the state would have spent $4.5 million to expand the kitchen.
But in early April, the Legislature voted against allowing the department to spend the money after Bronx legislators and the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver of Manhattan, raised objections, saying hundreds of potential jobs would be lost to the Orangeburg center. The Bronx, they argued, with its proximity to Rikers Island, has many potential sites, among them the Hunts Point Produce Market, at 331 Tiffany Street.
Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers said the Mayor agreed with them. Although the Dinkins administration had determined it would be far less expensive to truck the food into the city, it did not take into account the 427 jobs that would be created at the kitchen and elsewhere in the city or the ripple effect of those jobs on the economy, Mr. Powers said.
Mr. Powers said creating jobs in Rockland County would "send an inconsistent message" to the businesses that Mr. Giuliani has been trying to retain in the city. He said the city would put out a request for proposals from private companies that want to build the kitchen.
"It upset me because I saw us as having a message because New York is open for business again and we go to Rockland County," he said. "I felt the responsibility to keep the jobs here."
 
A 1995 Deadline
 The city is under a 1979 Federal order to change the way it prepares the meals as a result of a lawsuit filed for inmates by the Legal Aid Society after a series of riots in the 1970's. The suit complained about a variety of conditions, including food, cleanliness and visiting hours. The order set a deadline of September 1995.
The Dinkins agreement had defended its agreement with the State Department of Mental Health, saying it would insure that the city could comply with the court order and not be at risk of a strike or a business failure crippling whatever private company provided food to the jails.
Besides the new kitchen building, officials said the capital budget would include increases of about $50 million for repairs to the Williamsburg Bridge, about $20 million for repairs to the Queensboro Bridge, about $50 million for upgrading city computer systems, about $35 million for costs associated with an economic development project on 42d Street, and about $50 million for various Sanitation Department costs, including some new garbage trucks and a system to control water at the Fresh Kills Landfill.
 
No Police Academy
 Despite the additions, the budget still will not include financing for a new police academy in the Bronx, a politically popular project which Mr. Giuliani cut in February, officials said.
Nor will the plan include additional money for capital projects in the subway system or in the school system, despite calls for more construction dollars from both the Transit Authority and the Board of Education, officials said.
Money for rebuilding the Kings County Hospital Center will remain in the capital budget at the same level, but it will not be spent until a special task force that is re-examining the troubled project finishes its work sometime this summer, officials said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Again vs. Mark As Fed Remains on Sidelines

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the German mark yesterday for the seventh straight trading session as confidence in the American currency continued to wane and the Federal Reserve made no apparent effort to stem its slide.
On Friday, The Fed bought dollars for marks and Japanese yen after the dollar fell to a six-month low against the mark and an eight-month low against the yen. Now traders are waiting to see if the Fed is willing to defend the dollar again. 
 "People are testing the Fed's resolve," said Albert Soria, foreign-exchange manager at Kansallis Osake Pankki, a Finnish bank in New York. "Right now, there's no reason to buy dollars."
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6491 marks, down from 1.6540 marks on Friday. It was little changed at 101.67 yen, down from 101.70 yen. Trading was less active than usual because London, the world's largest foreign-exchange center, was closed for a bank holiday.
Many traders have become bearish on the dollar because it failed to rally in the first four months of the year, even though German interest rates fell and American interest rates rose, which should have made dollar-denominated assets more attractive to investors.
"The dollar is a dog right now," said David De Rosa, director of foreign-exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation. "Everything looked good for the buck, and it couldn't go higher. Now people are selling it."
The Fed raised its interest rate on overnight bank loans three times this year, lifting the Federal funds rate to 3.75 percent from 3 percent. But instead of following interest rates higher, the dollar has fallen about 5 percent against the mark and 9 percent against the yen since Jan. 1.
The Fed's dollar purchases on Friday failed to halt the currency's slide, in part because many traders did not expect the Fed to buy again unless the dollar's weakness took a toll on the Treasury market, the way it did last week.
"The Fed bought dollars to calm jittery stock and bond markets, not to defend specific exchange rates," said Lisa Finstrom, currency analyst at Smith Barney Shearson.
The Fed made no apparent effort to support the dollar yesterday, traders said. On Friday, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen announced that the Fed was buying dollars to "counter disorderly conditions." The Fed usually does not discuss its activities in the foreign-exchange market.
Bond prices fell during the last three trading days amid concern that a weaker dollar would diminish the value of American assets and worsen inflation by driving up prices for imports.
Elsewhere, the Venezuelan bolivar fell almost 3 percent against the dollar today amid concern that Venezuela's Government would impose restrictions on foreign exchange or devalue the currency. The bolivar was last quoted at 127 to the dollar bid and 128 offered, down from 124 offered late Friday.
The British pound fell to $1.5162, from $1.5185 late Friday. The dollar fell to 5.6485 French francs, from 5.6645 francs on Friday. It was steady at 1.4030 Swiss francs and 1,588 Italian lire. The Canadian dollar was little changed at 72.34 United States cents.

HEADLINE: Factory Data Were Strong During April

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
Manufacturing expanded for the eighth straight month in April, with the strongest showing in manufacturing employment in five years, the National Association of Purchasing Management said today.
In another report, the Commerce Department said today that construction spending rose eight-tenths of a percent in March, reversing two months of weather-related declines. 
 The purchasing managers' index -- a gauge of factory production, orders, employment and prices -- rose to 57.7 last month from 56.7 in March. A reading of 50 or more indicates the manufacturing economy is expanding.
Growth in heavy industry "edged forward in April after stabilizing in March and brought with it the first increase in manufacturing employment in more than five years," Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the association's survey committee, said.
 
17 Report Improvement
 Of the 20 manufacturing industries surveyed, 17 reported an overall improvement from March, the most to report improving conditions from the previous month since the association began tracking specific industries in March 1990.
The report "seems to be consistent with reasonably strong but not blockbuster growth," Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International, said.
Significantly, businesses hired workers in April. The purchasing managers' employment index rose to 50.8 percent last month from 48 percent in March -- marking the first time that index climbed above 50 since January 1989.
The Labor Department will release its April employment report on Friday. Analysts expect a gain of 190,000 nonfarm jobs, according to a survey by Bloomberg Business News. In March, the economy added 456,000 nonfarm jobs, though mainly in the service industries.
Also on the positive side in today's manufacturing figures, the purchasing managers' price index, considered a gauge of inflation, slowed to 63.2 from 64.2.
In the Commerce Department report, spending increased on housing and commercial buildings, but declined on public projects like schools and military bases, reflecting Government spending cuts.
Even so, today's construction report was weaker than expected. Private economists surveyed had forecast a gain of 2.1 percent in total spending during March.
Construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted 495.4 billion during March after a 1 percent decrease in February to $491.7 billion, initially reported as a 1.2 percent decline.
Pent-up demand after a harsh winter overshadowed buyer concern about increasing mortgage rates, analysts said. The Federal Reserve has raised its rate on overnight loans between banks three times since early February to keep inflation in check.
The last monthly increase came in December, when construction spending advanced 2.2 percent, to a record $508.7 billion, as the economy wound up its strongest quarter since the mid-1980's. Compared with a year earlier, spending rose 9 percent in March.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
North Sea Gas Explosions Drive Up Crude Oil Prices

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Oil prices rose yesterday after natural gas explosions temporarily shut down oil production from some North Sea oilfields.
The gains extended a monthlong rally, pushing crude prices near five-month highs. 
 The explosions, described as minor by the authorities, forced evacuations of most workers on an oil platform about 100 miles northeast of Aberdeen, Scotland. No one was hurt in the blasts.
Meanwhile, analysts tried to explain the crude oil market's surge of the last month, noting that wholesalers have been rebuilding inventories.
"If you look at the demand numbers, the U.S. is definitely carrying the ball," said Morris Greenberg, an energy analyst at Lehman Brothers who predicted crude might hit $19 a barrel.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for June delivery rose 26 cents, to $17.16 a barrel, after trading as high as $17.32 during the session.
As recently as late March, crude oil was approaching a five-year low of $13.75 a barrel after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to roll over its output ceiling of 24.5 million barrels a day until the end of the year.
But analysts said expectations for a tighter market later this year, when demand for OPEC oil may outstrip the group's supply, had nudged the industry into building inventories at cheap levels.
"It seems like companies are willing to add on to inventories, perceiving prices will be low relative to later this year," Cyrus Tahmassebi, chief economist at Ashland Oil, said.
"I think demand is definitely stronger than most people anticipated and, to me, it's a surprise OPEC countries are sticking to their pledge not to overproduce."
The cold winter reduced American crude inventories, which need to be replenished before the summer driving season.
The American Petroleum Institute, a trade group, estimated crude oil stocks at 339 million barrels, 6 million fewer barrels than a year ago. Gasoline stocks also are about 6 million barrels below last year's level.
"In the near term, I don't see crude stocks rebuilt substantially until possibly mid-June," Mr. Greenberg said.
Among other energy products, June unleaded gasoline gained 0.48 cent, to 50.47 cents a gallon, and June heating oil added 0.48 cent, to 47.57 cents.
On other commodity markets, aggressive selling by commodity funds hit soybean futures, while wheat prices surged because of damaging cold weather in the Plains and rumors of Russian demand.
At the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, July soybeans dropped 6.75 cents, to $6.6975 a bushel, and July corn edged down 0.25 cent, to $2.7175. Meanwhile, July wheat firmed 4 cents, to $3.3475 a bushel.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Renewed marketing efforts for the South African Krugerrand will play down the political.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE arrival of democracy to South Africa also means the return to America of South Africa's most familiar product, the Krugerrand. But the renewed marketing efforts for the gold coins are deliberately playing down the political in favor of the rational and the emotional.
An ambitious campaign for Krugerrands -- employing advertising, direct marketing, promotion and public relations -- just now beginning is the first in this country since 1985, when the importing of new coins was prohibited as part of the sanctions against the longtime apartheid policies of South Africa's former Government. Yet the print ads and test TV commercials spurn the issues surrounding the coins' comeback, eschewing upbeat photographs of Nelson Mandela and F. W. de Klerk in favor of a focus on the value of gold and its appropriateness as a gift. 
 One print ad, featuring a youngish grandfather (or oldish father) playing with a baby, declares: "The eternal wisdom of buying gold. For yourself, it's always wise. As a gift for someone you love, it's positively brilliant."
In a second print ad, showing a father and son on graduation day, the father declares, "We want to mark this moment in his life with something he'll have forever.
"And who knows?" the father continues. "Maybe someday he'll show it to his kid when he's trying to get him to do his homework." Both ads in the campaign, which has a 1994 budget of about $3 million, carry the theme "Generation to generation."
The decision not to exploit the intense publicity surrounding South Africa's first all-race elections, which were won by Mr. Mandela's African National Congress Party, seems curious in light of the growing trend toward advertising that takes advantage of public interest in news events, whether momentous (the collapse of Communism) or marginal (the dysfunctional Bobbitts and Buttafuocos). Those involved in bringing back the Krugerrand, however, consider their approach will be more effective by being less evanescent.
"It's really not our job to pitch the new South Africa," R. Elizabeth Rech, the United States marketing representative for the Krugerrand, said.
"Our job is to get gold out of the ground and into the hands of the man on the street," she added of the Krugerrand Marketing Group in Hingham, Mass., an affiliate of the Chamber of Mines of South Africa, a consortium of that country's mining companies. "We want to sell gold much more than sell the country from where it comes."
Bill Luceno, chairman and chief executive at Ally & Gargano in New York, the agency handling the advertising aspects of the campaign, said that centering the sales messages on the political changes in South Africa "was never an issue, never even discussed."
"Marketing any product on the basis of any temporary condition that could change is crazy," he added. "We wanted to introduce it on the marketing merits of the product, on the basis of its real value to the consumer. Period, the end."
Steve Brounstein, senior vice president and management director at Ally, said that consumers had guided the agency in that strategy.
"In the research we did, we did not identify the source of the Krugerrand," he explained, "and out of 200 people we talked to, only one or two were even aware the Krugerrand was mined in South Africa." So even if there was any consideration of marketing it "as a coin commemorating peace in South Africa," he added, "that was just not the right way to market this product."
Melissa Barasch, an executive vice president and group creative head at Ally, said the research also made it apparent the ads should be "centered on these golden moments in life, if you will, moments worth marking like the birth of a baby or parents' golden anniversary." That would result in selling Krugerrands, in four sizes from a tenth of an ounce to one ounce, for both gift and investment reasons, she added, rather than solely for investment purposes.
Such a dual pitch made particular sense given the changes in the American economic climate since the Krugerrands' first go-round, from 1975 to 1985. Purchases then were driven mostly by inflation fears, which forced gold prices to historic highs; Ms. Rech, who also worked on selling Krugerrands to Americans in the 1980's, said the peak year for sales, at more than two million, was 1978.
Ally's print ads are running in the May issues of personal finance magazines like Money and Worth. Tests of television spots based on the print ads will start on May 16 in Dallas and Seattle.
Ally was awarded the Krugerrand Marketing Group advertising account two months ago in a review that also included as finalists Grey Advertising and Wells Rich Greene BDDP, both of New York. Safani Direct in New York was selected to handle direct-marketing duties, like fulfillment of telephone calls to a toll-free "800" number, and communications with gold-coin sellers. Dorf & Stanton Communications is handling public relations.
And JK Designs in Old Greenwich, Conn., designed the first packaging for Krugerrands sold in America, replacing what Ms. Rech called "a piece of plastic junk" with gift boxes, pouches and envelopes for those "who buy one coin and stick it in a safe deposit box."

HEADLINE: Coming Back Around to Blass

BYLINE: By BERNADINE MORRIS 

 BODY:
"Every five years I get rediscovered," Bill Blass said wryly. He can tell this is one of the good years from the enthusiastic reactions of store buyers who were writing orders for his fall collection and the number of magazine editors who want to photograph his clothes. "My philosophy has not changed," he said. "But sometimes it works better than other times."
It was clear that Mr. Blass had a success from the moment the first of his fall styles appeared on the runway of the tent in Bryant Park, where most Seventh Avenue designers introduced their collections last month. Three models in brightly colored double coats with undulating edges appeared together; one was in an orange coat over a blue coat, another in orange over chartreuse and the third in purple over orange. Worn over black tights and black dresses, the coats were beacons of color in a fashion scene that has been dominated by dark or neutral colors for some time. 
 Later in the show, he returned to the double-coat motif, showing the same style with curving edges in black-and-white-striped satin over black wool.
 
Three Coats in One Package
 "The satin coat can be worn all year, the wool coat when it's cooler and the two together in the dead of winter," Mr. Blass said, indicating that even high fashion can have its practical side.
His attitude toward dressing dates back to the years before World War II when, at age 18, he came to New York from Fort Wayne, Ind., to take a job at David Crystal, a sportswear manufacturer. At about the same time, he was selling design sketches to a company that was making evening dresses, he recalled last week in his showroom.
"Those were my two interests," he said. "I always believed in sports clothes for day and glamorous styles at night."
Both themes are prominent in his current collection. After the double coats, he showed raincoats in pale colors, high-waisted dresses with lightly flaring skirts and many suits in checked and plaid woolens with pleated skirts or pants. Evening clothes were shown in cut velvet, handpainted silks and chiffon.
 
Dressy Meets Casual
 Some of the most intriguing outfits combine casual and dressy elements, as in a man's polo coat tossed over a chiffon dress. A cut-velvet dinner suit was accompanied by a sweater, not a blouse.
"Two types of clothes have been successful in the past few years," Mr. Blass said, "minimal and young. I still like clothes to be simple, but not really minimal. Women are saying they have had enough of plain drab clothes. Now they want 'more.' "
Another factor that has contributed to the collection's success, the designer said, is color.
"We're talking about women who don't want a wardrobe of black, gray and beige clothes," he said. "I was in California recently, and of course I went to the stores to see what was selling. Chanel suits were outselling everything else -- in bright colors like raspberry and green. They were pretty. Whatever happened to the idea of pretty clothes?"
Mr. Blass believes that pretty clothes will return after the most drastic change in fashion since the 1960's.
"Thirty years ago, clothes were youth-oriented, as they are today," he observed. "But we've mixed everything up with grunge, matted hair, the Depression look -- the baby doll has been tarnished. The 80's emphasized fantasy clothes because of the affluence everywhere. The 70's saw the emergence of the woman who works and needed clothes to help her compete with men.
"Now we have to create a new style -- not too bizarre, not too exotic, not too opulent. The clothes have to maintain a contemporary image and appeal to women of all ages, not just the very young."
 
A Problem Solver
 If his collection succeeded, he suggested, it was because he solved some of the problems involved in making this new style happen.
"I didn't show any ball gowns," he said, "because the short evening dress -- we used to call it the cocktail dress -- seems more acceptable to more women."
The suit jackets are generally shaped closely to the body in a high- waistline cut; dresses also follow this Empire silhouette. The results are styles that look fresh and snappy.
"There is every indication that the economy is improving, and this certainly will prove a boon to fashion," Mr. Blass said. "The business still intrigues me, and I love the fact that I have re-emerged again."
But being realistic, he said he would not be sure the collection worked until it started to reach consumers. It will this week, when the clothes are introduced at Saks Fifth Avenue.

HEADLINE: Arab Museums Try to Preserve a Purpose

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, May 2

 BODY:
The world of diplomacy is suffused with genteel language that hides, just beneath the surface, roiling passions. Especially, it would seem, in the Arab world, where the passions sometimes break defiantly through the surface. But if one knows the context, one can discover impassioned meanings in even the politest of formulations.
Or so it seemed here last week, when some 80 museum directors and related government officials from 18 Arab countries gathered for the first nearly comprehensive conference of the Arab museum world. (Only Kuwait and Saudi Arabia boycotted the proceedings, presumably on political grounds.) 
 The conference was organized by the International Council of Museums, a 10,000-member, 120-country organization founded in the United States and based in Paris, and it was called "Museums, Civilization and Development." Technically private, the council (known as ICOM) operates out of Unesco headquarters and partakes of diplomatic as well as museological manners.
 
What's in a Title?
 The conference's title might seem generalized to the point of vacuity; all museums supposedly espouse civilized values. But in the Arab world, riven just now by fundamentalism and confronted with a potential calming of tensions with Israel, the exact nature of "civilization" and "development" -- what those terms embrace, what they exclude and whose values (Arab? Islamic? Western? universal?) they can be said to represent -- remains intensely controversial.
Malika Bouabdellah, the director of the National Museum of Fine Arts in Algeria, described the conference's background most succinctly in a paper submitted before the sessions began. "The economic, political, moral and spiritual crisis that we are living through is pulverizing our standards of values and our very beings," she wrote. "We despair and tear ourselves apart. We regress in believing that we are realizing our hopes, we impoverish ourselves, we lose track of our roots."
Ms. Bouabdellah named no specific source for the crisis she described. But given Algeria's torment just now -- some of the Algerian delegates had either been threatened with death by fundamentalists or seen their museums physically attacked -- her meaning was clear enough, and formed the most imposing of the conference's several powerful subtexts.
On the surface, the conference proceeded in a smooth and orderly manner. Apart from a visit to Petra, the astonishing archeological site where one of the 2,000-year-old sandstone facades was the temple in "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom," the five-day event was devoted to public sessions and closed workshops concerned with matters of intense practical importance to museum officials: the training of curators and restorers, the management of museums, the standardization of terminology, the development of computer software and the compilation of personnel directories and registers of stolen artworks. There was also a call to form an Arab regional museum organization to be called either ACOM or ARACOM.
 
Frank Private Expression

 
 But the underlying agenda was more interesting than the official agenda. Any such conference -- the council's first in the third world took place in Africa in 1991 and another may be in the works for Asia -- is meant to forge personal bonds that lead to regional cooperation. Here, however, some of the issues were too sensitive for formal expression and found more frank and heated expression privately.
The Palestinian delegation, for instance, was determined to include in the formal recommendations a stiff demand that Unesco and ICOM be more active in the recovery of lost Palestinian cultural artifacts. Mouyad Mohammed Said Damerdji, the Iraqi director general of antiquities, aggressively sought language demanding international help in restoring artworks looted during the Persian Gulf war. "The language of Unesco is very bland; it has no taste," he grumbled.
But the most troubling concern, always implicit and sometimes explicit, was about the impact of Islamic fundamentalism. This is a tricky issue, because Arabs are convinced that Westerners stereotype them. Unless they are directly subjected to death threats, they are unwilling to seek outside assistance or even comment about their problems. Indeed, when they have been threatened, they may be even more shy.
"If there's a feud going on, it's a family feud," said Kristina Davies, an American who directs the Ford Foundation regional office in Cairo and who channeled $125,000 of Ford money to the Amman conference. If the Arabs are suspicious of the West, they had ample reason to be suspicious here, since a healthy portion of the budget (along with contributions from the Jordanian government and the Ford Foundation and Unesco), came from such unashamedly Western institutions as the Rockefeller Foundation, the J. Paul Getty Trust, the French Foreign Ministry and the British Council.
 
'All Our Heritage'

 
 Still, many of the delegates, usually sotto voce or off the record ("It's very easy to be branded as anti-Islamic," Ms. Davies remarked), conceded their concerns on this issue. Safran Tell, the Jordanian director general of antiquities and museums and the host of the conference, boasted that "we were once Jews, we were once Christians, and today we cultivate all our heritage" and denounced those "impossible people who are just ignorant, who don't know what they're doing."
The most outspoken of the delegates was Aicha ben Abed ben Khader, a curator and former director of the Bardo Museum, Tunisia's oldest and largest, who wrote in her paper of the "horror of the extremists that seizes us daily." These "forgers of hatred," she added, purveyed "demagoguery, pure and simple," which seeks to "obliterate civilizations preceding the Islamic conquest."
"It is evident," she concluded, "that in countries like ours the role of museums can be basic for not only presenting diverse civilizations, but also for introducing to the public an idea of tolerance and a respect for differences."
Several days into the conference, she had hardly backed down, adding that "it will take all our efforts to combat the obscurantism that threatens us at every moment." One of her projects is a traveling exhibition illustrating the diversity of Arab cultures before Islam.
 
Promoting Tolerance

 
 Her ideas found a place in the final recommendations of the "research, ethics and legislation" workshop, which call for museums to be "a privileged forum of transcultural exchanges" that "should fight against all kinds of extremism and promote tolerance." Mr. Damerdji of Iraq, the chairman of that workshop, responded "No, no, no" when asked if those clauses constituted a denunciation of Islamic fundamentalism. "She was speaking about radicalism in general," he said. This was technically true, but ignored her specific citation of the fundamentalist problem.
Ms. Davies of the Ford Foundation and Elisabeth des Portes, a Frenchwoman who is the secretary general of the council, also stressed that one goal of the conference's Western sponsors and organizers was to promote tolerance.
"Without specifying or targeting any group," Ms. Davies said diplomatically, "it's certainly in my interest to promote pluralism in this area."
Ms. des Portes argued that the very participation in a conference like this constituted a commitment to international values. "Not one of the people here could be called a fundamentalist," she said. "They don't express themselves directly, but cosmopolitanism is the sense of all their actions. If we can be a resource for tolerance, we can be a bulwark against fundamentalist ideas."

HEADLINE: Senate Campaign Is Financed by Individuals

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Health Debate Is Filling Campaign Coffers" (front page, April 19), on my race for the Senate, fails to put the issue in perspective.
You have repeatedly praised my health care plan because it is good public policy. Publications ranging from The New Republic to Fortune have also favored it. I drafted the legislation back in 1991 and 1992, long before I had any thought of running for the Senate. 
 I am the only major Senate candidate in America who has refused political action committee money, even though the Senate voted to ban PAC's only last year.
I have raised more money from individual Tennesseans who do not work in the health industry than any candidate in Tennessee history.
About 19 percent of my contributions do come from people who work in health care, but that's about its share of Tennessee's economy. It is the state's largest private employer.
Many people who attack my fund raising are frustrated with my health plan's popularity and are unable or unwilling to debate it on the merits.
As you note, I have never claimed to be a hero as a result of refusing PAC funds. Having voted for virtually every campaign finance reform bill in Congress, I chose three years ago voluntarily to limit myself without waiting for the ban to become law.
My campaign is financed entirely by individual contributions. And 80 percent of the individuals who have contributed to my campaign are Tennesseans. About 200,000 Tennesseans work in health care. These citizens have a right to be heard in the health care debate, regardless of the health care reform approach they support.
 
JIM COOPER
Member of Congress, 4th Dist., Tenn.
Washington, April 26, 1994

HEADLINE: Drug Issues Help to Drive Stocks Higher

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Strength in economically sensitive stocks, along with a big rally in drug issues, added up to a solid advance yesterday for the general stock market.
Despite early weakness, the market moved upward for the second consecutive day. And it was only the third time in the last month that stock prices gained while bond prices declined. With prices lower, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.33 percent, from 7.30 percent on Friday. 
 "It was a good day, maybe even a fairly normal day on Wall Street," Hugh A. Johnson, senior vice president of the First Albany Corporation, said. "The markets responded as they should respond to the news."
The major news event affecting the stock market was the April report of the National Association of Purchasing Managers. Its index rose to 57.7, a one-point rise that was greater than expected and that matched the January figure -- the highest mark of this key indicator in the last six years.
Another key factor in the broad market movement was the announcement that Roche Holding of Switzerland intended to acquire Syntex for $24 a share. The stock of the American drug company did not open until 12:30 P.M., yet it was still the New York Stock Exchange's most active issue. It closed at 23 1/2, up 8 1/4.
All three of the major market indexes advanced for the day. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 19.33 points, to 3,701.02; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 2.11 points, to 453.02, and the Nasdaq composite index advanced 6.84 points, to 740.68.
Trading on the Big Board was just short of 300 million shares, slightly more than Friday's volume of 294 million shares and near the yearly average of 305 million shares. Advancing stocks outpaced declining issues by 1,235 to 946.
Other drug stocks were strong yesterday, based on indications that the Syntex acquisition could presage further consolidation and restructuring in the industry. Merck advanced 1 1/2, to 31 1/8; Eli Lilly increased 2 3/8, to 51 5/8, and Upjohn rose 1 3/4, to 28 1/2.
Among the economically sensitive, or cyclical, issues, there were a number of standouts. For instance, chemical stocks that were higher yesterday included Du Pont, up 1 3/8, to 58 1/2; Dow Chemical, up 1 3/8, to 64 1/8, and Union Carbide, which gained 3/8, to 26 3/4.
Eastman Kodak jumped 3 1/4, to 44 3/4, apparently because of rumors that the company may spin off its Sterling Drug unit.
Also closing on the downside yesterday was Alpha-Beta Technology, a biotech company that suffered from a presentation at a medical meeting on Friday of disappointing data on its experimental product, Betafectin, which is designed to prevent infections in patients who have undergone surgery. The stock plummeted 9, to 12 1/2.
Trading in Lehman Brothers Holding began yesterday on the Big Board on a when-issued basis. Lehman, which is being spun off by American Express, has a book value of about $31 a share. However, the stock of the securities firm closed at 19 3/4 after reaching a high of 20 7/8.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 4, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the stock market's activity on Monday misstated the change in the closing price for Eastman Kodak in some copies. Its shares rose 3 1/4, to close at 44 3/4; they did not fall 3 1/4.
