HEADLINE: Clinton Defends Foreign Policy Record

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
Saying that the United States "cannot turn our back on the world," President Clinton offered a broad defense tonight of his foreign policy initiatives and issued tough-sounding challenges to North Korea and other foreign governments.
"America cannot solve every problem, and must not become the world's policeman," he said in an international forum televised by Cable News Network. "But we have an obligation to join with others to do what we can to relieve the suffering and restore peace." 
 Despite his strong words, Mr. Clinton also conceded that his foreign policy team had faced a more complicated world than he expected and that they made a number of errors along the way.
"All leaders sometimes have had to back and fill and alter their course throughout history," Mr. Clinton said. "But there is no vacillation in the principles of the policies here. It's just that we don't know what will work within the limits of our ability to deal with some of these problems.
"But as we venture out in these new areas, we have to risk error. And so I have been willing to risk error. And when you do that, you get more criticism."
 
Stymied in Bosnia
 Mr. Clinton said that he had been especially stymied by efforts to pursue a sound policy in Bosnia and said that it had been much more difficult than he had imagined during the 1992 campaign to put together an international coalition to try to stop the fighting between Serbs, Croats and Muslims in the former Yugoslavia.
"Do I wish we could have done more earlier?" he said. "Do I wish the Europeans and our other allies had totally agreed with me? Of course, I do. But I also respect their differences and their long experience in this area. I did the best I could, I moved as quickly as I could."
In response to a reporter who questioned the vacillation of his Bosnia policy, he said tightly that there "have been no constant flip-flops" by his Administration.
Mr. Clinton appeared on a 90-minute-long program provided by the Cable News Network to beam his defense of his policies to more than 200 countries and territories around the world. He seized on the opportunity to try to address lingering questions about his competence in determining when the United States should intervene in foreign conflicts and the consistency of American policy abroad.
 
An Audience Abroad
 White House officials said Mr. Clinton was conscious tonight that he was addressing a foreign audience as well as Americans, and hoped to demonstrate his command of foreign policy to that broad audience.
A New York Times/CBS News poll conducted April 21-23 showed that Mr. Clinton's foreign policy ratings have been dropping steadily since January. In the latest results, the 1,215 people surveyed were divided on Mr. Clinton's performance, with 41 percent disapproving and 40 percent approving.
The margin of error in the sample was plus or minus three percentage points.
Administration officials are working to reassert control over the sliding ratings by demonstrating a tough stance toward American problems overseas.
Part of that effort has been to send a unified message of American resolve toward North Korea. Defense Secretary William J. Perry said in a speech in Washington today that the United States remains prepared to defend South Korea by military force if the Government in Pyongyang refuses access to its nuclear weapons facilities.
Mr. Clinton issued a similar message tonight. "No one wishes this confrontation," Mr. Clinton said. "But neither does one wish to have a state not only with nuclear power but with a capacity to proliferate nuclear weapons to other nations. It is a very serious potential situation."
 
Economic Security Is Central
 Stressing that his foreign policy "road map" would continue to treat economic security as central to his global strategy, Mr. Clinton said the United States would also concentrate on promoting democracy throughout the world.
"Our goal is to foster the success of new democracies, like those in Latin America and now South Africa, and to apply pressure to restore democracy where it has been overthrown, as in Haiti," he said.
Mr. Clinton announced today that he will double American aid to South Africa in the wake of that country's first democratic election.
The new aid package will provide about $600 million to South Africa over three years, and Mr. Clinton said he believed it was important that the American commitment be sustained.
On Haiti, Mr. Clinton told reporters in Atlanta before the television appearance that he had "run out" of patience with the leaders of Haiti's military regime. But he immediately said he hoped tougher sanctions, rather than imminent military action, would be the best approach.
 
Patience at an End
 Tonight he said he believes in a "good neighbor policy" with countries in the hemisphere but that the United States can no longer tolerate the abrogation of democracy in Haiti. While saying that he had done his best to avoid pursuing a military option, he added, "We cannot afford to discount the possibility of a military option."
In response to a question from a television reporter from Trinidad and Tobago, Mr. Clinton said: "This is the responsibility not of the United States but the people who are running Haiti tonight. They have brought this reign of terror and poverty on their people" and they could end it tomorrow.
Mr. Clinton was asked starkly different questions on Bosnia from Belgrade, the capital of Serbia, and Sarajevo, home of the Muslim Government of Bosnia, and gave sharply different responses. When a correspondent from Belgrade wondered whether any change of American strategy could be expected on the Bosnian conflict, perhaps including equal treatment of all three sides and lifting sanctions on Serbia, Mr. Clinton replied: "I guess the short answer is no. But not entirely."
But when he was faced by a long and angry question from CNN's correspondent in Sarajevo, Christiane Amanpour, in which she asserted that the Administration had constantly flip-flopped, Mr. Clinton's reply was terse with irritation. Mr. Clinton said, "There have been no constant flip-flops, madam."
He went on to assert that "we have been much more active than my predecessor was." But he added, "I did not believe we should inject American ground forces" into the conflict in Bosnia to affect the outcome of the civil war there.
 
Underestimated on Bosnia
 Relaxing, Mr. Clinton then acknowledged that "I underestimated the difficulty of putting a coalition together" to influence the war in Bosnia. "I underestimated the difficulty of getting broad agreement through NATO. It took too long to get together." But he said, "It's not fair to say we've gone back and forth."
Mr. Clinton said the United States and its allies had stopped the Bosnian conflict from spreading, and he said he would try to get the parties to the conflict to negotiate "a decent peace."
Mr. Clinton said he and the other Middle East leaders all believed there was a greater chance than ever before to reach "a breakthrough agreement" between Israel and Syria. "We have a real chance to make progress this year," he said in answer to an Israeli journalist.
He agreed with a Palestinian journalist who suggested that territories previously occupied by Israel would need more than the $2 billion in aid pledged so far by foreign countries.
He said he expects private investors, including Jewish and Arab Americans, to increase their investments in the territories.
Mr. Clinton denied Japanese assertions that his trade policy constitutes one of "managed trade" or that he was seeking special treatment for the United States.
"We look to Japan for leadership," he said. "People worry because of the fight over trade. But we are not only partners but friends. We must not allow differences that reflect a mature relationship and debate to spoil a relationship important for the world."
 
Concerns on China Trade
 On another trade issue, Mr. Clinton said cancellation of China's most-favored-nation trading status would undermine relations between Washington and Beijing and would damage the standard of living of many people in China.
"I do not wish that to happen," Mr. Clinton said in response to a question from a Chinese journalist, but it is a possibility because China has not met all the criteria he set.
"That is clearly an option on the table," Mr. Clinton said, referring to the withdrawal of most-favored nation status. "It would be a bad thing" for China.
Mr. Clinton said China had made "significant overall progress" in satisfying some of his criteria, relating to immigration and prison labor, but had not satisfied all the criteria.
President Clinton said he was not telling "a great nation like China" how to treat its citizens or to conduct its internal affairs. But he said, "Human rights is very important to the United States."
Mr. Clinton seemed deeply affected by a question posed by a Ugandan reporter about when the United States should intervene abroad to save lives.
Mr. Clinton said the first lesson was that the United States could not intervene in a country under the illusion that it was a humanitarian mission that can be dealt with quickly. The people in Somalia were starving, he said, not because there was shortage of food, but rather because the food could not be distributed because of military and political factors.

HEADLINE: Embargo Seen As Insufficient For the Return Of Aristide

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 3

 BODY:
Even as the Clinton Administration has begun to push for broader United Nations sanctions against Haiti, many diplomats and Haitian analysts say that the effort will prove too little too late to restore the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
The analysts say that since October, when an international effort to restore Father Aristide collapsed amid a violent army-sponsored campaign of defiance, the Haitian military's hold on the country has grown steadily stronger. 
 Taking advantage of a porous border with the Dominican Republic, diplomats here say the army has circumvented sanctions that were intended to prohibit arms and petroleum supplies and has managing to stockpile large amounts of gasoline. At the same time, the military has completed long-needed repairs on the country's sole hydroelectric dam, and in recent days power has returned to the capital after months with little electricity.
 
Sanctions May Be Ignored
 Diplomats say that the proposed new sanctions, which would prohibit nearly all trade with Haiti, had little prospect of being respected by the Dominican Republic, whose army and political elite have close ties to the Haitian military and hostility toward Father Aristide.
Another weakness in the proposed sanctions, the diplomats say, is that there is no provision to end commercial air traffic with Haiti. Many Haitian businessmen fly in and out of the country to continue to conduct their affairs from abroad and to maintain minimum stocks of vital goods and spare parts in the country.
"I believe the military here is sitting on a substantial amount of fuel, so they will still be able to operate," said one diplomat who was critical of the new policy. "It seems the whole thing is based on the idea that there would be some kind of popular uprising, but the very reason we are seeing so much repression is to prevent that from happening. The army has already shown that they have no qualms when it comes to the suffering of the Haitian people."
While the army is expected to continue to make large profits by managing its lucrative trade in black-market petroleum products, relief officials have warned that a reinforcement of the embargo would risk a grave deterioration in the quality of life of poor Haitians who have already suffered from more than two years of intermittent sanctions and international isolation.
 
Conditions Said to Worsen
 An appraisal of conditions in Haiti performed in March by the United States Agency for International Development found that "overall, the nutritional status of children has worsened since March 1993 in every region but the south."
The report added that although all forms of malnutrition in Haiti had declined slightly, severe malnutrition was at the highest level in several years. CARE, the relief organization that now feeds about 477,000 Haitians daily, said in a recent report that the country is deteriorating daily.
"These people have sold off the last goat, the last pig," said Bill Novelli of CARE. "The embargo didn't cause all of this, but it has made it a lot worse."
The prospect of tightened sanctions, which has caused alarm even among some groups in Haiti that support Father Aristide, has caused many relief experts to fear a resurgence in the number of Haitians seeking to flee their country by boat.
Even if the new sanctions were to be quickly passed by the United Nations Security Council, diplomats here say that the military's stockpiling will mean that it could be weeks or months before they would have any effect on the Haitian Army.
Diplomats say that if no breakthrough can be reached before the fall, when the Haitian National Assembly's mandate expires, the military will be left as the only institution remaining in the country.

HEADLINE: Opposition by Suburban Parents Dooms Connecticut School Proposal

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 3

 BODY:
An ambitious plan to remake Connecticut's public schools has died in the Legislature, a target of resistance from teachers and vigorous opposition from some parents. But its fate seemed most rooted in the failure of its advocates to convince the public, particularly suburban parents, that sweeping change was needed.
The plan was similar to proposals being considered in more than 30 states. It called for raising academic achievement by setting high standards for what children should learn and then testing to make sure they did so. Teachers, in turn, would focus less on grading children and more on helping all children meet those standards. The stated goal was a "fundamental restructuring" of public education. 
 
 
If It Ain't Broke. . . .
 In Connecticut, the Commission on Educational Excellence worked for 18 months to draft the plan, which it promoted in outline at hearings around the state. But to suburban parents looking at their schools and their children, the argument of business, education and political leaders that the state's schools are failing, putting at risk everyone's economic future, was never compelling. The plan's natural allies, the parents of city children, were rarely heard from.
Distrustful of the education establishment after 30 years of school revampings, many parents listened instead to critics who attacked the plan as an unnecessary, costly experiment that would drag all schools down to mediocrity. In the end, in a state whose own innovations have become the basis of reform plans elsewhere, legislators facing elections this fall did not even want to debate the proposal. They saw no point in commiting themselves publicly on a plan that all agreed was doomed.
"I really thought people in this state wanted school reform, but they don't," said State Representative Nancy Wyman, a co-chairwoman of the Legislature's Education Committee. "What we see is people saying, 'Our schools are good, it's the other schools that aren't, so why should we be bothered?'
"When you have people who see their kids going on to good colleges, they say it's hogwash."
 
A National Consensus
 The Connecticut plan, however, closely follows an unusually broad national consensus among educators and business leaders on what should be done with the nation's schools. Its defeat here suggests that a gulf remains between the various aroused experts and parents worried about their neighborhood school.
According to Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States in Denver, the public is no longer willing to accept unquestioningly educators who can't clearly explain what they are doing. The commission has advised many states on school-improvement strategies.
"The Connecticut proposals assume that much higher performance on the part of all students is necessary," Mr. Newman said. "I happen to believe that. But unless you make that point in a way people buy it, everything that follows doesn't make sense."
"It used to be that your goal, as a parent, was to make sure your kid did well," he said. "What was clear in Connecticut was that people didn't accept the idea that, as a citizen, you have to worry about all kids doing well."
Many people disagreed, dubious that the proposals would work anywhere. The organized opposition in Connecticut came from teacher unions, which objected that the plan would undercut tenure protection, and from a group of parents called the Committee to Save Our Schools, which quickly formed branches in 60 communities.
Legislators and business leaders said the unions, even with 40,000 members, were the smaller obstacle. A 1986 law aimed at improving schools had sharply raised their salaries, making them the highest in the country, and many legislators said they were now prepared to hold teachers more accountable.
 
'Outcome-Based' Plans
 Similar groups had sprung up in other states, attacking plans as "outcome-based education" schemes intended to take the control of schools away from local districts. The only possible outcome of setting one standard for all children, they said, would be to reduce the brightest to the level of the worst.
The commission knew that the opposition elsewhere came mainly from religious conservatives, who felt that it was intended to teach liberal values, and it felt confident because the Legislature, in ordering a commission to draft a plan, had specified "an outcome-based, world-class educational system." The plan's advocates thus decided to disregard the grass-roots opposition. The commission simply substituted "results" for "outcomes" throughout its report and denied it was considering an outcome-based system.
Representative Wyman and other advocates contend that opponents misrepresented their proposal, attaching to it a grab bag of discredited teaching techniques that the commission never considered.
But the opposition in Connecticut came not from religious fundamentalists, but from parents in Greenwich, Weston, Westport and other Fairfield County suburbs, home to some of the nation's finest public schools.
Ms. Wyman and others admit they never expected the overriding message of those opponents -- that no crisis existed in their communities, that the proposed strategy was experimental, and that the probable result would harm their schools -- would ring true for many parents.
The calls that most worried legislators, Ms. Wyman said, were from parents who said they didn't understand the proposal, were scared by what they had heard, and wanted it put off. "I think it was killed by concerned parents who didn't understand," she said.
 
For Separate Debates
 Kay Wall, the P.T.A. president at her son's elementary school in Old Greenwich and a leader of the opposition, said parents in communities with good schools had sound reasons to fear the untested plan, which in one 97-page piece of legislation addressed scores of issues.
A main tenet of the Connecticut plan, as in other states, is that all of its provisions must be adopted together, but Ms. Wall said there is no reason each issue can't be debated and adopted separately.
"There was never any local support for the bill, as it was explained," she said. "This has slowed the process down for reform that we think is necessary. This tried to do too much too fast."
Business leaders like Robert D. Kennedy, the chief executive of Union Carbide Corporation and a commission member, vowed to make a better case when they try again. "A lot of people are complacent," he said. "They don't see a straight line between the education level of our people and economic collapse."

HEADLINE: Cost of 4-Year Degree Passes $100,000 Mark

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Several of the nation's leading colleges have broken the $100,000 barrier for a four-year degree.
Beginning this fall, Yale freshmen will pay $26,350 a year for tuition, fees, room and board, and Harvard students will pay only $120 less than that. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology is charging $26,075. Brown is $25,954. Swarthmore is $25,900, and Stanford is the cheapest of the costly at $25,465. 
 Swarthmore's vice president for business and finance, William T. Spock, echoed the feelings of many parents when he remarked, "I'm sure glad my kids are through with college."
College and university representatives said that this year's cost increases were made with great reluctance.
"We agonize over this every year," said Elizabeth Huidekoper, Harvard's budget director. "Obviously, the $25,000 mark has symbolic significance, but it wasn't a barrier. Any increase is carefully considered.
And Ms. Huidekoper, like other university representatives, was quick to point out that the numbers do not reflect the full story: many of their students -- 67 percent at Harvard and more than half at many others -- receive generous financial aid. At Cornell, for example, half of the students receive financial aid that averages about $10,000 a year.
Still, many students -- generally those who come from families with incomes above $100,000 -- are paying the full price. And many others have become part of a phenomenon known as "middle income melt." These students would almost certainly have gone to private colleges and universities if prices were lower, but today they are attending the much less expensive public institutions.
The cost of public institutions across the country is rising even more rapidly than that of the private ones, although of course the totals at the public colleges and universities are only a fraction of those at most private ones. The cost for in-state students last year (1994-95 figures have yet to be set by many state legislatures) range from $11,726 for the University of Vermont to $5,504 at the University of North Carolina.
The high cost of college has also greatly increased student borrowing. The United States Department of Education has yet to release figures, but a few institutions have issued reports on what some educators are calling the "borrowing blitz." For example, Stanford reports that students and their families borrowed $8 million in the first half of 1993-94. That is $2.5 million more than was borrowed in all of the 1992-93 year.
Charles H. Long, deputy provost of Yale, said colleges and universities found themselves in an inflationary trap.
"If you're in a business like ours in which most of your expenses are for personnel, and you also have to buy things like scholarly periodicals, library books and scientific equipment, which rise in cost at a rate higher than inflation," Mr. Long said, "you're not going to be able to hold your costs at below the rate of inflation."
Ronald G. Ehrenberg, a Cornell professor of industrial and labor relations who studies college costs, said the present annual tuition increases of many private institutions were up only 1 percent or 2 percent -- significantly lower than the 3 percent to 4 percent that these average costs climbed in the 1980's.
Asked about prospects for the future, Professor Ehrenberg said: "Take Cornell. It's now in the midst of a campaign to raise $1.2 billion, and it's close to reaching that goal. The question therefore is, Can Cornell, and similar institutions, sustain that level of fund raising in the years ahead? And are government research contracts going to continue at the present level? We just don't know."
 
Shifting Responsibility
 The reason for the increase in the cost of public institutions, which has been climbing at about three times the rate of inflation, educators say, is that for the past 15 years state governments have been steadily cutting back their support for higher education. As soon as those cutbacks began to take effect, state-supported colleges and universities throughout the country began to raise tuition to balance their budgets.
"The responsibility for paying for higher education is being shifted from taxpayers to students and their families," said Thomas G. Mortenson, a higher education policy analyst based in Iowa City. "We're heading toward a price-based admission policy where the people who can afford it will go to college and the others won't."
"In 1979," Mr. Mortenson continued, "a student whose family income was in the top quartile had a four times greater chance of earning a B.A. degree by the age of 24 than did a student in the lowest quartile. Today, that well-off student has a 19 times better chance."
Mr. Spock of Swarthmore said that the cost of faculty and staff was always the biggest expense faced by the committees that set tuition. "We can't raise tuition too fast," he said, "but have to raise it fast enough to keep these salaries competitive with those at other colleges and businesses. Our staff and faculty work extremely long hours and have very stressful jobs. We want to do everything we can to hold on to them."
 
'Lifetime Investment'
 Daniel S. Hamermesh, a professor of economics at the University of Texas who has just prepared a study of faculty salaries for the American Association of University Professors, said faculty salaries had been stagnant for the past four years, growing only 0.3 percent in real dollars last year.
On the other hand, Professor Hamermesh said, the number of administrators -- deputy provosts and assistant deans -- has been growing rapidly.
Professor Ehrenberg said much of this administrative growth included specialists in student services, student placement, auditing required to deal with new government regulations and fund raising.
Ms. Huidekoper of Harvard summed up the dilemma posed by rising college costs this way: "If you think of it as a lifetime investment, it's justified, but unfortunately most people don't look at it that way."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Good Economic News Depresses Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities declined yesterday, on the heels of a Government report that suggested the economy is likely to continue to grow in the months ahead.
The March index of leading indicators, the Government's gauge of economic activity in the next six to nine months, was up seven-tenths of 1 percent, slightly more than expected. The increase was aided by a large jump in the length of the average workweek, which had been held down in the February by frigid weather in much of the nation. 
 Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News had expected an increase of six-tenths of 1 percent in the index. The February index was revised to unchanged after being reported initially down one-tenth of a percent.
 
 
'Old Data'
 Analysts said Government bond traders did not run with the report since much of the data were already known. Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, called it "a repackaging of old data."
In late trading, The 30-year Treasury was down 6/32 of a point, to 8628/32 , for a yield of 7.35 percent, up from 7.33 percent Monday. Shorter-term bill rates rose on investor concern about another increase in short-term rates by the Federal Reserve.
The market's focus is now on next week's quarterly Treasury auction, Friday's March employment data and the approaching May 17 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making arm of the Fed.
Today, the Treasury is expected to announce the size of its quarterly refunding, with most participants looking for between $29 billion and $30 billion in new 3-year and 10-year notes. "I suppose anything outside those numbers would be a surprise," Mr. Fine said. "However, I wouldn't expect it to move the market even if it's a surprise."
 
 
Employment Forecast
 The forecast for the employment numbers range from an increase of 100,000 on the low end to a gain of 260,000 on the high end. "I'm looking for 220,000, higher than the market consensus of plus 170,000," Mr. Fine said.
James Hale, an analyst with MMS International, said the bond market yesterday repeated a pattern it had followed on and off for about two months. First prices trade up in a burst of short-covering but then gives it all back and then some. He added that the dollar's inability to rebound also dragged the bond market down.
Besides the worry of another short-term interest rate increase between now and the Fed's meeting May 17, Mr. Hale said that traders and investors were "concerned that a weaker dollar heading into the quarterly auction will result in a smaller-than-usual draw of foreign buyers and cause interest rates to move up as a result."
In the municipal bond market, California's sale of $400 million in general obligation bonds, the week's largest scheduled offering, was won by Prudential Securities. The bonds were reoffered for sale at a price that produced a maximum yield of 6.35 percent for a bond due in 2024.
 
 
Shorter Maturities
 For shorter maturities, yields on serial bonds range from 4.40 percent in 1996 to 5 percent in 2000; 5.55 percent for the 10-year bond due in 2004; 6.10 percent in 2010, and 6.25 percent in 2015. Other long maturities were priced to yield 6.27 percent in 2020 and 6.30 percent in 2018.
Underwriters said the bonds were rated double-A by Moody's Investors Service and Fitch, and A+ by Standard & Poor's -- except for securities due in 1998, 2000-01 and 2020, which are insured by either the Ambac Indemnity Corporation or the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company. The insurance gives those bonds a triple-A rating by the rating agencies.
As a sign of how much the market has sold off in the last month, similarly rated new 10-year bonds from the State of Washington were priced last week to yield 5.35 percent.
Elsewhere, holders of Denver International Airport bonds -- concerned about a possible downgrading of the credit ratings of the airport's $3.2 billion in outstanding debt -- got a clue from S.& P. The rating agency said yesterday that it would meet with Denver city officials next week before deciding what to do about the credit rating on the bonds. On Monday, Denver announced an indefinite delay in the opening of the airport.
Depending on how that meeting goes, "the airport's rating could be lowered, possibly to a noninvestment- grade level shortly thereafter," Ernie Perez, an S.& P. analyst, said.
Prices of the airport bonds tumbled more than a point on Monday after Denver officials announced the delay because of a computerized baggage system that does not work. In trading yesterday, the price of the bonds bounced back about a half-point, to 90.125, to yield 7.60 percent, down from 7.65 percent.

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Incinerator Opponents See Victory in High Court Ruling

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Residents and officials who have spent more than a decade waging legal and political warfare against New York City's plans to build new trash incinerators believe they now have some overwhelming ammunition: a convincing economic argument.
Opponents of incineration said yesterday that a Supreme Court decision on Monday requiring that the ash generated by incinerators be subject to strict hazardous-waste standards would make the costs of incineration prohibitive. They argued that the costs -- for testing as well as possible special storage -- could well doom the planned $450 million Brooklyn Navy Yard incinerator, as well as a proposal to reopen an incinerator in southwest Brooklyn. 
 "There is zero economic argument left for going ahead with plans for either the Brooklyn Navy Yard incinerator or the southwest Brooklyn project," said Kenneth K. Fisher, a City Councilman from Williamsburg, Brooklyn. "It's a serious blow to the project that pushes incineration that much closer to going over the edge of oblivion. And I don't see why the Mayor would fight to keep it from going over the edge."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday, however, that he had reached no conclusion about the implications of the Supreme Court ruling. He conceded that it was likely to raise the costs of incineration, but he said he had yet to determine by how much and whether it would be too much to consider going forward with the construction of the incinerators.
Kevin Stickney, a spokesman for Wheelabrator Environmental Systems, the company under contract to build the Brooklyn Navy Yard incinerator, insisted that the ruling would not have "a substantial effect on this company at all."
He said Wheelabrator had already developed a system for treating the ash generated by its incinerators, and that it could handle treating the full output of the Navy Yard plant without a significant increase in costs.
Anne Canty, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Sanitation, said the department was reviewing how the ruling would affect the Greenpoint incinerator currently operating and sending its ash to the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island. The plant is scheduled to shut in June.

HEADLINE: Executives Are Contented but . . .

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
With their sales rising smartly, a majority of America's top executives are far more sanguine about the economy than the general public is, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
But many executives also have a complaint: they can't get the price increases that many say are needed to keep their businesses thriving. The executives favor, in effect, a bit more inflation -- for their industries, at least -- than the current mild national level. 
 And that produced contradictory responses to two questions in the poll. Fifty-five percent of the 484 senior executives surveyed last week praised the Federal Reserve for pushing up interest rates in recent months as a precaution against future inflation. But 56 percent expressed alarm that the rising rates could hurt their sales.
 
Conflicting Attitudes

 
 "I appreciate that the Federal Reserve is a guardian against inflation," said Robert W. Cardy, president of the Carpenter Technology Corporation, a steel company in Reading, Pa. "But I also must say that the higher rates have increased the installment payments on our loans and they inhibit our customers. I know that I am giving a double answer here."
Despite the concerns about the prospect of higher interest rates, the executives who responded to the survey -- all top officers at companies representing a cross section of American industry -- were clearly optimistic. Eighty-seven percent of them rated business at their own companies as "very good" or "fairly good." Eighty-two percent gave the same ratings to the national economy. And 51 percent said the economy would continue to improve.
A Times/CBS News Poll earlier last month surveyed the public on these same two questions about the economy. In each case, the public trailed the executives in optimism by at least 25 percentage points. The difference might reflect the fact that while sales and profits are rising, pleasing the executives, hiring is increasing only slowly and wages are rising hardly at all, which is not so pleasing for the labor force, though it is a plus to business.
Sales are certainly booming at Automatic Systems Inc. in Kansas City, Mo., a manufacturer of assembly-line equipment, particularly for auto companies. "There is more work in my field today than in the 34 years that I have been in this business," Robert A. Hoehn, president of the company, said. That translates into more jobs -- up to a point.
While sales rose to $85 million last year from $75 million in 1992 and are likely to break $100 million this year, Automatic Systems is adding just 40 people this year, bringing its permanent staff back only to its 1991 level of 310 people. Mr. Hoehn said he would not go above 310 people or bid up wages to get skilled workers, although they are sometimes hard to find. The standard raise at Automatic Systems keeps wages roughly abreast of inflation. The pay is $12 an hour for production workers.
"We don't have enough confidence in the future to hire more people," Mr. Hoehn said. "From what our customers are telling us, 1995 and 1996 should also be good years. But I can't see the strength lasting beyond that."
Responses to the poll suggested that Mr. Hoehn's labor strategy was a common one. Fifty-one percent of the executives said their companies would keep employment levels unchanged over the next 12 months, although 63 percent said they would add workers over the next five years. In addition, 63 percent said that most of the jobs created at their companies in recent years had not been "high quality," by which they meant the jobs had not been high wage.
 
No Plans for Hiring

 
 "We will probably hold our employment at where it is now, which is 750 people," said Paul Wheeler, senior vice president of the Inland Group Inc., a Chicago company that buys and sells commercial real estate and owns and rents or leases more than 20,000 apartments and stores. Most of the employees are rental agents and maintenance personnel earning less than $25,000 a year.
Mr. Hoehn, Mr. Wheeler and Mr. Cardy were among various executives representing companies of different sizes and different industries who were interviewed after they had participated in the poll. Like most of the others, the three men tied the upturn in their businesses to the decline in interest rates through most of last year. The low rates gave a lift to the economy in several crucial ways.
Millions of people refinanced mortgages and their lower monthly payments gave them extra cash for spending. The lower rates also produced a boom in auto and truck sales, most of them on credit, and more business for the thousands of companies that supply this industry, including Mr. Hoehn's and Mr. Cardy's. In addition, the low rates helped housing and real estate, by lowering mortgage rates -- and also the rates on the Inland Group's $500 million in loans outstanding to finance its real estate operations.
"When the cost of financing goes up," Mr. Wheeler said, "we have to add that to rents or to the prices of real estate we sell. It is too soon to say whether the higher rates have hurt our business, but maybe they have."
 
Some Reservations About Policy

 
 Since February, the Federal Reserve has pushed rates up to slow the business revival and thus prevent inflationary price increases. But Mr. Hoehn, Mr. Cardy, Mr. Wheeler and others say the Fed may be acting too far ahead of the potential danger.
"The Fed is trying to stop inflation that is not here yet, but will come six to eight months down the road," Mr. Hoehn said. "That is a laudable goal, but it is crystal ball reading that we are not capable of. Maybe the Fed isn't either."
Just as there was ambivalence about the Federal Reserve, there was ambivalence among the executives -- many of them Republicans -- about the Clinton Administration. While only 27 percent approved of the President's handling of the economy, 67 percent said the Administration's policies had not had much of an impact on their companies, one way or another. By comparison, 43 percent of the 1,215 people polled in the survey of the public approved of the President's handling of the economy.
"I just don't feel a confidence in this man; I don't see a pilot in the pilot seat," said Louis E. Lavoie, president of Northeast Knitting Inc., a Providence, R.I., company that makes elastic waist bands that are sewn into clothing.
Still, Mr. Lavoie, who voted for George Bush, says that rising interest rates are a bigger problem for him than President Clinton is. His borrowing costs are up, he says, although they have not climbed enough yet to hurt; others share this view.
The Fed, however, pushed up rates just when some of the companies were hoping that the expanding economy might allow them to raise prices. Instead, 58 percent of the executives said they would hold prices steady over the next year, while 35 percent anticipated increases.
 
Outlook for Expansion

 
 Higher prices would bring fatter profits without having to rely so heavily on cutting costs, the executives said. And the higher prices might make possible a sufficient return on investment to justify greater spending to expand operations. Forty-nine percent of the executives said their companies would expand capacity over the next 12 months.
Andritz-Ruthner, an Austrian company with a factory in Arlington, Tex., has expanded. It makes equipment for waste-water treatment and to finish steel surfaces, both products in rising demand. "We expanded capacity a nudge at the start of the year, adding people and equipment, but not space, to increase the output by 10 percent," said Tim Ryan, the president. "Now we have stopped. We want to be sure that in 1996 we still have enough business; you make a big investment like that and you don't want to have to cut back."
 
Hoping for Higher Prices

 
 Andritz-Ruthner has been squeezing greater profit from rising sales volume and some cost-cutting, Mr. Ryan said. To sustain the profit and justify more investment, he says, there must be price increases.
"We can't get them," he said. "On both the environmental and steel side, there is a bunch of hungry competition. The steel competition is global -- a German company, an Italian company, anyone and everyone. On the waste-water side, the competition is mostly American, but here, too, there is plenty of supply. We see new companies pop up all the time. They think this is a hot button."
What would justify a major expansion? "Another $10 million a year in revenue for at least three years," Mr. Ryan said. That would bring current sales revenue to $60 million and would justify a $3.5 million investment to expand, raising employment in the process to 150 from the present 125. Rising interest rates endanger Mr. Ryan's goal, if they slow the economy, making price increases and greater sales revenue that much harder to get.
"I would have liked to see the Federal Reserve handle things differently," Mr. Ryan said, without being specific. "But rates will have to go up another couple of percentage points before they become a problem."
 
How the Poll Was Conducted

 
 The New York Times/CBS News Poll of business executives was based on interviews with 484 senior executives at companies throughout the United States, interviewed by telephone from April 15 to April 29.
The sample of companies and executives was randomly drawn by Dun & Bradstreet Information Services from listings in its data base of privately held and publicly owned companies.
Companies with $5 million or more in annual revenues were eligible for the section of the survey dealing with the economy. At each company one executive at a senior level was interviewed. Titles of those eligible to be polled included owner, partner, chief executive, president, chairman, executive vice president and senior vice president, with first opportunity for an interview given to the most senior executive.
The completed sample included 248 interviews in companies with $5 million to $99 million in annual revenue, 121 interviews in companies with $100 million to $499 million, and 115 interviews in companies with revenues of $500 million or more. The completed sample was then weighted by revenue size to reflect the actual distribution of all listed companies in the country, because smaller companies predominate.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, results based on such samples will differ by no more than six percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out senior executives at all listed companies in the country with annual revenues of $5 million or more.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for the biggest companies, those with $500 million or more in annual revenue, it is plus or minus nine percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey can introduce other sources of error. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: Index of Leading Indicators Advanced by 0.7% in March

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
In a sharp rebound from the effects of winter storms, the Government's chief economic forecasting gauge jumped by seven-tenths of 1 percent in March, the eighth consecutive month without a decline.
Though today's Commerce Department report was in line with expectations, economists said the rise in the index of leading indicators provided reassurance after last week's report that the economy had grown at a somewhat disappointing pace of 2.6 percent during the first quarter of the year. 
 "It shows that things are still alive and well," said Raymond A. Worseck, chief economist for A. G. Edwards & Sons, a brokerage house in St. Louis. "The pattern shows broad growth," he added, typical of this point in the business cycle, when expansion is well established.
 But others pointed to what they considered somewhat unnerving signs of a slowdown and faster inflation.
More than half the March advance was accounted for by a huge jump in the length of the average factory workweek that more than offset a big decline in February caused by exceptionally harsh winter weather. At 42.2 hours, the workweek is at the highest level since World War II.
The second-biggest contributor to the rise in the index was higher prices for materials especially sensitive to the level of business activity. This component, taken partly from the Labor Department's indexes of producer prices and partly from direct gauges of the spot market, has climbed four consecutive months, with each increase bigger than its predecessor.
 That indicated more rapid inflation ahead, said Russell G. Redenbaugh of Kairos Inc., a financial management strategy concern in Philadelphia, a prospect that could help sustain a slackening economy as consumers buy in anticipation of still higher prices. Mr. Redenbaugh noted price increases announced this week by the Ford Motor Company.
Seven other components also helped push the index higher, but none was decisive. They were a rise in building permits, lower first-time claims for unemployment benefits, a smaller decline in factory backlogs for durable goods, a rise in new factory orders, higher orders for plant and equipment, a rise in consumer expectations and an enlarged money supply.
The only restraining forces were vendor performance -- a smaller proportion of companies reported slower deliveries from suppliers -- and stock prices, which declined by 1.6 percent in March as gauged by the Standard & Poor's Corporation's 500-stock index.
One sign the economy may be slowing is that the leading index, though at a record high, rose by 1.1 percent in the first quarter, a bit less than its gain of 1.3 percent in the final three months of 1993.
 
 
'A Decent Clip'
 "We're still coasting at a decent clip," said Carl Palash of MCM Money Watch, a New York market advisory firm, "but the foot's off the accelerator."
A wide variety of analysts continued to predict that the Federal Reserve would decide at its meeting on May 17 to raise short-term interest rates again, with some saying the case was bolstered by the report today.
David Bostian, a New York economist, said the very long workweek and higher sensitive materials prices "probably could be read as justification to support the hawkish view" against inflation. Mr. Bostian constructs his own predictive index for the economy, which this month was unchanged.
Companion Commerce Department indexes on coincident and lagging economic indicators were mixed in March. The coincident index, gauging current conditions, rose by four-tenths of 1 percent after a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent in February and a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent in January.
The lagging index, composed of indicators that usually turn after the economy overall does, edged down by one-tenth of 1 percent in March after falling four-tenths of 1 percent in February and rising three-tenths of 1 percent in January.
 
 
Ratio Cited
 The ratio of the coincident to the lagging index -- regarded by many as a better predictor than the leading index -- rose to 116.8 in March from 116.1 in February and 114.8 in January.
Another private forecasting index, compiled by Safian Investment Research in White Plains, rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent in March, to 206.81. Of its 24 components, 14 rose and 10 fell.
The index still points to business expansion, according to Kenneth Safian, but the severe winter has clouded projections. "While there are no indications that a slowdown is developing," he said, "some individual series and the changed monetary policy point to a reduced pace of growth later this year."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues Its Decline Against Yen and the Mark

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar continued to fall against the Japanese yen and the German mark yesterday as traders questioned the Clinton Administration's commitment to defending it.
The doubts were heightened as traders said they could find no evidence that the Federal Reserve Bank of New York was buying the dollar to support it. 
 On Friday, the Fed, which acts as the Treasury's agent in the foreign exchange markets, bought dollars for marks and yen when the dollar fell against both currencies. Traders were looking for similar intervention yesterday as proof that the Administration was determined to put a floor under the dollar.
"People don't think the Fed is serious about defending the dollar," said Chris Iggo, international economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. "As long as it's orderly, the Fed seems willing to let the dollar fall."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 101.00 yen, from 101.67 yen on Monday, less than one yen away from its post-World War II low of 100.35 yen set in August.
The dollar also tumbled to 1.6370 marks, from 1.6491 on Monday. It traded as low as 1.6358 marks, its lowest point since Oct. 20.
Mr. Iggo and others suspect that the Fed will only buy dollars again if stock and bond markets go into a tailspin. Bond prices have fallen for four straight trading sessions amid concern that a weak dollar will diminish the value of American assets and fuel inflation by making imports more expensive.
Unless the Fed takes further action, the dollar is likely to suffer as more traders lose faith in it. "There's real anti-dollar sentiment out there right now," said Dave Glowacki, senior trader at NBD Bank in Detroit. "No one wants to buy it."
Many traders are abandoning the dollar because it failed to rally in the first four months of the year, even though German interest rates fell and American interest rates rose. Higher American rates usually make dollar-denominated assets more attractive. Instead, the dollar has fallen 5 percent against the mark and 9 percent against the yen since Jan. 1.
The dollar's decline accelerated yesterday after Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen again urged Japan to reduce its trade surplus with the United States. In a speech, he said Tokyo's new Government should cut taxes to raise consumer spending and increase Japan's appetite for foreign goods.
"Bentsen's tough talk on Japan indicates that the Administration isn't going to defend a certain exchange rate," said Amy Smith, currency-market strategist at IDEA, a consulting firm. "Bashing Japan and supporting the dollar are incompatible."
For more than a year now, the dollar has usually weakened every time the United States has put pressure on Japan over trade policy, as traders bet that the Administration would resume calls for a strong yen to make American exports cheaper and Japanese imports more expensive.
Signs of strength in the German economy also weighed on the dollar yesterday. With stronger growth, the Bundesbank will be under less pressure to cut interest rates.
"The dollar is a hot potato right now," said David Durst, a trader at Bear, Stearns & Company. "People buy it, lose a little money, and get rid of it."

HEADLINE: Pact Is Reached on Ecuador's Foreign Debt

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Ecuador and its creditor banks have reached a landmark foreign debt agreement that will restructure the country's payments on $7.6 billion in debt and overdue interest over the next 30 years.
The agreement, which was reached late Monday night, allows the banks to swap their old loans for more secure bonds while Ecuador will get a 45 percent reduction in the total amount of debt it owes. In addition, the agreement will let the South American nation rejoin international financial markets fully for the first time since it halted debt payments in May 1992. 
 Ecuador is the second Latin American country to come to a debt agreement with its banks in the last several weeks. Last month, Brazil, the developing world's largest debtor nation, signed an agreement with its banks. The Brazil deal basically closed the door on the debt crisis of the 1980's, which began with Mexico's default on its debt payments in 1982.
 
 
Brady Plan
 Both these deals, as were those reached earlier for countries like Mexico and Argentina, were done through the debt reduction plan originated by the former United States Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady. The plan allows creditors swap debt for open-market bonds at a discount.
Expectations that the agreement was imminent have helped raise prices for Ecuadorean debt on the secondary debt market in New York and London for over a week.
The two sides announced the agreement as support for the free-market economic reforms of Ecuador's President, Sixto Duran Ballen, has been slipping badly.
The ruling party lost all but 10 of its 37 seats in Congress in congressional elections Sunday, which opposition parties took as a public rejection of the Government's economic policies.
"After 12 years of debt crisis and several years of difficult negotiations, this agreement will normalize the country's relations with its private creditors," Ecuador's Finance Minister, Cesar Robalino, said in a statement issued in New York.
 
 
U.S. Bonds as Collateral
 Under the pact, creditors will be allowed to swap the principal amount of their loans to Ecuador for either discount bonds or par bonds, both dollar-denominated and both with 30-year United States Treasury bonds as collateral.
The discount bonds will be exchanged for existing loans at a discount of 45 percent from the face value of the debt. The par bonds, which are are swapped at face value, will have discounts on the interest rates.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Split Over Rate Rises

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
Members of Congress engaged in partisan wrangling over rising interest rates today, with Democrats warning that they could threaten economic growth while a prominent Republican called for further increases.
The flurry of comments on monetary policy followed the release this morning of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee's annual report on the state of the economy. Both the Democratic and Republican portions of the report concluded that higher interest rates were a big threat to the economy, but only the Democrats explicitly blamed the Federal Reserve for the recent increases in rates. 
 "The interaction of financial leverage with interest-rate increases by the Fed may be the single biggest danger to continued economic recovery," the Democratic section of the report said.
Representative Richard K. Armey, a Texas Republican who is on the committee, called at a news conference today for the Fed to continue to reduce growth in the nation's money supply, which means raising short-term interest rates. Further tightening of monetary policy is needed to reassure the public that inflation is under control, he said.
Mr. Armey drew a distinction between short-term rates, which the Fed controls, and long-term rates, which the Fed does not control. Long-term rates are rising because Americans are increasingly worried about inflation, not because the Fed has raised short-term rates three times this year, Mr. Armey said.
"The Fed's duty is to make the American people comfortable with a stable currency," Mr. Armey said.
Three times recently -- Feb. 4, March 22 and April 18 -- the Federal Reserve has raised the rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans, by a quarter of a percentage point each time.
Most private economists say raising short-term rates tends to hold down long-term rates, but seldom immediately. Long-term interest rates for bonds and mortgages have jumped by more than a percentage point since the Fed began raising short-term rates in February.
Two of Mr. Armey's Republican colleagues on the Joint Economic Committee, Representative H. James Saxton of New Jersey and Representative Christopher Cox of California, were more cautious, saying politicians should leave monetary policy to the Fed.

HEADLINE: Clinic Entices Patients With $10 a Visit

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
THE Prudential Health Care Plan, which provides health care to 45,000 Medicaid recipients in Baltimore, has undertaken an innovative incentive program to encourage poor, pregnant women to see a doctor and to attend sessions on nutrition, smoking and substance abuse. Every time a woman in its Medicaid program shows up for an appointment, she gets a $10 bill on the spot.
Since beginning the program in 1991, Prudential has seen a sharp increase in the number of pregnant women visiting its clinics and a decline in the average length of stay in newborn intensive care units. 
 Prudential considers the program an unqualified success. It now serves 1,500 women a year, giving out $6,000 a month in incentives. But some question whether it is sending the right message. Is it really better to pay people to take care of themselves than to plead with them? Do the ends justify the means?
 
Jump in Keeping Appointments
 Before the incentives started, just 40 percent of women who made appointments for prenatal visits showed up in the doctor's office, said Patricia Ann La Belle, who oversees the health program, which is owned by the Prudential Insurance Company of America. And, she added, of those who did go, "most were coming in in the second trimester or late in the third trimester; at that point, you have lost the battle."
Now, she said, 80 to 90 percent of women keep their appointments. Even among teen-agers, 60 percent of the women are visiting the clinics in their first trimester, up from 20 percent.
The length of stay in the newborn intensive care unit has dropped from four to six weeks a few years ago to three to four weeks today. Although more relevant data might be the number of babies entering the newborn intensive care unit, Prudential does not have those statistics. The company says it did not set out to do a scientific study that would have proved its effectiveness.
"We thought it was worthwhile from the beginning," said Ms. La Belle. If any intensive care admissions can be avoided, "we're ahead for the year," she said. Six weeks in intensive care costs $60,000 to $80,000. The children are often left with chronic medical conditions requiring lifelong treatment.
But while the program's supporters point out that health education and prenatal care can help prevent the birth of premature babies, saving millions of dollars in medical bills and averting personal tragedies, it has critics as well. They ask if society should be paying women to take advantage of medical care that not only can make a difference between a healthy baby and a sick, handicapped one but is free.
Dr. Uwe Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University, called the program an extraordinary indictment of the poor. "It's a sad commentary that we have to pay people to do what they should be doing anyway," he said.
 
No Patient Complaints
 Ms. La Belle expressed surprise at Dr. Reinhardt's criticism, and said she had heard no complaints from local people or community leaders. "I guess if it were truly insulting, patients would not come in and accept it," she said.
Dr. Sheila Kamerman, a professor of social policy and social planning at Columbia University, said she disagreed with Dr. Reinhardt's assessment. "There are so many barriers to health care, and the barriers are greatest for low-income women," she said. The $10, Dr. Kamerman said, "may reduce the cost of transportation or may pay for a baby sitter if she has another child."
"I guess it's a matter of where you're coming from," said Ms. La Belle. "For someone who's trying to think about a way to support their infant and provide for basics, you say, 'Wow.' "
Joan Willemain, a social worker at one of the Prudential clinics, at Sinai Hospital in Baltimore, said many of the women who visited her clinic were overwhelmed by transportation problems or reluctant to come in because they were drug users. "People who are abusing substances are often avoiding prenatal care, but they are the people we have to get in," she said. The payment, Ms. Willemain said, "is definitely a carrot for some people." But, she added: "I have mixed feelings about the message. It is strange to have to pay someone to care about their child."
The Prudential program also raises the question of what else people should be paid to do. For example, many people do not have their children immunized, although vaccinations are free for them.
 
Financial Incentive for Prudential

Should Prudential pay parents to have their children immunized? "We would seriously consider it," Ms. La Belle said.
One critic of the program points out that beneath the surface, Prudential has an added financial interest in carrying out the program. It may give Prudential an edge in the heated competition among managed care plans to sign up Medicaid recipients, said Dr. Bernard Guyer, chairman of the department of maternal and child health at the Johns Hopkins University School of Hygiene and Public Health. In poor neighborhoods, he said, "the H.M.O.'s are literally out on the streets signing people up," adding, "Two and two sorts of fits together and begins to add up to this strategy."
A few other insurers that run Medicaid programs are also trying incentives to encourage women to come for prenatal visits, but many say they cannot afford to do it on Prudential's scale.
In Alabama, says Debra Housch, the health education coordinator at the Jefferson County Board of Health in Birmingham, women sign a contract agreeing to come for eight prenatal visits and to see a social worker three times. On their second visit, they get a baby bottle with a bib and infant teaspoon tucked inside. If they complete the program, they get a layette with a diaper bag, blankets, and clothes for the baby. The gifts cost Medicaid $17, Ms. Housch said. The Alabama program has just begun.
 
Gift of Lottery Tickets
 In Denver, women on Medicaid who come in for prenatal visits are given lottery tickets worth $1 each. Loretta Ivory, the clinical coordinator for obstetrics and gynecology at the Eastside Neighborhood Health Center in Denver, said she and her colleagues had been perplexed by the finding that just 27 to 30 percent of poor women who eventually were treated at the clinic had come in for prenatal care in their first trimester.
They surveyed women and found that nearly all knew that prenatal care was important. "Ninety-seven percent of the women in our clinic said you should start as soon as you know you are pregnant," Ms. Ivory said. When asked why they did not get prenatal care, women most often replied, "I don't know."
"There were all these white, middle class men saying, 'Oh, they need to be educated,' " Ms. Ivory said. "They don't need to be educated." She and her colleagues decided to try lottery tickets as an incentive. The program, supported by the March of Dimes, began in 1992. Now, about 45 percent of the pregnant women treated at the clinic are coming in during their first trimester, she said. "It's great," she said. "We love it."
Researchers are not sure just what it is about prenatal care that is so beneficial. Dr. Marie McCormick, chairwoman of the department of maternal and child health at the Harvard School of Public Health, suggests that if the Prudential program results in healthier babies, it may be educational programs that make a difference.
A small project she directed in Harlem in the early 1980's also involved paying poor pregnant women to come in, in that case $5 for each visit to a doctor. But it did not have the same educational component, and although women did come in, the investigators saw no effect on the health of their babies. The researchers were discouraged, Dr. McCormick said, and never published their findings.
Dr. McCormick said there could also be practical problems with cash-incentive programs. How safe is it for clinic workers in inner-city neighborhoods to keep the cash that they hand out? Dr. McCormick said there was also a concern that women might use the money for drugs, alcohol or cigarettes.
Dr. Ronald Munson, an ethicist at the University of Missouri, said he took a pragmatic view of the Prudential program. "What would you see as another practical solution?" he asked. "This is a program that takes the situation as it finds it." And, he said, since everyone wins if women get prenatal care -- the taxpayers, the women, their babies and the insurance companies -- he finds it laudable.
 
Value of Money
 Women who visited the Prudential clinic at Sinai Hospital one week recently indicated that the money had made an impact.
Tyra Bannerman arrived with her baby girl, Aspen, in her arms. Aspen was born on March 1, at full term and weighing 8 pounds, 4 1/2 ounces. Ms. Bannerman said that she came regularly for medical care and education and that she would have come whether or not she got the $10 bills. But, she added, other young women, including her cousins, went there for the money.
"I think if they cut out the $10, a lot of girls would stop going to the clinic," she said. "I have actually been in the waiting room and heard females say that."
Bonita Moulden, eight months pregnant, sat down in the social worker's office and immediately asked for $10 because she had gone to an educational session on AIDS before visiting the obstetrics clinic. Asked whether the money made a difference to her, she said it did not. At the close of an interview with a reporter, she asked whether she would be paid $10 for that, too.
Ms. Housch of Alabama said that in the end, the only thing that mattered to her was getting women to come in for care. "We cannot be concerned with whether or not we are bribing, " she said. "I don't really care what I have to do to get them in as long as I get them in."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A health care plan pays patients $10 for keeping appointments. But Tyra Bannerman, with her daughter, Aspen, and Dr. Fritz Apollon at Sinai Hospital in Baltimore, said she would go to the clinic even if she were not being paid. (Marty Katz for The New York Times)
