HEADLINE: Auto Sales Slip From March Pace

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 4

 BODY:
After car buyers unexpectedly stampeded showrooms in March, the torrid growth of auto sales eased in April to a 4.9 percent jump, compared with a strong period a year earlier.
Auto makers whose sales growth slowed pointed to several factors in reporting their totals today, from shortages of some best-selling cars and trucks to rising interest rates. Regardless of the explanation, auto industry analysts, who perversely regarded the March news as too good, were delighted with the more measured pace of April. 
 "The bond market will be encouraged by the numbers, since they show the economy is slowing down somewhat from the first-quarter pace, on the auto side," said David M. Garrity, an auto industry analyst for McDonald & Company, a securities firm in Jersey City. Investors in auto companies will also be reassured, he predicted, since the sales jump of 19.7 percent in March had raised fears that the auto sales boom might peak sooner than 1996 or 1997, the peak predicted by many analysts.
 
 
 
'Comforting' News
 Jack Kirnan, the auto analyst for Salomon Brothers, called the results "extremely comforting." Given high levels of consumer confidence, combined with low consumer debt burdens and an aging fleet of vehicles on the road, Mr. Kirnan expressed no doubts that the recovery remained on track. "We've got close to six million units of pent-up demand left to be satisfied in the U.S. market," he said.
Many dealers said their biggest problem remained low inventories. "The demand is there and the supply isn't," said Ron Hughes, general manager of Diehl Chevrolet-Cadillac in Lewisburg, Pa. "We could use 50 percent more vehicles than we have in stock."
Dealers said they expected sales to stay strong through 1994, although some expressed fears that rising interest rates, combined with price increases announced this week by the Big Three, could scare away consumers. "Higher prices mixed with higher interest rates could hurt," said Billy Bruce, Ford new car sales manager at Blount/Strange Automotive Group in Montgomery, Ala.
 
Sales Up for Light Trucks
 Over all, dealers sold 1,306,385 vehicles in April, including imports, up from 1,244,950 a year earlier. Sales of light trucks -- pickups, mini-vans, and sport utility vehicles -- grew 9.5 percent, from 476,748 to 521,977. Car sales grew 2.1 percent, from 768,202 to 784,408.
The seasonally adjusted selling rate for cars was 7.4 million units, up from 6.9 million a year earlier, but down from 7.6 million in March.
The three domestic auto makers set truck sales records for April. In total, the Big Three lost a small amount of their overall vehicle market share to Japanese companies but the monthly results varied widely by company.
While the Toyota Motor Corporation lost some ground, the Honda Motor Company posted strong gains, as sales of the new Honda Accord surged 44 percent, to 32,751. The robust sales appear to have resulted partly from an attractive lease offer Honda has promoted for the car.
The General Motors Corporation saw its sales drop slightly. While its light-truck sales climbed 4.9 percent, to 168,135, its car sales slipped 4.1 percent, to 269,460, dragging down G.M.'s total sales in the period by eight-tenths of a percent.
G.M. attributed the drop in car sales in part to its effort to decrease less profitable sales to car rental companies. Also, G.M. pointed to low inventories of its Chevrolet Lumina sedan. Since November, G.M. has been retooling the Oshawa, Ontario, factory where it builds the Lumina, and it has slowly begun to produce a redesigned model.
Other companies appear to have had more success managing their inventories. The Chrysler Corporation entered April with lower dealer supplies of cars and trucks than either G.M. or the Ford Motor Company. Yet Chrysler had the biggest sales increases, with its light truck sales rising 13.6 percent and its car sales gaining 4.7 percent.

HEADLINE: Credit Bill Passed in Senate

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
The Senate passed a sweeping bill today to make it easier for consumers to fix erroneous credit reports so they are not denied loans. It would also require credit reporting agencies to maintain accurate files and correct wrong information within 30 days.
 The bill, which passed by a 87-to-10 vote, would be the first big overhaul of the Fair Credit Reporting Act of 1970. The full House is expected to act soon on similar legislation. 
 Consumers could get one report a year at a cost of no more than $3 under the Senate bill. The unemployed, welfare recipients and fraud victims could get free copies. Reports now cost $8 or more, although TRW Inc., one of the largest credit reporting companies, offers consumers free reports.
 Consumers could dial a toll-free number to contact big credit bureaus, which operate computer data bases brimming with financial information that help determine whether individuals get access to credit or land jobs.
 Credit reporting agencies would have to notify a person before reinserting data that had been previously removed.
 The bill would also make it easier for individuals to insure that the information in their credit files is not used by catalogue companies or other direct marketers.

HEADLINE: The Gun Minority Flexes Muscle

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
Foreigners cannot understand it. Neither can Americans who live in cities where neighborhoods are terrorized by guns and gangs. How can it be that the overwhelming majority of Americans say they favor stronger Government restrictions on firearms, yet Congress even has trouble controlling civilian possession of rapid-fire weapons originally designed for military and police use.
The answer is that Americans who oppose gun control tend to feel much more strongly about the issue than than do those who favor it. 
 Politicians read polls showing that 80 percent of Americans favor outlawing assault weapons, but they doubt that very many of their constituents who are part of that 80 percent will vote for or against them solely on the basis of their vote on the issue.
On the other hand, many politicians feel sure that their position on gun control will be the main factor determining how their constituents in the 20 percent minority will vote in the next election.
 
Showdown in House
 "If you polled my district, it would be a tossup," said Representative Jim Chapman, a Democrat from rural East Texas. "But all the calls are against it."
The matter will come to a head Thursday, when the House votes on whether to prohibit the manufacture, sale or possession of 19 types of weapons that were designed fully automatic weapons for military use but semiautomatic models of them are increasingly the weapons of street violence.
Staff assistants in the White House and Congress who are carefully keeping track of how the vote is likely to go said this afternoon that they expected the gun-control measure to be defeated narrowly, but they cautioned that the tally was so neck and neck that the outcome could change overnight.
Several lawmakers who had announced their opposition to the bill switched sides today and said they planned to vote for it. One, Peter I. Blute, a freshman Republican who represents small towns in central Massachusetts, said his mind had been changed by complaints from police officers in his district that they were being outgunned.
As a result of the switches, Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is leading the fight for the bill, said today that his side was only 5 to 10 votes behind and gaining. On Tuesday, he had put the gap at 15 votes.
President Clinton made a strong appeal for the measure at a meeting with administrators of municipal housing authorities and law-enforcement officers. He, Vice President Al Gore, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Attorney General Janet Reno spent much of the day calling undecided lawmakers.
The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, refused to predict the result of Thursday's vote, telling reporters, "It has definitely been moving toward a closer vote."
Mr. Foley, who comes from a rural district in eastern Washington where hunting is the sport of choice, is opposing the White House on this issue, the first time he has done so on a major vote since Mr. Clinton became President.
The proponents do not really believe that outlawing assault weapons would have much effect on crime. And the opponents do not really believe that such a ban would seriously intrude on the lives of law-abiding gun owners.
But both sides view the issue symbolically, as a foot in the door toward more restrictive gun laws like a prohibition of handguns or a requirement that all weapons be registered with the authorities.
Experts in public opinion say that American attitudes on firearms have shifted in the last decade as gun-related violence has increasingly dominated the news.
"Today if you vote for gun control, you can gain votes," said Peter Hart, a Democratic pollster.
But Congress seems to be somewhat behind the public curve on the issue, in part because many representatives who staked out a position against gun control years ago are loathe to be seen as flip-flopping.
"It's hard for us to win converts from their side," said Wayne R. LaPierre Jr., executive vice president of the National Rifle Association. "It's tough for them to win converts from our side."
Advocates of gun control have been saying for years that the rifle association's influence is waning. Maybe so. But stories are legion about the fighting ability of its army of more than 3 million members.
This is one issue in which party politics carries little weight. Three former Presidents -- Gerald R. Ford, Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan -- sent a letter to Congress today supporting the ban on assault weapons. If Democrats seem to be stronger proponents of gun control than Republicans, it is largely because lawmakers from cities tend to be Democrats.
Conservative Republicans from urban areas like Susan Molinari from Staten Island and Henry J. Hyde and John Edward Porter, who represent suburbs of Chicago, plan to vote for the bill on Thursday. Representatives David R. Obey, who comes from northern Wisconsin, and Pat Williams of Montana are among the prominent liberal Democrats from rural areas who have announced their opposition.
When his fellow liberals, try to change his mind, Mr. Obey, a sophisticated legislator who once was chairman of the Joint Economic Committee and now heads the powerful Appropriations Committee, explains how shooting squirrels and hunting game are a way of life in his rural district and how any restrictions on guns are at best an imposition.
If New Yorkers and San Franciscans have trouble understanding this, foreigners are completely baffled. "In most of the developed world," said the British magazine The Economist this spring, "guns are the province of policemen, hunters, marksmen and certain criminals." But in the United States, the magazine's editors went on in amazement, guns "are so ordinary, so common, they have become part of the furniture."

Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, talked to a reporter as he accompanied Attorney General Janet Reno to a meeting on the gun bill. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Vietnamese Delegation Seeking American Capital

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

 BODY:
Like many Vietnamese of his generation, Pham Chanh Truc protested against the American military presence in Vietnam. He was jailed once, escaped and worked eight years in the Vietcong underground before he was caught and jailed again. When Communist forces drove out the South Vietnamese Army in 1975, Saigon became Ho Chi Minh City and Mr. Truc joined its new Government.
Now, nearly two decades later, as vice chairman of the People's Committee of Ho Chi Minh City, Mr. Truc is leading the first Vietnamese delegation to the United States since the American trade embargo was lifted in February. With an ambitious two-week tour to drum up financial investment for the city, the Vietnamese are, in effect, inviting Americans back to Vietnam.
 
Forgoing Pride for Technology
 "I don't think I wasted my prime years," Mr. Truc said in an interview last week as the delegation headed to the headquarters of Pepsico in Somers, N.Y. "I did the thing I believed in, the right thing, fighting for the independence and sovereignty of Vietnam. So I don't think this is an irony for me, but an advantage. I was able to participate in the first phase of gaining back our country, and I am still here, participating in its construction." 
 If the trip might strike some Americans as audacious, Mr. Truc viewed it through a lens of pragmatism and economics. With so much of Vietnam's essential services and facilities in need of repair, much of it because of "the American war," as many Vietnamese call it, the delegates are turning to a country of proven engineering and technological skills, not to mention wealth.
Ho Chi Minh City is the economic engine of Vietnam, with 60 percent of the industrial output and 27 percent of the gross national product, according to the city's latest economic reports. Its population last year was about four and a half million, well above the three million-plus of Hanoi, the capital, in the north.
Yet beyond the city's threshold attempts to seek American financing for new ports, bridges, airfields, telecommunications, natural resource development and roads, the trip to New York and Boston last week, California and Seattle this week, was also planned to help Vietnam establish relationships with American interests at a time when few exist.
The countries have no normal diplomatic relations, and only a handful of big American companies, including Pepsi, Coca-Cola and Mobil, have substantial operations in Vietnam.
Further, many American companies are not likely to invest heavily until Vietnam gains most-favored-nation trading status, a designation that would enable it to export its goods to the United States under the lowest tariff rates.
American experts in United States-Vietnam relations predict that gaining preferential trade status could take two years or more, largely because of lingering concern over American servicemen still listed as missing in action, and the controversy raised in the 1992 campaign over President Clinton's draft avoidance during the Vietnam War.
With an obvious need for funds, Mr. Truc said, Ho Chi Minh City is willing to be patient. The cover article in last week's issue of The Saigon Times, a Government-subsidized weekly magazine, included a headline that said the country "urgently needs foreign investment" to develop adequate electricity supplies. And that is only one area of major need.
 
Playing the America Card
 But the reasons Ho Chi Minh City and the rest of Vietnam appear eager to have Americans back might not be be altogether economic.
Rather, the experts say that an expanded American presence in Vietnam would serve as a strategic buffer against other nations in the region, particularly China, whose economic might provides great advantages over developing nations like Vietnam.
Thomas J. Vallely, director of the Vietnam Program at the Harvard Institute for International Development, cited as one hedge against China Hanoi's decision to grant Mobil exploration rights to the Blue Dragon oilfield in the South China Sea. "A wise decision," he said of the grant.
Two years ago, China signed a contract with another American company, the Crestone Energy Corporation, for rights to explore waters nearby.
A recent analysis of Vietnam's economic situation by a team of Japanese and American scholars said the country also worried about China's dumping of cheap consumer goods in Vietnam and its building of airstrips on the Spratly Islands, disputed by the Chinese and the Vietnamese.
"The Vietnam Government is not only anxious, it is almost desperate to have an American presence in the country," said Irwin Jay Robinson, president of the Vietnam-American Chamber of Commerce in New York. The organization sponsored a business seminar for the visiting delegation last week.
While the lifting of the American embargo by President Clinton in February was a watershed in the old adversaries' relationship, and the expected precursor to normalized trading, this green light hardly unleashed a heavy flow of business traffic into Ho Chi Minh City.
One reason is that the Communist Government lifted its clamps on private enterprise in 1986, ushering in waves of investment from Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore, France and Malaysia. Companies from those areas all have a huge step up on American businesses, especially those that would make products for the domestic market.
Imagine a land in which Marlboro, made by the Philip Morris Companies, is not among the leading foreign cigarettes. In Vietnam, the best-selling brand is 555, from B.A.T. Industries of Britain.
 
Want More Than Wage Advantage
 More than $3 billion in foreign capital is currently financing about 300 projects in the metropolitan area, Mr. Truc said.
The vast majority of that is from countries other than the United States. Until American interests can identify specific advantages for investing in Vietnam, there is little reason to expect change. While companies like Caterpillar and Boeing are eager to sell bulldozers and aircraft to satisfy Vietnam's development needs, far more American companies need more favorable trading conditions to tap the obvious benefits of skilled but cheap labor.
"We're in a never-never land kind of relationship," said Virginia Foote, president of the United States-Vietnam Trade Council in Washington. "American companies are allowed to sell and invest in Vietnam, but they have no real opportunity to buy. The support system to provide that is just not available."
For all the exchanges and contacts they expected to make on their trip, not even a week had passed before Mr. Truc and other members of his delegation reflected a degree of resignation over any sudden increase in American interest. They acknowledged that they would wait at least two years for Congressional consideration of favored trade status for Vietnam.
 
Sugar-Coating Defiance
 Cao Van Quoi, chairman of the city's planning committee, said the visitors had "a long way to go to accomplish" their mission, adding, "I am encouraged by the spirit of cooperation, but I don't think we can have any tangible results right away."
In the meantime, Mr. Truc said Ho Chi Minh City would seek other options. "We're not looking for any specific country to fill the void," he said sharply. "We seek cooperation and building good relations with all countries. If the United States does not come to us fully, we can always go on with partnerships in other countries."
But lest he sound too dismissive of the country he once said he "hated with all my guts," Mr. Truc quickly added, "I would like to reiterate, however, that the United States is a big partner, and we would welcome America to our country."

HEADLINE: Life as a Watershed Irks Putnam County;
New York City Tightens Regulations, and 46 Developers Fire Back by Filing Suit

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BREWSTER, N.Y.

 BODY:
The water that percolates through the soil and courses down the streams of Putnam County is the same water that eventually gushes out of hundreds of thousands of taps in New York City 60 miles to the south. So, for almost a century, the fate of this small, no longer bucolic county has been hitched to the city's thirst for clean water.
But the county's strong-willed residents have never quite thought of themselves as just a watershed, some appendage to a big city, and many say they have become tired of being pushed around by the Goliath to the south.
 
Even Harsher Rules
 Residents complain that the city, to protect its water and avoid spending $8 billion on treatment plants, has stepped up enforcement of long-ignored regulations for sewage treatment and storm-water drainage, forbidding the construction of household septic tanks and asphalt parking lots. In the next few weeks, the city plans to publish even harsher rules that county residents say will make it impossible or prohibitively expensive to build new businesses and homes and will derail the resurgent economy of a county that is two-thirds watershed. 
 Last month, a group of 45 Putnam developers and one Westchester developer filed a $9 billion suit against New York City, charging that their property has been devalued without fair compensation. Beyond Putnam, 34 towns and 5 villages in a second watershed that runs from the the Catskills to the Delaware River filed a similar suit charging economic harm.
"Instead of saying, 'let's work together,' they have bullied everyone," said Thomas Bisogno, a writer and real estate agent who supports the suit. "Even if you had a small office park they would find ways of slowing it down or making it expensive to do the job."
One Putnam litigant, Jack Forbes, said that he once proposed building 60 homes on Quaker Hill Road in Patterson and received all the necessary local approvals. But he said the city objected that his land was too steep for the septic systems he was planning and would send inadequately treated water into streams feeding the watershed. Now, after investing more than $1 million, he has despaired of building anything larger than a 10-home development, disappointing his investors.
"They've ruined my name, my business, my reputation in this town without due process of law," Mr. Forbes said.
New York City officials, and some environmentalists, respond that the city must act to stem the degradation of its water. Marilyn G. Gelber, the city's environmental protection commissioner, said she must enforce regulations that have been in place since 1953 and strengthen them in line with "new thinking" about watershed protection. But, she adds, she wants to do so in consultation with Putnam officials.
"The strong preference is that we settle it over a conference table rather than a courtroom," she said.
For a city struggling with fiscal problems, there is a major economic incentive to protect the watershed. On Dec. 30, Federal regulators gave the city three years to prove it can safeguard the watershed, or else it must spend up to $8 billion to build massive filtration plants. The city has already earmarked at least $439 million during the next three years to acquire 80,000 acres of additional protected land, to upgrade sewage treatment plants in the watershed and for other programs.
But as critics point out, the city's own house is not in order. It runs nine sewage plants in the watershed that have long been in disrepair and have violated state guidelines.
The debate is complicated by another of Putnam's uses: as a rustic retreat for New Yorkers. For decades, New Yorkers driving to summer houses in the Berkshires or Columbia County or Putnam could leave their urban tensions behind when Route 684 turned into Route 22. There it became a mostly two-lane country road flanked by grazing cattle and roadside stands where farmers sold fresh apple pies. A stop at the Red Rooster Drive-In, an old-fashioned takeout place famed for its quick hamburgers, hot dogs and milkshakes, has been de rigueur.
 
A Wave of Development
 But a wave of development during the mid-1980's erased much of the pastoral feel, bringing glass-skinned corporate parks, streamlined shopping centers, and sprawling housing developments. These days, only 1 percent of Putnam earns its living by farming.
David C. Gordon, who monitors reservoirs for the Hudson Riverkeeper Fund, an environmental group, supports the city's new discipline. He says Putnam is turning itself into a suburb like Westchester.
"We're taking a natural resource, our natural landscape, our towns, and turning them into junk," he said.
Many Putnam residents, if not most, want development, however, because it brings jobs and tax revenues that help pay for schools and other services. Mr. Gordon argues that such reasoning is specious. The new office parks and homes, he says, eventually require more services, actually increasing the tax burden.
A study prepared for Putnam says that the city's new regulations will cost the county 3,190 jobs by the year 2,000 and increase taxes by 16 percent.
 
A Watershed Identity
 It is difficult to overestimate how much of Putnam's identity is interwoven with the watershed, the vast network of reservoirs and streams from Westchester to the Catskills from which New York draws its water. Two-thirds of Putnam's 231.5 square miles is watershed, and its demarcation as a watershed preserved the county's rural character. One-third of the county's 84,000 residents drink the same water as New Yorkers.
The city obtained almost unparalleled authority over its watershed lands earlier in this century. The State Legislature gave it the right to acquire properties far outside its own borders that would be flooded as reservoirs and it added the power to regulate how other land draining into those reservoirs could be used.
For decades, the city did not enforce many of its regulations. No one cared much at first because Putnam was remote from the suburban pressures transforming Westchester. But with the arrival of Interstates 84 and 684, businesses and commuters were attracted to relatively inexpensive Putnam. In 1980, for example, Putnam granted 199 residential building permits. By 1986 that number leaped to 944.
Four years ago, New York realized that unrestricted development was beginning to erode the taste and purity of Putnam water and began cracking down. The city, the litigants say, has gone too far, turning down two out of every three septic tank proposals in some towns and stalling on others, crippling home building and renovation.
The outcry against the city's watershed regulations has not been as great in northern Westchester, lawyers bringing the suit say, because the area is built up and development pressures have not been as intense.
Three years ago, the city drafted tougher regulations that it expects to publish within weeks. They would require office buildings, shopping centers and factories to build individual sewage treatment plants that discharge their filtered water into the ground, not into streams as most now do. Critics say that only a few spots in the county have soil that could accommodate discharges in line with city standards.
The number of new homes has indeed fallen, from the peak of 944 permits in 1986 to 297 last year. But Michelle Powers, a county planner, says that while regulations have had "a chilling effect," what "really stopped these projects is the economy."
Not everyone in Putnam supports the lawsuit, including its County Executive. Risking the hostility of the County Legislature, the County Executive, Robert Bondi, prefers to negotiate and persuade New York officials to allow county agencies to enforce most watershed regulations. That, he says, would eliminate one more bureaucratic hurdle in the cumbersome process of winning approvals for construction.
He and the litigants agree, however, that Ms. Gelber has been far more open to compromise than her predecessor in the Dinkins administration, Albert F. Appleton.
The lawsuit here has been spearheaded by Edward R. Heelan, a major developer whose small converted schoolhouse of an office overlooks the Middle Branch reservoir. Mr. Heelan, a burly, ruddy-faced surveyor and one of Putnam's largest builders, likes to point out projects that have been stopped by the city's newfound enforcement effort.
 
Individual Approvals
 Mr. Heelan showed a reporter one housing development, Crosby Hills, that was to consist of 49 houses. Only three, he said, have been occupied because the city has been approving each septic tank individually. Most of the corridor of gleaming office buildings and malls along Route 22 could not have been built under the city's proposed regulations, he said.
An ally of Mr. Heelan's, Harold Lepler, owns a lot overlooking Interstate 84 that was to be developed as a storage depot for Safety-Kleen Corporation, a company that recycles used motor oil from gas stations.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In the waters of Putnam County, the crosscurrents run deep. Some two-thirds of it is a watershed for New York City, and its purity means billions of dollars not spent on treatment plants. Many residents, though, feel their prosperity has become the victim of the stringent pollution controls. George Ryer fished in Middle Branch Reservoir. (Dan Cronin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Are Mixed Despite Dollar Defense

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Investor skepticism about how serious a defense the Federal Reserve is mounting for the dollar caused prices of Treasury securities to bounce up and down before ending mixed yesterday, analysts said.
A coordinated intervention by the Fed and foreign central banks yesterday morning in support of the dollar had a positive effect on the market, they said, before stronger-than-expected data for factory orders cut the rally short. 
 Matthew F. Alexy, a government-trading strategist for CS First Boston, said bond prices failed to recover fully despite the intervention because many investors concluded that the central bank was intervening just to stabilize rather than to strengthen the dollar.
The 30-year bond rose 3/32 , to 871/32 and a yield of 7.33 percent, down from 7.35 percent yesterday. Shorter-maturity bills were mixed, with the rate for a three-month issue unchanged at 4.03 percent and a six-month bill up a basis point, to 4.44 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Factory Orders Rise
 Factory orders for March rose 1.1 percent, the seventh increase in eight months. The increase was more than expected by many economists and reinforced the market's fears of faster economic growth and higher inflation. The result was lower bond prices, as investors sold amid rumors that the Federal Reserve would raise rates sooner than May 17, which is the date of the next scheduled meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary-policy-making arm.
Some analysts said there was widespread talk that the Fed would increase the Federal funds rate, its target for short-term interest rates, and the discount rate, the rate it charges on loans to member banks, as the intervention to support the dollar was taking place. Most speculation centered on a move of half a percentage point on both rates. The reason for such rate increases is that they would give more punch to the dollar intervention as well as stem the bearish trend in the bond market.
Bond prices stayed lower until late afternoon, when the Treasury announced the size of its quarterly auction, which is next week, and Detroit issued its monthly car sales reports.
The Treasury said it would sell $29 billion in three-year and 10-year notes next week to raise $775 million in new cash. Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities, said, "The absence of any great surprise on the size of the refunding and sales of motor vehicles that were a shade below expectations enabled the market to do a little better."
Ahead of next week's quarterly auction, the three-year note began trading on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.29 percent and the 10-year note at a price to yield 7.09 percent.
 
Denver Bonds Downgraded

 
In the municipal market, the Denver airport revenue bonds were little changed yesterday, even after Moody's Investors Service lowered the debt rating on $3.2 billion of the securities, traders said.
Because of the city's recent decision to delay the opening of the new airport indefinitely, the rating agency dropped the credit rating of the securities to Baa, from Baa1. The Baa rating is the lowest investment grade Moody's gives.

HEADLINE: Russians Tour Temples of Capitalism

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
For a Russian of not so long ago, bristling with ideology, a trip to Wall Street would have seemed like Daniel being cast into the lion's den.
But for Leon Asrian and 24 other emerging capitalists from Moscow and Siberia, their visit earlier this week to the world's financial capital was not only a long-sought education but also a delicious chance to gawk. 
 Huddled high above the New York Stock Exchange in the visitors' center, they smiled down at the din of bustling capitalist tools. Later, a few blocks away and 80 feet underground, the Russians swooned at the sight of 10,500 gleaming tons of foreign gold stored at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. (To their disappointment, none of the more than 200 trillion rubles worth of gold is believed to be Russian.)
 
Helping Russia's Economy
 "I don't consider myself a Marxist at all," said Mr. Asrian, a wiry international-currency expert with thick aviator-style glasses and sad eyes. "Karl Marx was not a silly man. He was a very wise man. But that is politics, this is economics. I want to make some improvements to our country. That is why I am in your country."
Mr. Asrian, 30 years old, said Russia "is headed for disaster and we must fix it." He noted that bread that once cost 40 kopecks, or 0.4 ruble, now costs 300 rubles. "Russian bread is good, but it is not that good," he said.
In the post-cold-war era, when senior Russian military officers can tour American nuclear-missile silos as television cameras from "60 Minutes" look on, a visit by Russians to Wall Street may not seem unusual.
But this visit is part of a larger pilot program, organized jointly by the United States Treasury Department and the financier George Soros, that is intended to prepare the participants for the more lasting problems of post-cold-war peace and an exhausted Russian economy.
 
25 Russian Executives
 Mr. Asrian is part of a group of 17 men and 8 women from Russia, mostly in their 30's. They are executives from Government and newly privatized financial institutions, such as banks and trade and planning departments, as well as from new ventures like a hotel and a construction company in Siberia.
They were chosen by the Treasury Department and the Soros Foundation, an organization in New York established by the Hungarian-born billionaire to promote the exchange of financial expertise between the United States and Russia and Eastern Europe.
Since mid-April, the Russians have lived in Washington, D.C., attending classes in banking, accounting, insurance and other financial matters.
On Monday, they will begin internships at major American corporations and Government agencies. Mr. Asrian, for example, will work at Riggs National Bank in Washington, learning about banking. Others will work at MCI Communications, Mobil, Marriott International, the Federal Reserve Bank and the Securities and Exchange Commission.
 
A Bourse-and-Bullion Tour
 Earlier this week, Mr, Asrian and the other Russians, none of whom had visited America before, traveled by bus to Wall Street. Shuffling into the narrow visitors' center of the stock exchange, they were greeted with visitor's guides written in Russian.
Most were taken aback by the swirl of hundreds of stock traders on the floor of the exchange -- except, perhaps, for Mr. Asrian. "I am sure this is interesting," he said, nodding his head. "But I am always sleepy. It is eight hours different in Moscow, you know?"
Indeed, other Russians could be seen nodding gently, not always in concentration, during a briefing at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. They perked up when they went several stories underground and behind a 240-ton steel door to see $118 billion worth of gold.
Later, over a lunch of fried catfish ("What is this, cat and fish?") and mashed potatoes in a Greenwich Village barbecue restaurant, Mr. Asrian talked about what brought him to the United States.
A specialist in international currency, Mr. Asrian is deputy chairman of Mashbank, a small bank started by Moscow entreprenuers and Government officials. The bank's assets are 9 billion rubles, but they are barely worth $5 million -- if they could be exchanged in the world's financial markets, which they cannot.
Technically speaking, Mr. Asrian is a millionaire several times over in rubles, but at current market rates in Moscow his 1-million-ruble-a-month salary is equivalent to about $555.
Under the turbulent Government of Mikhail Gorbachev, Mr. Asrian worked as an economist and financial expert. He is a 1984 graduate of the Moscow Institute of National Economy, where he studied "state supply."
"You ask what that is?" Mr. Asrian said, smiling. "It means that when you are a business and apply to the central authority for a necessary item, you learn whether to cut the request by a half or by three-quarters."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Leon Asrian, foreground, a Russian currency expert, and other emerging capitalists from Russia, touring the New York Stock Exchange. The visit was part of a program to help the nation revive its exhausted economy. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Reports Show Economy Growing Solidly

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
The economy is growing solidly in most of the nation except California, the Federal Reserve said today, as the Government reported a surge in March factory business.
 The Fed's so-called beige book report on activity across the country underlined the pickup in the economy in the spring after two months of exceptionally severe winter weather. 
 "Solid economic growth is reported in most parts of the country," said a summary prepared by the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco that included comment from all 12 district banks. It was a much stronger assessment of the economy's vigor than the last summary in March, which reported only moderate expansion.
 Price rises were restrained by competition, the Fed said, an encouraging sign that inflation was under control.
"It's more evidence the economy is on a brisk growth path and that so far the inflation genie is being kept in the bottle," said an economist, Robert Dederick of the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
 In another economic report, the Commerce Department said factory orders shot up 1.1 percent in March to a seasonally adjusted $274.7 billion -- more than double Wall Street economists' expectations of an increase of five-tenths of a percent. Orders fell three-tenths of a percent in February.
 The Fed survey, which covers the period up until the end of April and is more current than the Commerce Department report, said that manufacturing companies continued to do booming business.
 "Production of autos, vehicle parts, steel and building materials is near capacity," the Fed said.
 Despite signs that some industries were reaching production limits, which could drive prices higher, the Clinton Administration professed no concern about inflation. Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, speaking to reporters at the White House, said: "There is no inflation on the horizon at all. Incomes are growing, but they are not growing in any ways that would signal inflation."
 The report on March factory orders showed broad-based strength. The Commerce Department said last week that orders for long-lasting durable goods, like computers and cars, which account for about half of total factory business, rose in March by four-tenths of a percent. But it revised that upward in today's report to show a stronger increase of eight-tenths of a percent.
 Orders for nondurable goods, like paper products and food, rose 1.4 percent in March after a 1.5 percent February gain.
 The Commerce Department also said February factory orders did not weaken as much as previously estimated. Instead of being down 1 percent, they fell only three-tenths of a percent.
 Several recent reports on the nation's manufacturing sector point to a spring revival after exceptionally harsh weather in January and February, including the devastating California eathquake. On Tuesday, the Government said its broad-based index of leading indicators rose strongly in March after two months of relative sluggishness.
The March factory orders report showed orders for transportation equipment fell 1.4 percent after a 9.2 percent February drop. Excluding transportation, factory orders rose 1.5 percent in March -- the strongest monthly increase since a 3.2 percent gain in December 1992 -- after a 1.3 percent February increase.
 Shipments of manufactured goods, which reflect more immediate demand than orders, gained by nine-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted $274.3 billion, after a 1.3 percent rise in February. Order backlogs increased for the second time in three months, rising one-tenth of a percent in March to a seasonally adjusted $446.6 billion.
 
Home Prices Rise
 Separately, the National Association of Realtors said home prices rose in most metropolitan areas. The national price of homes was $107,400, up 3.5 percent from a year earlier. The association said its metropolitan home price survey showed that the median price for existing single-family homes ranged from a low of $48,100 in the Waterloo-Cedar Falls area of Iowa to a high of $355,000 in Honolulu. A median price is the midpoint, with half the homes selling for more and half selling for less.

HEADLINE: Unpaving the Parking Lot, So to Say, and Putting Up Paradise

BYLINE: By BARBARA GAMAREKIAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
When the residents of a low-income housing project in a drug-ridden section of northeast Washington were invited to name their newly rehabilitated buildings, they chose proud names: Miracle Court, Harmony Court, Freedom Court, Justice Court.
"We called the first building Miracle because the whole business took a while, and we were amazed when it actually came about," said Cathy Jordon, a resident of the project since 1979. 
 Bill Hamilton, a 27-year resident and retired postal worker who volunteers at the project's community center, explained: "This place was just mud in the winter and dust in the summer and little square boxes. We've got grass now, and the exteriors are gorgeous, and we feel as safe as any place in town."
Rising like a phoenix out of a treeless, muddy wasteland is Paradise at Parkside, as the complex is now called, and it signals the rebirth of the Parkside neighborhood. It was in 1985 that a nonprofit church group, the Gospel Spreading Church, approached Marilyn Melkonian, a Washington lawyer, and asked her assistance in rehabilitating the half-empty, dilapidated housing project that the church had built in the 1960's.
"The place was rampant with drugs, and people were leaving in droves," Ms. Melkonian recalled. "They were looking for a partner, someone to show them the way."
Ms. Melkonian, who was the deputy assistant secretary for housing at the Department of Housing and Urban Development in the Carter Administration, had never been a developer. "I didn't even know if I was that interested," she said. "But when I went out there, I fell in hate with it: the physical condition, the lack of anything attractive."
In late 1986, she organized a new ownership group, putting together a $21 million package in public and private financing. The cinderblock-and-brick exteriors of the nondescript 650-unit complex were a challenge, but the cinderblock was covered with stucco, ugly concrete stoops were demolished, gables were added to the roofs of the 15 barrackslike buildings and oval cornices were placed over the doorways.
"Some buildings were as long as a football field, and without gabling, it looked like a prison," said Ms. Melkonian, who believes good design is cost-effective. "It's essential to the longevity of the project. Good design can't save it from bad conditions, but absent those conditions, it can flourish."
The one- to four-bedroom apartments rent for $450 to $650, and about 250 of the 650 households receive rent subsidies. The median household income is $16,000 a year.
Suman Sorg of Sorg & Associates in Washington was the architect for the renovations, and Paradise was awarded a Pillar of the Industry Award by the National Association of Home Builders in 1990 as an example of what it called "the best in multifamily rehabilitation."
The overall cost, $33,000 a unit, is considered modest in the rehab business, said Gloria Cousar of HUD's Office of Severely Distressed and Troubled Housing Recovery. "It is a remarkable accomplishment," she said. "It took a lot of time, but the residents provided leadership, the developer was progressive and had a lot of foresight and commitment, and everyone hung in there together."
Families moved from building to building during the five-year transformation as new roofs and electrical, heating and air-conditioning systems were installed.
Ms. Melkonian hired James van Sweden of the landscaping firm of Oehme, van Sweden & Associates in Washington -- whose clients include Oprah Winfrey and David Brinkley -- to make the desolate space beautiful. Low wrought-iron fences surround each of the buildings to create front yards and a sense of private space. There are now small terraces where residents can sit and chat, winding brick walkways, wooden benches, lampposts with frosted globes, a wading pool with dolphins that spout water, and a multitude of flowering trees and perennials.
On a recent spring weekend, children on skateboards and bicycles whizzed by, and teen-agers played basketball on the half court near the wading pool.
"Getting the utility lines buried was one of Marilyn's great triumphs -- it was two years of pressuring Pepco," said Mr. van Sweden, referring to the Potomac Electric Power Company. "And she insisted walkways be six feet wide so people could walk side by side. She has a tremendous appreciation for how the whole feeling of community is expressed in outdoor space."
But none of this would have worked, Ms. Melkonian and Mr. van Sweden said, if residents had not joined in efforts to banish the pervasive drug market that made Paradise scary turf. Tunnel-like covered walkways connecting parking lots to the entry courts of buildings offered a haven for drug deals and muggings. The walkways are now brightly lighted. With the cooperation of other residents, more than 60 families were evicted for selling drugs, and members of the Nation of Islam from a nearby mosque were invited to assist in community security patrols.
"The neighborhood still has its problems," said Sgt. Robert Garaffo of the District of Columbia Police Department's Sixth District, which includes Paradise at Parkside. "But it is a dramatic change from what it was. We still have disorderlies and disputes, but most of the drug traffic has disappeared, and it is much safer." Since the renovations, he added, "people tend to take more responsibility, and there is a real neighborhood community there now."
Tenants were involved in planning their new community from the beginning, forming a resident council and participating in focus groups to identify community needs. A $500,000 grant from the Department of Health and Human Services provided job training and classes in setting up a household budget and how to buy a home. The grant also underwrote the construction of a day-care center and the focal point of the complex: a community center that offers arts and crafts classes, movie nights and after-school programs. A computer-equipped learning center provides tutoring for students.
More than 100 residents are now employed in construction, property management and maintenance jobs at Paradise and the neighboring Parkside complex. "Some people had a lot of disbelief, but they take pride in this place now," said Mark Phillips, a three-year resident whose company, Paradise Builders, constructed the community and day-care centers and provided training in the building trades.
Young People on the Rise, an ad hoc group begun in 1987 by 27 teen-agers under the stewardship of James Gibbons, then the president of Consumers United Insurance, guarantees financial support for any student who wants to go to college. And Paradise tenants have organized themselves into a cooperative, said Mrs. Jordon, its president, with the goal of buying their apartments.
Ms. Melkonian's company is also overseeing the construction of 100 moderately priced town houses (52 of which have already been sold) at Parkside, adjacent to the Paradise complex. The appealing Victorian-style houses with copper turrets, gas fireplaces, hardwood floors, nine-foot-ceilings, tiled baths and fenced patios sell for $97,000 to $141,000 and are available to families with incomes ranging from $25,000 to $45,000.
Ms. Melkonian, who graduated from Brooklyn College in 1965 and received a law degree from Stanford University, dates her involvement in community issues to 1967, a summer of urban riots and racial unrest when she was intern for Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts. Later, came a stint of working on housing issues in New York as a lawyer and four years at HUD, followed by a job in California as general counsel to the film producer George Lucas.
Ms. Melkonian, who is 49, is now dividing her time among three cities. In Miami, she is developing a plan for Dade County to apply for designation as one of six Federal Empowerment Zones, to encourage business and housing development. In Yonkers, she has been appointed as a special housing master by Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan to advise on the construction of privately owned affordable housing. And in Washington, her company is coordinating a development on Capitol Hill. A 1941 public housing project will be razed, and in its place, about 175 town houses will be built for residents with a mix of income levels, up to $50,000.
The name of her company, Telesis, comes from the Greek, meaning "achieving a desired end through intelligent effort," Ms. Melkonian said.
The investment in communities that have been written off, she said, "is returned manyfold: in stronger communities, stable families and healthier kids, all the common-sense things that we know are true."
But given the poverty and violence of the urban area that surrounds Paradise and Parkside, can this oasis of serenity prevail? Or will decay and obsolescence eventually take over?
"If the community stays together, it will remain beautiful," she said. "The key is the community and the strength and ability to protect itself and care about each other."
Typical of her somewhat cosmic thinking is a starburst of patterned brick in the main courtyard of Paradise. It forms a large compass.
"I thought it would be nice for folks to be able to orient themselves to the rest of the world," she said.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Nixon's Last Word on the World

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

Beyond Peace
 By Richard Nixon
 Illustrated. 262 pages. Random House. $23.
Of the dead speak nothing but good, it is said. But a book remains alive, even when published posthumously. So to any reader impatient with the recent canonization of the 37th President of the United States, the first to be forced to resign from office, let it be said that there is lots to find fault with in Richard Nixon's 10th and final book, "Beyond Peace," which he completed just a few weeks before he died. 
 He offers no apologies or expressions of rue in this final summing up of his views, or any acknowledgment of error. There is nothing even personal, unless you count his observation that Boris N. Yeltsin's inclination to become depressed after winning a battle "is not an uncommon characteristic of leaders." Or his remark that "those of us who complain about the behavior of today's media must remember that similar complaints are as old as the republic."
That familiar clang of inauthenticity sounds in these pages. You encounter his old tendency to aggrandize: he calls "the defeat of Iraqi aggression in the Persian Gulf war in the spring of 1991" one "of the greatest events of the 20th century," and he writes that "America is the greatest, most successful social experiment in the history of man."
You find so many examples of strained quotation that you picture Mr. Nixon sitting in his study crushed by volumes of Aquinas, Irving Babbitt, Isaiah Berlin, Brandeis, Burke, Churchill, Lord Curzon, Engels, Goethe, Hobbes, Eric Hoffer, Ibsen, Kant, Malraux, Nietzsche, Pushkin, Schumpeter, Toynbee, Weber, Wellington and, of course, Tocqueville, to mention but a handful of the heavyweights cited in these pages.
And he exercises his old habit of vividly recalling how great leaders of the past sat him on their knees and told him such-and-such. "It was the Russians who defeated Napoleon," he writes, "and as President Eisenhower once told me, it was the Russians who, after incredible suffering and sacrifice, played the indispensable and primary role in defeating Hitler," as if someone with Eisenhower's perspective were required to reveal this not exactly well-hidden secret.
Still, for all its irritations, "Beyond Peace" is Mr. Nixon's best book. The former President was always strongest writing about foreign policy, and the present book was completed shortly after the much-publicized visit to Russia during which he met with several opposition leaders, over President Yeltsin's objections. Where Mr. Nixon tended to slight the Soviet Union in favor of China in some of his earlier books, here he treats post-Soviet Russia in concrete and arresting detail.
Mr. Nixon even includes a touch of unwonted humor in an account of an interview in March with Gen. Aleksandr V. Rutskoi that was made difficult by "the simultaneous and totally incomprehensible conversation between two large parrots in separate cages in the middle of Rutskoi's sitting room." Mr. Nixon adds, "The birds were not speaking English, and I knew enough Russian to know they weren't speaking Russian." As it turned out, "they spoke only Malaysian."
Out of these and more weighty details grow the larger messages of Mr. Nixon's book. These are roughly that the end of the cold war represented a victory of American free-market capitalism over Soviet command-economy communism, and that because the terms of this conflict are still relevant to the world, the United States must continue to exert international leadership by waging the peace as actively as it conducted the war.
Having developed these points with regard to the present situation in Russia, which he considers dire but by no means hopeless, Mr. Nixon then takes us on a tour of the globe. He points to the Clinton Administration's failure in Bosnia as an instance of shirked responsibility, although he offers no alternate proposal beyond lifting "the embargo against the victims of Serbian aggression." He argues that economic freedom in China will lead to political freedom and that we should therefore not revoke China's most-favored-nation status. "Today, China's economic power makes U.S. lectures about morality and human rights imprudent. Within a decade, it will make them irrelevant. Within two decades, it will make them laughable. By then the Chinese may threaten to withhold most-favored-nation status from the United States unless we do more to improve living conditions in Detroit, Harlem and South-Central Los Angeles."
Mr. Nixon is less provocative and more predictable when he comes home and takes a tour of domestic issues. True, he makes you stop and think when he points out that the national debt ought to be reduced not by tax increases but by cuts in the Federal budget, 40 percent of which is devoted to non-means-tested entitlements, or payments to those who have the means to take care of their own needs. Or when he asserts that Paul Kennedy, the Yale historian, is wrong when he argues that the United States has become militarily overextended, if only because Mr. Kennedy and other critics "missed the essential point that the proportion of G.N.P. consumed by America's defense spending in 1953 was twice the share of G.N.P. spent at the height of the Reagan military buildup."
But such arresting specifics are few and far between. The problem, as Mr. Nixon readily admits, is that setting the goals of peace is a good deal harder than defining the objectives of war. Mr. Nixon believes that the ultimate solution to the ills that beset America is a return to traditions like church and proper child-rearing. But he is hard put to explain how to undertake this spiritual journey, so he is forced to fall back on mere exhortation and assertion.
He writes seemingly without irony that we cannot solve our problems "unless we return to the principles that made this country great." You wonder if he felt any twinge of discomfort wheeling out a cliche as worn as this one. Or was he so moved by the idea that the words struck him as if newly minted? Reading "Beyond Peace," you end up pondering the familiar mysteries of Richard Nixon once again.

HEADLINE: A Wall Falls in Jericho

 BODY:
It may be days, weeks or even months before Israelis and Palestinians grasp the meaning of the autonomy accord signed in Cairo yesterday. The small print spells out the terms of limited self-rule that will apply imminently to the town of Jericho and the Gaza Strip. But it is the big print that truly matters: after years of strife, bitter antagonists have come together on a formula first proposed at Camp David in 1978 that will permit Israeli forces to withdraw honorably from West Bank territories that Israel seized in the defensive 1967 war.
In short, millions of words about the "Middle East peace process" have been translated, finally, into deeds. A wall has fallen once again in ancient Jericho; within three months, limited Palestinian self-rule is to be extended throughout the rest of the West Bank. This has happened despite acts of desperate terrorism by a fanatic core of Arabs and Jews who view these steps to peace as treason. Whether they succeed depends on the momentum of a deal struck between a pragmatic Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, and his enemy-turned-partner, Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman. 
 There are promising omens. Mr. Arafat needs to show positive results, quickly, to Palestinians skeptical about an arrangement that falls far short of statehood. Propitiously, the World Bank and the P.L.O. have hammered out a three-year aid program, drawing on $2.4 billion in pledges from 40 donor countries. And there are signs that Washington's strategy -- to reach simultaneous Arab-Israeli agreements on all fronts this year -- may yet work.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who was present for the signing of an accord he helped midwife, has been patiently leaning on Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, for concessions essential to dismantling Israeli settlements on the formerly Syrian Golan Heights. At the risk of provoking an uproar among settlers allied with his own Labor Party, Mr. Rabin has talked of a real withdrawal in return for a real peace. Mr. Assad is beginning, however haltingly, to discuss substance, which for Syria is progress.
As important is evidence of Israel's new status in the post-cold-war world. Last week Mr. Rabin became the first Israeli Prime Minister to visit Moscow in an official capacity. He won promises that Russia will supply only non-offensive weapons and spare parts to its Arab customers. Israel's new clout is directly related to its willingness to yield land for peace on the West Bank, and to engage the only Palestinian leader with international standing.
This is not to ignore the unremitting threat of terrorism, especially if hopes raised by yesterday's accord are not swiftly addressed. All the more reason for Israel and the P.L.O. to tie up vital loose ends like the disputed boundaries of Jericho, and whether Palestinians can post guards on the Allenby Bridge connecting the West Bank to Jordan.
It is a paradox that old and bitter adversaries find it easier to agree on big issues than on lesser matters that repeatedly bog down negotiations. Yet with each step forward, Israel and the P.L.O. deepen their investment in a successful outcome.

HEADLINE: Increases in Wages Don't Create Inflation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Different Take on the 'Myth' of Inflation" (letters, April 27), three responses to the April 15 Op-Ed article by Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, criticize her on tactics, but not on principle. 
 Discussions generated by Federal Reserve Board increases in interest rates, which were designed to decelerate economic growth, have focused on keeping unemployment above 6 percent (9 million people). Economists agree on the need to slow down economic growth, but disagree on action now to keep unemployment high. Ms. Tyson says not yet, predicting unemployment will anyway remain above her proposed floor of 5.9 percent to 6.3 percent.
The theory that wages push up inflation has been used to justify a 20-year downtrend in real wages in the face of rising productivity. This combination has accelerated income inequality -- more billionaires at the top; more poverty at the bottom.
The wage-push theory is contrary to such concepts of justice as the human rights resolution of the United Nations: the right of all people able and willing to work to have a job.
And it is economically flawed. Prices are determined by the balance of demand and supply on the market for goods, often manipulated upward by private monopoly or government production limitations on supply. Wages are determined by the balance of forces between employers and workers, and the resulting division of the proceeds between capital and labor. The consumer market and the labor market are independent.
Labor's share has been so slashed in the last 20 years that it would take a very large increase, far beyond anything foreseeable, to restore the formerly prevailing distribution.
The most rapid rise in prices has been in pharmaceuticals, where wages are only 6 percent of value added by manufacture. Hardly wage-push inflation here. And Ms. Tyson unwittingly provides another example. She states that if unemployment remains high and wages low, which she expects, "the economy seems well positioned to experience a decade-long phase of steady growth and modest inflation, such as it did from the mid-1950s to the mid-1960s."
Her research is half-right and all wrong. Indeed, between 1955 and 1965 consumer prices increased only 1.6 percent a year, the lowest for any postwar decade. But wages went up twice as fast: 44 percent, or 20 percent in real terms. And unemployment averaged well below the "inflationary" range cited by Ms. Tyson and others.
No. Measures are required to reduce unemployment sharply, through shorter hours without reduction in pay, large-scale programs of public works, of housing, education, environment -- programs that require the employment of millions of workers. And inflation should be prevented by curbing price gouging by private monopolies and by ending government price increases, as in postal rates and transit fares.
 
VICTOR PERLO
Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., April 27, 1994
The writer is an economic consultant.

HEADLINE: Increases in Wages Don't Create Inflation;
Unite, You Unemployed

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Growth of Jobs May Be Casualty in Inflation Fight" (front page, April 24) reports the concern of the Federal Reserve Board and many economists that the danger of inflation would increase if unemployment fell below its 6.5 percent rate. The Federal Reserve has raised interest rates three times to slow the economy so that fewer jobs will be created. 
 The net effect of this policy is to deprive the 8.5 million individuals unemployed (and some 6 million who have been locked into involuntary part-time jobs) of the hope of finding decent-paying, full-time work. Thus, the unemployed, victims of the recession, are victimized again now that the economy has strongly recovered.
In 1978, Congress passed the Humphrey-Hawkins Full Employment Act. It set a governmental target of a 4 percent unemployment rate to allow for structural changes in the economy and the movement of workers seeking new jobs. Some reputable economists thought the 4 percent rate too high. Yet, since then, unemployment has never declined below 5 percent, and today, in what is described as a booming economy, the unemployment rate is stuck at 6.5 percent, with many cities and states experiencing even higher rates.
It is questionable that there will be such a surge of rehiring that employers will have to pay higher wages to attract workers and thus stimulate a rise in inflation. The trend among corporations has been to shrink employment opportunities by using labor-saving technology, downsizing work forces and moving factories overseas to low-wage countries. One economist you quote says of this country's unemployed workers, "We need this pool to meet the normal demands of the labor market."
It is apparent that we are receiving a replay of the scenario of "The Forgotten Man" of the 1930's, but with this difference: whereas during the Great Depression there were organizations of the unemployed that fought militantly in their behalf, today no such organizations exist. The unemployed are politically powerless and easy targets to be dumped on. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. beset with many problems, has shown little interest in actively championing the unemployed.
In the end, the unemployed themselves may need to develop their own leaders.
 
HARRY KELBER
Brooklyn, April 25, 1994
The writer is a retired professor of labor studies at Empire State College, SUNY.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
PRICES RAISED FOR U.S. SALES OF HONDA AND ACURA MODELS

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
Honda North America said yesterday that it had raised sticker prices on Honda and Acura vehicles. The company raised prices for Honda passenger cars an average of 1.1 percent, or $185 a car, and increased the price on its new Honda Passport sport utility vehicle an average of 0.97 percent, or $211 a vehicle. The company cited inflation and higher operating costs for the change. Including the increases, prices for Honda passenger cars range from $9,500 for the Civic CX Hatchback to $25,400 for the Prelude Si 4WS with automatic transmission. Honda said prices at its Acura luxury division were up an average of nine-tenths of 1 percent, or $254 a car.

HEADLINE: If Not Born to Win, Expected To

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 3

 BODY:
"Never let them see you sweat," says William F. Weld, reflecting the patrician style that has taken him from Harvard to the top job in the criminal division of the Reagan Justice Department to the Republican governorship of one of the nation's most Democratic state.
He prides himself on his vacations at his family camp in the Adirondacks, where he goes fishing on a private lake, reads Yeats and dines on trout and venison cooked by his guide. Back in Boston, the millionaire Governor plays squash three afternoons a week. "I love sort of lying around on the weekend," Mr. Weld, who lives in Cambridge with his wife and five children, said in a recent interview. "I enjoy not working as much as I enjoy work itself." 
 Whether, as some critics suggest, it is part of a calculated image -- Bill Weld, the natural, born to win -- or whether it is the real Bill Weld, he is expected to glide to victory this fall in his bid for a second term.
None of his three Democratic opponents are well known. The prominent Democrats who might have given him a race, including Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, have decided not to take him on. After tantalizing voters for weeks, former Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, now the Ambassador to the Vatican, said last week that he would not run.
 
Support From Top Democrat
 The most powerful Democrat in a Legislature controlled by Democrats, William M. Bulger, president of the Senate, has practically endorsed the Governor. "He's up for re-election, and most of us would just as soon keep him around," Mr. Bulger said recently.
It is not politics as usual in this bastion of liberalism and Kennedys. "This was a one-party state under Dukakis," said James Braude, the head of the Tax Equity Alliance of Massachusetts, a citizens group, and a longtime Weld critic. "Now it's a one-party state under Weld, only it's the other party. His political skills are stunning."
Michael S. Dukakis, defeated in the 1988 Presidential election by George Bush, was Governor of Massachusetts from 1974 to 1978 and 1982 to 1990.
For Mr. Weld, a 48-year-old moderate Republican, the Governor's job is his first in elected politics. With his libertarian streak, he says, it is a natural fit for him to be fiscally conservative but liberal on gay rights and abortion. He won by a margin of three percentage points in 1990, elected by Democrats who could not bring themselves to vote for his opponent, John R. Silber, the president of Boston University.
 
Voters Blamed Dukakis
 The state was going through a fiscal crisis, and the voters blamed Mr. Dukakis and his liberal spending policies. "Just as you couldn't have had a Ronald Reagan without Jimmy Carter, you couldn't have had a Weld without a Dukakis," said Kevin Phillips, a Washington political analyst.
Mr. Weld, who has professed admiration for Mr. Reagan's management style, believes in minimalist government. "That goes on social issues as well as fiscal issues," he said. "Out of your pocketbook, out of your bedroom."
He signed legislation last year making it illegal to discriminate against homosexuals in public schools. And he has supported abortion-rights legislation that lowers the age of parental consent to 16, though his position on abortion has shifted. In early 1989 he described himself as "modified pro-choice," saying he opposed public financing for abortions. He won the election with a platform supporting the right to abortion.
His views, which he affirmed at the 1992 Republican Convention in Houston, have infuriated the religious right. Lately, with his name being mentioned as a potential national candidate in 1996, the Governor has been playing down his stand on abortion. "We should focus on economics," he said in a recent interview. "My whole point is that we should not lead with the abortion issue in 1996."
Reminded that he had emphasized it in Houston, he answered: "That was then, now is now. I want to be in the same party as Pat Robertson. They're very nice people."
Mr. Weld calls himself "to the right of Attila the Hun" on crime. And he recently proposed one of the toughest welfare programs in the country.
The affable, self-assured Mr. Weld has disarmed some Democrats. "I would say that his most infuriating trait is perhaps his most endearing one," said Tom Birmingham, the chairman of the State Senate Ways and Means Committee. "He has a sort of cavalier sense of the whole process as a type of game. I'm not sure there are too many issues he cares deeply about. But the arm's-length approach is refreshing, for me at least. Here's life outside politics."
Answering those who say he lacks conviction, Mr. Weld said: "I like to have fun with politics, but I also take my politics very seriously. I care very passionately about not wasting taxpayers' money."
 
Attracting Attention
 While his aides confide that Mr. Weld has national ambitions, he is not talking about them now while he seeks re-election. Still, he gets noticed without trying. He is 6 feet 4 inches tall, red-haired, good-looking and extremely smart. He graduated first in his prepatory school class, at Middlesex Academy, and summa cum laude in classics from Harvard, where he wrote his senior thesis in two weeks while starring as a rabbit in the Hasty Pudding theatrical club's production of "Right Up Your Alley."
His patrician bearing and background are sometimes tempered by another persona: Bill Weld, regular guy. While Bill Clinton plays the saxophone on the Arsenio Hall show, the Governor goes to Grateful Dead concerts.
Mr. Weld is credited with bringing calm to a chaotic State Legislature, cutting taxes and trimming the state work force by 12 percent. He has balanced the budget, though he does not mention that his job was eased considerably by two big tax increases won by Mr. Dukakis near the end of his term. In addition, voters rejected a 1990 tax rollback -- endorsed by Mr. Weld as a candidate -- that would have reduced state revenue by nearly $2 billion annually.
Steven Gold, director of the nonpartisan Center for the Study of the States in Albany, gives Mr. Weld mixed grades. "If all you care about is holding down taxes he gets an 'A,' " Mr. Gold said. "But I think one also has to consider how he held down taxes, and there has been serious deterioration in the elementary and secondary schools and in higher education. And thousands of poor people were turned off the welfare rolls."
Last year, Mr. Weld signed a $1.3 billion education bill that was sponsored by a Democratic State Representative, Mark Roosevelt, who is running for governor.
 
Some Long Family Roots
 The youngest of four children, Bill Weld grew up on a 500-acre estate in Smithtown, L.I., descended from the Welds who came to America in 1635. His father, David Weld, was a partner in the family investment banking firm on Wall Street. When a reporter for The Boston Globe asked Mr. Weld in 1989 where he got his money, he said, "We don't get money, we have money."
Some people say the Governor cannot relate to the common man. "You walk around Harvard, there's Weld Hall and Weld Boathouse," said Jack Corrigan, a former aide to Mr. Dukakis. "He doesn't care about state government because his life has no relationship to the state government. He doesn't care about people on welfare because he's never depended on government for assistance in any way."
Responding to the accusation that he is out of touch, Mr. Weld said: "I think I'm a hell of a lot more in touch with what working people and taxpayers want than professional politicians who lecture them about what they should want and go about raising taxes to feed a big bureaucracy."
Mr. Weld's social class can be a political advantage here, in this outpost for Brahmin Republicans, from Henry Cabot Lodge to Elliot L. Richardson to Frank Sergeant, the last previous Republican Governor.
"Massachusetts Democrats have always had a kind of fondness for people who never had to chisel or work their way up," said Hale Champion, a retired executive dean of Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. "It's the noblesse oblige business."
The Governor almost never becomes defensive. To the frustration of his opponents, would-be crises seem to dissolve before him. In a front-page series of articles last year, for example, The Globe explored the easy access the Governor gives to business and special interest groups that have contributed to his campaigns. There was little, if any, political fallout over the articles, which Mr. Weld, a former United States Attorney, termed "a good series."
Asked in a recent interview to name his biggest failure, Mr. Weld was silent for a long moment. "I don't know," he said. "I don't have a very good legal mind, but I don't consider that a failure."
His campaign manager, Ray Howell, reminded him of his 1978 campaign for State Attorney General, in which Mr. Weld was trounced by the popular incumbent, Frank Bellotti.
 
'Not Successful Ladies' Man'
 The Governor laughed. "I don't consider that a failure," he said, adding that the race was interesting.
Finally, he admitted, "I was not a successful ladies' man." He did marry Susan Roosevelt, a great granddaughter of Theodore Roosevelt. Their five children are 9 to 16 years old. A graduate of Radcliffe and Harvard Law School, Mrs. Weld is an adjunct professor of Chinese law at Boston College Law School.
Some Republicans are already saying that Mr. Weld could give balance to a national ticket in 1996 led by a more conservative Republican from the Midwest or West. But the Governor might not be a hit beyond Massachusetts.
"A Republican primary voter is not a natural Weld constituent," said Eddie Mahe, a Republican political consultant. "We are slightly over 50 percent pro-life. It's that simple."
Asked about his ambitions, Mr. Weld mentioned, among other things, the ambassadorship to Portugal. "Small country," he said. "Lots of sun, good wine. Lots of espionage, lots of exciting stuff."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 16, 1994, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 5 about Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts misidentified the boarding school he attended. It was the Middlesex School, not Middlesex Academy.
