HEADLINE: Hawaii Is a Health Care Lab As Employers Buy Insurance

SERIES: The Basics of Care -- A periodic report on national health issues.

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, May 3

 BODY:
The toughest question in the health care debate is whether to require employers to buy insurance for their workers.
But if members of Congress could overcome their fears of being accused of junketeering and actually visit Hawaii, they would find compelling evidence about how such a system actually works, and they would not have to rely on a range of absolute, if uninformed, opinion. 
 About 96 percent of Hawaiians have health insurance. Employers, regardless of the size of their work force, must pay for most of it. Nonetheless, they have thrived, despite frustration over expanding benefits and rising costs.
Moreover, Hawaiians seem healthier, and more satisfied with their health care, than other Americans.
Recent surveys by both the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company and by the American Public Health Association have rated overall health in Hawaii better than in any other state. The Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ranked Hawaii at or near the top in low infant mortality, longevity and early death from heart and lung disease and cancer.
Two opinion surveys sponsored by the Kaiser Family Foundation found that 82 percent of Hawaiians, compared with 71 percent of Americans overall, were satisfied with their health care services. Only 18 percent of Hawaiians, compared with 39 percent of Americans, said their health care system worked badly.
There are no comparable surveys of doctors, many of whom complain that they make less money in Hawaii than they could elsewhere. But Jonathan R. Won, executive direcfor of the Hawaii Medical Association, said that in a very portable profession few doctors had moved away. "Physicians really say, 'I choose to practice here,' " he said. "Nobody has come up with a better idea as yet," he said.
Hawaii is also the only state where a recent United States Chamber of Commerce survey of its members, who are mostly engaged in small business, found a majority backing compulsory payments.
Hawaii is the only state with experience with that system, but it is a little-used laboratory. Only one Congressional subcommittee has come here this year to hold a hearing. Nor is there significant academic research, even by the University of Hawaii.
Still, 20 years of Hawaiian experience does offer support for requiring employers to pay, as President Clinton has urged, but also for some of the fears that the proposal raises among small businesses.
It is clear that the "employer mandate," as the requirement to buy workers insurance is known here and in Washington, has succeeded in bringing Hawaii to the threshold of universal health insurance coverage. That seems to have helped restrain health care inflation, a serious problem here but less critical than on the mainland: health insurance premiums are about 30 percent cheaper here, while almost everything else in Hawaii is more expensive.
The state health director, John C. Lewin, argues that the system has done more than that. "By emphasizing primary care, it has improved the health status of the people of Hawaii," he said. As one example, he said, early detection of breast cancer -- despite a high rate of it in Hawaii -- had enabled the state to achieve the nation's lowest rate of mortality from the disease.
Yet Hawaiians seem rather blase about the fact that they have something unique. So they may not notice being free of the mainland fears that their employers will cancel a health plan, or that existing medical conditions will either keep them locked in their jobs, force up their rates or deny them insurance altogether.
Nor is there an echo of the intense lobbyists' argument in Washington that compelling most employers to pay for insurance will cost millions of jobs and force thousands of companies out of business. That did not happen when Hawaii's mandate took effect in 1975, nor during the worst of the recession of the 1980's, nor in the last few years, when insurance premium inflation occasionally reached double digits.
 
Full-Time Workers Covered
 Part-time workers under 20 hours a week do not have to be insured, but no matter how small a company is, it must cover all its other workers -- and without the kind of subsidies contained in President Clinton's proposal. A report this year by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said, "We found no evidence that the employer mandate resulted in large disruptions in Hawaii's small-business sector."
But a different, less shrill concern of small business heard in Washington does echo here, that Congress may include enough exemptions and subsidies to make the employer mandate bearable when it takes effect, but not forever. That has been a problem in Hawaii. As Bette Tatum, state director of the National Federation of Independent Business, put it here the other day, "Subsidies come and go; mandates last forever.".
There is no doubt that Hawaii's system is tougher on employers now than when it was enacted.
 
Limits on Worker Premiums
 Over the years, Hawaiian officials have been prevented by Federal law from raising the ceiling on worker contributions to health care that the state law set in 1974. It is limited to 1.5 percent of a worker's salary, and no more than half the premium. For a minimum-wage worker in 1975, the limit of $5.20 a month was nearly a third of that year's $18.62 monthly cost of basic health insurance.
But health insurance costs have grown much faster than the minimum wage, which was $2 in 1975 and is $5.25 here now, or $910 a month based on a 40-hour week. The most that can be deducted from a minimum-wage worker now is $13.65 a month; that is such a small share of the $131.02 premium for a worker's basic coverage that many employers do not bother to collect it.
Though Federal law blocked Hawaii from requiring workers to pay a bigger share of their insurance premiums, Hawaii's lawmakers found a way to add benefits.
Barred from amending their 1974 Prepaid Health Care Act, Hawaiian legislators changed the basic insurance laws, requiring all health insurers and health maintenance organizations to add coverage for mental health and drug and alcohol treatment, mammograms, more well-baby care and in-vitro fertilization.
 
More Benefits, But Low Cost
 Marvin Hall, president of the Hawaii Medical Service Association, the local Blue Cross-Blue Shield group that covers just over half of Hawaiians, says those additions amount to less than 10 percent of a premium.
Beyond the cost, the fact that the heavily Democratic, pro-labor Legislature shoved the changes down its throat rankles small business. Don Moore, who runs the hardware store in Kula, on the island of Maui, said scornfully, "They keep adding bells and whistles."
Teena Rasmussen, a wholesale flower grower who produces leis and bouquets in Kula, said the combination of new mandates and health care inflation "was not something the employer had any method of covering, except by lowering the coverage." She said foreign competition prevented her from raising her prices. While she once voluntarily helped cover workers' families, she no longer does so and is buying the cheapest coverage she can for her nine full-time employees. But there is no business revolt. "Employers are very resigned to it over here," she said.
 
'Hardly Worth It'
 Mr. Moore certainly fills that bill. "There are costs in any business," he said, "and certainly health insurance is one of them. It's pretty consistent that it goes up, but I wouldn't say that it has gotten out of hand." He could deduct a total $200.85 from his nine insured workers every two weeks. But, he said: "The 1.5 percent is hardly worth it. You've got an employee relationship to maintain."
One more local business gripe is a counterpart of the widespread doubt that Congress will subject itself and Federal workers to the same terms it imposes on the rest of the nation. Consider the way state government treats itself here. It pays 60 percent of the cost of insurance and requires workers to pay 40 percent.
Big business has less trouble with the system. Of the 17 percent of Hawaiians in 1974 who lacked insurance that would cover both doctor and hospital bills, most worked for small companies, in small factories, shops, restaurants and similar businesses. This is a heavily unionized state, and most union contracts had ample health insurance 20 years ago. But other big businesses, to compete for workers, matched that benefit.
 
Putting Theory to Work
 Peter Lewis, vice president of Hawaiian Electric, the islands' major power company, said: "Speaking for most big businesses, we support the idea of the Prepaid Health Care Act. As a company, we are very much focused on the preventive end. In the long run, it will save us money."
After 1975, commercial insurers, denied the chance to avoid unhealthy clients, quickly dropped out of the market, and the H.M.S.A., the Blue Cross carrier, with about half the market, has competed ever since with Kaiser Permanente, whose H.M.O.'s have about a fifth of the market. The competition has kept prices down and encouraged the sort of preventive care that means a slightly above-average rate of doctor visits yearly but also lower hospitalization rates, shorter hospital stays and less frequent surgery.
There are disputes about how complete the insurance coverage really is. Speaking for the independent-business group, Mrs. Rasmussen, the flower grower, told Congress that 3 percent to 7 percent of Hawaiians were not covered and "many experts estimate that the numbers may be higher." Dr. Lewin often claims 98 percent coverage.
Analyses based on the Census Bureau's monthly household survey suggest that 93 percent of Hawaiians have health insurance. A much larger survey, conducted by the state Health Department, indicates that 96 percent of Hawaiians are insured.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Employers in Hawaii must pay the greatest share of their full-time workers' health insurance premiums. As costs have risen, small-business owners like Teena Rasmussen, foreground, a flower grower on Maui, have sought the cheapest coverage for their employees. (Adam Clymer/The New York Times) (pg. A18)
 
Chart: "FOR AND AGAINST: The Employer Mandate for Health Care"
 
WHAT IT IS -- Requiring employers to provide health insurance for their workers and pay most of the cost.
 
ARGUMENTS FOR -- Most health insurance is already provided through the workplace, and the smoothest way to expand coverage with the goal of achieving universal care is to require all employers to furnish it. This will end the inequities of a system in which people and companies that pay for health insurance subsidize emergency care for those who do not.
 
ARGUMENTS AGAINST -- Additional costs would cripple thousands of small businesses and force thousands more to cut their work force. Other changes could make health insurance less expensive and more widely available, and still permit individual businesses to choose the kind of insurance their particular workers needed.
 
WHO SUPPORTS IT? -- Most unions, the Health Insurance Association of America, most large companies that provide insurance, including automobile manufacturers and phone companies, and the American Medical Association, if it is limited to larger employers.
 
WHO OPPOSES IT? -- THe National Federation of Independent Business, the largest small business organization in the nation with 600,000 members and a strong lobbying operation in Washington, and also the United States Chamber of Commerce.
 
THE CLINTON PROPOSAL -- All employers must insure their workers, paying about 80 percent of the premium cost. Where family members work at different companies, those companies share the health insurance cost. Subsidies are given to small companies.
 
HOW IT WORKS IN HAWAII -- All employers mus privide health insurance for all full-time workers, meaning everyone who works 20 hours a week or more. Workers can be required to pay a share of the premium up to 50 percent of the cost or 1.5 percent of their wages, whichever is lower. While they are not requried to do so, many employers pay part or all of the cost of health insurance for a worker's family. The required coverage includes doctor and hospital bills but not prescription drugs or dental or eye care.
 
STATUS OF CLINTON BILL -- Proponents are trying to find more or larger subsidies and, perhaps, exemptions for very small companies. In the Senate, there is growing support for a Republican measure that would require employers to offer insurance without having to pay for it and compel individuals to buy insurance for themselves if it is not available to them on the job. (pg. A18)

HEADLINE: 2 Die as Helicopter Crashes Near Lincoln Tunnel

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
A small, low-flying helicopter heading toward Manhattan with a flying instructor and his student snagged a power line, cartwheeled in midair and crashed in flames on a busy elevated-highway approach to the Lincoln Tunnel in New Jersey yesterday, killing the two people on board.
No one on the ground was killed or injured, but the crash set off a chain of fires that engulfed scores of cars in a commuters' parking lot under the highway, a shadowland where people returned after the day's work to find singed skeletons where they had left shiny roadsters and getabouts. Other effects also rippled outward: power failures in 10 New Jersey communities and an interstate traffic jam that affected tens of thousands. 
 The cause of the crash was not immediately determined, but officials said the helicopter, a two-seat Robinson-22 that had taken off from Teterboro Airport six miles to the northeast, was only about 150 feet in the air when its rotor hit the power line and it spun down to a fiery death.
Terrified witnesses -- motorists, children in a nearby school, workers in an industrial area laced with cloverleaf roads and rail and power lines -- told of explosions and fireballs as the chopper came down, skipped and broke apart on Interstate 495 a mile west of the Lincoln Tunnel in North Bergen at 12:50 P.M.
"It hit the wire and just came tumbling down right in front of my car," said Frank DePinto, 20. "I just slammed on the brakes so I wouldn't hit it. It just kept burning. Vehicles were zig-zagging all over the place, trying to get out of the way."
Alexander Gichan, who saw it from his wood-recycling business, said, "It was like three blasts of lightning. The white bursts had to be a hundred feet wide." His brother, Greg, added: "It was like a rock skipping on the water, like a fireball bouncing on 495. I thought it was a bus. It was that big."
As blazing wreckage, a live power line and volatile fuel cascaded onto a park-and-ride lot 60 feet below the elevated crash site, fires broke out and explosions erupted, incinerating 25 vehicles, damaging 53 others and turning the lot into a war zone of smoldering ruins where commuters later wandered gloomily in search of Grand Ams and BMW's that had become blackened hulks.
Meanwhile, the downed power line knocked out a Public Service Electric and Gas substation in Jersey City, and electricity failed briefly in 15,750 homes and businesses in North Bergen, Jersey City, Secaucus, Union City, Weehawken, Guttenberg, Leonia, Fort Lee, Fairview and Ridgefield. About 7,000 customers were without power for nearly an hour, and 2,000 were out for two hours, a spokesman said.
As police and emergency vehicles rushed to the scene, the authorities shut down some of the main traffic arteries linking New York City and New Jersey -- Interstate 495 in the vicinity of the crash, two of the three tubes of the Lincoln Tunnel, Exits 16E and 17 of the New Jersey Turnpike, and busy Route 3.
The resulting traffic tie-ups spread out through midtown Manhattan and much of northern New Jersey in the afternoon, forcing a diversion of traffic through the Holland Tunnel and across the George Washington Bridge. While the wreckage was cleared by the afternoon rush, continuing delays affected many commuters well into the evening.
As Federal, state and local authorities began investigating the crash, officials said its timing, with midday traffic at an ebb on a six-lane highway that is a bumper-to-bumper nightmare during most weekday rush periods, may have spared many from death or injury.
 
Victims' Identities Withheld
 The identities of the two people killed in the crash were not immediately disclosed, pending the notification of relatives. But officials of the Titan Aviation Academy and Helicopter Service, the owner of the aircraft, said the two men were a flight instructor for Titan and a student pilot who was working toward a commercial flying license.
Eric D. Pangborn, the chief pilot of Titan, said the helicopter had left Titan's airport base at Millville, in southern New Jersey, yesterday morning and had flown 100 miles to Teterboro Airport, where it was serviced at Atlantic Aviation before taking off again.
The Robinson-22 is a 2-seat, 30-foot-long chopper that carries a maximum load of 30 gallons of fuel, a cruising speed of 90 miles an hour and a range of 200 to 300 miles. Known among pilots as a Robby, some 2,300 have been built, commonly for use in pleasure flying, pilot training, law enforcement, aerial photography, mapping and agricultural spraying.
"It's elegantly simple to fly, economic, easy to handle and basically trouble-free," said Paul Dudley, manager of Linden Air Services at Linden Airport in New Jersey. He has 800 hours of flying time on Robinson-22's and said its versatility makes it one of the most popular helicopters.
 
Snags a Wire
 Aviation officials said the helicopter in yesterday's crash was heading for Manhattan, perhaps for a landing on one of the riverside helipads, when it flew across a tangle of heavily traveled roadways west of the Lincoln Tunnel and, apparently dipping too low, snagged one of the high-tension wires strung across Interstate 495 on pylons that stand about 165 feet high.
It was unclear exactly how high the helicopter was, how fast it was going or even who was at the controls when the aircraft flew between two transmission towers and struck the topmost of eight lines between them.
Neil Brown, a utility spokesman, said the line that was hit was a non energized static wire put up to catch lightning strikes and deflect their energy from the high-voltage lines under them, but it became energized with thousands of volts instantly when it snapped and touched two 230,000-volt lines beneath it.
Pat Allen, 35, who was driving on nearby Paterson Plank Road, heard what sounded like an explosion and looked out. "The power line was burning as it came down," he said. "The helicopter did two and one-half cartwheels in the air before it hit the roadway."
 
Main Route to Tunnel
 The helicopter went down in flames on the eastbound lanes of Interstate 495 just east of a huge cloverleaf that serves that highway and Routes 3, 1, 9 and the New Jersey Turnpike, a few hundred yards to the west. Interstate 495 is the main route into the Lincoln Tunnel, the major link between New Jersey and midtown Manhattan.
Witnesses said the chopper broke apart as it skipped on the highway. While a large section burned furiously on the road, forcing astonished motorists to halt and swerve in a desperate ballet that somehow did not lead to a pileup, other sections of the aircraft hurtled over the edge of the viaduct and plummeted 60 feet onto a vast parking lot used by motorists who take buses or ferries on the last leg into Manhattan.
On the highway, Mr. DePinto, the chief of operations for a Union, N.J., ambulance service, slammed on his brakes and halted 35 feet in front of the helicopter. He said he and two co-workers leaped out and ran to the burning aircraft to try to save the two occupants, but the interior was ablaze and it was hopeless.
He said other motorists also halted and approached the burning craft. "We had to hold people back," he said. "We told them to stay back -- there was nothing they could do."
On a bluff overlooking the scene, Carole Prena, a secretary at the McKinley School, where 320 children were in elementary classes, said: "It hit just as I looked out. I saw showers of fire coming out of the wires near the towers. It went down on the roadway and went up into a ball of fire. It was a bunch of fire -- that's all I could see."
Then, she said, the fires spread in the parking lot. "The cars were going off -- one, two, three -- like a chain reaction." Later, she said, psychologists had to be brought in to soothe the kindergartners, who had seen the accident and had begun to cry.
 
1,200 Cars in Lot

 In the lot below -- a lot owned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and operated by New Jersey Transit with buses to the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan -- were about 1,200 cars, according to Penny Bassett Hacket, speaking for the transit agency.
Nicholas J. Sacco, the Mayor of North Bergen, said fuel from the helicopter fell with the flaming wreckage and the live power line into the lot, touching off fires that spread quickly. "When the line hit the fuel, it exploded," he said. "Car after car was exploding, almost in rows."
Bruce Walter, director of emergency management services for Hudson County, said the flames and explosions destroyed 25 vehicles, incinerating most down to metal frames, and damaged 53 others. Fire departments from surrounding communities put out the fires by midafternoon, saving more than a thousand vehicles.
But by late afternoon, as commuters who had left their cars in the morning returned to the parking lot, they found bizarre scenes of devastation -- rows of charred skeletons that had been their vehicles.
 
'It's Just a Car'
 "I think this is my car," said Harlan Marks, a 38-year-old sales manager for an office parts company in Manhattan, as he looked over the remains of a green Ford Taurus he had bought last November. Mr. Marks, who lives in Lincoln Park, N.J., seemed resigned to the loss of the car and the golf clubs that were in it, and started thinking about insurance. "It's just a car," he said, "and they are going to pay for it."
Zvia Herrmann, of Fair Lawn, N.J., lost her 1994 Toyota Camry, and Mark DiPrima of Glen Ridge, N.J., lost his 1994 Pontiac Grand Am. But Karen Siegel Forster, 29, of Mahwah, counted herself lucky after finding her 1988 Toyota undamaged. "The car behind me was singed to a crisp," she said.
The afternoon was a mess for other commuters as well. Traffic was especially heavy in the Holland Tunnel and and on the George Washington Bridge, and some buses to New Jersey ran an hour late, even after officials reopened the Lincoln Tunnel, which carries 56,000 vehicles in a weekday rush.

The authorities said the line, which was not energized, was cut and brushed an energized line as it fell, and became energized itself. It fell into a parking lot, touching off a fire that burned dozens of cars.

HEADLINE: U.S. Portrays Sheik as Head Of a Wide Terrorist Network

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Prosecutors will argue in their case against Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman that various terrorist acts dating back to 1991 were all part of a single, overall conspiracy led by the sheik to punish the United States for its support of Israel and Egypt, according to court papers.
The effort, the papers say, was undertaken by a "jihad organization" that had "headquarters" in several American cities and ties to similar groups in other countries. 
 The prosecution's argument, contained in a 100-page memorandum that the Government submitted to the presiding judge in the case, for the first time presents a full theory of extremist Islamic activity in this country.
It contends that Mr. Abdel Rahman, the blind Egyptian cleric who prosecutors say is at the center of an alleged plot to blow up New York City landmarks, led 13 other defendants in a mission of "punishing the United States for its perceived status as leader of the 'infidel' order to be toppled."
The trial is expected to begin in September.
The document gives examples of the evidence the prosecution will present against Mr. Abdel Rahman, including quotations from writings and speeches in which he talks of the duty of all Muslims to sacrifice themselves for jihad, or holy war, his call to "strike terror into the hearts of the enemies" and his conversations with a secret F.B.I. informer in which he approves or disapproves of certain proposed terror targets.
The document, written in response to motions submitted earlier by defense lawyers, ties together several incidents and plots, including last year's bombing of the World Trade Center and the 1991 assassination of an extremist rabbi, Meir Kahane, not as the isolated instances they seemed to many at the time but as parts of a loosely coordinated terrorist whole.
It summarizes much of the evidence against Mr. Abdel Rahman, whom it portrays both as providing a kind of overall religious justification for acts of violence carried out against the perceived enemies of Islam and as approving or disapproving specific terrorist targets.
"The crimes and acts alleged in the indictment," the prosecution says, "are not random, disconnected acts of unthinking brutality. They are, instead, all parts of the same very real battle the defendants and their co-conspirators saw -- and still see -- themselves fighting."
The prosecution's statement, by far the most complete description of the case against Mr. Abdel Rahman and his suspected followers, lists among the actions of the conspiracy a plan, ordered, the prosecution says, by Mr. Abdel Rahman, to assassinate Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and a foiled plot to set off bombs at the United Nations, a Federal office building in lower Manhattan and Hudson River crossings.
"The attack on Rabbi Kahane did not occur in a vacuum," the prosecution's memorandum says. "It was instead a small, albeit brutal step in a terrorist campaign which comprehended not only assassinations of individuals but the mass destruction of political, social and economic assets of the 'infidel' West, of which the United States was deemed the leader."
The document, submitted to the judge late Wednesday and provided to reporters yesterday, involves what is commonly called the second case, which is separate from the completed case against four men convicted of carrying out last year's car bombing of the World Trade Center. The second case will focus on the alleged terror activities of Mr. Abdel Rahman and a band of followers, including several Egyptian, Sudanese and Palestinian immigrants and two American-born Muslims.
But three of the men convicted in the trade center bombing -- Mohammed A. Salameh, Nidal A. Ayyad and Mahmud Abouhalima -- are listed as unindicted co-conspirators in the second case and are said by the Government to have played a role in other activities, including the assassination of Rabbi Kahane.
 
Government Arguments
 Technically, the Government memorandum argues against some earlier defense motions, specifically that some of the defendants be severed from the case. The presiding judge, Michael B. Mukasey, has also asked the Government to explain why the counts in the indictment involving the Kahane and Mubarak matters should be included in a case centering on charges of seditious conspiracy, since those actions, even if proved, do not, the judge has said, seem to be directed against the United States Government.
It was in answering that last question that the prosecution yesterday laid out its theory of an overall conspiracy against the United States, inspired by Mr. Abdel Rahman's beliefs, of which the Kahane and Mubarak matters were parts. The document presented to Judge Mukasey says that a "jihad organization" came into existence in the late 1980's, well before the Kahane assassination. It carried out paramilitary training at remote spots in New York State and Connecticut, the prosecution says, and "set up headquarters in various American cities in New York, New Jersey, Texas, California, Michigan and elsewhere." The organization, the memorandum says, "had ties to jihad organizations in Egypt, the Sudan, Pakistan, Afghanistan and elsewhere."
The Government's memorandum, in spelling out what it says was the central role of Mr. Abdel Rahman in giving overall guidance to the "war of urban terror," provides few details not already disclosed in earlier court documents. Mr. Abdel Rahman, who has said he will act as his own lawyer during the trial, denies playing any role in any terror conspiracy and there seems little doubt that he will dispute the interpretations placed by the Government on his words and opinions.
 
In His Own Words
 The Government, for example, quotes from speeches and writings of Mr. Abdel Rahman that show, it contends, his overall motivation of punishing the United States for its support of Israel and Egypt, whose Governments Mr. Abdel Rahman bitterly opposed. One quotation is from a book written by Mr. Abdel Rahman in which he describes the "duty of all Muslims to sacrifice and do Jihad so that the word of the unbelievers becomes submissive to God's word."
The Government document also shows Mr. Abdel Rahman being informed of the existence of the training camps. It says that at a January 1992 meeting at the Abu Bakr mosque in Brooklyn Mr. Abdel Rahman said that "he would be sending more of his followers from the al-Salam mosque in New Jersey to training sessions.
"Rahman remarked that the time was coming when 'we' must all be 'trained and ready,' " the prosecution says.
The Government document also summarizes the conversations that Mr. Abdel Rahman had with Emad Salem, a former Egyptian Army officer who, acting as an F.B.I. informer, infiltrated the group around Mr. Abdel Rahman and secretly recorded his meetings with him.
One of the conversations, for example, shows Mr. Abdel Rahman counseling against an attack against the United Nations on the grounds that "it would muddy the waters for Islam." Instead, Mr. Abdel Rahman orders his followers to "find a plan to inflict damage -- to inflict damage on the Army, the American Army."
For the prosecution, such statements show that Mr. Abdel Rahman played a central role in discussing targets and therefore must have had a critical part in the overall conspiracy. When Mr. Salem, in the same conversation, asked Mr. Abdel Rahman what he thought of the plan to bomb the F.B.I. headquarters in Lower Manhattan, he responded:
"Well, uh, a little bit later. We'll talk about this."
The prosecution memorandum continues: "When Salem indicated that the plan was currently in motion, Rahman offered a lesson in patience from history: 'It doesn't matter. Slow down. Slow down a little bit. The one who killed Kennedy was trained for three years."

HEADLINE: Fare Increase for M.T.A. Riders Delayed by Improving Economy

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
Subway and bus fares will remain at $1.25 at least until July 1995, six months later than previously planned, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday.
Corporate profits are up because of the improving economy, so the authority's levy on companies in the region, which is about 2 percent of profits, will bring in about $486 million in 1994, up from $460 million last year, said John Cunningham, a spokesman. 
 A stream of new riders, some of them rejoining the ranks of the employed, will bring in an additional $38 million, he said. Sales tax revenues are also rising, putting the authority's total revenues at $106 million above projections, the equivalent of about 10 cents a fare.
The authority's chairman, Peter Stangl, reported to the Governor's office yesterday that the Authority had achieved some cost savings compared with its projections when the current fare, $1.25, was established in January 1992.
The M.T.A. had considered a $1.50 fare, and last year went so far as to hold hearings about an increase. But that was averted when the legislature gave the authority new revenues from a state tax on petroleum companies. That pushed the date for a fare increase from January 1994 to January 1995. Now, discussion of an increase will be delayed until after November's election.
In Albany, Mary Ann Crotty, director of policy management in the Governor's office, said the region's improving economy was "something none of us had anything to do with." But the authority, she said, could also take some credit because it had "controlled expenditures better than we first anticipated."
In a telephone interview, Mr. Stangl said ridership was rising faster than employment, because the subways were safer and more reliable. Costs were down, he said, because the Transit Authority had cut its workforce by about 8 percent between 1990 and 1993. "We've been quietly managing our costs down," he said.
Mr. Cunningham said the delay in consideration of an increase in the transit fare has no relevance for fares on the Long Island Railroad and Metro-North. But those lines, he said, are in generally good financial condition, and there is no plan now for an increase.

HEADLINE: Fighting Threatens Union Of North and South Yemen

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SANA, Yemen, May 5

 BODY:
Bombs and artillery shells exploded in battles across Yemen today after an increasingly violent feud between north and south turned into full-scale civil war.
Fighting raged near the presidential palace in Sana, the Yemen capital, and warplanes from each side reportedly attacked targets in Sana and in Aden, the capital city of the formerly Marxist Southern Yemen. 
 There was no immediate estimate of casualties.
 
French Forces on Alert
 In Paris, the French Foreign Ministry said it would evacuate French citizens from Aden, and the United States and Britain, which had been the colonial power in Southern Yemen until 1967, warned their nationals to prepare for a similar effort.
French military officials said French forces in Djibouti, across the mouth of the Red Sea, were on alert to assist the evacuation.
State Department officials estimated that about 5,000 Americans live in Yemen, most of whom work for American oil companies. British officials said about 200 Britons live in Yemen.
President Ali Abdullah Saleh, a northerner, ordered a 30-day state of emergency across the country in a statement read over the Government-run radio.
Later, the radio broadcast an order banning the carrying of arms or shooting in the streets of the capital, but there was no sign that the ban had any effect.
 
First Elections Last Year
 Officials in north and south said it was the worst fighting in the country since the pro-Western north, then known as Yemen, was united with Southern Yemen on May 22, 1990.
A nation of 14 million people at the southwest corner of the Arabian peninsula, Yemen had instituted a democratic political system and held multi-party elections in which women had full participation only last year.
But differences over power-sharing came to a head last August when Vice President Ali Salem al-Beidh, who led Southern Yemen before unification, angrily left Sana and returned to his stronghold in Aden.
He asserted that the northerners -- led by President Saleh, who has ruled Yemen since 1978 -- were seeking to marginalize the impoverished south.
Mr. Beidh also accused General Saleh's forces of a campaign of violence in which, he said, more than 150 of his supporters had been killed during the last two years.
After Arab mediation, General Saleh signed a reconciliation agreement in Jordan on Feb. 20. But the next day the pact failed as northern and southern forces clashed. The fighting has spread during the last month.
 
Airport Is Closed
 European diplomats said that northern warplanes attacked the airport in Aden and southern planes retaliated by striking the Sana airport and the presidential palace at daybreak today. The authorities closed the Sana airport after the raid.
Smoke rose from the vicinity of the presidential palace and one diplomat said southern troops shelled the compound with artillery. The Government and military did not say whether President Saleh was inside.
Artillery explosions could also be heard to the south of Sana, and small-arms fire echoed around the city. Fighting was also reported on the main road leading to the Red Sea and the port at Hodeida.
At nightfall, antiaircraft fire resumed in Sana, and power outages darkened homes and forced hotels to rely on emergency generators.
Late today, Aden radio reported air raids on Aden's airport, harbor, power station, radio station and oil refinery, but said that antiaircraft fire drove off attacking jets and that three of them were downed. The southerners reported downing two warplanes earlier in the day.
The refinery, with a capacity of 120,000 barrels a day, is an economic lifeline for Aden. But the Gulf News Agency quoted a military spokesman in Sana as denying that northern planes had attacked vital targets in Aden.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Civilians ran for cover yesterday in Sana, the capital of Yemen, after street battles in several parts of the city plunged the republic into civil war. (Associated Press)
 
Map of Yemen shows the location of Sana and of Aden.

HEADLINE: County Prescribes Its Own Cure

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOUNT CARMEL, Ill., May 4

 BODY:
In the rural tradition of neighbor helping neighbor this oil-and-farming town of 10,000 on the Wabash River is not waiting for Washington to solve its health care problems. When the oil industry collapsed a couple of years back, leaving many residents without jobs or insurance, the community opened one of the country's few all-volunteer clinics for the poor.
The Wabash County Medical Volunteers Clinic operates on Tuesday and Thursday evenings at Wabash General Hospital in a wing that had been empty since the last obstetrician left town two years ago. 
 Its patients are largely people down on their luck but too proud to ask for Government assistance like Medicaid. The support staff is a round-robin of volunteers so enthusiastic that some complain that they do not have a chance to answer phones or greet patients or perform other helpful tasks often enough.
 
Didn't Even Want Grants
 "If they had more clinics like this one they wouldn't have to reform the whole system, because the primary problem of the underinsured would be taken care of," Dr. Naren Anadkat, an internist who volunteers at the clinic, said. "Our health care system is probably the best in the world, and I don't think government has the ability to be efficient."
Self-reliance was a guiding principle in opening the clinic 18 months ago.
"We didn't want the Federal Government involved, even in grants," said Roger L. Holloway, administrator of the 56-bed hospital that is host to the clinic. "It's not a community that thinks it's someone else's job to take care of our problems."
On the contrary, many here dread an overhaul designed by Washington not only because they believe in caring for their own but because they fear that health care dollars will be doled out in the state capital, Springfield, but controlled by powerful politicians in Chicago, 300 miles to the north.
The director of rural hospital services for the Illinois Hospital Association, Barbara Dallas, called the effort a model for rural America, where even more people are uninsured than in urban areas because many are self-employed. "Dinner table conversation is, 'When is health care reform going to start?' " Ms. Dallas said. "Well, this is health care reform."
Robert T. Van Hook, a specialist on health care in the Department of Health and Human Services and former head of the National Rural Health Association, said he was impressed that the Wabash clinic was set up without government help. But he added that under a national plan such efforts would ultimately be unnecessary because most plans included universal coverage and incentives to attract doctors to rural areas. "It's a holding action," he said.
Residents for and against changing health care nationally say it is their duty to improve access to care. After the regional economy took a nosedive several years ago, the Public Health Administrator of the County Health Department, Mike Henry, came up with the idea for the clinic. He enlisted Mr. Holloway, who felt the clinic would not only help patients, but also save the hospital money.
In recent years the state started enforcing its policy of refusing to pay for nonemergency Medicaid visits to the emergency room.
Within several months four of the five working general practitioners in the town also signed on, along with one retired physician. They were employed by the hospital at an annual salary of $1, qualifying them for coverage under the hospital's malpractice insurance.
Appointments are made through the Health Department, where residents are screened for eligibility. They cannot have incomes of more than than $26,000 for a family of four, which is 133 percent of the state poverty standard. But most of the patients, predominantly young and middle-age men, actually have an average annual incomes of less than $5,000.
Workers say they rarely collect more than a few dollars from any patient. About 15 percent are on Medicaid, Mr. Henry said, because many are too proud to accept public assistance.
 
Eager Volunteers
 At the reception desk on one recent evening a retired social worker and the postmaster of nearby Allendale welcomed patients like the old friends that many were. A nursing student from a community college took their vital signs, and a registered nurse listened to their complaints, which included chest pains and a swollen wrist that had been injured in a motorcycle accident months earlier. The man said he had been treating the pain and swelling with Tylenol.
In the bright waiting room, where talk of fishing and Little League drowned out an episode of "Roseanne," Grace Lloyd said she had counted on the clinic for care since her husband had been laid off from his job at a meat-packing plant last year. She works as an aide at a nursing home, but like most others here is not insured. She had taken her 15-year-old son to the clinic to be treated for strep throat.
"They don't downgrade you or anything here," Ms. Lloyd said. "They treat you like a patient, which is really good."
Bob Howder, a former ambulance driver in a black felt hat, said he had lost his job, and his insurance, five weeks before suffering a heart attack in the fall. He had stopped seeing his doctor, "because I owe him for the last office visit." He went to the clinic, for the first time, he said, only because he had stopped hoping that he would soon find work. "I can't even walk half a block," he said.
In an examining room down the hall, Dr. Hytham Beck, a surgeon, was taking his time with each patient. He told a young woman with a hernia how to eat, sleep and take her medicine for maximum relief; warned the mother of an 8-year-old who had stepped on a rusty nail to "keep watching like a hawk" for signs of an infection, and spoke for nearly half an hour with Tommy Short, 60, an uninsured former maintenance man.
Dr. Beck and Mr. Short slowly reviewed the foods that might be making Mr. Short's high blood pressure worse, discussing labeling on canned foods and the sodium content in cereals and soups. Dr. Beck made Mr. Short promise to bring his wife with him the next time, so that they could further discuss shopping and cooking.
Then the doctor saw Kathy Moudy, who had become temporarily blind in one eye for a terrifying 15 minutes six days earlier. She had waited until clinic night to seek any medical attention, she said, and even then came only at the insistence of her mother.
"Usually I don't go to the doctor," said Ms. Moudy, who earns just over the minimum wage at an electronic components factory where she winds wire around plastic bobbins. "I treat myself."
Dr. Beck conducted a neurological examination, said Ms. Moudy had most likely suffered a "ministroke" and referred her to a specialist, who, he added, might give her a break on his fees.
Two hours past the closing time, after Dr. Beck had seen his last patient, he said he made time to volunteer because he had seen "things that make you feel ashamed, things that shouldn't happen in the United States." Those included a man who died of an extremely curable form of skin cancer because he had deferred treatment for so long.
"A lot of physicians think they've already done their duty because they've seen public-aid patients and didn't get paid," Dr. Beck said. "But that's not enough, because a lot of people are too proud to come if they can't pay. If reform takes care of these problems later on, then hallelujah. But we could also be waiting a long time."

HEADLINE: U.S. Aide Admits North Korea Nuclear Policy May Not Work

BYLINE: By MICHAEL GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
The Administration's top official handling the dispute over North Korea's nuclear program said today that he was not confident that a diplomatic solution could be reached, and that the United States had not yet won China's support for economic sanctions.
The stark admission by the official, Robert Gallucci, the Assistant Secretary of State for Political-Military Affairs, that Washington's strategy of using diplomacy and economic sanctions may fail comes at a critical moment in the negotiations aimed at persuading North Korea to allow full inspections of its nuclear sites. 
 It is also likely to heighten the debate over whether the Clinton Administration's policy on North Korea represents prudence or timidity.
As a senior State Department official, Mr. Gallucci has been deeply involved in the negotiating effort and was recently named by the White House to head American policymaking on North Korea.
In his comments, Mr. Gallucci sought to defend the Administration's policy against charges that Washington was wasting time in unproductive talks while North Korea continues its nuclear weapons program.
"The whole idea is to test the proposition that the North Koreans are willing to deal," he said. "And I always put it in terms of 'test the proposition' because I don't have, nor should I have, nor should anyone have, high confidence that we actually can resolve this through negotiations."
 
Sanctions May Not Work
 Even while trying to lower expectations that Washington's diplomacy would succeed, Mr. Gallucci argued that Washington needed to continue its diplomatic efforts because the alternatives are more dangerous: launching a pre-emptive military strike against North Korea's nuclear sites or moving unilaterally to impose economic sanctions.
"I am convinced we should not pursue this at all costs," he said.
Mr. Gallucci said Washington would ask the United Nations Security Council to consider economic sanctions against North Korea if Pyongyang rejects demands for international inspections and removes fuel rods from its reactor at Yongbyon without monitors present. But even as he discussed the prospect of economic sanctions, he conceded that the threat may be empty.
"What will the Chinese do?" Mr. Gallucci said, referring to China's veto in the Security Council. "Will you be able to pass a sanctions resolution? If there is anybody in this room who thinks they know, if they are willing to give me odds, and I do not care in which direction, I'll take them. I do not know what the Chinese are going to do."
Mr. Gallucci's comments come at a important juncture in North Korea's dealings with the International Atomic Energy Agency. In a step that could add to its potential supply of bomb-grade material, North Korea recently shut down its Yongbyon reactor and announced that it plans to discharge its fuel soon, perhaps as early as this week.
North Korea has said that the agency's inspectors could monitor the removal of the fuel. But it has rejected the agency's demands that its inspectors be permitted to take measurements of the fuel rods to help determine how much plutonium North Korea might have diverted to weapons programs in past years. It has also rejected a compromise under which the fuel rods would be set aside for measurements at a future time.
Hans Blix, the director general of the atomic agency, recently presented another proposal, which North Korea officials are still considering.
A compromise over the reactor, however, would not settle all of the nuclear disputes. North Korea has refused to let inspectors visit two nuclear waste sites, which experts want to inspect as part of their investigation into how much plutonium might have been diverted to weapons programs in past years. The agency also wants to complete inspections at a plutonium reprocessing plant at Yongbyon that the North Koreans blocked in March.
 
Leverage Limited
 In his comments today, Mr. Gallucci said openly what many Administration officials say privately: that Washington's diplomatic leverage is limited, that China is an impediment to tough sanctions, and that ending the North Korean nuclear program is not worth starting a war.
And critics complained that the Administration's diplomatic efforts have faltered even as North Korea has continued building a new, larger reactor and has moved to expand its capacity to reprocess plutonium.
"What we have now is a losing strategy," said Gary Milhollin, the director of Wisconsin Project on Arms Control.

HEADLINE: San Jose Leaps Into Big Leagues

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 4

 BODY:
This sprawling city passed San Francisco in population in the last decade and built itself a shiny new downtown. Yet San Jose remained very much the second city in the Bay Area, a place that many Northern Californians considered dull and charmless and that many residents left when they wanted a night on the town.
But all that has changed because of the success of a new downtown arena, which in eight months of operation has brought San Jose into the big leagues of sports and entertainment. This, combined with a revitalized downtown and a lively arts scene, has given its citizens something to brag about and persuaded some snooty San Franciscans that there might be a reason to drive 40 minutes down the Bayshore Freeway. 
 The reason for such a drive on Friday is the return home of the National Hockey League Sharks, the Cinderella team in this year's Stanley Cup playoffs, who have San Joseans honking their horns in celebration and teen-agers around the world lining up to buy the teal-and-black caps and jerseys that are this year's cool playground fashion statement.
Next month the San Jose Arena will showcase Barbra Streisand, who chose the capital of Silicon Valley as one of only five American stops on her concert tour. And last month the new building was packed and the nearby restaurants bustling because of Luciano Pavarotti, who delivered his signature arias in a city heretofore known for the Dionne Warwick pop lyric, "Do you know the way to San Jose?"
 
'Something to Rally Around'
 "No one is singing that song anymore," said Mayor Susan Hammer, who said that the Sharks and other attractions have given the 821,700 citizens of San Jose "something to rally around" and poured "millions and millions of dollars in spinoff revenues" into the city coffers.
The $165 million arena, approved by the voters in 1988 when the economy here was booming and paid for almost entirely with public funds, is the capstone of a decadelong $1.4 billion rebuilding effort, made possible under a state law that allows tax revenue to be used for redevelopment in some blighted districts.
Under a clever financing maneuver, San Jose merged 10 redevelopment districts scattered throughout its 174 square miles. The city brought new industry into districts at its fringes, sold bonds on the strength of the expanded tax base and then sank that revenue into the downtown area, which had fallen into disrepair after the valley's orchards gave way to semiconductor plants, tract houses and suburban malls.
Begun in the administration of former Mayor Tom McEnery, now a Democratic candidate for Congress here, the makeover of San Jose has included construction of a convention center, a half-dozen office towers, three new hotels, two new museums, a 20-mile light rail line, an open-air shopping pavilion and highway extensions to ease access to the core of what is, in effect, a brand new, pastel granite city.
 
Focus on Arts Institutions
 The next stage of the makeover will focus on the city's arts institutions, which include a symphony, an opera company, a civic light opera, a repertory theater, a children's museum, a technology museum and an art museum. This weekend the art museum will begin a $4.4 million collaboration, primarily financed by the San Jose Redevelopment Agency, with the Whitney Museum of Art in New York City. The agency will also have a role in the financing of a new home for the repertory theater and the construction of a 4,000-seat, eight-screen movie complex.
The collaboration between the two museums will include four shows in San Jose over the next six years, composed of masterpieces from the Whitney's 10,000-piece collection. The first show, tracing developments in contemporary American art from 1900 to 1940, opens on Saturday.
The arts institutions here, even before an infusion of capital from the city, kept the downtown alive, if barely, during the early years of redevelopment, when the streets were torn apart by rail construction and the first wave of new buildings seemed a stage set for a city rather than a city itself.
But none of the arts groups individually -- nor all of them in combination -- drew the huge, diverse crowds to San Jose's center that have come since the opening of the arena.
Frank Jirik, executive vice president for building operations, said 1.3 million people had passed through the arena since its opening in September for circuses, ice shows, concerts, amateur and professional sporting events and tractor pulls.
"There's something for everybody," Mr. McEnery said. "It's very much like a town center of old. Everybody goes there -- every race, every economic part of society."
Mr. McEnery supported the arena against the advice of many political advisers, who mistakenly thought residents here would oppose it.
The arena was set just blocks from the heart of downtown so that patrons, 70 percent of them from surrounding Santa Clara County and many of the rest from points south like Monterey and Gilroy, would get a taste of the revitalized central San Jose.
 
Hints of Financial Lift
 So far, the evidence of economic benefit from the arena is anecdotal, but compelling, and is being compared to the situation in downtown Phoenix, where the America West Arena spurred a 13 percent increase in tax revenue after its 1992 opening.
San Jose has yet to tally the total economic impact. But, for example, the Tied House Cafe and Brewery on San Pedro Square, the closest commercial strip to the arena, says its business has quadrupled. And a 45,000-foot sports bar in the new shopping pavilion has been doubly blessed. Shark fans without tickets watch the games there and those with tickets come to eat before games and drink afterward.
There seems no question that residents of the Silicon Valley are hungry for entertainment in their own backyard: tickets for the Pavarotti concert sold out in 59 minutes, those for the Streisand concert in 26 minutes and Sharks' playoff tickets in 11. And when the Sharks showed early-round, out-of-town playoff games on big screen televisions at the arena, more than 6,000 people showed up to watch and then to skate on the hallowed ice.
The people who live here can barely swallow a smug smile when they hear of San Franciscans grousing about having to drive here for events like last month's Pavarotti concert, or for the 1996 United States Figure Skating Championships or the 1997 National Collegiate Athletic Association regional basketball tournament -- the sort of event that they had long considered their own.
"We've been schlepping somewhere else for years to do things," said Vicki L. Herl, manager of the retail pavilion. "We don't have any sympathy for them on that one."

HEADLINE: Productivity Growth Off; Labor Costs Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
Growth in nonfarm productivity slowed sharply in the first quarter, as labor costs rose by the largest amount in more than three years, the Labor Department said today.
Analysts blamed harsh winter weather for the 5 percent rise in labor costs, which reflected a slowing in the rate of economic growth. Meanwhile, the five-tenths of 1 percent increase in productivity was down sharply from the fourth quarter's 6.4 percent gain, when the economy was growing at the fastest pace in a decade. 
 Productivity measures the time, effort and cost of producing goods. Rising productivity suggests businesses are improving their efficiency in delivering goods at competitive prices. Conversely, a slowing of productivity growth could signal a rise in inflation.
In this case, however, analysts saw few red flags in today's report. "It's the weather," said Robert Dederick, chief economist at Northern Trust in Chicago. "Labor costs are being held well in check," particularly in manufacturing.
Bond investors seemed to agree. The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond was unchanged at 7.33 percent.
Meanwhile, another Labor Department report today showed that the lingering effects of a truckers' strike contributed to a larger-than-expected increase in the number of workers joining the nation's unemployment lines last week.
First-time jobless claims rose 17,000, to a seasonally adjusted 350,000. Analysts had expected an increase of just 1,000 claims. The four-week moving average for claims, a less volatile barometer of employment, rose to 349,750 from 346,250.
Today's economic reports were overshadowed on Wall Street by concerns over the April employment report, to be released on Friday, which will provide a better gauge of the economy's strength.
In surveys, economists forecast that the economy added 170,000 to 190,000 jobs last month, following an increase of 456,000 in March. Bond yields soared after the March report was released, even though economists said the employment gain was a weather-related rebound from the winter's severe storms.
Inflation worries have played a large role in the move toward higher interest rates, and on first blush, today's productivity report appeared to confirm investors' worst fears, with a 5 percent increase in total labor costs in the first quarter -- the largest gain since the fourth quarter of 1990 -- after declining 3.3 percent in the fourth quarter.
But analysts called the rise in labor costs a statistical quirk that reflected the economy's reduced output during the winter storms. Indeed, last week the Government said wages, salaries and benefits rose just seven-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter.

HEADLINE: Pioneering Bronx Plant To Recycle City's Paper

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
In the first inner-city project of its type in the nation, one of the country's leading environmental organizations, two paper companies and a community development group are expected to announce a proposal today for a $100 million plant in the South Bronx to produce recycled paper from New York City's trash.
Proponents say the project is intended to take advantage of what environmentalists call the "urban forest" -- the vast amounts of paper discarded by offices every day. But for residents of the South Bronx, the plant would also be intended to create perhaps 300 new jobs and bring other economic benefits, including housing, training, day care and health care services for the workers. 
 The planners, who have been quietly discussing the project for two years, say they expect to raise $2 million from the paper companies and state and local governments to pay for detailed engineering and economic studies, which they hope to present to investors this fall to raise money for the plant.
The recycling operation, which would be run as a for-profit company called the Bronx Community Paper Company, would be on a 19-acre site in the old Harlem Rail Yard just north of Randalls Island and could be operating by fall 1996, planners said.
John Adams, executive director of the environmental group behind the plan, the Natural Resources Defense Council, said the project would also promote social values.
"We get everything we want: jobs, recycling, a process we like and social equity," he said. "We save lots of trees and end the waste of putting a valuable resource into landfills."
Clay Lifflander, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, which seeks to attract businesses to the city, said the Guiliani administration supported the plan. "We will do what we can to help see this vision brought to reality," Mr. Lifflander said.
The White House, which last year issued an executive order requiring Federal agencies to increase their use of recycled paper, also praised the South Bronx plan. "This initiative shows that economic development, job creation and environmental protection can work together for the benefit of us all," Vice President Al Gore said in a statement.
The real test of the project's viability will be whether a business payoff can be seen by the paper companies and outside investors who will be asked to pay for the plant.
"This is not a social project for us -- we need the pulp," said James D. Black, a vice president of S. D. Warren, a Boston-based unit of the Scott Paper Company that has contributed $250,000 to the effort. The other paper company involved is the Modo Paper Company of Stockholm, which operates recycling plants in Europe and has contributed $300,000 so far to the South Bronx project.
"We need high-quality pulp to make printing and writing papers," Mr. Black said. "And our customers increasingly want recycled content."
Even for the business-minded, there may be pragmatic value in the perceived social benefits. Because of the participation of a community group, the Banana Kelly Community Improvement Association, project organizers expect the active support of local residents, rather than the community opposition that can severely delay development proposals.
 
Partnership With Residents
 "The residents of the South Bronx appreciate being included as partners from the outset, rather than being cornered into the role of adversaries," said Yolanda Rivera, chairwoman of Banana Kelly, which is named for the curve of Kelly Street in the South Bronx.
Of the approximately $100 million it will cost to build and equip the plant, $6.2 million will be earmarked in advance for day care and health facilities, housing and education. "These social services will help people move out of unemployment to train for real jobs," Ms. Rivera said.
The plant is expected to employ 180 to 200 people, with approximately 100 more jobs coming from the related social services. Most of the people hired are expected to be from the South Bronx and would be trained by Banana Kelly.
If the money is in place, construction could begin in February, said Allen Hershkowitz, a senior scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council.
Although other companies in the city call themselves recyclers, their work involves only the collection of trash, which they sort to remove the recyclable materials, which are then bundled and sent outside New York City to be processed. The Bronx mill would be the first in the city to render used paper into clean pulp that paper companies could then make into high-grade printing and writing papers.
In recent years the number of paper-recycling plants has increased throughout the nation. But most have been in old paper mills in rural areas or in industrial parks in the Midwest, where land and labor are cheaper than in urban areas and where there tend to be fewer bureaucratic obstacles.
But with enough local support, the South Bronx could have certain advantages, Mr. Hershkowitz said. "The economics of transportation work in our favor," he said. "Most mills are hundreds of miles from cities, so we will have a $15-a-ton cost advantage."
David Gatton, an environmental adviser to the United States Conference of Mayors, said the project might set an important precedent by showing how abandoned inner-city industrial sites, like the Harlem Rail Yard, can be redeveloped.
Initial plans call for the installation of equipment to remove ink from used paper so the resulting pulp can be used to make new paper elsewhere. But if the venture is successful, a paper mill may be built on the site as well, which would bring additional employment.
Private haulers who collect paper from office buildings are expected to be main suppliers for the plant because they have access to large amounts of high-grade used paper, like the paper used for computer printouts. Paper collected by the city from residences is usually too contaminated by other materials to meet the plant's quality requirements.
Environmental groups and paper companies have been antagonists in the past because paper companies have been seen as damaging forests by cutting down large numbers of trees and by operating mills that emit air and water pollutants. In fact, the Natural Resources Defense Council has sued three paper companies in the last decade because of water pollution. And the council has a petition pending before the Environmental Protection Agency to ban discharges of dioxin, a toxic byproduct of paper bleaching -- a prohibition that could close some paper mills if enacted.
But environmentalists tend to like paper-recycling plants, because they use existing paper as their raw material, saving trees. And the recycling process to be used in the Bronx project, based on techniques developed in Japan, would minimize pollution by using none of the chlorine normally associated with paper bleaching. It would also use water recovered by a nearby city-operated waste-water treatment plant and be powered by "clean" electricity produced by a gas-fired generator to be built for the operation.
"This is the next stage of environmentalism," Mr. Hershkowitz said. "Instead of suing to stop projects we do not like, we are going to promote the ones we do like."
In addition to environmental and social goals, organizers are hoping to bring high esthetic values to the project. The architect Maya Lin, best known for her design of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, has been hired to design the plant and its surroundings.
In a written proposal, she said she wanted to showcase the recycling process, rather than hide it inside a featureless building, and to make ornamental, landscaping use of the water used in the process.
In addition, Ms. Lin's design specifies the use of recycled materials wherever possible.

HEADLINE: Stock Traders Reticent, Awaiting Jobs Data

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stock prices closed essentially unchanged in light volume yesterday, as traders held back purchases in advance of closely watched employment data scheduled for release today by the Government.
Bond prices were little changed, and the dollar gained slightly, while the price of gold plunged. 
 Some stocks gained, however. Sears, Roebuck, the huge retailer, rose after strong same-store sales for April. Royal Dutch Petroleum, the oil company; American International Group, the insurance company, and Autodesk, a computer design software company, also gained.
But in general, traders were bracing for April unemployment data to be released this morning. The consensus estimate among private economists is for a 6.5 percent jobless rate, with the number of jobs increasing by 170,000 to 190,000.
Some traders contend that a larger-than-expected increase in the number of jobs created may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates for the fourth time in as many months. A surge in the March jobs data preceded the Fed's third rate increase last month.
Higher short-term interest rates may strengthen the dollar, which has dropped sharply against major currencies in recent weeks. But higher interest rates would increase companies' operating expenses, as well as damp loan demand, and thus might slow the economy.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.78 points, to 3,695.97, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 fell 0.34 point, to 451.38. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 0.25 point, to 740.55.
The number of shares changing hands on The New York Stock Exchange was below normal. Volume totaled nearly 256 million shares, or 16 percent below this year's average of 304 million shares.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond's yield was unchanged at 7.33 percent. The dollar rallied for a second day to close at 102.90 yen, up from 101.88 yen. Meanwhile, gold futures for June delivery, the spot month, fell $3.00, to $374.70 an ounce.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.26 point, to 250.49, and declines outnumbered advances by 1,087 to 1,019. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 2.09 points, to 441.70.
Of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow, 18 fell, led by General Motors, which fell 1 1/8, to 55 5/8. The world's largest car maker said yesterday that it planned to cut car production by 9,300 cars, or six-tenths of 1 percent, in the second quarter, in part because of slightly slower sales of its mainstay Chevrolet cars.
In the S.& P. 500 stocks, 225 fell, led by G.M. and Pepsico, which dropped 1, to 36, on no clear news.
Intel was the most active stock yesterday, with 5.5 million shares traded. It rose 1/2, to 581/16 . On Wednesday, the company, which makes microprocessors for computers, forecast industry sales of personal computers at 100 million a year as early as 1998.
Cisco Systems, a maker of systems that link computers into networks, was the second-most-active stock at 5 million shares. It rose 3/4, to 31 1/2, after independent testing confirmed that its products performed faster than the nearest industry competitor.
Kmart was the third-most-active stock, with 4.4 million shares traded, and fell 3/8, to 15 5/8. It reported disappointing same-store sales for April.
Royal Dutch Petroleum rose 2 1/8, to 107 7/8, after the International Energy Agency said yesterday that demand for oil was rising. American International Group rose 2 1/2, to 88 1/4, after a variety of analysts said the stock might be undervalued. Autodesk gained 2 1/4, to 54 1/2, following comments by industry analysts that sales of personal computers would rise, thus helping software sales.

HEADLINE: 'Whispers' Urged Rifkin to Kill, His Laywer Says

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., May 5

 BODY:
Testimony ended in the Joel Rifkin murder trial today with the defense contending that Mr. Rifkin was driven to kill by whispering voices from deep within his troubled psyche.
His lawyer, John Lawrence, said the whispers were clear evidence that Mr. Rifkin was a paranoid schizophrenic, unable to separate fantasy from reality and therefore legally insane when he murdered the 17 women he has confessed to killing. 
 Mr. Rifkin is on trial in Nassau County Court for the murder of his final victim, Tiffany Bresciani, who was 22 and lived in Manhattan. The prosecution has argued that while Mr. Rifkin may suffer from a long list of mental disorders, he was not legally insane when he killed. He knew the consequences of his conduct and that his conduct was wrong, the prosecution asserted.
In rebuttal, Mr. Lawrence contended that Mr. Rifkin suffered from a serious thought disorder that unhinged him from reality. "And in that dreaming-while-awake-state, Mr. Rifkin actually saw his dead victims as living people, talked with them and tried to provide for their comfort and safety," Mr. Lawrence said.
He drew the jury's attention to a transcript of a taped conversation between Mr. Rifkin and Dr. Park Elliot Dietz, chief witness for the prosecution.
According to the transcript, Mr. Rifkin told Dr. Dietz that at times he would speak to the corpses, "saying reassuring things as he drove with them." He also said he had positioned the body of one victim in a steel drum so she "would be comfortable."
Mr. Rifkin also told Dr. Dietz during the daylong examination that he liked Ms. Bresciani and did not want to kill her. But while he was pondering whether to strangle Ms. Bresciani, the "whispers" told him to do it, Mr. Rifkin told Dr. Dietz.
"It wasn't a casual command, it was a 'Yes,' probably the loudest I ever heard it," Mr. Rifkin said in the transcript.
Dr. Dietz raised the subject of "whispers" during his testimony for the prosecution on Wednesday. He then characterized them as nothing more than an "internal dialogue" by Mr. Rifkin, just as "everyone makes decisions," Dr. Dietz said.
Called back to the witness stand today by Mr. Williams, the doctor was asked whether such "whispers" might not be a delusion or hallucination -- both symptoms of paranoid schizophrenia. Dr. Dietz said he did not believe so, but added, "some might disagree on whether they are hallucinations."
Under further questioning, Dr. Dietz confirmed that Mr. Rifkin had told him of an incident in the basement of the Rifkin home in East Meadow, where Mr. Rifkin had killed one victim.
"The phone rang when he had a body in the basement, and he had a notion that the body was calling him," Dr. Dietz said.
Mr. Rifkin, who has worn his father's shoes and ring for reassurance while in court, sat at the defense table and showed little emotion or none. Mr. Rifkin, a 34-year-old unemployed landscaper, was arrested last June 28 with Ms. Bresciani's body in the back of his pickup truck.
