SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1270 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Life's Hard? Blame the Market

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
IN the 1970's, inflation outran wages, and you blamed Jimmy Carter and the Arabs. In the 1980's, Wall Street hustlers dined on beluga while the Department of Agriculture declared ketchup a vegetable, and you blamed Ronald Reagan and Michael Milken. Then came the recession, the first to take a whack at white-collar jobs, and you blamed George Bush and the Japanese.
 Now the recession is over, the Democrat in the White House says he feels your pain -- and yet you're worried as ever about paying the bills. In fact, the corporate downsizing that began in the 1980's seems to be gaining momentum, leaving even privileged Americans to ponder a future life in the slow lane. Who's left to blame? 
 The better question, argues Frank Levy, an economist at M.I.T., is not who, but what. And the best answer is free markets -- more specifically, the way markets divide the economic pie. "Rising productivity means rising living standards on average," notes Mr. Levy. "But these days, hardly anyone is average." Indeed, the collapse in prospects for unskilled workers and the emergence of what Robert Frank of Cornell and Philip Cook of Duke University have dubbed winner-take-all economics has strained the collective faith in the justice of markets.
 Part of the confusion over what constitutes economic fairness stems from the American genius for living with contradiction. According to the Horatio Alger definition, fairness is equality of opportunity, the idea that the prizes should go to the fleet as long as everyone starts at the same place. But people also like to believe that return should be related to virtue -- that the reward for teaching school or inventing a new drug should be roughly proportional to its social value. Still another standard would measure economic justice by the treatment of those at the bottom.
 Americans long managed to ignore these apparent contradictions. In the 1950's and 1960's prosperity marched in lockstep with diminishing inequality. And while these decades were apparently exceptions, most of the decades that preceded the golden postwar era were not so bad, either. The gap between rich and poor often widened in periods of rapid growth, but almost everyone gained while some even managed to grab the brass ring.
 America's luck seems to have run out in the mid-1970's, and with it the luxury of assuming that capitalism's natural face was benign. As almost everybody has since acknowledged, the economy has created millions of losers -- unskilled workers, younger workers, children in single-parent households -- and put the striving middle-class on a strict regime of two often-insecure jobs per family. What is not resolved, however, is what could or should be done about it.
 It's easy enough to explain the plight of the unskilled. Economists will be busy for years apportioning the blame among technology, competition from women, freer trade, deregulation, de-unionization, immigration and changing attitudes toward work.
 
Economies of Scale
 The hard part is explaining why the incomes of workers with nominally equal qualifications have diverged so sharply. This phenomenon is most evident at the superstar level, with the near-doubling of earned income of the top one-quarter percent of taxpayers. But there are echoes of winner-take-all outcomes through the rest of the pecking order. Consider, for example, the split between $25-an-hour autoworkers who assemble Fords and the $5-an-hour fast food workers across the street who assemble burritos.
 One explanation, argues Robert Frank, is that changes in technology, marketing and corporate organization have created fantastic economies of scale in highly specialized services. "One soprano's voice on a CD can do the work of hundreds" in old-fashioned concert halls, he notes. Since most people get their music on CD's, the very best sopranos make fortunes while others wait on tables. By the same token, he says, a fine lawyer may be only marginally better at the craft than the competition, "but if you are being sued for $100 million, think how much more it is worth to hire the one who can improve your odds of winning by just a few percent."
 Another explanation is the breakdown of social conventions that limited extremes in compensation and deterred those with the wherewithal from simply taking the money and running. Paul Joskow of M.I.T. estimates that during the 1980's, a period of stagnant average wages, the pay of chief executives at 800 large corporations rose by 75 percent. And this apparent breakdown in we're-all-in-this-together civility, argues Andrei Shleifer of Harvard, could also help to explain the ruthlessness of corporate restructuring, in which divisions are liquidated or moved abroad, middle managers fired, pension plans abandoned and union strikers replaced.
 What, if anything, should be done about winner-take-all outcomes, argue most analysts, turns on what is driving the phenomenon. Economists are generally inclined to give the benefit of the doubt to markets, assuming that interference will reduce productivity by distorting incentives to work, hire, save and invest. Thus what the late economist Arthur Okun called "the big tradeoff" between economic efficiency and fairness was a rationale for caution -- caution reflected in everything from worries about the impact of high tax rates to flat-out opposition to minimum wages.
 But some critics, notably Derek Bok, the former president of Harvard and author of "The Cost of Talent," thinks there is no real market to preserve at the very top -- corporate executives, he argues, effectively control their own pay -- and thus little reason to worry that interference would reduce efficiency. For his part Mr. Frank believes that winner-take-all is often the consequence of a subtler form of market distortion, one in which much of the investment in learning "superstar" trades such as investment banking goes to waste because only a tiny fraction of the applicants ever get the superstar jobs.
 "If Frank is right," concludes Jim Rebitzer of M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management, "it's a win-win situation" to discourage such overinvestment by heavily taxing the superstars. Mr. Frank would also like to level the playing field by subsidizing investment in productive activities, like teaching, that offer no prospect of superstar status.
 By the same token, corporate restructuring is often seen as necessary medicine for what ails a slothful corporate America no longer shielded from global competition. On the other hand if, as Mr. Shleifer suggests, the shuffling and reshuffling of corporate assets has largely served the short-term interests of investment bankers and fad-obsessed managers, rules against plant closings or firing without generous severance might raise productivity.
 But to Mickey Kaus, the author of "The End of Inequality," this debate is a distraction from some uncomfortable truths. Adam Smith's invisible hand has no moral sensibility, he argues, and the outcomes determined by markets are unlikely to be fair. Worse, he predicts, the politically tolerable level of tinkering with income distribution -- everything from education reform to tax policy -- will be insufficient to right the balance.
 What, then, is left to do? Mr. Kaus thinks the best hope is to convince people to value community more and material success less. "The goal should be social equality, not money equality," he argues. "Some might drive Porsches and some might not own cars -- but they would all be willing to live in the same neighborhood and send their children to the same schools."

HEADLINE: Clinton Grants Haitian Exiles Hearings at Sea

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
President Clinton decided today to grant asylum hearings to Haitians who are halted at sea while trying to reach the United States, reversing a policy that has required the Coast Guard to forcibly return the boats, White House officials said.
Responding to growing pressure from Congress and supporters of Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, White House officials said the United States would grant asylum interviews to potential refugees on United States vessels in the Caribbean or at sites in other countries in the region. 
 Administration officials said they had not yet decided which countrieswould be asked to receive the refugees for processing. They have considered and rejected approaching Honduras and Guyana.
Refugees deemed not eligible for asylum would be returned to Haiti.
Shortly before he took office last year, Mr. Clinton announced that he would continue the Bush Administration's policy of intercepting boats filled with fleeing Haitians and forcibly returning the refugees to Haiti without a hearing. During the presidential campaign he had described that policy, instituted in May 1992, as cruel..
When he decided to adopt the Bush Administration's approach, President Clinton defended his action by saying that allowing Haitians to land would encourage thousands more to risk their lives on the high seas.
But a senior White House official said that recent developments in Haiti, including reports of a renewed wave of military terror and killings, had forced a reconsideration.
"The situation in Haiti has become more violent, and the Government more repressive," a senior White House official said today. "Our concern has increased about that percentage of people who take to the boats who have a justifiable claim for political refugee status."
The official said that no more than 10 percent of Haitians who now apply for asylum at processing centers in Haiti are found to be eligible, and that the United States does not expect this to change.
Many have been judged to be economic refugees. Haiti is the poorest country in the hemisphere, and international sanctions adopted after the 1991 coup against Father Aristide have aggravated the deprivation faced by ordinary people.
In settling on the new approach, which officials expect to announce formally on Sunday and put in place in about two weeks, Mr. Clinton is reviving a formula that the United States used from 1982 to 1992 but discontinued, in part because interviews conducted on Coast Guard vessels were considered unreliable.
Human rights campaigners had also raised concerns about shipboard reviews because of living conditions aboard the smaller Coast Guard vessels.
This time, officials said, the processing will take place on board larger Navy ships that can better accommodate the individual asylum hearings. The White House remains opposed to reopening the processing center at the United States naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, used in the first few months after the September 1991 coup.
The options approved today allow the White House to address the immediate issue without encouraging a flood of Haitians to set out for Florida.
The change of policy comes as part of a general re-examination of Haiti policy, which the President has recently said must be revised.
 
A Storm of Protest
 Over the last few weeks, the Administration's 16-month-old approach to the Haiti question has stirred wrath among members of Congress, who have called for a military invasion, a suspension of the direct return policy and an extension of an oil embargo to cover nearly all trade with Haiti.
The Clinton Administration's policy on forcible repatriation of refugees has also angered Father Aristide, Haiti's first democratically elected President, who has lived in exile in the United States since he was ousted by the Haitian military.
On Friday, the United Nations Security Council voted unanimously to tighten the embargo in response to a call by the United States for tougher action to press the military to let Father Aristide return.
 
Hunger Strike by Robinson
 Mr. Clinton had also been asked to abandon the repatriation policy by Randall Robinson, the executive director of the TransAfrica Foundation, who has been fasting for nearly a month in an effort to step up pressure on Mr. Clinton to change the policy. He has lost 12 pounds from his 6-foot 5-inch, 195-pound frame on a diet of juice and water and was treated briefly in a hospital for dehydration this week.
Asked about the change in policy today, Mr. Robinson only responded: "I hope that the Administration will change course but, of course, I can't respond until I hear it officially from the Administration."
Administration officials had considered and rejected shipboard or third-country hearings just two weeks ago. Holding hearings in another country was then considered too expensive and unwieldy, and officials questioned whether the country involved would be able to deport the refugees who were denied asylum.
Administration officials who have spoken with Mr. Robinson said today that his condition played some role in their decision to revise the policy now. But they also stressed that the White House had been reviewing it for more than a month and did not negotiate with Mr. Robinson.
Mr. Clinton met for three and a half hours today with Vice President Gore, Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Gen. John Shalikashvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; Defense Secretary William Perry, Madeleine K. Albright, the American delegate to the United Nations, and other senior aides.
 
Limits of New Policy
 The aides emphasized afterward that the change in policy did not mean the United States would open its docks to any Haitian fleeing the nation for economic or other reasons unrelated to political persecution.
"We don't want any Haitian to believe he or she can get a better deal by taking to boats instead of going to internal processing centers," a White House official said. "This is not an easier way to get in."
American officials have abandoned efforts at achieving Father Aristide's return through negotiations and have recently begun hinting in public that they would consider using force to oust Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the military leader.
 
Cool to Proposal on Island
 Some human rights groups have supported creating a safe haven on Ile de la Gonave, off the Haitian coast, for people fleeing persecution. But the Administration rejected that last year because it would require building installations and American military occupation of Haitian territory.
Father Aristide said in an interview conducted before Mr. Clinton's meeting today that American policy would have to shift to take into account the latest repression in Haiti.
"Our Haitians cannot flee political repression," he said on the CNN program "Both Sides" with Jesse Jackson. "The U.S. vessels are around our island. And when they escape, they send our refugees back to this house on fire after seeing 5,000 killed by the military."

HEADLINE: U.S. SHIFTS STANCE IN EFFORT TO SLOW ECONOMIC GROWTH

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
After a year and a half of seeking faster economic growth, the Clinton Administration has now reluctantly changed course, putting the stability of financial markets ahead of rapid economic expansion.
No longer do Administration officials promote low interest rates and a falling dollar. The economy's health, coupled with the political uncertainties that have led an already weak dollar to sag further, has driven the Administration to abandon those early policies. 
 The forces driving the shift became clearer in the last week, as the dollar's slump forced 16 countries to come to its rescue on Wednesday. And on Friday, United States employment figures provided new evidence that the slow, jobless recovery of 1992 and 1993 was now neither slow nor jobless.
As a result, officials appear resigned to higher rates and a strong dollar -- two policies that will brake the economy and dampen job creation this year.
The shift in stance has been expressed most clearly by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen. He said without criticism three weeks ago that he expected further increases in short-term interest rates of up to half a percentage point by the Federal Reserve. And on Wednesday, he organized the international rescue of the dollar.
"This Administration sees no advantage in an undervalued currency," he said then.
The goal of the shift is not to stop the recovery. The aim is to do whatever possible to insure that the economic expansion is as long and inflation-free as possible -- ideally lasting through the next Presidential election in 1996.
"Growth is good for this society as long as it doesn't pass the point of tripping off inflation," Alan S. Blinder, one of the Administration's most influential economists, testified before a Congressional committee on Friday.
But Mr. Blinder, an economist from Princeton University and a member of the White House's Council of Economic Advisers, who has been nominated by President Clinton to become the Fed's next vice chairman, gave an unusually cautious definition, at least for a Democrat, of how much growth could set off inflation. If growth persists for more than two years from now at an annual pace of 3 percent -- a fairly modest rate -- then inflation could resume, he warned.
The Clinton Administration's shift could be unpopular with liberal Democrats who have criticized the Fed for its rate increases. But it is in keeping with Mr. Clinton's political goal of positioning himself as a Democrat who is not feared on Wall Street.
More basically, it reflects a change in the Administration's view of where the real risks lie in the economy. In the 1992 Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton made reviving a moribund economy his central promise and talked of stimulating the economy with Federal spending programs, usually described as investments. "We have to both bring down the deficit and get our economy going through these kinds of investments in order to get the kind of wealth and jobs and incomes we need in America," he said in a Presidential debate on Oct. 16, 1992.
That talk has faded, particularly after Congressional Republicans defeated the President's economic stimulus proposal a year ago. Administration officials then began pointing to low interest rates as the engine of recovery.
But back then, as Mr. Blinder said on Friday, pursuing faster growth by holding down rates posed little risk of inflation, while slow growth posed a strong danger of keeping millions of Americans out of work.
Now, he said, the economy is so close to producing at maximum output that inflation has become more of a worry. Growth that is too fast is now as dangerous as growth that is too slow. "The risks are not one-sided" any more, Mr. Blinder said.
 
A Consistent Policy
 Robert E. Rubin, the head of the President's National Economic Council, said in a telephone interview today that American economic policy had been consistent since President Clinton won the election. The difference now, Mr. Rubin said, is that the American economy is much further along in the business cycle.
"When we took office, what we wanted to do was get a sustained recovery going, and that is what we have accomplished and put ourselves on a path that on average, over time, will produce solid growth and moderate inflation," he said.
As a result, Administration officials now pay more attention to inflation, although they continue to watch for signs of slowing growth, Mr. Rubin said.
"With growth now at a healthy rate, people are more focused on the issue of inflation than they were when growth was low," he said. "And as you would expect with higher growth, people expect slightly higher inflation, but they still expect inflation to be at moderate levels."
President Clinton's comments on interest rates have reflected the gradual shift within the Administration. He said in December that he thought it would be inappropriate for the Fed to raise interest rates. He accepted the Fed's first increase on Feb. 4, but said interest rates should not continue to rise. After the latest increase, on April 18, he had no criticisms, saying, "This is still within the range of interest rates that should not do anything to harm the economy."
 
A Transitory Effect
 Comments like the President's are the closest the Administration has come recently to trying to alter the overall level of domestic economic growth. Budget policy is virtually frozen for five years by the 1993 budget act, Mr. Blinder said on Friday. The Treasury Department's efforts to prop up or drive down the dollar have only a transitory effect unless backed up by changes in interest rates. And the Fed controls interest rates, tolerating little interference from the White House.
Some economists say the Administration should have abandoned sooner its enthusiasm for low interest rates and a low dollar. "The inconsistencies of its policies are coming back to haunt it," said Michael J. Boskin, who was the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Bush Administration. "You cannot be telling the Fed to keep interest rates low and talk down the dollar simultaneously, which puts upward pressure on interest rates."
The shift on interest rates and the dollar is likely to restrain inflation, but also slow economic growth, economists said. "I would taper down the growth in the latter half of 1994 and in early 1995 because of their new policy," said Neal M. Soss, who watches the Fed for the CS First Boston Corporation.
 
The Rate-Dollar Conundrum
 A low dollar makes American cars and other exports cheaper in foreign markets, stimulating growth. Low interest rates encourage banks to make many loans that also fuel economic growth.
But a low dollar can also foster inflation, by making it more expensive for Americans to buy imported products like French cheeses and Italian shoes. A falling dollar puts pressure on the Fed to raise interest rates to prop up the dollar and forestall inflation.
A preoccupation with the economy's maximum capacity for producing goods and services has guided the Clinton Administration's new outlook, several officials said in interviews during the last two weeks.
The ceiling on economic growth is the nation's maximum level of sustained economic output, when most factories are operating at full capacity and most workers have jobs. As long as the country's economy is not operating at its full potential, the economy can grow quickly by putting factories and people to work. Total economic output then rises quickly.
But when the economy reaches maximum capacity, it can only grow as fast as the maximum capacity grows. The capacity grows at the rate that new workers join the labor force and existing workers increase their productivity and output.
Most economists say this rate of increase in the economy's capacity is slower than the pace at which the economy is likely to grow for the rest of the year.
 
A Political Implication
 Mr. Blinder said in a recent interview that he thought the economy was between three-quarters of a percentage point and one and a half percentage points short of reaching its maximum capacity. The maximum capacity appears to be growing at a rate of 2.5 percent a year, so economic growth will have to slow to that pace when the economy reaches the ceiling, he said.
Those estimates have a very strong political implication that is broadly shared and understood both within the White House and the Fed. Through simple arithmetic, they imply that the economy has only about 9 percentage points of growth left through the 1996 Presidential elections, and that the Administration may want to conserve some of that growth for 1996, rather than splurging in 1994 and 1995.
The arithmetic shows that economic potential will grow by 2.5 percentage points a year through 1996, or a total of 7.5 points (or a little more because of the compounding effect, like interest in a bank account). Add to that the maximum of one and a half percentage points of growth remaining before the ceiling is reached and as little as 9 points of growth remain. "I think that's a reasonable way to think about it," Mr. Blinder said.

HEADLINE: Fast-Lane Killer: A special report.;
Heroin Finds a New Market Along Cutting Edge of Style

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 4

 BODY:
The rising young fashion photographer was acting jumpy. He scratched the label off a beer bottle and skittered his fingers over the buttons of a cellular phone without ever dialing. For more than an hour this evening he'd been marking time in a dark and narrow bar in Hollywood called simply The Room.
No sign identifies the place, and its entrance is off an alley lined with garbage Dumpsters. Yet, far from turning off customers, the furtive underground atmosphere has made The Room a voguish hangout. 
 Finally, around midnight, the man the photographer had been waiting for arrived. There was a discreet exchange: $100 for a tiny packet of the new drug in town. The photographer and two of his friends -- a director and an actor -- disappeared behind a velvet curtain across the entrance to the ladies room. When the photographer emerged, he was smiling the smile of feeling no pain.
The new drug is heroin, which, a generation ago, may have evoked the specter of the ultimate dead end. But for users too tender to remember, it is once again unfolding its black crepe wings.
"It's exploding," said Peter Bill, the 29-year-old son of the director Tony Bill and an observer of the scene who club-hops many nights a week with young Hollywood. "At just about every party I've been at in the last six months, whether public or private, whether early or late, there is a definite bitter almond smell," the scent of heroin being smoked.
Heroin use, some drug-abuse experts say, is reminiscent of the pattern set by cocaine in the late 1970's and early 80's, when cocaine was the cocktail of choice for the chic, before it filtered down to the mass of urban professionals and, then, in its cheapest and most destructive form, as crack, to the poor. High-grade heroin that can be smoked rather than injected has caught on, on both coasts, in circles whose habits often set trends -- young people piloting the fast lane in the film, rock and fashion industries.
"Heroin is prevalent in all those areas just the way cocaine was 15 years ago," said Dr. Robert B. Millman, director of substance-abuse programs at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. A lot of the new users "skipped cocaine or had a brief flirtation," he said, "but it had lost a lot of its glamour, whereas heroin reacquired its romance."
"Heroin was seen as dark, inner-city, secretive," Dr. Millman said. "The romance obscured the reality that this drug is thoroughly horrible."
 
The Numbers
Surging Use By the Affluent
 Visits to hospitals for heroin-related emergencies rose to 30,800 nationwide in the first half of 1993, from 21,400 in the first half of 1992, an increase of 44 percent, according to the Federal Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration. Law-enforcement officials have reported signs of increased heroin use across the socio-economic spectrum, in some small cities as well as large, but the most surprising surge, experts say, is among the educated and affluent.
Dr. Millman, who oversees treatment for about 600 patients in New York City, said, "In the last year there has been a remarkable increase in the number of people who are doing heroin in the middle and upper classes."
Recently, his programs have treated a feature film director, a partner in a corporate law firm, a famous model and a fashion designer. The much publicized deaths of River Phoenix from an overdose of heroin and cocaine in October, and of Kurt Cobain, who had heroin in his bloodstream when he shot himself to death last month, have apparently done little to slow the scene.
"It's one of those things that never actually went away but for some reason it's back as the hip thing to do," said Detective Dave Valentine of the Los Angeles Sheriff's Office, who investigates drug use on the Sunset Strip. He said there was no specific operation directed at heroin, which is still less common than cocaine and methamphetamine.
The reasons cited for heroin's return range from declining prices on the global market, to amnesia about its human devastation, to images in films, magazines and music videos implying that, as a talked-about article in Vogue by Charles Gandee recently put it, "It's hip to be high."
In Southeast Asia and Latin America, bumper crops of heroin-yielding poppies have led to falling prices and increasing purity. As recently as 10 years ago, bags of heroin bought on the street were only about 4 percent pure, according to the Justice Department, but today the average purity is 65 percent. The elevated potency makes it possible to get high by snorting or smoking the drug rather than injecting it. In the past the needle scared off many would-be users, a fear reinforced by the AIDS epidemic. Now that barrier has fallen.
In the trendy precincts of Los Angeles, the preferred way of using heroin is to heat it, either as a powder or a less refined resin known as tar, on a piece of silver foil. As the heroin liquifies and evaporates, users inhale the smoke through a rolled-up foil straw held in the mouth. It's called "chasing the dragon," an image conjured up by the dance with the straw as the user sucks up the curling smoke. The practice has spawned an underground fashion, dragons emblazoned on baseball caps and shirts, which have been spotted on the Venice boardwalk and on Hollywood Boulevard.
In New York City, by several accounts, heroin is less common than on the West Coast, appealing typically to longtime cocaine abusers who have found that it eases the jangled nerves and depression that often accompany the end of a cocaine binge.
"I still see people doing the uptown thing, which is cocaine," said an owner of a popular SoHo bar. "If people say, 'We're going uptown,' it means blow. And 'downtown' is heroin."
The new means of imbibing and the new slang are insidious, Mr. Bill said, because they let people deny they are really on a road to junkiedom. Mr. Bill, who says he spent more than two years in private treatment at a cost of $150,000 to his family to kick a heroin addiction, added, "The justification and the rationalization are incredible."
Degrees of addiction, Dr. Millman said, fall along a continuum from a small number of "controlled users" who get high once or twice a week, maintaining jobs and busy routines, to a much larger number of compulsive daily users in the process of self-destructing. Users develop a tolerance that demands strikingly larger doses to achieve the same effect. Despite the new purity, many are eventually driven to upgrade from snorting and smoking to injecting the drug.
"They think they can control heroin the way they can control cocaine, but they can't," Dr. Millman said. "Heroin is much more profound in causing a chronic dependency."
 
The Aura
From Tawdry Past To Chic Present
 In the 80's, cocaine and crack were the focus of an unrelenting obloquy in a national war on drugs. Heroin, which had been the leading cause of death among young men in New York City in the late 60's, slid into relative obscurity, along with the sad and tawdry image of the ghetto user with track-marked arms.
As the drug lost its stigma, it acquired a pedigree of authenticity, primarily among middle-class whites pursuing the cutting edge in the arts. They rediscovered its time-worn image, from the era of Charlie Parker to that of Keith Richards, as a drug for stylishly tortured souls. The re-glamorization of heroin is now appearing everywhere, from alternative music to the fashion runways.
In San Francisco, the names of underground bands like Pale Horse and Morphine pay homage to the drug. In the music video of the Black Crowes' 1993 song "Sometimes Salvation," Sofia Coppola is an addict in a tiger-print coat who gets her "salvation" in the form of a fix in a picturesquely seedy tenement.
Two films by Gus Van Sant, talismans of young Hollywood, are often cited as giving addiction a world-weary romance: "Drugstore Cowboy," with Matt Dillon pulling a series of pharmacy heists, and "My Own Private Idaho," in which Keanu Reeves slums among drug-using runaways like River Phoenix.
"I thought they really glamorized addiction," Michael Hill, an A & R executive with Warner Brothers Records, said of the films. "Certainly the one with River Phoenix took it beyond glamorizing to really mythologizing it."
Mr. Van Sant did not return calls seeking a response.
Corinne Day, a leading fashion photographer, has shot the waifish model Kate Moss for British Vogue lolling vacantly around an apartment with spilled ashtrays and old coffee cups. In the taste for the emaciated, hollow-cheeked look, some social critics see an allusion to hard drugs.
The news media, too, is accused of making heroin exciting with reports of its return. "To talk about it as chic is a come-on, which got us into so much trouble with cocaine," said Dr. Herbert D. Kleber of Columbia University, a top anti-drug official in the Bush Administration.
 
The Attitude
Fueled by Fame And Insecurity
 If cocaine, a stimulant whose effects are hyper-alertness and paranoia, was emblematic of the high-flying 80's, heroin, too, seems to have caught on in part because it speaks of the moment. It is a downer for the neo-beatnik esthetic prized by certain young people in the 90's, an anti-yuppie drug that produces feelings of satiation and lassitude.
"It seems like heroin has more soul to it, whereas coke is total 80's, Studio 54, glitter," said a recovering heroin user from Los Angeles, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to protect her job as a producer at a cable-television network. Erin Culley, a 30-year-old writer for US magazine, who once shared a house with Perry Ferrel, the founder of Jane's Addiction, a band named for a heroin habit, said: "My generation is the first to not have a life style richer than our parents. There's a malaise. This is a very numbing drug. There's something alluring about its decadence."
The same fashionable nihilism fuels much of alternative rock, where heroin, in its most recent incarnation, first appeared. Since 1987, the toll of underground rockers who have died from narcotics use includes Hillel Slovak of the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Will Shatter of Flipper, Charles Ondras of Unsane and Stefanie Sargent of Seven Year Bitch.
In Seattle, heroin found fertile soil in the grunge movement. The death from overdose in 1990 of Andrew Wood, the leader of Mother Love Bone, led his surviving bandmates to form Pearl Jam. Kurt Cobain's love-hate relationship with heroin was well documented, and after his death, Courtney Love, his widow, accused Seattle of being a mecca for the drug.
But it isn't fair to single out Seattle. "I would say just about everybody I hang out with uses," said a bartender at a music club in San Francisco, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. She says her friends are mainly musicians with time on their hands. "Like, 15 of us will be in my apartment for four days, everybody using," she said.
Dealers, like pizza deliverers, bring the drugs to her door. "If they don't hear from you in a couple of days, they call," she said. "They're worried about their business, which is booming as far as I can tell."
From alternative music, heroin crossed over to young Hollywood, those familiar with the scene say. In clubs in and around the Sunset Strip, actors and studio executives in their 20's mix with musicians.
The passion and commitment of grunge appeals to actors made insecure by the seeming superficiality of their success. "They're in a world where they're getting a lot of money, and their self-doubts tell them they're getting rich because of their cheekbones," said Jonathan Roberts, a Los Angeles-based screenwriter. "You become consumed with doubts about your own authenticity and look for authenticity in areas that are, unfortunately, cliches, such as the heroin-using artist. Living closer to the edge somehow makes you more than just a pampered Hollywood pretty boy."
 
The Users
Doing Favors, Looking Terrible
 By all accounts, the death of Mr. Phoenix caused few to question their own hard-drug use. "This stuff is definitely on the upswing," said the dealer who delivered the heroin to the fashion photographer at The Room. He said he had about 20 regular customers, including an actor once nominated for an Academy Award.
Indistinguishable from the other 20-ish patrons in the bar, he said he had a day job as a furniture industry executive and was not moving drugs for the money. He would be out club-hopping anyway. He saw himself performing a service so users did not have to drive to seedy parts of town and buy on the streets. "It's almost like a favor that I do," he said.
But the San Francisco bartender would disagree. She said she first snorted the drug two years ago, not long after moving from Long Island, where she grew up, to Los Angeles, where she took a job in the music industry. "It was incredible you could do so little and get so high," she recalled.
Soon, however, she wasn't getting high enough by snorting or smoking and began to shoot up. Thinking she could shake her habit by changing cities, she moved to San Francisco, but her habit followed. It grew into a $50 a day expense. She wasn't doing it to feel good anymore, just to be able to get to work in the morning.
"It got to the point where I would get an hour off between shifts, run home to get high and come back," she said. "It got to the point where I lost 15 pounds in the last three months. I wasn't looking too good. It showed really bad, especially in the morning. Your eyes are all swollen. You look like a drug addict. People I'm serving on the other side of the bar who don't look so damn good themselves are telling me I look terrible."
She has tried to kick it. "What happens is you just don't sleep," she said. "It's very, very physical. You want to pull your muscles off your bones. You lie there looking at the clock, watching hours and hours go by. You start hitting the walls.
"I'm living in an apartment with no furniture, nothing hanging on the windows. I have a cat who I love to death and I'm not even taking care of. When was last time I changed the litter box? I don't have time. I'm too busy getting high.
"All of a sudden all the money you've saved and worked hard for is gone. I'm 30 years old. It would be nice to have a nice home and things."

HEADLINE: Residents of Dying California Town See Future in a Prison

DATELINE: WEED, Calif.

 BODY:
The residents who remain in this dying lumber town say they have two choices: either leave before the town becomes a glorified truck stop or strive for a future. And the most promising future for them, they say, is prisons.
Officials in Weed, population 3,100, are hoping to make their town at the foot of Mount Shasta the home to a 4,000-inmate maximum security prison. Officials say a new prison would bring jobs and money for the city coffers. 
 The prison's appeal is simple in a town where cutbacks in the lumber industry have left unemployment at 20 percent and residents have to drive eight miles to buy socks, said Neva Barnett, a city councilwoman.
"Prisons don't go out of business," she said.
But not all people in Siskiyou County, where Weed is situated, share the town's aspirations. These opponents say it is hard to imagine a prison at the northern base of the majestic Mount Shasta, an ice-covered volcano jutting 11,000 feet into the air that has enchanted writers, artists and spiritual seekers.
 
A Spiritual Haven
 They argue that a prison would destroy the area's laid-back way of life, attract urban problems and scare off tourists. Some have also voiced concern that a prison might hurt Mount Shasta's reputation as having spiritual powers. In 1987, at a time of "harmonic convergence" when the planets were aligned, 40,000 people gathered at the volcano to pray for "planetary purification."
But scenery does not pay the bills, Weed officials say. A prison would provide 900 construction jobs and 800 to 1,200 full-time jobs on completion, half of which would go to experienced prison employees from outside the area. Corrections officials estimate that the prison would create 400 to 600 service jobs in town.
Jan Williams, an official at California's Department of Corrections, says the state is looking for six new prison sites now to ease crowding at other prisons. She said 17 additional sites might be needed within five years.
Over the past year, Ms. Williams has visited small towns and distributed promotional materials showing beautiful sunsets over prisons and industrious inmates building schools.
It used to be that no one wanted a prison, Ms. Williams said. "Now, we get calls from communities we've never heard of," she said.
Both sides of the prison issue have lobbied the Siskiyou County Board of Supervisors, which will vote on Wednesday on whether to allow Weed to have its prison.
Opponents of the prison, like Richard McFarland, who runs a lumber recycling company in nearby McCloud, say Weed should either die or become more creative about how it survives. Weed has a company town mentality, he said. In its heyday in the 1970's, the International Paper Company owned the hospital and department store. Even Weed's odd name derives from Abner Weed, the company boss.
 
'They Saw Dollars'
 "I can understand wanting to be taken care of by mother company," Mr. McFarland said. "They saw dollar bills and went off panting."
Missi Gillespie, who owns a spiritual book store in the village of Mount Shasta, said Weed residents were short-sighted about the future.
In the past month, Weed residents have held prison rallies and barbecues to raise money to hire a public relations concern to argue their case. A sign in a bakery window reads, "A Depressed Economy Needs Corrections." One prison supporter has spray-painted "Prison -- Yes" in hot pink on a boulder near Mount Shasta.
Ms. Barnett considers herself among those who think Mount Shasta "has an energy field that can create a higher level of consciousness in people."
She added, "I feel there are no better people to give that to than prisoners."

HEADLINE: Racial Slur Causes Political Turmoil for Democrats in Northwest

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SPOKANE, Wash. May 7

 BODY:
A racial slur directed at Asians 18 months ago has turned into political quicksand for this state's Democratic Party, which has been sucked into deeper trouble with every effort to extricate itself from the controversy.
Last Tuesday the party dropped plans to hold this year's state convention in Spokane, where two local party officials have been accused of calling Hong Kong businessmen "chinks." 
 Denny Yasuhara of Spokane, a spokesman for the Japanese-American Citizens League, called the remark "a disgrace to American politics and the Democratic Party."
Last November the league filed a Federal civil rights suit, seeking to dismantle the Spokane County Democratic Party and, backed by black and Hispanic civil rights groups, demanded the resignations of the officials accused of making the slur.
The uproar began in November 1992, when members of the board of the Spokane County Democratic Central Committee were discussing where to hold a fund-raising event for Mike Lowry, the newly elected Governor. One suggested Spokane's landmark Davenport Hotel, which is owned by Hong Kong investors.
Several of the 22 people present said a longtime party worker, Marge Davis, referred to the owners as "those chinks." Others in attendance said the slur was repeated by John Workland, an official of the Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union.
Susan Strauss, a 57-year-old businesswoman from Spokane, says she immediately objected to the term but was rebuked. She told Carl Maxey, a Spokane lawyer long active in civil rights causes, about the incident, and he called on Governor Lowry to intervene.
But the Governor called the slur a local matter, for which Mr. Maxey dubbed him a "cowardly lion," and many people, particularly among Seattle's Asian-Americans, expressed outrage.
Ms. Davis at first admitted making the remark, then denied it. Mr. Workland denied using the term. Both refused demands that they resign from the party board.
 
An Insulting Bow
 Three months later hostilities escalated at a meeting to mend fences. When Chris Marr, a Japanese-American, refused to shake hands with the party's newly elected vice chairwoman, Betty Drumheller, she bowed sarcastically to him and said that had he been white she would have given him a profane gesture with her middle finger.
Ms. Drumheller quickly apologized and later attended racial sensitivity courses sponsored by the party.
Last week, party leaders decided to move the convention to Richland, which is 120 miles away but still east of the mountains that have historically divided this state into distinct political entities and cultures.
The party has traditionally alternated its biennial June convention. In Presidential election years, it is held on the west side of the state; in off-years, it has always been in Spokane, the hub of Eastern Washington.
The Spokane Chamber of Commerce estimated that the loss of the convention, with its 3,000 delegates, party members and guests cost the city economy at least $800,000, and organized labor, a main party constituency, was angered by the transfer because Richland has no hotel that employs union workers.
Richland has no convention center, so the Democrats will gather in the high school auditorium, creating another problem.
The city's claim to fame is the Hanford Nuclear Reservation, which built the atomic bomb dropped on Nagasaki. The city commemorated the event by adopting the name "The Bombers" for its high school athletic teams, and when Japanese-American delegates enter the auditorium they will be greeted by a large mosaic of a mushroom cloud.
"This has just been a political headache I'd like to rid ourselves of," said the weary state party chairman, Charles Rolland.

HEADLINE: January's Cold Hitting Farmers Now

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LIVINGSTON, N.Y., May 6

 BODY:
Russell Bartolotta stood on the edge of his cherry orchard here today, examining the nearly bare limbs of his sweet cherry trees.
Instead of the beautiful white blossoms that usually cover the trees, only tiny green leaves were visible. Mr. Bartolotta pulled one of the buds that would normally have produced a blossom in early May and a cherry in June. It crumpled in his hand. 
 "They're all dead," he said.
The crop fell victim to temperatures that dropped to 25 and 30 degrees below zero in January. That cold spell killed the buds on many of the fruit trees in the Hudson Valley and other parts of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
"There will be no sweet cherries, peaches or nectarines in the whole valley this year," Mr. Bartolotta said.
 
'Not One Peach Bud'
 Mr. Bartolotta, who with his brothers operates Klein's Kill Fruit Farm here in Columbia County, has 600 peach trees covering six acres.
"There's not one peach bud in the whole orchard," he said.
However, the hardier fruits like apples, the major crop in the Hudson Valley, and some varieties of pears and plums, did survive, said Craig Telgheder, the fruit expert of Cornell University's Cooperative Extension Service in Columbia County.
Mr. Telgheder estimated that one-third of the area's apple crop had been lost to the cold, along with 50 percent of the pears, 60 to 70 percent of the plums and prunes, all of the peaches, nectarines and sweet cherries, and all but a handful of tart cherries.
 
Apple Trees in Bloom
 Despite the losses, the apple trees are coming into bloom in the area this weekend, their white blossoms visible to motorists along Routes 9 and 9H.
Like the other farmers, Lee D. Brown, who operates the Cherry Ridge Farm south of Hudson, lost his sweet cherries and peaches. But unlike the others, his tart cherries survived because they grow on a western slope facing the Hudson River, which moderates the cold weather.
The valley's other major early crop, strawberries, which grow close to the ground, was not affected because they were covered and protected by a blanket of snow for most of the winter.
 
Imported Fruit
 For consumers who frequent farm stands and greenmarkets, the crop disaster will mean little locally grown fruit early in the season. However, supermarket customers will still be able to purchase sweet cherries, shipped in from Washington, the leading cherry state in the nation, and peaches from Georgia, South Carolina and southern New Jersey.
For New York fruit growers, though, it will mean a substantial economic loss, mainly of sales at farm stands and pick-it-yourself orchards where the best sellers are sweet cherries in June and peaches in July, before the apple harvest begins.
Mr. Bartolotta estimated that he would lose $60,000 in sales at his farm stand. At LoveApple Farm in Claverack, which specializes in peaches, Chris Loken, its operator, said receipts at his farm stand would drop about $200,000.
Mr. Loken has begun to replace some of the older peach trees damaged by the frost. He has put in 300 to 400 new trees, he said, but they will not produce fruit for several years. He said he plans to open his farm stand as usual in June, importing some fruit for regular customers.
"At best, it's going to be a break-even season, but it's important to keep open to retain your customers," he said.
The crop damage from the cold and snow was so severe throughout New York State that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo appealed to Washington to designate eight counties -- Broome, Columbia, Oneida, Orange, Oswego, Suffolk, Ulster and Wayne -- as disaster areas. If so designated, farmers in those counties would be eligible for low-interest Federal loans.
 
All Over the Northeast
 The fruit growers reported that the damage to trees from the cold weather extended from Connecticut through New York, northern New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Ohio and southern Michigan.
In Connecticut, John Lyman Jr. of the Lyman Orchards in Middlefield reported damage in the northeastern and northwestern parts of the state. His own farm in central Connecticut came through with "a reasonably strong bloom," he said.
In New Jersey, too, there was a geographic dividing line between damage and a good crop -- an east-west line roughly parallel to Interstate 78, said Skeeter Kielblock, operator of the Hillview Farm in Meyersville, near the line.
"We have about 30 to 40 percent of a crop," he said.
But the picture was different farther south. "In northern New Jersey we had some substantial damage, but in the south, where most of the peaches are grown, the bloom looks pretty good," said Robert Battaglia of the State Agricultural Statistics Service in Trenton.
In the Hudson Valley, the farmers, inured to blows from the weather, took their losses philosophically. "It's not going to be a bumper year," Mr. Loken said, with a grin.

The trees, like many in the Hudson Valley, are victims of the frigid weather in January. (Dan Cronin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Overcrowded Vietnam Is Said to Face Catastrophe

SERIES: Vietnam Revisited: A periodic report.

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE, Special to The New York Times; The writer of this article covered Vietnam during the war years, successively for The Associated Press, ABC News and The New York Times. Now a senior science writer for The Times, he was the paper's last bureau chief in Saigon when the city fell in 1975. He spent April in Vietnam.

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam

 BODY:
Their streets are blocked by peddlers, beggars and parked motorbikes, their houses are overflowing with young children and visiting relatives, and even after death the urns containing their ashes must compete for space on the crowded shelves of Buddhist pagodas.
Vietnam is bursting at the seams with people, and unless the nation can change its demographic, social and economic trends, the Vietnamese will face a catastrophe, many experts believe. 
 As the population booms, the Communist Government seems to be floundering in its efforts to balance the demands of a free-market economy against the state supervision and support needed to maintain national social and economic cohesion.
Liberalized Government economic policy has attracted foreign investment and allowed shopkeepers to fill their stores with imported television sets and motorbikes. But predatory packs of thieves roam Ho Chi Minh City -- which is still called Saigon, except in official usage -- unchecked by police forces that are paid so little that the officers must extort bribes to feed their families.
Public health, education, road-building and other nation-building pursuits have been starved of money and official support. The Government has moved at glacial speed to meet a growing need for new laws on taxation, trade, banking, traffic and countless other activities.
Many Vietnamese experts say that a lack of managerial skill is the country's most serious shortcoming and that because of the decline in the country's education system, new managers are scarcer than ever. Because improvement of the education system depends partly on recruiting effective new managers, the country is locked in a vicious cycle, some say.
Since 1975, when the "American War" came to an end, Vietnam's population has increased by more than 60 percent. This impoverished land, which is only about the size of New Mexico, now has more than 72 million people, making it the 12th most populous country on earth. Demographers predict that by 2025 the population will reach 168 million, a staggering number considering the limited space and resources available.
Hanoi has mounted a campaign to reduce the birth rate, and most state and recently privatized businesses now threaten to fire any worker who has more than two children. Billboards that graphically depict the use of condoms, intrauterine devices and vasectomies adorn intersections in cities and towns.
But in a country where two-thirds of the population is still agricultural, such advertising has limited effect. "We city dwellers don't need to be told to have only two children," a shopkeeper said. "Most of us already use birth control."
Throughout Asia, farmers traditionally have large families to share the labor of growing and harvesting rice, and to make up for high infant mortality and short life expectancy. Vietnamese farmers, by all accounts, have largely ignored the official injunction against large families.
And many farmers have recently taken to moonlighting in the towns and cities to earn money for Japanese motorbikes and electronic gadgets. Between crops, many farmers migrate to towns to take temporary jobs as bicycle-taxi drivers or manual laborers, further swelling city populations.
 
Teeming City Lacks Many Public Services
 The population of Saigon in 1975 was about 2.5 million, but today this largest city in Vietnam has 4.5 million permanent residents and another half million temporary residents, most of them migrant farmers.
During nearly two decades of privation under Communism, many Vietnamese accumulated savings they are now spending on imported motorbikes, televisions, video recorders, boom boxes, refrigerators and other luxuries from the industrial world. Few buy automobiles, for which the import duty is 170 percent, but most Vietnamese families own at least one motorbike, costing around $2,100.
Although Vietnam's people have begun to acquire some of the products associated with prosperity, the Government remains too poor to sustain public services.
Despite the policy of doi moi -- renewal -- introduced in 1986 and the rapid recent transition from state socialism to a chaotic market economy, the Hanoi Government has yet to learn how to collect the taxes it needs to pay for roads, railways, clean water, health care, industrial research and an honest police force.
Officials acknowledge that Government salaries are so low (a police officer is paid about $16 a month and a teacher makes about $25) that graft and corruption are far more widespread than they were under the notoriously corrupt Saigon Government up to 1975.
 
Medical Care And Schools Scarce
 Medical care in many parts of the country is virtually nonexistent, even though some 300 doctors are currently unemployed.
Dr. Do Hong Ngoc, director of health information and education for Ho Chi Minh City, said about 300 doctors graduate from medical schools in southern Vietnam each year, but to work they must spend their first three years as Government employees, paid $25 a month. If a young doctor can survive for three years on such a salary, he or she is then permitted to go into private practice and make a decent living.
"Starting doctors can make much more money as traders and business people, so many of them abandon their medical careers," Dr. Ngoc said. "Young people look upon our generation of doctors and scientists as poor people, not to be emulated."
The same problems plague public education.
The Vietnam News Service, a Government agency, recently reported that in the mountainous central province of Gia Lai, 203 hamlets are without schools. Nationwide, a report by the Ministry of Education and Training estimated that about two million Vietnamese between the ages of 15 and 35 were unable to read or write, a marked decline in the literacy rate from what it was in 1975.
American visitors who knew Vietnam before the Communist victory in 1975 are startled these days to see the shoulders of most of the roads in southern Vietnam covered by golden kernels of rice drying in the sun. The new drying system is a symbol of both the promise and the potential catastrophe facing the desperately overcrowded country.
 
Rice Crop Booming; So Are Traffic Jams
 The Communist Government abandoned collectivized farming in 1988;, since then, land has been distributed by the state to small farmers under 20-year renewable leases. Rice production has boomed as a result, and once again Vietnam is a major exporter of rice, which helps to pay for the economic recovery.
But there is a debit side to this boom.
Before the 1975 "liberation," most privately owned farms were relatively large, but today the average farmer owns only a backyard garden or at most a few acres -- too little to waste on sun-drying rice. The rice, nevertheless, must be dried, so farmers have taken to spreading out their grain along asphalt-paved road shoulders. Foreign importers of Vietnamese rice increasingly complain that it contains bits of asphalt, debris from the wheels of trucks and motorbikes, and the droppings of birds, dogs and farm animals.
The population boom and the consequent crowding and elbowing touches every facet of life.
Townspeople laugh ruefully at their monumental motorbike traffic jams, among the worst in the world. But the casualty rate is no laughing matter.
During the first three months of this year there were 396 serious accidents in Saigon alone, causing 133 deaths, injury to 434 people and heavy damage to 498 vehicles. Stoplights are few and far between, and even when they work, many people simply ignore them. The hardy pedestrian bent on crossing a street customarily half closes his eyes, smiles benignly and walks into the thick of the beeping, yelling, roaring maelstrom.
The pedestrian usually survives, but drivers sometimes come to grief. There is no law requiring motorbike users or bicyclists to wear helmets, and no seat-belt law for car drivers. Owners of most motorbikes, those with engines rated at 50 cubic centimeters or less, do not need drivers' licenses, and many bikers are downright reckless.
The police often stop them -- they stop even the most law-abiding drivers several times a week -- but for a bribe of a dollar or two, a driver is sped on his or her way without undue inconvenience.
 
Gap Between Rich And Poor Widening
 The Government has given top priority to stimulating development by creating a market economy and by attracting extensive foreign investment and technical help. But this has created huge problems that are worsened by the population explosion.
One problem cited by Deputy Foreign Minister Le Mai is the widening gap between rich and poor, a direct affront to the ideals of socialism.
There are painfully apparent differences between the standards of living of relatively wealthy entrepreneurs and the street people who sell lottery tickets, postcards and stolen watches.
Huge families that live in the tropical squalor of crumbling brick-and-stucco buildings have almost nothing in common with the brokers and business people who are making fortunes by arranging deals between newly privatized Vietnamese enterprises and foreign companies.
There is also a large and potentially dangerous economic gulf between northern and southern Vietnam, which in many ways remain separate countries despite the postwar unification. Foreign investors still feel more comfortable dealing with enterprises in the former South Vietnam than they do in the north, a fact reflected by the substantially larger investments being made in and around Saigon.
Many Saigonese believe that within sharply defined limits, Hanoi has decided to leave southern Vietnam to its own devices, provided that the southern part of the country continues to bring in the trade and investment essential to national development. Many Vietnamese say they feel more free in the south than in the north.
 
Foreign Criticism Not Appreciated
 But despite its zeal to join the developed, industrialized world, Vietnam is unwilling to accommodate pleas from the United States and other Western countries for greater toleration of Government critics.
"Human rights involve national perspective," Mr. Mai said in an interview. "The United States may be troubled, for example, by China's insistence on limiting families to two children. For their part, the Chinese may regard widespread gun ownership in the United States as a threat to human rights.
"As for Vietnam, we fully support human rights, but we oppose initiatives by outside nations to interfere in our internal affairs."
In fact, many foreign businessmen argue that Vietnam needs tougher legal and economic restraints, and that liberalization of human rights policies is not one of the country's immediate priorities.
"This country is out of control and just growing like Topsy," said an American trader, who spoke on condition that he not be identified. "There's no comprehensive system of law covering investment, taxes, mortgages, bankruptcy, insurance or the other cornerstones of a free-market economy. Most of all, this country needs law. And it needs to create the means of enforcing laws."
The fines imposed for civil infractions are tiny. The B.G.I. Tien Giang Company, a French-Vietnamese joint venture that makes beverages, was recently convicted of adulterating one of its products with saccharine -- a sweetener that is illegal in Vietnam. The company was fined the equivalent of about $100, a penalty several American businessmen called woefully inadequate.
"You can get away with almost anything in Vietnam if you have a few dollars to pay a tiny fine or pay someone off," an American said. "That's got to stop if this country wants to make real progress."
Most of all, Vietnamese leaders agree, there are too many Vietnamese, and a brake must be applied to the birth rate, which threatens to double the population in 28 years.
"We'll never apply the draconian measures used in China to curb population growth," said Nguyen Xuan Oanh, an economist and investment consultant. "But we've got to do something before it's too late."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Calls Budget Deal Too Costly

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 7

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo doused a tentative budget agreement between legislative leaders with icy water today, saying it would result in spending at least $150 million more than the state could afford this year and would leave a $500 million budget gap next year.
But legislative aides said their budget package would spend little more than Mr. Cuomo and legislative leaders had agreed to allocate in a pact reached on April 1. 
 They speculated that the Governor's hostile reaction may have been provoked by the absence of several Cuomo initiatives from their plan, like construction of a special high school in Albany for exceptional math and science students. And they questioned why Mr. Cuomo was voicing criticism now when he has left much of the negotiating to the legislative leaders in recent weeks.
Mr. Cuomo said in a telephone interview from the Executive Mansion that he would veto such a budget if it were sent to him. But by angrily rejecting the deal today, he virtually insured that Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Democrat, and the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican, would have to resume negotiations.
 
Time, Too, Is Money
 The budget is five weeks late, and fiscal planning by local governments and nonprofit agencies has already been disrupted by delays in state payments. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, for instance, will have to present his first budget on Tuesday without knowing exactly how much money New York City can expect from the state.
In addition to counting on hundreds of millions of dollars in new state aid, Mr. Giuliani has decided on bond refinancing and other measures to help plug a budget deficit, mayoral aides said. [Page 31.]
The Governor, who has remained relatively even-tempered throughout this year's protracted budget fight, made it clear today that he had lost his patience. In addition to deriding the Legislature's spending plans, which he called irresponsible, he expressed outrage that legislative aides leaked details of the agreement to reporters on Friday before discussing them with him.
"They did something that was cheap, I think, but is customary," Mr. Cuomo said. "Having said they wouldn't do so, they leaked everything.
"What has happened here is they told one side of the story. The public has to know there is another side of the story, not only that the spending is excessive, and it is, but that maybe you shouldn't make the spending at all."
John E. McArdle, a spokesman for Mr. Marino, said Mr. Cuomo was "making arguments that are totally baseless." He said, "Everything we've proposed is affordable."
Mr. Cuomo accused the legislative leaders of trying to accommodate constituents in an election year by spending beyond the state's capacity. He was particularly disturbed by a bailout for hospitals that would cost the state $18 million this year, and by a plan to carry out business tax cuts faster than he recommended. Cuomo aides said that the Legislature would also give more money to schools and to local governments than they had agreed to spend five weeks ago.
"All I know is that with a billion dollars more, they couldn't satisfy themselves in an election year," Mr. Cuomo said. "I am not going to, in what may be the final stage of my career, be selling out for votes. You can't do it. You have to pay for tax cuts."
But legislative aides charged today that Mr. Cuomo's response was also motivated by election-year politics. By using the lawmakers as a foil, they said, he was seeking to position himself as a fiscal conservative in a defensive battle against what he depicted as a spendthrift Legislature.
In seeking a fourth four-year term with dismal approval ratings, the Democratic Governor is considered highly vulnerable to Republican attacks on his stewardship of the state budget and the economy.
"I think he's looking to make himself a political victor in the context of a late budget," said one Assembly aide, who insisted on anonymity. "I really think this is Mario Cuomo the candidate and not Mario Cuomo the Governor speaking."
 
Smaller Items on the Table
 The agreement reached by Mr. Silver and Mr. Marino late this week covered major budget issues like tax cuts, aid to schools and fiscal relief for local governments. But the leaders were still negotiating smaller items, like how to expand the state's program of fingerprinting welfare recipients and whether to expand a state-subsidized health insurance program for poor children.
On Friday evening, they sent Mr. Cuomo's budget aides a synopsis of their accomplishments. It included details of a menu of tax cuts, many of which would take effect faster than Mr. Cuomo had recommended.
For instance, the legislative plan would phase out the 15 percent surcharge on the corporate income tax over three years, rather than the four years Mr. Cuomo proposed. It would also create an earned-income tax credit on the personal income tax that would be more generous than the one proposed by Mr. Cuomo.
The Governor said today that eliminating the corporate tax surcharge so quickly would leave the state with a $500 million budget gap next year. He said he would support such an acceleration only if it were offset by additional cuts in spending.
"If you want to speed it up, that's fine, but you have to pay for it," he said. "You'd need 15 percent growth in the economy to make it go away, and we're projecting 3. It's just irresponsible."
Mr. Cuomo also criticized the Legislature's plan to drive $145 million to hospitals, $18 million of it in state Medicaid spending, by changing the state's hospital reimbursement formula. Although the Legislature and the Governor increased hospital reimbursement rates late last year, hospital officials contend that their costs have grown because they are handling more complicated procedures than in the past.

HEADLINE: Haim Bar-Lev Dies; Israeli General, 69

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TEL AVIV, May 7

 BODY:
Haim Bar-Lev, an Israeli war hero and diplomat for whom a defensive line at the Suez Canal was named, died in a Tel Aviv hospital today, a hospital spokeswoman said. He was 69.
The hospital spokeswoman said the cause was apparently heart failure. 
 Mr. Bar-Lev, whose last post was as Israel's Ambassador in Russia, fought in Israel's independence war in 1948 and was deputy chief of staff to Yitzhak Rabin, now the Prime Minister, in the 1967 Middle East war.
He was an army general and the Chief of Staff of the army from 1968 to 1971, and built a line of fortified defense bunkers along the Sinai side of the Suez Canal that became known as the Bar-Lev line.
He entered politics in 1972 but rejoined the army during the 1973 Middle East war.
Before being appointed Ambassador to Russia in 1992, Mr. Bar-Lev had served as a Labor Party Member of Parliament, including Cabinet posts as Minister of Police as well as Minister of Trade and Industry and as acting Finance Minister. In the last two positions he worked to gain increased foreign investment in Israel. He became secretary general of the Israeli Labor Party in 1978.
Mr. Bar-Lev was admitted to hospital Tuesday after returning from Moscow complaining of general weakness. Medical tests showed he suffered from muscular dystrophy, the hospital said.
Mr. Bar-Lev was born in Austria and immigrated to Israel from Yugoslavia in 1939. After his military service, he graduated from Columbia University in New York and became an economist.
He is survived by his wife, Tamar, a son and a daughter.
