HEADLINE: WORLD CUP '94;
Romania's Other Revolution

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, May 5

 BODY:
At the final match of the Romania Cup soccer tournament last weekend, an antiquated television camera roamed the sideline like some hulking metal insect, tattered sofa cushions lined metal benches in the press box, advertising placards promised soft drinks from the West while vendors hawked only the seeds of sunflowers and pumpkins, and police ringed the field wearing riot helmets and carrying batons.
When the match was over and a team from Transylvania, Gloria Bistrita, had won a surprising 1-0 victory over the university-affiliated Atomic Lions from Craiova, the police charged the disconsolate Craiova fans, clubbing them as they reached for jerseys being tossed over a fence, and later skirmishing with the supporters outside of the stadium. 
 Apparently, the Craiova fans had been taunting the police during the match, witnesses said. But if suspicion of authority hasn't lessened since the 1989 revolution that resulted in the overthrow and execution of the dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, Romanian soccer has changed dramatically as the national team prepares for World Cup '94 next month in the United States.
Notable for its absence from this final match was the traditional power Steaua Bucharest, the once indomitable army team formerly run by Ceausescu's son Valetin through shrewdness, threats and intimidation.
Missing, too, from this match were any of Romania's top players. Since the revolution, all but one of its stars have emigrated to play the regular season in Western Europe, escaping the economic paucity of Europe's poorest country other than Albania, where reform has been slow and uncertain under the government of President Ion Iliescu.
 
Training and Rewards
 Playing in such places as Italy and Spain and the Netherlands, Romania's stars have learned the necessity of rigorous training and the possibility of financial reward, a combination that makes the Romanians among the favorites to advance to the second round of the World Cup from a four-team group that includes the United States, Colombia and Switzerland.
The Romanians will travel to the United States to play soccer and pass around a symbolic tin cup, hoping that athletic success will attract American investment and soften the grave images that many Americans have of Romania -- the legacy of Communism, revolution, poverty and orphanages with children suffering from physical handicaps and AIDS.
The United States has restored most-favored-nation trading status to Romania, which offers a market of 23 million people, second only to Poland among the former Soviet satellites. Still, many Western analysts remain unconvinced about the commitment to economic and democratic reform.
Romania has avoided shock therapy, favoring instead a policy of economic gradualism; only 300 of 6,000 state-run companies have been privatized since free elections were held in 1992. It is a familiar lament in Bucharest that under the Communists there was money but no food and now there is food but no money. Enter the Romanian soccer team as ambassadors and spin doctors.
"If Romania does well in football, it will have an impact economically, politically and culturally," said Anghel Iordanescu, the coach of the national team. "Soccer, sport, is a better way than politics for diplomacy. Nadia Comaneci made more for the image of our country than Ceausescu."
 
30 Cents and a Dream
 On the wide, dusty boulevards of this fatigued capital, World Cup lottery tickets can be bought at small tables among the outdoor bazaars that offer books, breads, bananas, audio cassettes and other products of entry-level capitalism. For 30 cents, a buyer of a lottery ticket can win a trip to the United States to watch the World Cup, and if the recent past is any indication, perhaps to start a new life.
During the qualifying for the 24-team World Cup finals, Romanian fans developed a desperate habit of following the national team to a game in another country and applying for asylum, seeking to escape from government inertia, poverty and skyrocketing prices. In October 1992, about 300 fans followed the Romanian team to Belgium, and half of them did not return, said Radu Timofte, press officer for the Romanian Soccer Federation. A month later, 90 fans followed the team to Cyprus and 30 remained behind, Timofte said.
Some Romanians believe the United States has been overly cautious in granting visas for the World Cup. Gheorghe Fodoreanu, the official travel agent for the Romanian soccer federation, said that 3,400 tickets had been tentatively sold to Romanians for three first-round matches, but added he didn't know how many of the ticket-buyers would be able to obtain visas. The United States Embassy here denied that any special restrictions were being placed on Romanians.
Spectators are not the only ones leaving. An estimated 150 to 200 of Romania's top players now play professionally in other countries, where they receive higher-paying contracts. Gheorghe Hagi, a tempestuous midfielder who is Romania's biggest star, plays for Brescia in Italy. Florin Raducioiu is a striker for Italian champion AC Milan. While such top-flight international competition certainly benefits Romanian's national team, there is a concern that the domestic league is being stripped of its best young players. Many domestic teams, however, are struggling to survive without state support, and see little choice but to accept transfer fees for players who wish to take their careers elsewhere.
The years immediately following the revolution were particularly chaotic, soccer officials and journalists said. One team, Inter Sibiu, found itself without transportation, so it traded one of its players, Alexander Szenes, to a Hungarian club in 1991 in exchange for a bus, said Timofte. Another team, F. C. Bittor, traded a player to a Hungarian club for 10,000 bottles of soft drinks, Timofte said, and then resold the soda pop for cash in order to buy other players. A third Romanian team, Olimpia Satu Mare, venturing into the import-export business, traded a player to a Hungarian club for a large quantity of powder used for ice cream, Timofte said.
 
The Professional Route
 To contain this drain of talent, the Romanian league has gone professional, and done something that other businesses have been reluctant to do: privatize. Eight of the 18 teams are now assisted or owned by wealthy businessmen or a consortium of businesses, soccer officials said. One businessman, Gheorghe Paunescu, has promised each of the national team players a Mercedes for qualifying for the 1994 World Cup finals, said the striker Ilie Dumitrescu.
"We know he has had some problems, but we believe he will keep his promise," Dumitrescu said.
But money, or the lack of it, continues to be a problem. Four or five of the 18 teams in the top domestic league are in danger of folding, Timofte said. Further, a general corruption exists -- rigged matches, unscrupulous referees -- journalists, Dumitrescu and some soccer officials said. There is loose talk of organized crime controlling the domestic league, but facts are elusive and the press writes about the problem obliquely.
"It is hard to prove, but we all know the names," said Gheorghe Stanta, an influential journalist who is the editor of two magazines.
"In my opinion, it is the biggest problem of our soccer," Dumitrescu said of corruption. "The players suffer, and the first consequence is for the national team. If the domestic championship was healthy, the national team would be much better. In these conditions, the coach of the national team doesn't always know who is an actor and who is a player."
Yes, the problem exists, said Iordanescu, the coach, who has been applauded by journalists for fighting corruption. "But," he added, "show me where it doesn't."
True, corruption scandals have beset such soccer powers as France, Brazil and Italy. But it is difficult to imagine more spectacular abuses than those that occurred during the Ceausescu regime. Two stories, in particular, are told in soccer circles.
The club F.C. Olt from Ceausescu's hometown of Scornicesti once needed a victory by 17 goals to advance from Romania's third division to the second division. The team won, 18-0, averaging a goal every five minutes.
"This was Ceausescu's team; everyone knew what would happen," said Filip Romulus, a journalist with Football Plus, a soccer magazine. "If they needed 30 goals, they would have scored 30."
The second story involves a 1988 match between Steaua Bucharest, the army team controlled by Ceausescu's son Valentin and Dynamo, the team sponsored by the Securitate, Ceausescu's secret police. Late in the match, with the score tied at 1-1, Steaua scored, but the goal was disallowed because of a violation of the offsides rule.
When the referee would not relent, Valentin Ceausescu pulled his Steaua team off the field. Thinking they had won by forfeit, the Dynamo players picked up the cup trophy and went home. The next day, though, Steaua was mysteriously -- or not so mysteriously -- awarded the disputed goal and declared a 2-1 winner.
"They couldn't admit to losing," Mircea Lucescu, who coached Dynamo in that game and now coaches the Italian club Brescia, said of the Ceausescus. "They were afraid that losing a soccer match would be interpreted as political defeat."
When Steaua needed Hagi, Romania's top player, for an important European Cup match in 1987, he was taken from his club team on loan and never given back, Lucescu and journalists said. When midfielder Gheorghe Popescu declined to move from his Craiova team to Steaua, he was drafted into the army so that he was forced to play, at least temporarily, for Valentin Ceausescu's team.
 
Privileges for Players
 Even Valentin's enemies, though, concede that he knew how to build a soccer power. He offered players privileges that others were denied -- an apartment, a car, a chance to bring home video and audio equipment from international matches. He also oversaw vigorous training, and in 1986 Steaua Bucharest became the first Eastern bloc team ever to win the coveted European Champions Cup tournament.
Romania has qualified for five previous World Cup finals -- 1930, 1934, 1938, 1970 and 1990. The current team struggled during qualifying for the 1994 finals, though, and Coach Mircea Sandu was fired last June and replaced by Iordanescu, the longtime coach of Steaua Bucharest.
Romania won its final three games, qualifying for a trip to the United States with a 2-1 victory over Wales at Cardiff on Nov. 17, only to be sequestered at the Cardiff airport for four hours before being allowed to go to Bucharest.
An elderly man had been killed by a flare launched from the bleachers at the match, and the Romanian players, coaches, officials and fans were questioned as potential witnesses. Eventually, two Welshmen were arrested and charged in the killing.
Even though the Romanian team was four hours late arriving, 2,000 to 3,000 fans waited at the Bucharest airport in a numbing November cold that froze some of the champagne bottles kept on hand for the celebration, Timofte said.
"There are many problems economically in Romania, but for a little while the people can forget their difficulties and come back to soccer," Iordanescu said. "It's like a medicine."

HEADLINE: Trade Won't Guarantee Human Rights

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his plea that the Clinton Administration retain China's most-favored-nation status ("In China, Let Free Markets Aid Liberty," Viewpoints, April 24), Stephen Robert's expectations for democracy in China are much too high. While maintaining free trade is the proper approach in helping improve China's political situation, Mr. Robert's assumption that "economic freedom is rapidly thrusting China toward political freedom that will be . . . ingrained in the fabric of Chinese society" is dangerous. 
 Too many Americans are anxious to believe that political freedom based on the Western concept of human rights can be easily transported to other cultures once certain conditions are met. Mr. Robert assures us that "once a free market system is established, it is but a short step to political democracy." But he ignores one significant fact: before Communist rule, China existed for centuries as a free market economy without political freedom. Why would one suppose that individual freedom and rights would suddenly take hold in a nation where the people have been guided by collectivist Confucian principles for hundreds of years?
 
JAY GANGI
Westport, Conn., April 24
 
The writer, a marketing consultant, has lived in China and Taiwan.

HEADLINE: Badly Needed Intelligence

 BODY:
Not since the 1970's have so many Americans across the political spectrum asked so many anxious questions about what is known in Washington as "the intelligence community." Startling disclosures of Central Intelligence Agency involvement in assassination plots led in 1975 to inquiries by the Church and Pike committees, and by President Ford's Rockefeller Commission. One salutary result was the adoption of a new executive order against the dirtiest of tricks: plotting to kill a foreign leader. And the Senate and House for the first time attempted serious oversight of clandestine agencies.
 The time seems right, a generation later, for comparable full-scale inquiries into the role and performance of all U.S. intelligence services. At the least Americans deserve to know why security procedures failed to expose Aldrich H. Ames, a free-spending C.I.A. official who spied for Moscow from 1985 until his arrest in February. 
 But more broadly, it is the quality and predictive power of U.S. intelligence that calls out for scrutiny. The C.I.A., along with the Presidents it is supposed to inform, has been repeatedly caught unprepared: by the Shah's fall in Iran, by Saddam Hussein's seizure of Kuwait and, most dramatically, by the collapse of the Soviet Union.
 The most obvious question, given this track record, is why America still needs so many overlapping agencies -- C.I.A., National Security Agency and various Defense and State Department intelligence units -- in a world without a serious global adversary. Nobody can sanely doubt the continued need for intelligence gathering when so many nations have nuclear appetites and nuclear capacities. So long as terrorism is a threat, and ethnic wars tear nations apart, intelligence will be a vital element of national security.
 But do we still need an enormous secret bureaucracy, whose budget is still not divulged, designed to cope with a now-defunct enemy? Many Americans scarcely realize that the main sources of intelligence are not spies but satellite surveillance, intercepted signals and raw data harvested from open sources or routine reports filed by attaches in hundreds of embassies and consulates. These are the meat and potatoes of intelligence, but spy games, which commonly yield meager results at inordinate costs, grab the headlines.
 Americans may rightly wonder what interests are served by spending billions to penetrate foreign intelligence services, an activity that Washington condemns as reprehensible when other governments do the same unto us. Spy wars are a sideshow, of passionate interest to its actors but of only the most marginal significance for national policy.
 The Clinton Administration has so far been preoccupied with damage control on the Ames case. To head off legislation that would give the Federal Bureau of Investigation paramount responsibility for counterintelligence, President Clinton has signed an executive order naming his national security adviser, Anthony Lake, as head of a new board to oversee the detection of spies in the United States. But at best, this only closes a barn door. It fails altogether to deal with what's in the barn.
 Critics of the C.I.A. like Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York contend that the agency routinely inflated the economic and military strength of the old Soviet bloc while grossly underestimating the threat posed by Islamic fundamentalism. An authoritative Congressional inquiry, drawing on testimony of all current and former intelligence chiefs, would honor Mr. Clinton's promise of a more open government. More importantly, it would bring under democratic scrutiny a hidden bureaucracy whose task in peacetime needs vigorous and cost-conscious review.

HEADLINE: Mr. Gingrich's False Alarm on Trade

 BODY:
The minority whip, Newt Gingrich, has threatened to vote against the trade agreement that the U.S. and over 100 partners signed last month after seven brutal years of negotiation. That is a bizarre turnabout for a man who almost single-handedly bailed out the Clinton Presidency by rounding up Republican votes for a similar accord -- the North American Free Trade Agreement -- over the opposition of House Democrats. Bizarre -- and wrong.
 Mr. Gingrich says he is for world trade but against world government. He fears that the World Trade Organization, the oversight body provided for in the new agreement, would subject Americans to rules imposed by third world countries. But the W.T.O. would be more pussycat than tiger -- and would protect U.S. interests better than the existing General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, which has governed trade for almost 50 years. 
 The W.T.O.'s primary function will be to resolve disputes. And the procedures it will follow are those the U.S. fought hard to win. In a typical dispute, country A accuses country B of violating a trade rule. An international panel is then appointed to review the charges and render a decision. Under GATT rules the panel's decision can be blocked by any country -- putting country B in the ridiculous position of vetoing its own "conviction." Congress has rightly ridiculed the GATT for its spineless procedures.
 The W.T.O. would turn these dispute procedures around 180 degrees. Panel decisions would prevail unless all parties to the W.T.O. unanimously decided to set them aside. The sharpened ability to resolve disputes would overwhelmingly help the U.S. because it brings more complaints under the GATT than any other country.
 There will be times when dispute panels will rule against the U.S. But even in these cases the W.T.O. bares no fangs: it cannot force Congress to change trade laws. If the U.S. refuses to change an offensive practice, the W.T.O. can authorize the plaintiff to retaliate -- say, by raising tariffs on goods it imports from the U.S. Yet the U.S. would have little to fear; few countries would engage in masochistic tit-for-tat retaliation with the U.S.
 There are other ways the W.T.O. would benefit the U.S. Compared to the GATT, the W.T.O. would require a larger majority to amend or adopt trade rules -- better insulating the U.S. from Mr. Gingrich's third world tyranny. The W.T.O, furthermore, would give the U.S. more freedom to decide which of an offending country's exports to shut out; under the GATT, the U.S. can be restricted to punishing inconsequential industries.
 The new trade agreement would dramatically lower tariffs and bring agriculture, services and intellectual property -- important export sectors for the U.S. -- under fair-trade rules. The W.T.O. may sound scary. But it, and the trade agreement it oversees, will greatly benefit all consumers.

HEADLINE: Even Now, Nixon Stirs Up Friend and Foe Alike;
Tempered by Caracas

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Most Americans seeking to understand better the life of Richard M. Nixon, only dimly remember his 1958 good-will tour of South America. As an eyewitness and press attache then at the United States Embassy in Caracas, Venezuela, and after recent research, I wonder: Did this crisis contribute fundamentally to his subsequent style of bold innovation in foreign policy? 
 In 1958, the Vice President had come into prominence as a Communist hunter without much international experience. The tour changed that. He confronted angry students in Montevideo, Uruguay, and Lima, Peru, and made front-page headlines when he arrived in Venezuela.
 There, Communist agitators, skillfully using evidence of official United States support for the recently ousted military dictator, found willing followers, especially among the young. We Embassy officers could only watch as infuriated mobs spat upon the Nixons; others attacked his enclosed limousine with stones, iron rods and fists. At one point we feared they would overturn it and set it afire.
 Later that day, safe at the Ambassador's residence, the shaken but controlled Vice President told a press conference: "The Communists were able to gain great support from students in this country because of what has happened over the last 10 years. What we are seeing is the terrible legacy of the dictatorship."
 He returned to Washington and a hero's welcome, with President Eisenhower and 80,000 spectators cheering his statesmanlike courage. He promulgated a seven-point program to encourage democracy and economic improvement in Latin America, presaging John F. Kennedy's Alliance for Progress.
 Perhaps Caracas dramatized to him that since local conditions primarily caused anti-American sentiment, international Communism might not really be monolithic. This may have influenced his Presidential decisions to deal directly with Communist leaders in China and the Soviet Union.
 
ROBERT AMERSON
Brewster, Mass., April 25, 1994

HEADLINE: The Man Who Knows Everything;
Murray Gell-Mann

BYLINE: By David Berreby; David Berreby has written for Discover, The Sciences and other publications.

 BODY:
SIX WRITHING LEGS GLINT LIKE copper in the strong New Mexico sun. Murray Gell-Mann, discoverer of the quark, winner of the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1969, author of a new book that attempts to explain, oh, pretty much everything, has caught an insect. He holds it delicately by its folded wings as he clambers down from the immense window where he found it crawling.
"Come on, kid," he says. The bug wriggles. Gell-Mann opens a door onto his patio and tosses the creature out among the pinons and junipers that surround his adobe mountain home near Santa Fe. "I like these fine," he says. "I just like them outside." 
 Does Gell-Mann know what kind of insect he's returning to nature? What a silly question. The essence of Murray Gell-Mann is to know.
"They're conenose bugs," he says. "I can't remember the Latin name at the moment. They're harmless, but they're closely related to the kissing bug, which causes Chagas' disease in the tropics. Chagas' disease is a devastating kind of sleeping sickness. It's transmitted when they bite you on the mouth while you're sleeping. Hence the genus is also known as assassin bugs. Anyway, these don't carry the organism, so they're harmless."
By the way, he adds, the white plastic net under his arm isn't really right for capturing bugs. "It's a fishing net." How does he know? He stops in his tracks. A small, stooped man with white hair curling over a pink scalp, he can look like your best friend's amiable grandfather from Brooklyn -- until he encounters a thought he doesn't like. "A butterfly net would be much longer," he says, with a pained scowl and the air of one explaining that the big red light on top means "stop" and the big green one at the bottom means "go."
Even Murray Gell-Mann's credentials -- a director of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, member of the Council on Foreign Relations, adviser to the Pentagon on arms control, collector of prehistoric Southwest American pottery, amateur ornithologist, to name a few -- can't prepare a visitor for the full extent of his erudition. He pronounces "Chagas" as it is heard in Brazil. He has been known to correct the Ukrainian pronunciation of native Ukrainians and disparage the Swahili of Kenyans. His love of language, in fact, is responsible for much of the poetic nomenclature of modern particle physics, including the word "quark" to describe the particles that, in inseparable groups, make up larger subatomic particles like protons and neutrons. Gell-Mann, who made the theoretical case for quarks in the 1960's, decided on the nonsense sound, and when he later found a reference in James Joyce's "Finnegans Wake" for "three quarks for Muster Mark," that settled the matter for good.
As his wife, Marcia Southwick, makes sandwiches at the kitchen counter, Gell-Mann explains that he's on a low-fat diet, so the tuna salad is made without something that sounds like "my own haze" -- "mayonnaise" as pronounced in Paris. At the California Institute of Technology, where Gell-Mann taught from 1955 until last year, his friend, rival, fellow Nobelist and polar opposite, Richard Feynman, would occasionally feign incomprehension when Gell-Mann pronounced, say, "Montreal," in his special fashion. Sometimes, as when Gell-Mann enunciates the name of the anthropologist Clifford Geertz ("Hghayrts -- it's a Dutch name"), you have to think Feynman wasn't always faking it.
GELL-MANN, AN Austrian immigrant's son from New York City, has been doing this kind of thing for nearly all of his 64 years. (His literary agent, John Brockman, likes to say "he has five brains, and each one is smarter than yours.") His is not a know-it-all manner, but a know-it-all philosophy. He combines a mania for the smallest detail with an intellectual ambition whose confidence is strikingly out of sync with an era obsessed with the limitations of knowledge. Even many scientists nowadays do not share Gell-Mann's conviction: that it is indeed possible to know it all, that in principle there is nothing to prevent the future day when sovereign science will be able to explain absolutely everything, in a single coherent picture of how the universe works. That picture will inherently contain a certain amount of randomness and unpredictability, Gell-Mann says, but even then scientists will be able to explain why.
"There's something extremely admirable about that," says Seth Lloyd, a physicist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory and a friend and protege of Gell-Mann's. "I know that's not a very fashionable point of view, but if you're going to be a scientist, particularly a great scientist like Murray, then you have to be confident that the analytical tools you apply to the world are going to work."
Gell-Mann titled his new book, published last month, "The Quark and the Jaguar," to suggest the full width of the intellectual space he wants to span. Though not an autobiography, it is a kind of summa of all his many interests, connecting in a single skein of thought everything from the fundamentals of matter to the need for wildlife conservation and population control, with pauses here and there for marginalia, like reports of fish falling from the skies.
It is, above all, a book about beautiful theories -- triumphs of abstract thought like relativity, electromagnetism and natural selection that made the bewildering universe yield its secrets to human intelligence. Gell-Mann himself is responsible for two of the most important theories in modern particle physics, and in the book he describes what he believes will become the next great idea that will apply to jaguars, economies, human minds and all the other phenomena that particle physics doesn't consider: the theory of complexity.
Complexity theory (Gell-Mann prefers to call it "plectics") is a way of describing why the kissing bug on Gell-Mann's window is more than the sum of its parts. The basic components -- atoms, molecules, cells -- are each simple enough, but as they interact with one another, new properties emerge: the bug, for example, is capable of deciding whether to crawl up or down as Gell-Mann goes after it. The result, in Gell-Mann's parlance, is a "complex adaptive system," a collection of simple parts that interact to form a complex whole capable of learning about and reacting to the outside world.
Complexity theory rests on two ideas. The first is that complexity is not merely a quality to be noted but a quantity that can be measured. (Linguists, Gell-Mann says, might measure the complexity of some language by the length of its grammar.) That makes it possible to talk about levels of complexity and to say with confidence that complex things tend over time to give rise to more complex things.
The second key idea is that complex adaptive systems are everywhere alike. For example, Gell-Mann writes, the process of learning -- testing a model against reality and then modifying it to suit -- occurs on different time scales throughout biology. Migratory birds adapt to their environment over eons of evolution; consequently, the information they carry in their genes includes a kind of map for each bird to follow. The immune system, Gell-Mann writes, "undergoes a process very similar to biological evolution . . . but on a time scale of hours or days instead of millions of years." Where previous generations of scientists might regard that idea as a fruitful analogy, complexity theorists pursue it as possibly literally true -- that there is a way of understanding complexity, using models from mathematics, physics and especially computer science, in which evolution and an immune response would be seen as fundamentally similar. (Complexity theory, it should be noted, is related to chaos theory, which is the study of systems -- the stock market, say, or weather and traffic patterns -- that can be altered in enormous and often unpredictable ways by even the slightest change in input.)
Gell-Mann's personal prestige and network of contacts have had much to do with the current vogue for complexity theory. In 1984, he and several physicists from the nearby Los Alamos National Laboratory founded the North American mecca of complexity research, the Santa Fe Institute. Lodged in a nondescript office complex, the institute is a warren of 35 offices and a few conference rooms, all crammed with computers and books. Some 200 researchers a year from a variety of disciplines walk up and down the stairs and through little courtyards, coalescing to discuss this problem or that in a kind of ongoing, high-intellect show-and-tell of blackboard scribbling and computer simulation. Like other participants, Gell-Mann, who is a trustee of the institute and co-chairman of its science board, wanders about, listening to and buttonholing other researchers. But his is a special role. With his vast knowledge, he is a useful link between disciplines that often use mutually incomprehensible notations and concepts. Admittedly, much of the work remains to be done. "Of course, the real goal is verification," Gell-Mann says. "Predicting things that are then found to be true. We don't have a lot of that to show yet. But we will. You have to be patient. You should give it 20 years."
IT IS ENTIRELY IN CHARACTER that Gell-Mann should be promoting the biggest and most wide-ranging of new ideas in science. Throughout his career, his eye was always on the biggest prize, the most capacious theory. When the physicist and writer Jeremy Bernstein won a National Science Foundation fellowship in 1959, Gell-Mann persuaded him to come to Paris. "Stick with me, kid," Bernstein recalls Gell-Mann saying, "and I will put you on Broadway."
Gell-Mann did indeed reach physics Broadway. The Standard Model of reality that physicists use to guide their theorizing and experiments would not exist were it not for two major contributions by Murray Gell-Mann. As early as the 1950's, he was attempting to find unity in what others saw as a bewildering assortment of unrelated subatomic particles. By 1961, Gell-Mann had circulated a paper around Caltech proposing a unifying scheme in which to class the new particles, often in groups of eight. Gell-Mann dubbed it "the eightfold way" in puckish homage to the Buddhist path to nirvana. The scheme succeeded in classifying a vast array of particles according to underlying properties that were not at all apparent at first, second or even third glance. The eightfold way often has been compared to a 20th-century periodic table in its predictive power. The scheme foretold the existence of a variety of particles that had not yet been detected. As the 1960's progressed, the particles were all discovered, precisely where they were supposed to be. Gell-Mann won the Nobel Prize in 1969.
Attempting to refine the eightfold way, Gell-Mann and his collaborators proposed that some of the fundamental particles of the atom could be understood as made up of even smaller components. These were the quarks, and though the original proposal had to be made more complicated, by the mid-1970's the quark concept, too, had been resoundingly confirmed by discoveries in particle accelerators. Two weeks ago -- on the morning after Gell-Mann's book party -- physicists at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory announced that they had found evidence of the so-called top quark, the last holdout of the six quarks predicted by Gell-Mann.
At the Santa Fe Institute, Gell-Mann's combination of intellectual grandeur and mania for detail is well known. He constantly urges his colleagues to stretch further -- and explain more. "Murray pushes people with a nice abstract model to connect it more to the real world," says L. M. Simmons, the institute's vice president of academic affairs. "Sometimes he presses a little too hard. Sometimes you have to crawl before you can walk. But Murray's point is: Always think about walking."
The Gell-Mann treatment is not always pleasant. Scientists who work in solid-state physics do not appreciate his oft-quoted description of the field as "squalid-state physics." Over dinner and a carefully chosen bottle of wine in a quiet Santa Fe restaurant, Gell-Mann cannot resist a passing reference to "the good Gleick," the scientist brother of James Gleick, author of "Genius," the best-selling biography of Feynman. The book's portrayal of Gell-Mann was not nearly as flattering as he would have liked.
On the other hand, Gell-Mann's praise can be as warm and sunny as his impatience is cold and hard. When he describes a naturalist or a chemist as a "brilliant, wonderful guy," his enthusiasm fills the room.
"He's only rude to people when he thinks they're wrong and that what they're saying obscures the right way of looking at things," Lloyd says. "Which means that the things that make him obnoxious to some people are the same things that make him a great scientist."
In any event, no one has ever claimed that Gell-Mann isn't just as hard on himself. "The Quark and the Jaguar" was agony for him to write, and a considerable pain to live through for his friends and colleagues. After his huge ambition and equally huge advances from publishers around the world were ballyhooed at the 1990 Frankfurt Book Fair, anything much less than a best seller will make the book "the 'Heaven's Gate' of popular-science publishing," says an acquaintance. (A brief review in The New York Times Book Review last Sunday labeled his musings "unremarkable.") Gell-Mann's absorption in "The Quark and the Jaguar" reduced his mental presence at the Santa Fe Institute and at Los Alamos. Some friends say it even had something to do with the mild heart attack he suffered late in 1992.
Uneasy with any work that isn't world-class perfect, Gell-Mann for years found writing excruciating, and the book was no exception. His agent thought a ghost writer would help. Gell-Mann plowed through three. One, who had helped produce the 32-page proposal that sold the book, bowed out after that point and wrote his own book ("Complexity," by Roger Lewin); the next one simply couldn't bear the flaws Gell-Mann would find in everything he wrote and dropped out; a third wisely decided his three-month job was only to edit and encourage as Gell-Mann agonized over his own hen-scratchings. The chapters Gell-Mann finally delivered were written by no one but himself.
By then, having fallen far behind schedule, Gell-Mann was dropped by his first publisher; he found a second one, but nearly exhausted its patience with his last-minute corrections. "I had people calling me up every day, threatening me," Gell-Mann says. "It took years off my life."
"Ours, too," says a source at W. H. Freeman & Company who was close to the production process. "Let's just say Freeman's been pretty flexible. In fact, let's say no other author has pushed us this far. I don't want them to get the idea they can."
With the book completed, it's time now for Gell-Mann to return to the Olympian task of finding out how the bug and Chagas' disease and all other scientific knowledge fit together. Gell-Mann says certain sciences are "more fundamental" than others, as physics is more fundamental then chemistry. Each subject has its own, useful theoretical tools, he says, but it is also important to work on the "staircases" or "bridges" that will connect the various levels of inquiry into a single coherent house of knowledge. For example, Gell-Mann writes, the well-developed laws of chemistry can explain why two hydrogen atoms link together in a molecule. But more complicated bridgework would be required if, say, a theoretical chemist wanted to relate those laws to the more fundamental science of physics, which describes how the electrons in the hydrogen atoms act to connect the pair.
Gell-Mann's colleagues, however, are divided on whether such bridges and ladders can ever be built. Knowledge of how simple things come together in complex systems "is not seamless," says George Cowan, a former Los Alamos nuclear scientist who also helped found the Santa Fe Institute and served as its first president. As a system becomes more complex, Cowan says, "things arise that we call 'emergent properties' or, with more honesty, 'things we don't understand.' " Because the properties are not understood, he says, it's far from clear that the different kinds of knowledge represented by biology, chemistry, physics and psychology will one day neatly fold into one another. "These are the opening rounds of something that's going to go on for a long time."
But, Cowan adds, "Murray wants an all-embracing view. It comes of the success he's had by assuming that there had to be a fundamental elegance and beauty in subatomic particles. That led to quarks, so the faith paid off. In complexity, the jury is still out."
A MESSAGE: "CALL Murray." We've said goodbye only a few hours before.
"Those insects," Gell-Mann says when he is reached on the phone from "inside the fence," where people with security clearance work at the Los Alamos National Laboratory. "The family is Reduviidae. I don't know how I could have forgotten. And I said they didn't carry Chagas' disease. That's not right. They do carry it. But apparently they don't transmit it, because they don't defecate while feeding. The way the disease is carried by their relatives is that they bite you on the lips and defecate and then you smear the feces into the wounds when you wipe your lips. So what I said before was not quite right."
Gell-Mann's voice on the phone is warm, cheerful, deeply happy that any misapprehension he may have spread about the kissing bug has been corrected, that the tiniest of details is now precisely right. "Thanks," he says. "Thanks so much for calling back."

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Hotels Catering To Children

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
IT was probably inevitable: Two hotel chains now have frequent guest programs for children, and one Washington hotel has weekend "kids' concierges," who are contemporaries.
Promotions like these, as well as the more usual summer programs, underline the rising importance of children to the lodging business. Marketing surveys indicate parents want to take young children along, even on business trips. As for vacations, Nancy Vaughan, a spokeswoman for Best Western International, said: "A lot of decisions are being made by kids. They influence the family." To respond to both possibilities, hotels may combine price promotions for the bill-paying parents, and recreation activities, gifts and cartoon character tie-ins that appeal to children. Virtually all major chains have something for this market; here is a selective list of new or revised programs. 
 If the place you want to stay is not given, ask anyway, suggesting some added value. In hotels that do a big convention business, it is frequently possible in the summer to get a discount on the cost of an adjoining room for the children. It's also a good idea to ask the maximum age for a child to stay free in an accompanying adult's room.
The Best Western chain is one with a child's frequent stay promotion, the Young Travelers Club. The club began last year and this spring was revised into a frequent-stay program similar to the one for adults. The member, age 16 or younger, joins at a hotel or by calling an 800 number. A point is awarded for each dollar the parents spend on the hotel room. Points may be redeemed for United States savings bonds, certificates of deposit to pay college tuition or for merchandise. As a sample, a savings bond that matures in 12 years to yield $200 would require 2,350 points. Parents traveling alone may use the child's card instead of their own and help accumulate points.
 
Family Features
 The 3,314 independently owned Best Westerns set their own top ages for letting children stay free in the room with parents, but club members up to 16 stay free at any participating hotel. A third of the Best Westerns had signed up by mid-April. Best Western Young Travelers Club: (800) 528-1234.
The other children's frequent stay program, at the Hyatt Hotels, is linked to Camp Hyatt. Children under 12 who stay four times at any of 100 Hyatt resorts or hotels in the United States, Canada and the Caribbean and have the visits punched in their club passports receive free Camp Hyatt merchandise. The hotels with camps offer a second room for the same family at a 50 percent reduction in price. Hyatt Hotels: (800) 233-1234.
The 52 Westin hotels and resorts in the United States, Canada and Mexico are beginning a program on May 15 that will have a number of features for families.
The hotels will prepare rooms for young children with devices like night lights, cribs, bed railings, potty seats and high chairs. Baseball caps and other gifts are given, including a bottle or cup that will be filled free at mealtimes. Other safety devices will be available. Children up to the age of 17 stay free in parents' rooms.
Westin is offering a free-meal program from May 15 to Aug. 31 for children 12 and under. The offer covers three meals a day ordered from a special menu available in some but not all Westin restaurants in a given hotel. Two children are eligible for each adult who is eating in the restaurant. This Westin Summer Getaway also involves reduced rates at 46 Westin hotels, $119 at the ANA in Washington, for example. As is typical with these offers, not all rooms are available at the promotional rates. The Plaza in New York and the Governor Hotel in Portland, Ore., are not taking part in the summer program. Westin hotels: (800) 228-3000.
Free meals are also a central part of the Holiday Inn program. From tomorrow through Sept. 5, 1,100 Holiday Inns of the 1,600 in the United States, Canada and Mexico will provide three free meals a day to children ordering from the children's menu; 700 of the chain's hotels do this year round anyway. The child must be accompanied by an adult who is eating and a maximum of four children from each room are allowed. Children 19 and younger stay free in the parents' room. Holiday Inns are also stocking Parker Brothers games for free loans; 10 different games are available at each hotel. Holiday Inns: (800) 465-4329.
 
Radisson's Discounts
 All 271 Radisson hotels in 30 countries are joining in the chain's sixth Shades of Summer, running May 12 through Sept. 5. Savings of 30 to 50 percent on regular prices are offered, and the chain says that half of its hotels include a free breakfast. This program also has a limited availability; according to Thomas J. Polski, a spokesman, an average of 10 percent of a hotel's rooms are set aside for customers paying the promotional rates. Children 16 and younger stay free in their parents' room. Advance reservations, with a request for Shades of Summer rates, are required. Most Radissons do not require payment in advance to guarantee this rate. Radisson Hotels and Resorts: (800) 333-3333.
Choice Hotels International lets children 18 and under stay free at all of its 2,350 hotels bearing the Sleep, Comfort, Quality, Clarion, Friendship, Econo Lodge and Rodeway names. Starting June 1, these hotels will be participating in a promotion tied in to the Western movie "Maverick." Game cards given on registration will all be good for prizes, some as modest as a soft drink, others ranging up to $100 gift certificates for Western clothing or a pickup truck. Children arriving at Comfort, Quality, Clarion and Sleep Inns will receive decks of playing cards.
The 1,100 Comfort Inns are now providing a free breakfast that includes fruit, cereal and milk along with the usual coffee and bread, making it possible to feed the children. Choice Hotels: (800) 424-6423.
Sheraton's program, Summer Suresavers, will run from Memorial Day through Labor Day. When the caller asks for this rate, the reservation agent gives the lowest possible rate other than a negotiated rate for Fortune 500 companies or the travel agent rate. This program also has limited availability, 10 to 20 percent of a hotel's rooms. Sheraton: (800) 325-3535.
 
Littlest Concierges
 The Kids' Concierges serve on weekends at the Omni Shoreham in Washington near the zoo. The program began three years ago, according to Arnold Fine, a spokesman. Eight children from schools in the area, public and private, get these minimum-wage jobs. They advise young guests on attractions and give behind-the-scenes tours of the hotel, which has two outdoor pools and other recreational facilities. Family weekend packages at the Shoreham cost $99 a night for a deluxe room, with children 16 and under free in the same room. A pizza party for four and a free video movie are included. Mr. Fine said that the rate was capacity controlled. Omni Shoreham: (800) 843-6664.
Hotel phone numbers and guidelines on rates are given in the free Washington, D.C., Guide 1994 from the Washington Convention and Visitors Association, 1212 New York Avenue, N.W., Suite 600, Washington, D.C. 20005; (202) 789-7000.

HEADLINE: Park Avenue, Without Doormen

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
IF one thinks of the stolid apartment houses lining Park Avenue as $100 bills, then the little buildings sprinkled between them are loose change. Some are silver, like the half-dozen surviving mansions, and some are nickel, like the occasional modest apartment house or tenement.
This is about the pennies, the tiniest and most humble of the bunch, the five two- and three-story buildings at 870, 949, 985, 1108 and 1110 Park Avenue. Most are more than a century old, but they all have somehow survived to serve an unusual group of tenants and owners. 
 In 1870, four stories scraped the sky on upper Park Avenue; few of the buildings on the half-built avenue were that tall. The railroad had been running up the center since the 1830's, making the avenue extra wide but also subjecting its residents to increasing smoke and noise as rail traffic grew. All the tracks south of 96th were placed below grade in 1872-1875, and new, planted center sections bestowed a faint gentility on the street.
This sparked a building boom of four- and five-story buildings and, after the 1890's, elevator apartment houses an astonishing seven stories tall. These were, in turn, wiped away after 1906, when the electrification of the railroad provoked a second boom, of the tall luxury apartment houses that still exist on Park Avenue.
Two successive building campaigns did not leave much in the way of Park Avenue's earlier history, but what was left over by the 1920's has largely remained to this day. Perhaps the well-known gallery of Portraits Inc., has made 985 Park Avenue the most familiar of the surviving small structures. It is a chubby little building, with a 25-foot frontage, in other circumstances a mansionesque dimension. But this is a plain little building, with bare Italianate detailing. It was built in 1870 by Ellen Smythe, a milliner, at a cost of $6,000 as a three-family dwelling; the storefront is probably a later alteration.
A view of Park Avenue in 1912 shows it in a row of little buildings with storefronts selling beer, ice, coal and other goods, but since the 1920's big apartment houses at 983 and 993 have hemmed it in on both sides.
Those who spent their childhoods on the East Side remember 985 as the home of the Florence Market, one of those fancy grocery stores that took phone orders for the Park Avenue gentry. Indeed, Anthony Tucciarone, who ran the market, bought 985 in 1948 and has kept the building even after closing the business in the late 1970's.
Now, instead of butterfly-cut lamb chops and choice fruit, the storefront offers the talents of its portrait artists, whose dreamy pictures of beautiful people in the windows make you wish you had been born rich. Marion MacKinney, the owner of Portraits Inc. who emigrated from the Fuller Building in 1986, says, "We wanted to be a little off the beaten track, but still have beautiful exposure."
"When people meet me somewhere else they say, 'Oh, I know that building,' " she said. "I don't want the foot traffic of Madison; this is a genteel business, and we often sit with a client for hours."
Mr. Tucciarone lives on the third floor and declined to respond to a request for an interview. But his second-floor tenant, Mary Beth Makula, says that "you don't really feel like you're living in New York," especially Park Avenue. The apartment she shares with her husband, Peter, and baby boy is quiet, homey and unassuming.
"It feels like a cottage, like a house in Vermont" she says.
The Makulas came from Boston four years ago, and this is their first apartment here. Their overnight guests can sleep upstairs at Mr. Tucciarone's -- "he's like my grandfather," she says -- and the doormen at 983 and 993 look out for their packages.
The oldest of the little buildings are a red brick pair between 89th and 90th Streets, 1108 and 1110 Park Avenue. These three-story buildings were put up in 1856 and are among the oldest buildings on Carnegie Hill.
By the 1880's they, too, had storefronts, and the 1910 census shows them occupied as two-family dwellings; the tenants included a policeman, a Parks Department driver and a department store saleslady in 1108 and an artist and a music teacher in 1110.
PHOTOGRAPHS of the 1930's show the store tenants as the Baldwin Fish Market at 1108 and the Bristol Market -- "Choice Meats" -- at 1110. Now Rita Farrell, a lawyer who lives around the corner on 90th Street, splits a storefront at 1108 with Marta Coiffure and the Plaza Florist is in the ground floor of 1110.
The owner of 1108 declined to allow his name to be used, but said that "there's nothing good and everything bad" about living there. He bought it in the 1970's when he was searching for a fallback location for a business he operated nearby on Park Avenue. That was never necessary, but he remained at 1108 nonetheless, and he feels quite apart from his typical neighbors in the big apartment houses.
"They go away for weekends," he says. "They just sleep here. They pay a million or more for their apartments and then another million to fix them up, and in their buildings they have a manager, a superintendent" and other building staff.
He says he has to do things himself, like laying his own sidewalk, which he carefully designed with shells and pebbles. "When I do things myself, I know it's done," he says, "and if I didn't do it myself I couldn't hang on to it."
His onetime neighbor, the late Judith Rothschild, bought 1110 in 1985 after a decade as a tenant and added a brutally modern top-floor art studio. She established a foundation to help other artists, which has offices in the building. A man who said he was handling the foundation's affairs but declined to give his name said that Mrs. Rothschild, who died last year, had had houses in Big Sur, on the California coast, in Provincetown, Mass., and Saugerties, N.Y., but that "she felt diffident about being an artist and being on Park Avenue," even wanting to adopt a sidestreet address, although without result. Her building has an exquisite set of Victorian doors inset with colored Minton tiles.
A few blocks south, anyone wanting to emulate Mrs. Rothschild can rent the two-story-high 949 Park Avenue from the Duell Estate for $12,500 a month for what they measure as 3,000 square feet plus a basement. Alfred P. Arnold, a mason, built 949 in 1864 and a photograph taken around 1915 shows a little building dominated by a projecting plate-glass storefront on the ground floor and a projecting cornice with five-foot high sign on the top: "Lincoln Markets -- D. Werdenschlag."
By the 1950's an interior decorator had displaced the cold cuts, and Ruth Blumka, an art dealer, leased the building in 1975, moving up from East 57th Street.
"Our clients come by limousine, or on foot, and only by appointment," she says, and the traditional art gallery addresses have come to mean little to her. She took a 10-year lease from the Duells, and redid the front to its present appearance. "I loved that building," she says. "I wanted to buy it."
But the Duells, who declined requests for an interview, did not sell, and Mrs. Blumka moved to a ground-floor apartment next door, at 941 Park. The next tenant was a plastic surgeon, but the building is now empty.
AT 870 Park Avenue, between 77th and 78th Streets, what looks to be a futuristic beach house is, way down inside, a private stable built in 1897. The original 870 was almost identical to the twin survivors around the corner at 75 and 77 East 77th Street.
In 1910 John J. Hackett, a 41-year-old "chauffeur -- private family," lived with his wife, Viola, and 6-year-old son above what was by then a private garage. In 1940 the architects Kahn & Jacobs redesigned it in the Regency style for a doctor. The architects Robert A. M. Stern and John S. Hagmann further modernized it in 1976.
The client for the 1976 alteration, Judith Stern Peck, is still the owner, although she is living elsewhere while she battles with her insurance company over reimbursement for a fire at 870 18 months ago.
Mrs. Peck said that she had been specifically searching for a private house in New York and the building at 870 was "the most secure way I could live in a town house -- with two big buildings on either side; there was no second choice."
Another benefit has been the abundant sunlight from Park Avenue, much wider than the usual brownstone sidestreet, but she says that the only reason she would move out is "too much space" now that her children are grown.
If the owners and occupants of Park Avenue's little buildings see themselves as separate from the rest of Park Avenue, sometimes the survival of the small structures has been due in part to their giant neighbors.
Mrs. Stern's house was owned for many years by the owner of the apartment house at 876 Park Avenue, which apparently held it as a light protector. In 1978, 955 Park Avenue, then undergoing conversion to a co-op, won an agreement with the owner of 949 Park Avenue not to increase its height.
According to the owner of 1108 Park, the developers of the 1920's apartment house at 1112 Park Avenue sought to bring 1110 and 1108 into their assemblage. But Julius Daub, the owner of Bristol Market, refused, explaining the odd T-shape that 1112 makes behind the little buildings.
In 1936, 1112 signed an agreement to pay the owner of 1108 $100 a year for the encroachment of its casement windows over the lot line of 1108.
ONLY the modern 870 Park Avenue is under landmark control and the bulky addition on 1110 Park Avenue proves that not everyone prizes these buildings as antiques. Despite the antisliver building law of 1982, any of these buildings could be subject to the kind of repeated additions that changed the little 415 East 57th Street from four stories to 15 stories in 1992.
The economic engine that makes most of these buildings go is the commercial or professional ground floor, which can generate significant rents. Leslie J. Garfield, the president of his eponymous real estate firm, says that 870 Park Avenue might sell for $4 million to $5 million and the other buildings in the $2 million range, putting them on a level with a rowhouse off Park Avenue. But it would be an oddball sell, Mr. Garfield says, because "I don't think the typical New York family wants one."
Edward Lee Cave, the owner of a real estate firm that bears his name, says "they aren't big enough to be grand, and Park Avenue bespeaks engraved stationery" adding that the east-west orientation of the houses means none of them could have the coveted south garden.
Each owner -- and even the lessees -- seems attached to the buildings. One, who used to play marbles on the sidewalk half a century ago in front of what became his house, says that even while complaining about the cost and the isolation, "I could never move."
"I don't know why," he says. "It's just one of those things."

Among them are, clockwise, from the top left: Nos. 985, 1108, 1110, 870 and 949. (Photographs by Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/Bronx Terminal Market;
Trying to Duplicate the Little Flower's Success

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
IN 1935, a new get-tough Mayor, Fiorello H. LaGuardia, took over the failing Bronx Terminal Market and in seven months made the multimillion-dollar boondoggle useful and profitable for the first time.
Now the market, along the Harlem River between 149th and 152d Streets, is a shambles under a troubled private lease deal, and another get-tough Mayor would like to repeat LaGuardia's success. 
 When LaGuardia took office in 1934 he began a program of construction of public markets for economic development and to reduce the number of New York's pushcart vendors, long considered an unsavory nuisance. Most of these markets were new construction, like the one under the railroad trestle on Park Avenue above 110th Street.
But in the Bronx there was a fortress-like cold-storage warehouse on the Harlem River between 151st and 152d Streets, begun by Mayor John F. Hylan in 1917 and never finished, even though it had swallowed up $17 million by the time the Little Flower was elected. Between Oct. 1, 1934, and May 1, 1935, the city built a new complex just south of the huge Hylan structure: small two-story concrete buildings of simple design, constructed at a cost of $570,000.
Designed by Samuel Oxhandler with John D. Churchill and Albert W. Lewis, the buildings were originally painted light yellow. The next year, 1936, the market's flagship structure went up, a small, cubist-style polygon at 149th Street with "Bronx Terminal Market" in large relief in the concrete, a piquant landmark to every northbound motorist on the Major Deegan Expressway. This building was designed to serve as a bank and, upstairs, a hotel for farmers.
The complex had a float bridge (to bring in rail cars by barge), a spur of the New York Central Railroad and good road connections to the Triborough and George Washington Bridges. So popular were the new 3,000-square-foot units in the two-story buildings that 80 companies squeezed into the initial 48 spaces, firms like Andrew Casazza, bananas; Cherson & Moss, apples, and the Illinois Meat Company. The large covered farmer's market has since disappeared.
In December 1935, LaGuardia visited the Bronx Terminal Market to announce "a serious and threatening emergency." He proclaimed it illegal to sell, display or even possess artichokes. Mob control, he said, had inflated prices, costing consumers $100,000 a year over the previous decade, and he aimed to break its hold. The price dropped and the artichoke ban was lifted the next year.
In 1937 the Department of Markets announced that it was giving up on the older cold-storage warehouse. Although the building was then fully occupied, the maintenance costs were high, and the cold-storage warehouse had never generated more than $65,000 a year in rent. But the newer, small units were making money.
In the 1950's the Major Deegan Expressway went up over Exterior Street, the market's main artery. At the same time there was talk of consolidating the city's markets at the Bronx Terminal Market, but the huge Hunts Point site was later chosen.
In 1972 the administration of John V. Lindsay leased the entire complex to the Arol Development Corporation for 99 years. But in the 70's and 80's the city repeatedly took action against Arol for failure to pay its rent and for not expanding the market facilities as it had promised in the lease. Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, reported finding evidence of bribery, corruption and self-dealing in the market lease by Arol and city officials, but it appears that no formal charges were ever filed.
Today the market bustles in the early morning hours; it has a secure niche as a central shopping point for foods for the city's bodegas, with wholesalers offering specialty foods from around the world. But the cold-storage building is a shell, and the piers a twisted wreckage, covered with junk.
Arol renamed itself Strategic Development Concepts last year. David Newman, a spokesman, said that the 1970's allegations were "harassment and an abuse of the judicial system to try to gain unfair political advantage" and regain control of the market. He said that in the past the city avoided maintenance "possibly to constructively evict our tenants" and that the company's redevelopment proposals had been ignored.
Last July the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins announced it would no longer fight to revoke the lease, but would instead condemn the 32-acre Bronx Terminal Market and the cold-storage warehouse for a specialized urban-renewal plan.
As it now stands, the plan calls for rehabilitating some buildings, demolishing others, providing public access, improving the streetscape and encouraging compatible commercial and retail development. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is continuing the effort and according to Simon Leopold, a spokesman for the city's Economic Development Adminstration, consultants will probably finish the plan this summer. Then the plan must go through planning reviews, which will take until September 1995. Only at that point can condemnation proceedings begin.
Mr. Leopold says that with "an aggressive schedule" they might be complete by January 1996.
Mr. Newman, the Strategic Development spokesman, said that his company had not studied the condemnation proposal but that "we don't want to fight with the city."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Bronx Terminal Market building in 1935, top (The Avery Library); the market building today on Cromwell Avenue. (Ed Quinn for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
An Assessment System With Distortions Built In

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
IN about a month the City Council will set the tax rates for the various classes of New York City property. Then the Finance Department will send out tax bills for fiscal 1995, which begins July 1.
What better time for owners of a house, co-op or condominium to haul out a calculator and figure out their own effective tax rate? This is the percentage that expresses the relationship between the property tax in dollars and the market value of the property. 
 Punch in the total property tax this year (fiscal 1994, which ends June 30). Divide it by a best guess of the current market value of the property. Move the decimal point two places to the right to get the percentage.
The result of this exercise done across a spectrum of properties citywide is to demonstrate irrationality in the New York City property-tax scheme, politically acceptable though it may be.
Legislators have created and maintained preferences that rest on cardinal principles of New York life: Load as much of the tax burden as possible on commercial property; hold down the taxes of homeowners by capping assessment increases and hold down taxes on co-ops and condominiums by assessing them comparably to rentals.
And, of course, maintain rent regulation.
All this creates special advantages for some of the city's wealthiest residents living as owners in its most valuable older housing, just as rent regulation provides the same for wealthy renters willing to stay put over a long term. And it puts many buyers of new housing at a disadvantage, especially in moderate-income neighborhoods where rental property, if there is any, rents at close to market value. Staten Island condominium owners, as an example, pay high effective tax rates.
This year a nuance has been added. A state law enacted last year and adopted by the City Council after modification seeks to decontrol apartments that rent for more than $2,000 a month and are tenanted by households with income of more than $250,000 a year.
Even before income and expense data are available to show that the law has had a positive effect on rental income, the city's assessors plan to adjust values of rentals in prime Manhattan locations upward to reflect the presumed benefit. That will lead to upward adjustments of nearby co-ops and condominiums. The impact will first be felt on the 1995-96 assessment roll, effective for taxes in the year starting July 1, 1995.
Meanwhile, those with calculators can ponder the effects of the arcane laws governing assessment practices. They favor not only one-family houses but also co-ops and condominiums in older neighborhoods with high market values and little recent construction. Even when market values slide 25 or 30 percent, as they may have in the last few years, the tax burden on these properties is modest compared with those of similar value outside New York City.
In the metropolitan area it is typical in one-family-home communities to find effective tax rates somewhat under 2 percent. At 2 percent, the owner pays $6,000 a year on a house worth $300,000.
The New York City homeowner who is writing these words is luckier. He lives in a sizable 1925 house in the St. George section of Staten Island, and he thinks it is worth about $300,000. (A neighbor's comparable house sold for $400,000 six years ago.) The annual taxes are about $2,500, so the effective tax rate is 0.83 percent.
Numbers like these spur legislators in co-op districts to seek to remove their buildings from Class 2 (apartment buildings, whether rentals, co-ops or most condominiums) and put them in Class 1 (one- to three-family houses and condominium buildings with three or fewer units).
CLASS ratios were established by the Legislature in 1981. The idea was to prevent a reassessment at 100 percent of market value, called for in a Court of Appeals decision in a case involving a house in Suffolk County. Had the city reassessed all property at 100 percent of market value, instituted differentials in tax rates for differing types of property and a system of phase-ins, a more equitable system might have emerged. But the technical difficulties would have been formidable even if the political will had been there. And it wasn't.
The Legislature instead enacted a law known as S-7000, setting assessment ratios for four classes of property. Assessment increases were then capped for one-family homes at 6 percent a year, and 20 percent over five years. As market values rose in the 80's, effective tax rates for the class fell.
Subsequently, smaller rentals also were given preferential treatment -- a 30 percent limit on assessment increases over five years, and no more than 8 percent in a single year. In the 90's the caps for small rentals were extended to small co-ops and condominiums.
The larger co-ops and condominiums don't have annual caps, but those that are in strong market areas, with older rent-regulated buildings nearby, have had favorable treatment anyway.
On the West Side and East Side of Manhattan, some of the most valuable co-op apartments in the city appear to have effective tax rates about as low as one-family houses as a class.
The law instructs assessors to determine value by imputing a rental value to co-ops and condominiums, rather than consider sales value. Rent-regulated buildings are typically the comparables in older residential neighborhoods. Low turnover in the most desirable locations suppresses their rent rolls relative to market values. Moreover, there has been little new rental construction to provide rents that reflect newer values.
Newer buildings -- usually condominiums -- benefit less because they are assessed in comparison with rents in newer buildings, which usually are closer to market values.
"There is a big difference in assessments between 1930's buildings, 1960's buildings and 1980's buildings," said Robert M. Pollack, a lawyer who handles real-estate tax appeals.
He estimated that 1980's condominiums on the East Side typically paid taxes at a rate of about $6 a gross square foot, or $8,400 a year for a two-bedroom apartment with about 1,200 net square feet of space. Its market value is about $330,000 ($275 a square foot); the effective tax rate is 2.5 percent. But the average assessments per apartment in older East Side buildings is often much lower than $6 a square foot.
CO-OP owners can calculate their effective tax rate by multiplying their taxes per share (typically reported to them annually by the management) by the total shares they hold in the co-op corporation, and dividing the result by their estimate of market value.
Data developed in the real-estate industry indicate that 2,400 co-ops with Central Park West entrances from 59th Street to 87th Street are paying average taxes of $5,600 per apartment this year. The average price in 66 sales last year was $898,000. The effective tax rate is therefore 0.6 percent.
On the East Side avenues -- Fifth, Madison and Park, 59th Street to 87th Street -- the effective rate for co-ops appears to be about 0.8 percent. There were 245 sales in 1993 at an average price of $1.18 million. There are about 6,600 co-ops in 122 buildings.
The sales information comes from Douglas Elliman Gibbons & Ives, the large management and marketing firm. The data on the number of buildings and apartments and the assessments per apartment were worked out by the Real Estate Board of New York.
The effective tax rates were calculated on the basis of actual assessments, although this is a slight distortion since there is a five-year phase-in of new taxes outside Class 1 when actual assessments rise. In that period taxes are based on a transitional assessment. But the gap between transitional and actual assessments is great only in periods of sharply rising values, and in recent years it has narrowed.
Brokers say that the largest apartments in older buildings with the finest views and extravagant improvements, which command premium sales prices, often have a share allocation that does not reflect their true value. Therefore they may have an unusually low effective tax rate. These may have been the very apartments that were selling best in 1993, driving down the effective rate along the prime residential avenues in Manhattan.
Property-tax revenue is slumping as well. But the distortions are thriving. According to the Real Property Tax Reform Commission, which issued a report last December after a six-month study of property taxes requested by former Mayor David N. Dinkins and City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, the effective tax rate currently for Class 1 property as a whole is 0.78 percent. For Class 2 it is 2.5 percent; for Class 3 (utility property) it's 3.13 percent and for Class 4 it is 4.75 percent.
"THE Legislature should never have passed S-7000," said Dick Netzer, professor of economics and public administration at New York University. "It is the worst piece of property tax legislation ever passed in the United States. It enshrined discrimination among the classes and it made matters worse."
Well-to-do co-op owners, of course, are paying many taxes besides the property tax. Their total tax burden may well be heavier than that of people of like income living in surrounding communities who are paying much higher effective property-tax rates.
A study done in 1988 by John E. Petersen and Ian Allen for the Government Finance Research Center in Washington compared the total Federal, state and local tax burdens of families with gross incomes of $125,000 in New York City and other communities.
The burdens were similar -- $38,800 in New York City, $41,900 in Glen Cove, L.I., $34,700 for a family living in South Orange, N.J., and earning its livelihood in Newark. The property-tax burden was far lighter in New York City. The New York household paid only $3,300 in property taxes, while the Glen Cove household paid $11,900. But the New York household paid more in Federal, state and local income tax.
