HEADLINE: Commercial Property/The SoHo District;
Grit to Glamour: The Evolution of SoHo

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
OVER the last few decades, SoHo has changed from a district for light manufacturing to a haven for artists to a home for the poshest of galleries. Now it is steadily marching into the realm of the uncharacterizable, an area where furniture stores and art galleries and funky fashion shops -- and lately, even a soupcon of mainstream stores like Armani A/X and Lechters Housewares -- coexist.
"What was once just an art gallery place has become an international marketplace for style and design, a place that foreigners routinely include on their New York itinerary," said Louis E. Sagar, owner of Zona, a store at 97 Greene Street that sells expensive, handcrafted items. 
 Stephen Werther, the owner of both Portico Home and Portico Bed & Bath, both of which sell high-end linens and other home accessories, put it more simply. "This feels like the world's greatest shopping mall," he said.
Not every denizen of SoHo, which is bounded by Houston and Canal Streets to the north and south, and Lafayette Street and West Broadway on the east and west, greets the influx with delight.
Many long-time residents are, through organizations like the SoHo Alliance, striving to keep the neighborhood's once-insular nature from fraying even more. They are fighting to prevent local restaurants from opening sidewalk cafes and to keep existing rules that make it difficult for anyone but working artists to rent apartments.
Retailers, meanwhile, are often shellshocked by the scads of peddlers that still throng SoHo streets on sunny days. Landlords still must go through a ponderous permit process before they can convert ground-floor space into stores.
And some SoHo-watchers worry that SoHo is growing so fast that it will fall prey to the Columbus Avenue phenomenon -- trendy retailers, with their willingness to pay high rents, driving out local shops only to go out of business themselves when sales do not sustain those rents.
Last November, the Replay Country Store, which sells new and used jeans, took space on Greene and Prince Streets for about $85 a square foot a year. A few months later a tee-shirt store agreed to pay $175 a square foot across the street.
"There's no way the new store will ever do the volume to sustain that rent," predicted one retail expert who insisted on anonymity. Still, neither the hassles nor the fears nor the rules have kept SoHo from turning into an international marketplace cum tourist attraction that is luring more and more stores and office tenants each day.
"The demand for retail space in SoHo is outstripping the supply," said Caroline P. Banker, senior vice president of New Spectrum Realty, a retail brokerage. "They're getting $100 a square foot on Prince Street for space they couldn't have gotten $55 for two years ago."
Local building owners are equally ebullient. Not only are their street-level spaces going fast, but they also are filling the upstairs offices that were vacated in droves when the recession wrought havoc with the art galleries that once occupied them.
Jonathan P. Switzer, a managing director of Winoker Realty who is leasing agent for 568 and 578 Broadway, says he has been renting space not only to out-of-town galleries looking for short-term leases but also to such non-artsy tenants as pediatricians.
Jeffrey Gural, who owns 560 and 594 Broadway, says his buildings are full. "Sure, lots of the galleries that catered to the yuppie crowd are gone, but we're filling up with small ad lagencies, architects, people who realize it is a lot more fun to work here than to join the suspenders crowd up north," Mr. Gural said. "This is the strongest market we've ever faced."
STILL, the most visible sign of SoHo's resurgence is on the ground floor. For now, most of the classier shops are congregated around Prince and Spring Streets, with many of the better restaurants on West Broadway and the furniture stores clustered on Wooster Street.
And, of course, the art scene still exists and thrives, with galleries sprinkled throughout those streets.
"All the traffic has turned West Broadway into an internationally known restaurant row," said Robert S. Bookman, an attorney for the West Broadway Association, a group of restaurant owners that wants to be allowed to operate unenclosed sidewalk cafes.
Lately, the demand for space is revitalizing even lower Broadway, a street that until a few years ago was characterized primarily by the type of low-end retailing usually associated with West 14th Street.
Last year there was a Blimpie's on the corner of Spring and Broadway; today there is a coffee bar. And the corner of Prince Street and Broadway has turned positively upscale: Armani A/X is on the northeast corner; Dean & DeLuca, a specialty food store, is on the southeast; the Nature Company, which sells products to promote nature and conservation, is on the southwest and the Guggenheim Museum SoHo commands the northwest.
"This corner has become the epicenter of SoHo," said Benjamin Fox, a New Spectrum partner.
That is probably an exaggeration, in that SoHo's eastern end still does not attract much strolling traffic. That's one reason that Terra Verde, a self-described ecological department store, recently moved from Lafayette Street to 120 Wooster Street, right off Prince Street.
"In the old location we had regular customers, but here we get weekend people who trip over us as they walk the street," said Katherine Tiddens, the store's owner.
But Broadway has its pluses. The rents remain cheaper, although they are creeping up. There are huge spaces available. And retailers who have established a loyal following elsewhere can sometimes bring those customers along with them.
Dean & DeLuca, for one, started out in a tiny shop on Prince Street. Six years ago, when it wanted to expand into the bustling Zabar's-type place it is today, it moved to Broadway, keeping the former shop as a coffeehouse.
"The rents were good, and this was close enough to my home base so that I could take my old customers with me," said Giorgio G. DeLuca, the store's owner.
Mr. DeLuca's retail neighbors are aggressively luring new customers. The Nature Company recently took out ads in several newspapers announcing that Jane Goodall, the zoologist, would be available to sign copies of her new book, "The Great Apes: Between Two Worlds." The ad noted that while the book was available at all Nature Company stores, Ms. Goodall would only be in SoHo.
Last February, Miriam Novalle opened the T Salon below the Guggenheim Museum Shop. She's not only selling teas and teamaking paraphernalia, but also offering what the store bills as a "proper English tea" from 3:30 to 6 P.M., and a "New York tea" -- same menu, different time -- from 6 to 8 P.M. Perhaps most important for the neighborhood, the salon stays open until midnight.
"TODAY, only destination stores with deep pockets can be successful pioneers on Broadway," said Mr. Werther, who never considered a Broadway location for Portico.
"But you'll see, five years from now, Broadway will be the logical extension of the SoHo we already know."
All this activity is an unexpected twist for a neighborhood that the city tried for years to maintain as a last bastion of manufacturing. In 1980 the city government ruled that no ground-level space of more than 3,600 square feet in SoHo that was not already used for retailing could be converted to that use unless the owners proved they had made "good faith" efforts to rent to a manufacturer. No residential use was allowed at all.
"Everyone felt the area could work as an incubator, a place where small manufacturers could get their start," recalled Norman Marcus, a zoning lawyer with the Manhattan law firm Bachner, Tally, Polevoy & Misher. He was a lawyer for the Department of City Planning when the zoning rule was passed.
As manufacturers moved out in the 70's despite the city's ardent wishes, many artists started to move into the upstairs lofts the manufacturers vacated. "Landlords maintained the fiction that these were studios, where people manufactured art," Mr. Marcus recalled.
Ultimately, the city changed the zoning to permit the lofts to be used as joint living/ working quarters for artists. But it left the retail rules intact.
The rules didn't much affect the tiny street-level galleries or coffee shops serving residents or art browsers, but it put the kibosh on any plans to woo major retailers.
Some developers tried to get around the rules, building bizarre structures that, technically, did not have any ground-level space at all. At 430 West Broadway, between Prince and Spring Streets, for example, there is a four-story building, without elevators, that was built in the 80's as a potential retail mall. The "ground" floor is a flight of stairs down; the "second floor" is 10 feet above street level.
Legally, it was rentable for retail; the problem was, no one wanted it. The building has but one tenant, a small Oriental gallery. A similar building stands empty nearby.
BUT as the spendthrift 80's turned into the thrifty 90's, other buildings thrived. Furniture manufacturers along Wooster Street -- Knoll International is a good example -- that once sold exclusively to the trade started selling retail, to capitalize on the number of people who were dispensing with expensive decorators and doing their own rehab. As more furniture shoppers showed up, new stores like Portico Bed & Bath opened in SoHo to serve them. Some were in buildings whose landlords had gained exceptions to the zoning rules; others turned a blind eye to legality.
One reason they could do that -- and risk being shut down should the city crack down on zoning violations -- is that SoHo stores often cost little to set up. Many of the old factories have great natural architecture -- high ceilings, ornate columns, hardwood floors, big basements perfect for storing inventory. And the stores have been able to move in with a minimum of buildout work, using the existing structure as decor.
At Portico Bed and Bath, which is in a building where blackboards were once manufactured, the original tin ceiling, floors and columns blend nicely with the fancy linens and furniture arrayed for sale. Terra Verde sports huge windows and a striking skylight in the back, a holdover from the building's industrial use.
Kate's Papery, a high-end stationer, moved into the landmarked Singer Sewing Machine building at 561 Broadway, off Prince Street, about 18 months ago. The owners hung paper on the ceiling, through which the original duct work shows -- an artistic look that was quite inexpensive to create. And brokers say the space is costing no more than $35 a square foot a year.
THE zoning problem may become moot soon anyway. Two years ago city officials issued a report acknowledging that ground-floor use in SoHo had changed enough to warrant re-examination of the rules. Joseph B. Rose, the city Planning Commissioner and director of the City Planning Department, says he is doing just that.
"Some of the measures that were adopted to maintain SoHo's special character may be anachronistic," he said. "SoHo has become a thriving retail environment in spite of all the regulations, and it's probably time to simplify the process for opening a shop."
SoHo's explosive growth has already simplified the expansion process for some of its retailers. Portico Bed & Bath has developed enough of a reputation to open stores in Westport and Greenwich, Conn., and in Short Hills, N.J. Zona has traveled even farther afield, with stores in Italy and Japan, and one scheduled to open soon in London.
"The travelers who got to know us here made it easier for us to succeed over there," said Mr. Sagar, Zona's owner. "If we were in, say, Chelsea instead of SoHo, we could never have gone international."
 
 
 
NOHO PICKS UP THE SOHO PACE
 UNTIL a decade or so ago, Houston Street was not just a physical slash through Broadway, but a cultural one as well.
To the south was SoHo, with its artistic patina. To the north was NoHo, with its insurance companies and smattering of inconsequential stores. SoHo came alive at night; NoHo died.
But now NoHo's Broadway, particularly through Eighth Street and Astor Place, is seeing a commercial upheaval all its own, albeit one with roots far different from those of its sister neighborhood to the south.
For SoHo, the changes followed the economy. For NoHo, they followed one store: Tower Records, which opened its behemoth emporium on the corner of Broadway and East Fourth Street in 1983.
With its midnight closing and huge music selection, Tower quickly became a place for local New York University and Cooper Union students to hang out. Soon after that, teen-agers from around the city and New Jersey started hanging out, too. The area even made it into tourist books geared for European students traveling through.
"Tower Records put this area on the map as a place for transient kids," said Benjamin Fox, a partner in New Spectrum Realty. "Now, just as SoHo is becoming more established and richer, NoHo is becoming younger and less affluent."
That switch has not gone unnoticed by national chains. Benetton, The Body Shop, Software Etc., and other stores that cater to a young crowd have sprung up a few blocks north of Tower, paying more than $100 a square foot a year for their space. Barnes & Noble plans to take over the store at 2-10 Astor Place that the bankrupt Conran's has closed.
In fact, NoHo and SoHo are starting to swap stores, as their newfound identities stabilize.
Several antiques stores and galleries have moved to Lafayette Street in NoHo, driven off by SoHo's rising rents. And Pottery Barn, which has a store on Broadway and West Fourth Street, is looking at a bigger storefront on Houston and Broadway, just across the line into SoHo.
"Houston Street remains a psychological barrier," said Jonathan P. Switzer, a managing director at Winoker Realty who is leasing agent for a couple of SoHo buildings. "You have N.Y.U. supporting NoHo, but you have a universe supporting SoHo."
 CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

HEADLINE: 19th-Century Reformer's Way With the Homeless

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
THE mothers and their children stare at the camera in the shelter where they will spend the night -- tired, apprehensive, huddled like sheep, afraid of the dark outside.
At another shelter, this one for men, the occupants are getting ready to sleep on cots so close together that they look like a carpet of rectangles. 
 These are the homeless, but not of today. These are the faces of the 1890's, a time known as the Gilded Age, but not for everyone. The Gilded Age had an underbelly of poverty and homelessness, and it was captured on film and in prose by an unlikely social reformer from Hartford.
The reformer was the Rev. John James McCook, the rector of St. John's Episcopal Church in East Hartford. He also taught languages at Trinity College in Hartford and eventually became head of its modern language department.
 
A World Traveler
 In social rank, Mr. McCook was far removed from the impoverished people he would come to know so well. Before he was 21, he had traveled in Europe for almost a year. After he had married and raised a large family, he took one of his daughters, Frances, on a world tour spread over two years, returning home laden with Oriental art and a huge collection of Japanese armor.
In the interim, however, he discovered the poor.
As a citizen of Hartford, living right on Main Street just a few blocks down from City Hall, he became concerned about the amount of public money going for aid to poor people. So in 1890 he went to a meeting of the Common Council to complain. In a brilliant political move, members of the council appointed Mr. McCook to study the situation and compile what they called an alms report, which he did. And in the detailed document he brought back to the council, he disclosed that he had changed his mind. The poor were not getting enough charity, he said. They needed much more.
The report transformed Mr. McCook into a leading advocate for the poor and a crusader for reform. For 37 years, until his death at 84 in 1927, no social problem was outside his purview: homelessness, the buying of votes, prostitution, unfair laws regarding paupers.
 
Records Are Voluminous
 His high level of energy, preaching at his church and teaching at Trinity, was only fueled by his new interests. He wrote voluminous, detailed reports about his excursions into a world seldom seen up close by people of his station. He often spoke in public about social problems that troubled him and proposed solutions.
His horizons did not stop at his own city. He prowled the missions, the flophouses, the police stations and the saloons of New York and Boston, often accompanied by his son Philip, who took photographs. One shows an establishment known as the Bum Beer Saloon on the East Side of Manhattan.
It was just one of dozens of pictures Mr. McCook had taken of bums or hoboes or tramps -- they were called all of these -- because they fascinated him the most. The other poor people he studied -- the abandoned mother, the man who would vote 15 times under 15 names on Election Day, the neglected child, the drunkard, the disabled veteran -- he would keep at an objective distance in his reports. But he came to know the tramps personally and in many cases fondly.
"I always realize the oneness in humanity as I talk and get these people to talk in return, easily and freely," he once wrote.
When the tramps arrived at his back door, he would question them at length about their travels, where they came from, how they lived. And the more he knew, the more he wanted to know. He satisfied some of his curiosity by printing a questionnaire and sending it to 40 police departments around the country, asking that indigents fill them out. (Many police departments of the era provided sleeping accommodations of sorts for people passing through their communities.)
The tramps responded to the invitation to tell their stories, occasionally with good humor. Asked his occupation, one answered, "Gentleman." To the question "When are you going to work again?," the answer was, "Never."
 
Letters From Roving Bill
 From the 1,349 returned questionnaires, Mr. McCook arrived at a profile of the tramp of the time: a single, white, Roman Catholic male between 20 and 40, literate, unemployed and intemperate.
But to Mr. McCook each tramp was an individual. Some had fascinating nicknames -- Connecticut Fatty, Dan the Dodger, Providence Bob, Philadelphia Shorty -- and fascinating exploits. He carried on a 20-year correspondence with one tramp, Roving Bill Aspinwall, although they never met. Mr. McCook had asked Connecticut Fatty to write to him from the road, and Fatty turned the duty over to Roving Bill, a more literate type.
When the tramps showed up at his door, Mr. McCook would send them to a nearby photographer's studio, where they would pose for their portraits. Then they would return to the house to be fed, but only after doing some chore, like chopping wood. Mr. McCook did not believe in tramps being on the dole.
After his death, two of his unmarried children, Anson and Frances, continued to live in the family home. Anson, a lawyer, died in 1967 and Frances in 1971. The house, parts of which date to 1782, passed on to the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society. It still sits on Main Street, a graceful touch of the 18th and 19th centuries perched between two bland modern buildings, the Federal building and a residence for elderly people.
 
Touring Another Age
 A visit to the Butler-McCook Homestead (John James McCook married his second cousin, Eliza Butler, who lived in the house) offers an intimate look at a family of affluence a century ago. Details include overstuffed furniture, dark woodwork, bric-a-brac, china and silver, games the children played, and the formal garden in back where they roamed. (The house is open to the public from mid-May to mid-October, on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays from noon to 4 P.M.)
The homestead is authentic because the family never threw anything out, said the Antiquarian andLandmark Society's resident expert on John James McCook, Trudy K. Jones. "They kept diaries, journals, checkbook stubs, everything."
When members of the society were first sorting through the treasures in the house, however, it appeared that the credo of keeping everything had been violated. They found a note from Mr. McCook to Frances, asking her to destroy his personal papers, including those on all the social issues that troubled him. But Frances's prudence won out over her father's wishes. Tucked away in the attic were boxes of the real legacy of John James McCook.
Out they tumbled -- the surveys, the recommendations, the pictures that showed the face of poverty in the Gilded Age and what Mr. McCook wanted to do about it.
Among the papers was a sketch of a state reformatory he wanted to build in Hartford, to try to rehabilitate people instead of ignoring them or simply warehousing them.
 
Posing With the Trains
 The reformatory was never built. It had been proposed for Fairfield Avenue, an area of fine homes, then and now, in the South End of the city. Neighborhood residents protested, not against the reformatory but its location. "There was a lot of 'Nimby' then too," Trudy Jones said.
The most fascinating pictures are of the men who most interested Mr. McCook: the tramps, posing for the camera in a studio or with the trains that carried them from city to city.
And the question comes up: Did John McCook, the clergyman, the college professor, really want to be a tramp, a man free to go when he wanted and return when he wanted, without the constraints of the age in which he lived?
Trudy Jones has thought about that. "He probably would have loved being a tramp," she said. "But he couldn't be. He was caught up in the Victorian ideal: family, job, tradition. But he got to understand them and became sympathetic to them. He really lived his Christian faith."

Jones, said: "They kept diaries, journals, checkbook stubs, everything." (Pg. 15) (Photograph by George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

Assessing Assessment By a Co-op
 
Q. When I bought my co-op apartment in 1988 I was informed that the board of directors would vote an assessment whenever some improvement had to be made in the building. What I was not told is that suddenly we would have an assessment every year. 
 In 1991 the board voted an assessment of $3 per share payable over three months. In 1992, there was a permanent 10 percent monthly increase. In 1993, there was an assessment of one month's maintenance payable over six months. This year, there will be an assessment of one and a half month's maintenance payable over seven months.
In four years, we have had three assessments and one increase. Only the first assessment was calculated according to the shares. Are these assessments legal? Have they been done properly? If not, what can we do? . . . Maria S. Mendonca, Jackson Heights, Queens.
 
A. They are all legal, said Charles Rappaport, president of the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives, assuming that the board has adopted a budget that requires the increases because the co-op's income will not be enough to meet the projected expenses.
All the assessments have been calculated according to the number of shares an owner holds, Mr. Rappaport said, because maintenance is determined according to the number of shares, and everyone in a co-op should pay the same amount of maintenance per share.
"People pay different amounts, based on the value of the apartment, its size and location, but the amount is always proportionate to the number of shares one owns," he said. "It may be unfortunate that the economics of the co-op requires such increases, but they are legal."
 
Sublet Rights Of a Condo Owner
 
Q. As a nonresident condominium owner who rents to a tenant, I am required by the condo bylaws to file a lease with the managing agent, pay a fee on initial filing and another fee at each renewal. Why? I have title to and own the premises. Should I not be free to exercise the rights of ownership? Are not these bylaws restrictive of such rights? What if I choose to rent on a month-to-month basis with no lease? I opted for a condo rather than a co-op to avoid this sort of annoyance . . . Sheldon S. Sachs, Manhattan
 
A. Sorry, Mr. Sachs, but those are the facts of condominium life. "Although condominium ownership structure generally provides individual owners with more rights and more flexibility than co-ops do, a condominium owner nevertheless does subject him or herself to various restrictions set forth in the condo's declaration and bylaws," said Michael Finder, a Manhattan lawyer.
Those restrictions, Mr. Finder said, "generally include granting to the condo board a right of first refusal in connection with any sale or lease of a unit."
The condominium board, Mr. Finder said, cannot restrict the owner's right to sell a unit. "Unlike a co-op board," he said, "it can't just reject the potential buyer so the unit owner has to find another purchaser. It only has the right of first refusal. So if the board thinks the owner is selling or leasing far below the unit's value, or if it is unhappy with the prospective tenant or buyer, all the board may do is buy or lease the unit on the same terms or conditions. And that rarely happens."
With the right of first refusal, he said, "the condo board is entitled to request information, including a copy of the lease or contract for the rental or sale of the unit." A board, he said, is also generally entitled under standard bylaws to be paid administrative fees for processing such requests. "Although this may be viewed as burdensome by the letter writer," Mr. Finder said, "it does provide certain protection when other unit owners wish to lease or sell their unit. And a court is not likely to view the charging of an administrative fee for rental or renewal as unnecessarily restrictive."

HEADLINE: Does Sharpe James Retain Common Touch as Mayor of Newark?

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 7

 BODY:
The President was on the line to the Mayor of Newark. Could he, would he come to Washington, discuss the anti-crime bill, maybe stay the night?
Relishing the moment of two months ago, Sharpe James, president of the National League of Cities, occasional news-show guest and new Friend of Bill, chuckled at the President's politeness. 
 "When the president calls," said Mayor James, "you try to go."
So two months ago Mr. James went to Washington, where he slept in the Lincoln Bedroom, and later gave a fiery endorsement of the anti-crime bill. He was back at the White House last month and again two weeks ago.
In the last few years, the Mayor of this long-maligned city has become an increasingly popular figure on the national stage, a leading player on urban issues and a sought-after speaker.
"He's a great champion of cities and urban issues," said Donald J. Borut, executive director of the National League of Cities. "We have more requests for Sharpe to speak than I can remember. He's enormously popular."
And as his third bid for mayor winds to a close, the man who defeated the four-term incumbent, Kenneth Gibson, in 1986, then sailed to his second term unopposed, seems well positioned to remain leader of New Jersey's largest city for another four years. None of his three opponents has held elective office. None has come close to raising the $1.4 million he has for his campaign (his closest opponent has raised $36,000). None seems able to raise anti-incumbent murmurs to full pitch. Mayor James does not seem to be so much running for re-election as striding to certain victory on Tuesday.
Or is he?
In a way, Sharpe James is like Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York: often more popular in the nation than back home. Mr. James's critics say he devotes too much energy to defending Newark, almost to the point of self-parody, and not enough time planning for the city's poorest neighborhoods. They point to some of his properties -- the house along the shore, the one in Florida, the yacht -- as proof he is losing his common touch. People complain that he is away a lot; and who minds City Hall when he's gone?
In Newark, voter apathy is such that if few show up at the polls, the Mayor could be in trouble.
"I don't see a huge upswell of people fervently supporting anybody, which is why this race seems hard to gauge," said Rich Cammareri, executive director of the Newark Coalition of Neighborhoods.
Mayor James's challengers -- Colleen Walton, a podiatrist who moved to Newark from New York several years ago; Ras Baraka, an eighth-grade teacher and son of the poet Amiri Baraka, and William Payne, the brother of Newark's Congressman, Donald Payne, and head of a nonprofit youth-mentoring program -- say their campaigns have gained momentum in the last week.
"It's unfair that the press keeps saying there are no viable challengers," said Mr. Payne, who is considered the Mayor's chief rival. "We're getting all kinds of indications that the Mayor is going to be unseated."
 
A Curious Campaign
 No recent polls have been taken, so no one knows exactly what voters are thinking. The campaign has been a curious one, with opponents mainly squaring off in one raucous debate or forum after another stacked with the candidates' campaign workers.
But it does seem people have not made up their minds.
"I'm undecided," said Cynthia Brown, a receptionist at the co-op building where Mr. Payne and former Mayor Kenneth Gibson each live (and where Mr. James bought and sold a co-op as an investment).
"James has done some of what he said he was going to do," Ms. Brown said. "And he's already in, so I think a lot of people are just going to stay with him. He does have a lot of people on his side."
Among his friends in high places, Mr. James counts Henry G. Cisneros, who brought his commissioners from the Department of Housing and Urban Development several months ago for a public session where he delivered a $6 million check to Newark's public housing tenants. The Rev. Jesse Jackson was scheduled to visit Sunday for a pre-election breakfast.
But public endorsements from political figures are few and far between. The Rev. Al Sharpton, running for the United States Senate in New York, endorsed Mr. Baraka, not because he has known his father for years, he said, but because the younger Mr. Baraka is galvanizing young people to join the political process.
Turnout for elections in Newark is almost always low. Only 35 percent of the eligible voters are registered, and only 40 percent of those typically show up to vote in statewide and presidential elections. In March, the school board elections brought out 4 percent of the electorate, even though the system faces a state takeover.
 
Apathy Among Voters
 "There isn't much enthusiasm for this election, either," said Mgsr. William J. Lindner, founder of the New Community Corporation, a nonprofit organization that has built housing complexes for 5,000 people, health-care centers for the poor and a supermarket, among other things, in Newark's most desperate neighborhoods. "People on the City Council act as if they have a divine right to remain there, this even after three members of nine members of the cCouncil were indicted."
In March, the current and the former Newark Council presidents, Gary Harris and Ralph T. Grant Jr., respectively, were indicted on charges that they accepted bribes from a towing company seeking city contracts. Both seek re-election.
To Monsignor Lindner, the apathy is understandable given the state of the city. Newark surprised the nation, and itself, by winning an All-America Cities Award, and a most livable city award in 1992, the same year Mayor James was honored as a "most valuable public official" by City & State, a national newspaper for government officials. But Newark's vital statistics remain grim.
The city's per capita rate of AIDS infection is second only to that of New York City, and it has the highest rate of AIDS among women in the country. Unemployment hovers at about 15 percent, almost twice the state average. Crime continues to plague its neighborhoods. And not only is the school system in trouble, but the city's population, at about 268,000, is dropping faster than almost anywhere else in the state -- 15 percent since 1980.
 
A Tale of Two Newarks
 Many have seized on the notion of two Newarks. The outer one, seen by 250,000 commuters to the city each day, is graced with skyscrapers and $6 billion in new office construction since the mid-80s. The inner city, similar to ones across the country, is mired in poverty, drugs, teen-age pregnancy, homelessness and crime.
Judging from his demeanor on the campaign trail, Mr. James does not seem worried about Tuesday's vote. Tall and athletic, the 58-year-old former gym teacher and Essex County College coach demonstrates the same energetic, outgoing style that charmed voters into electing him Mayor in the first place.
After defeating Mayor Gibson with 56 percent of the vote in 1986, Mr. James's first campaign slogan -- "A Sharpe Change" has become "Sharpe Changes." He points to the construction of hundreds of units of new housing and the addition of more police officers to support that idea.
"We've built more houses and hired more police under the James administration than at any other time in the city's history," Mr. James said. "New housing in every ward of the city, new recreation for the kids." And car theft is down 35 percent.
Lately, he said, he has spent a good deal of energy preparing Newark's application for the Federal urban empowerment-zone program, which would bring the city $100 million in loans, tax incentives and direct aid.
 
'Things Are Changing'
 These are precisely the kind of programs Newark needs, said Ronald Rice, a State Senator and City Councilman, who considered a run against the Mayor. He decided to remain on the Council -- his re-election bid is unopposed -- and is actively supporting Mr. James's campaign.
"Things are changing," Mr. Rice said. "Maybe not to the degree and satisfaction that we hope for, but they are. When you look at Mayor James's ability to lead, I think if the taxpayers and public are honest about the candidates I think it's best for the city if the Mayor were to remain at City Hall, especially with Governor Whitman talking about cutting aid to cities."
Mr. James has become a wealthy man in his years in office. He makes about $115,000 in salary as Mayor. His wife, Mary, appointed to the state Violent Crimes Compensation Board by Gov. Jim Florio in 1991, makes $83,000 a year. In addition to the yacht, Mayor James owns or co-owns five properties, including one in a pleasant Newark neighborhood.
An article in the New Jersey Law Journal in February 1993 questioned how it happened. And while Mr. Payne has prodded Mayor James to release his tax forms, the Mayor has refused.
"I want to know where the allegations are here," Mr. James said. "So what? I own property. Didn't know it was a crime to own property."
Mr. Cammareri of the Coalition of Neighborhoods said people have heard about the Mayor's real estate but don't seem to consider it a real issue. "They want to know what's going to be done for the city," he said. "And by whom."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 10, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about the Mayor of Newark, Sharpe James, misstated the year that Newark received two awards. It was 1991, not 1992, when Newark won an All-America Cities award from the National Civil League and was honored as one of the nation's most livable cities by the United States Conference of Mayors.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: VILLAGES, EAST AND WEST;
Cruising With the Decibels Down

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE 

 BODY:
It is Saturday night on Eighth Street and the rites of spring have commenced. Clusters of young women parade down the street, followed by groups of young men clutching 40-ounce bottles of beer or malt liquor in brown bags. The occasional Jeep or expensive sports car cruises by. But there are far fewer of the boomboxes that tormented residents last year, and those that remain are conspicuously quieter.
"They're getting the word," said Captain Peter Cassidy of the Sixth Precinct. For the last month, his officers have been engaged in Operation Soundtrap -- identifying vehicles playing stereos louder than 80 decibels -- on weekend evenings in the rectangle bounded by Eighth Street, Avenue of the Americas, Broadway and Bleecker Street. The increased police presence appears to have made a dent in the problem: last summer, in five test operations, 62 cars were seized as evidence; this year, in eight operations, only eight cars have been taken. 
 Greenwich Village has always drawn young people from all over, and the residents have tended to be tolerant. And as the Village's main commercial strip, Eighth Street has always been a bit of a youth-culture bazaar. But as the economic character of the area has changed, many local people say, so has the atmosphere on Eighth Street.
Tom Marcosson, president of the board of 2 Fifth Avenue, an apartment building that extends from Eighth Street to Washington Square, recalled that when he first came to the area as a New York University student in 1955, the street was dotted with cafes, bookstores and craft shops, as well as dry cleaners and other everyday businesses. But in the mid-1980's, soaring rents pushed out many of the old businesses, and shoe stores, with their fast turnover and youth appeal, moved in.
At the same time, crack took over Washington Square. When the park closed, at 11:30 P.M., the unruly crowds would spill onto Eighth Street, Mr. Marcosson said. "By last summer, Eighth Street became such an intimidating place for many residents, they were afraid to walk in the neighborhood."
The police say it was about three years ago that new crowds of youths began cruising Eighth Street, blaring rap music from boomboxes and giant car stereos and provoking more complaints about noise, public drinking, crowding, graffiti and public urination.
Police officials and store owners acknowledge that many of the newer young people are black and Hispanic, but they say people are reacting not out of racial fear but out of irritation about a declining quality of life.
The police have promised aggressive quality-of-life enforcement. And partly to tackle these problems, the Village Alliance Business Improvement District was established this year. The alliance's sanitation crew sweeps the whole district daily except Tuesdays, and specialists have steam-cleaned graffiti from facades and repainted security gates. Next weekend, the alliance's private security guard will hit the streets.
Many store owners are delighted by the changes, but at least one is worried. Jimmy Sheppard, a fashion designer who opened Shep's Nubian Fashions next door to Shakespeare's restaurant two years ago, says more police may scare business away.
"Maybe guys with their boomboxes look intimidating, but they're just trying to get the attention of local girls and trade beeper numbers," he said. "People who live here have to understand the Village is a landmark, a place for young people to hang out, and we must make allowances because they are the future." MARVINE HOWE

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MELROSE;
At Melrose Court, Progress in Shades of Teal

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
For 14 years, Crucita and Abraham Rivera lived in a bleak three-bedroom apartment in a sprawling building in East Tremont where hypodermic syringes littered the stairwells, drug dealers loitered in the hallways and falling asleep to the sound of gunfire was a way of life.
In December, the Riveras joined legions of others who over the last decade have bought the new homes that have begun to tranform sections of the South Bronx. Their only regret is that their four grown children are not with them to share the dream. 
 The Riveras' new two-bedroom condominium town house is in Melrose Court, a high-density development with balconies, patios and grassy interior courtyards with benches, walkways, trees and lampposts. Bright teal canopies grace the stairway entrances to many of the 265 two- and three-bedroom town houses on St. Ann's Avenue between 156th and 159th Streets. Security gates surround the 4.5-acre development not far from the Hub, the central business district in Melrose.
"We have less space, but we feel safer," said Mrs. Rivera, 52 years old, a housewife whose husband works as a nurse's aide at Bellevue Hospital.
The development, a $25 million public-private venture, is the city's latest foray into the thorny issue of affordable housing in the South Bronx. Urban renewal in the 40's and 50's tended to produce towering public housing developments. But after social ills remained unchecked, such developments lost popularity, and the trend went toward low-density projects like Charlotte Gardens, Salters Square and the Nehemiah Houses. Now, developers are mixing high- and low-density housing, spread out in relatively low buildings like Melrose Court.
As a result, the neighborhood has become a landscape of houses, town houses, tenements and dilapidated buildings. Some residents and officials criticize the mixture as a hodgepodge, while others embrace it.
"Our effort is to mix density and provide a fabric for the community -- not Levittown," said Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer. "We have proven that all types of housing are marketable to a class of homeowner that already exists in the Bronx. What we seek is the economic integration of the community to avoid economic ghettoization."
At Melrose Court, all but about 10 units have been sold, said Marvin H. Meltzer, the Manhattan-based architect who designed the development, considered a prototype for future affordable housing ventures in the South Bronx. It recently received the 1994 Pillars of the Industry Award.
The project was built by the Procida Construction Corporation of the Bronx, which has produced 2,000 housing units in the area since 1984, in conjunction with the City Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the Bronx Shepherds Restoration Corporation and the New York City Housing Partnership.
Nearby, plans are under way for Melrose Commons, a 2,000-unit project that is part of a proposal to revitalize 200 square blocks with the construction of new homes, apartments and businesses.
"I grew up in the South Bronx," said Rosa Rivera (no relation to Crucita or Abraham), 34, a school crossing guard who moved into Melrose Court in January with her 13-year-old daughter after spending years in a cramped apartment in University Heights. "Now, I've moved back in style. I have a patio and I can't believe it." LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

HEADLINE: Client Aid; Legalities and Practicalities

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:
ASSUMING you can find someone, which often isn't easy, hiring domestic help can be a tricky proposition.
Hiring a self-employed cleaning person (someone not affiliated with a service) to clean a one-bedroom apartment in New York City costs an average of $40 to $50. Hiring someone from a service can cost $55 to $70. 
 Whether it's worth the difference is a matter of personal choice. But a service does offer certain advantages.
For one thing, a service generally accepts liability for anything that is broken or missing. "We are responsible for our maids," said Chris McLaughlin, vice president of McMaid, a national service based in Manhattan that has more than 100 employees.
Perhaps more important, a service takes care of sales and Social Security taxes, bonding and liability insurance, worker's compensation and disability and health insurance for the workers.
The law requires that if you pay someone cash wages of $50 or more over three months, you are considered the employer and so are responsible for all the usual tax filing requirements.
"And if you try to get around it, you are breaking the law and will have to pay penalties and fines in the future when caught," said Frank Keith, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service.
Many people, of course, do not comply and avoid being caught, although the issue of compliance with these and related regulations has come under increased scrutiny since two of President Clinton's Attorney General nominees were forced to step aside.
Following are steps to take if hiring a self-employed cleaning person:
* Get an Employer Identification Number from the I.R.S. by filing Form SS-4.
* To verify that the employee is eligible to work in the United States, file Form I-9 with the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Even if the employee is in this country illegally, the tax obligations are the same. But since it is illegal to hire such a person, anyone who does so faces penalties ranging from $250 to $3,000.
Rick Kenney, a public affairs specialist at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, acknowledged that many people hire illegal immigrants. And in the vast majority of cases, they do so without getting caught. "We wouldn't have any way to find out if the law was broken unless someone complained," he said.
* The wages paid must be reported by the employee on Federal, state and local income tax returns. You are not required to withhold income tax on these wages, but you can do so at the employee's request.
* You must withhold Social Security tax if you pay the worker more than $50 in a three-month period. For the exact amount to withhold, ask the I.R.S. for Circular E, Employer's Tax Guide (publication 15). About 6.2 percent is withheld, matched by the employer and sent in quarterly.
* You must also pay New York State unemployment insurance taxes if you pay the worker more than $500 in a three-month period .
* Liability and disability insurance is not required unless someone works for you for more than 40 hours a week.
The I.R.S. explains these steps in Publication 27, "What You Need to Know if You Hire Domestic Help." Phone: (800) 462-8100. MONIQUE P. YAZIGI

HEADLINE: Long Branch Journal;
Mayoral Campaign Threatens to Divide City

BYLINE: By ARTHUR Z. KAMIN 

DATELINE: LONG BRANCH

 BODY:
THIS historic oceanside city, which recently quelled what the police called a drug-related riot and is struggling to regain its economic health, is in the throes of an often bitter mayoral and Council election campaign. Some complain that the campaign is only further dividing the 28,700 residents and stalling a revitalization plan for the city.
The nonpartisan election, to be held on Tuesday, has drawn regional attention. It pits a councilman, the brother of a powerful member of Congress who also is the Democratic political leader here, against an incumbent mayor, who says the two have teamed up to defeat him. 
 "I'll be glad when this campaign is over so we can get back to the business of trying to improve Long Branch," said Frederick A. Eyerman, the owner of the Coast Hardware store on Broadway. "There's a lot of work to be done, and all of that sniping doesn't help things." He is concerned, he said, that crime has been raised as the major political issue and is driving away his customers.
Robert J. Furlong Jr., an Ocean Township clothing company owner, is the president of Long Branch Tomorrow, a group of business, professional and governmental leaders seeking to draw up a growth blueprint for the city's 5.2-mile-long beachfront area. "I guarantee you, on the day after the voting, our organization will be back operating at 100 percent," he said. "Right now, some people are afraid to take sides and are waiting to see who wins."
Seeking re-election is Mayor Adam Schneider, a 39-year-old lawyer who came into office in 1990 as part of a so-called "clean sweep" ticket that pledged reform and financial stability for this five-mile-square city.
One of Mr. Schneider's running mates elected to the Council in 1990 was John Pallone, 38, the owner of a New York City video production company and the younger brother of Representative Frank Pallone Jr.. The Congressman represents the Sixth District and will be seeking his party's primary election nod on June 7.
John Pallone, now a mayoral candidate, proclaimed crime as his central campaign issue and charged that it increased 16 percent under Mr. Schneider. He mailed out fliers to residents saying, "We shouldn't be prisoners in our own homes." He wants the Police Department reorganized and the public safety director replaced.
Mr. Schneider said John Pallone was "lying, using scare tactics to gain votes, and threatening the image of Long Branch."
Patrick E. Caron, the director of public safety and a 20-year police veteran, cited the New Jersey State Police Uniform Crime Report, from January through October 1993, showing that the total crime index -- a summary of seven major offense categories -- is down 14.5 percent. Violent crime was down 22 percent, he said, and nonviolent crime down 13 percent.
Michael A. Rescinio, an accountant and president of the 150-member Greater Long Branch Chamber of Commerce, said John Pallone had seized on an "emotional issue and it is hurting Long Branch." Mr. Rescinio added, "From what I see, the police are doing a good job in fighting a problem that is not only in Long Branch but all around us."
In the midst of the campaign came a three-hour melee, on Feb. 21, involving what the police described as a hostile, bottle-throwing crowd of 300 people. The police linked the melee to stepped-up efforts to arrest drug dealers. Two officers were injured and two vacant houses burned. Five businesses were damaged, and two police cars and a fire truck vandalized. Mayor Schneider imposed an 8 P.M. to 6 A.M. emergency curfew. Five people were arrested.
The Mayor said that he did not want to minimize the existing crime situation and that steps were being taken to correct it in the city, which is Monmouth County's largest urban municipality.
Mr. Schneider, also a Democrat, said: "The real issue in the campaign is that Frank Pallone wants to gain complete, total political control in Long Branch, and the only way he can do that is to have his brother as Mayor." He said the Representative had objected to several of his appointments and become angry with him because he had other people in mind for the posts.
Frank Pallone, a former Councilman here and a former State Senator, denied that and said he, indeed, was active in his brother's campaign. He added he was raising campaign funds and using his influence to assist him.
He called Mr. Schneider "a dismal failure" as Mayor. He said his brother was correct in bringing up the crime issue. "It's real," he said. "Things are so bad I'm afraid to go out of my Long Branch office alone at night." He said those who downplay crime "are sweeping it under the rug."
John Pallone would not comment on his brother's campaign involvement.
Meantime, the city is starting to make what Frank R. Gaynor, general manager of the Ocean Place Hilton Resort and Spa on the oceanfront,called "remarkable progress." The hotel has become the city's redevelopment anchor. And the Monmouth Medical Center, with 2,200 employees and a $76 million yearly payroll, is planning to build a multistory, $6.5 million parking garage.
The state has approved Urban Enterprise Zone status, which, with its tax breaks for consumers and employers, is expected to give a boost to the shabby downtown business district with its empty storefronts. The West End commercial area has attracted trendy, upscale shops and new restaurants. About $6 million in state and Federal grants and loans is coming in for housing and open space acquisition.
It was last summer that John Pallone decided he wanted to be the city's Mayor -- no surprise, observers say, because the unity of the "clean sweep" team had evaporated midway into the term. John Pallone vigorously began challenging Mr. Schneider on many issues.
It set the stage for what Michael J. Booth, publisher of The Atlanticville, the local weekly newspaper, called the "hardest-fought election I have ever seen, with stakes very, very high for Long Branch in the critical years ahead."
Controversy is also swirling around Mr. Booth and his 10,000-circulation newspaper over the campaign's coverage -- much of it, he said, coming from the Pallones and their lawyer, who have threatened suits over articles and pictures. "They want to control The Atlanticville," Mr. Booth said.
Frank Pallone said there was "no question The Atlanticville is biased against me and my brother." He said he did call Mr. Booth on occasion, but only to get "a fair shake."
There are two other mayoral candidates -- Councilman Michael L. Palughi and Harold F. Cooper. Mr. Palughi, 68, is a retired firefighter who was also a member of the "clean sweep" team. He said the job needs a "full-time Mayor, someone with maturity and experience."
Mr. Cooper, 46, is a Board of Education bus driver. He is black and said the other aspirants "do not relate to the minority community," which makes up about 19 percent of the population. He is a write-in candidate.
Fourteen candidates, two of them incumbents, are running for the five four-year Council openings. The Mayor receives $6,000 in annual salary. Council members each earn $3,500.
Frank Pallone, a lawyer, serves in the realigned Sixth District, which encompasses 26 Monmouth municipalities and 13 in Middlesex. He had a hard fight in a Democratic primary in 1992 but emerged victorious and then won handily in the general election. Long Branch, the Pallone hometown, is considered a Democratic stronghold by about a 4 to 1 margin.

HEADLINE: Professional Soccer Comes to the County

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHEN Bob Butler was a child in England, he started playing soccer. "I was 4 or 5, and I played the game enthusiastically until I was 35 years old," he said. "Soccer was my game and a great one it is. Outside of the United States, it is the most popular game in the world. But over the last decade there has been a tremendous growth in youth soccer here, with 1 out of 4 American kids now playing the game. So I feel that this is the right time to bring professional soccer back to the New York region."
It is to that end that Mr. Butler, a multifaceted businessman, has organized a professional soccer team, the New York Fever, which is New York's first professional soccer team since the demise of the Cosmos. And Mr. Butler has chosen Westchester as the home for the new team. The New York Fever will play its 12 home games at Barrett Stadium at Westchester Community College in Valhalla, with the first home game against the Delaware Wizards scheduled next Saturday at 5 P.M. 
 "The New York Fever represents the Empire State in the United States Interregional Soccer League, which has 72 teams divided into 8 regional groups," Mr. Butler said. "The U.S.I.S.L. was founded in 1986 by its commissioner, Francisco Marcos, who has set two main goals for the league: grass-roots ownership and organization for the teams and a stable environment for the nurturing of young players."
 
International Representation
 Observing that it has been a decade since New York has had a professional soccer team, Mr. Butler said, "In New York, with a million registered student and amateur soccer players, a whole generation of kids have never been able to see a live pro soccer game."
Referring to the fact that the Meadowlands is to be the site of World Cup matches this summer, Mr. Butler continued: "That event will certainly stimulate further interest in soccer, especially among the young. The organization and development of youth leagues, similar to baseball farm systems, is one of our goals. We have a strong commitment to youth soccer. Ultimately, we will have 10 youth teams. We already have a camp program, for kids 7 to 17 in place for this summer at three sites in Westchester and one in Fairfield County."
The Fever roster, he said, is made up of players with international representation, including those with World Cup experience. Coaches with national honors will direct the soccer camp programs.
"I call soccer the health food of major sports, because it's safe, not violent," he said. "Injuries are not major, and soccer is terrific exercise. Unlike baseball, every kid on the team has to run around."
Another plus, he said, is that soccer is comparatively inexpensive. "It costs about $50 to outfit a kid handsomely," Mr. Butler said. "Compare that with the hundreds of dollars spent on football gear."
 
Toy Company Employee
 The number of people involved with soccer in the United States has risen in a decade to almost 60 million from 19 million. "There are more American colleges today with soccer than with football," Mr. Butler said. "Women are also playing, and they are good. The United States International Ladies Team was world champions in Switzerland in 1992."
Now in his late 50's, Mr. Butler, a mechanical engineer by profession, first arrived in the United States after he was recruited by the Mattell toy company in California. Eventually, he became president of Marx Toys, when it was based in Stamford. He left Marx in 1976 to go into business for himself. "For years here and in England, I had been an investor and a silent partner in several restaurants," he said. "And the business intrigued me. So 17 years ago I bought the Spinning Wheel Restaurant in Redding, Conn., which was built in 1746. We did a major rehab, and it has been a successful enterprise for 17 years."
But it was through the toy business, he said, that he got into the world of international soccer.
"Marx Toys has one of the licenses for the N.A.S.L. and the great Pele was one of the licensees, so I was close to professional soccer and the Cosmos for 14 years," he said. "Why did they fail? Well, for one thing, when they started playing it was a different time. There was still a sense that soccer was a foreign sport. Then the team management insisted on playing in the big leagues in a stadium at the Meadowlands in New Jersey, which holds 80,000, when they rarely had an audience of more than 20,000. So the effect was negative. It looked like an unpopular sport with so few people in a huge stadium. And then, they didn't reach out and set up youth teams, which is an important factor."
 
$30 for a Family Outing
 Soccer, Mr. Butler said, should be enjoyable, affordable and convenient for all family members.
"Our aim is to make it possible for a family of four consisting of two parents with two children -- one under 6 who doesn't pay admission, to enjoy a day out for less than $30, that includes admission, parking, program, drinks and snacks," he said. "By contrast attending a baseball game with the same features costs a family $115."
The Fever head coach, George Vizvary, will be in charge of the Fever soccer camps and of developing boys youth teams in Manhattan and Westchester, Putnam, Dutchess, Rockland and Fairfield Counties. A woman's team and an indoor team are also being planned for next season.
"The concept is to create broad interest in all family members by participation or viewing from the sidelines," Mr. Butler said. And the prospect of a multigenerational audience for soccer, he said, has proved an effective marketing tool. "We have been able to attract some terrific sponsors who like the concept," he said. "For instance, we are the only club to be chosen by Nike in the league as its exclusive equipment supplier. Our Westchester sponsors include Pepsi Bottling Company, Ramada Inn, the White Plains Bus Company, Westchester County and the Pontiac Dealers of Westchester."
 
Lucrative Franchises
 And most Fever investors, he added, also come from the county. "So far 19 investors have taken a piece of Fever," he said. "Because individual investors are restricted from owning more than 10 percent, the amount they put in, ranging from $5,000 to $50,000, is relatively modest for an investment in a major sports franchise. We have 24 investors as our limit."
How valuable can such an investment be?
"Sports franchises can be very lucrative," Mr. Butler said. "For example, if you had invested $10,000 20 years ago in the New York Giants, you would be a multimillionaire today." And the investment the team is making in Westchester, he added, will add considerably to the local economy.
"Not only will we, for example, be buying goods and services here such as $45,000 to $50,000 for local advertising but we will also be hiring caterers, using area hotels, paying rent for new offices in Mamaroneck and the salaries of the 35 people that we are hiring for the stadium.
"In addition, every home game will bring in new business to the county since we exchange 88 tickets with other teams, and we expect those people will come, and with them visiting supporters. All of them will require lodgings and meals. And they will patronize the shops."
Westchester County officials agree. Phillipe M. Gille, senior executive assistant to County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said, "The arrival of the New York Fever, the first professional soccer team in Westchester, gives us new opportunities for recreation, and an added plus is the spinoff in economic activity. And the college will also benefit from improvements that will be made to Barrett Stadium."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Madrid Weathers a String of Scandals

BYLINE: By Ana Westley 

DATELINE: MADRID

 BODY:
MADRID'S stock market was shaken last week by corruption scandals that rocked the Spanish Government, prompting fears of prolonged financial panic. In fact, the opposite happened. After two days of steep plunges, the market began bouncing back once Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez made clear that he had no intention of resigning. Although analysts do not rule out further volatility, most feel that Madrid's Bolsa index will continue to rise as the economy improves. For all the ups and downs, there are still good buys for those in for the long run.
The market in Madrid, which enjoyed gains of over 50 percent in 1993 and a big surge this January, has behaved much like other European markets of late. It plunged over concern about rising interest rates in the United States, and recovered with cuts in Spain's own domestic rates. 
 Most brokerage companies bet that the Madrid index, which ended last year at 322.77, will surpass its January record of 358 before year's end. On Friday, it closed at 318.22, still below the level of the week before.
But Spanish politics provide no lack of thrills and spills. Madrid's market reeled last week in response to a succession of corruption scandals that created a sensation of imminent political instability. But the evidence now is that some foreign investors seized the opportunity to step in and buy what jittery locals dumped.
From an investor's viewpoint political events hardly looked encouraging: The former governor of the Bank of Spain, Mariano Rubio, and the former chairman of the Madrid stock exchange, Manuel de la Concha, were arrested and jailed on charges of tax fraud. A former national police chief accused of embezzling millions of dollars went on the run. And two Government ministers and two members of Parliament resigned.
"Naturally, with these daily installments in the press and political uncertainty, the markets get very nervous," said Jose Sevilla of FG Inversiones Bursatiles, a Madrid brokerage firm that deals often with foreign investors. But Mr. Sevilla, and other dealers, blamed most of the nervousness on edgy Spanish investors, not foreign ones.
"Domestic investors are relatively new in the stock market," Mr. Sevilla said, "and they are afraid that the foreigners are going to pull out as the corruption scandals hit the foreign press."
With interest rates falling, market watchers here say, Spanish institutional investors only jumped into the market late last year, according to most market watchers. Equity trading volume for the first three months of 1994 more than doubled over that of 1993.
"Domestic investors were just convincing themselves that it was time to buy stock portfolios, and now they fear they had been caught holding the bag," said Amadeo Reynes, of Analistas Financieros Internacionales, a financial consulting firm.
But on the bond market, which is more affected by foreign investment, interest rates on 10-year bonds, which had dropped to as low as 7.75 percent in January, soared back up to nearly 10 percent on Thursday before settling back to 9.65 percent by Friday.
At an investment seminar here last week, Finance Minister Pedro Solbes urged foreign fund managers "not to analyze the situation through the foam of corruption, which is hiding the reality of the country, which is frankly very good."
The growth in Spain's gross domestic product in the first quarter -- up at an annualized rate of 1 percent -- confirmed dealers' confidence in economic recovery. Last year, the economy contracted by 1 percent. The Government now estimates that it will grow by 1.3 percent in 1994. Indicators from car sales to housing starts and exports also point toward recovery. Tourism, a major source of foreign income, is expected to break all records this summer.
Despite market swings, traders see some abiding investment opportunities in Spain. For uncertain times, traders recommend electric utilities, the traditional refuge of long-term investors. The giant state electrical utility, Empresa Nacional de Electricidad S.A., or Endesa, is always popular. So is the smaller Catalonian utility Fecsa.
In banking stocks, analysts are hard put to explain the practically unstoppable rise of shares in Banco Espanol de Credito, or Banesto, which have soared 57 percent in value since the troubled bank was acquired by Banco Santander less than two weeks ago. No dealer recommends it, but the stock continues to climb while Santander's equity value has slid.
"Technically, it's impossible to understand how Banesto can be worth more than Santander's purchase price," said Jaime Smith of Benito y Monjardin, a brokerage firm. Buyers beware.
Traders see Banco Popular, Spain's fifth largest bank and its most profitable, as a better buy, along with the state-controlled bank Argentaria as well as Banco Bilbao Vizcaya, the rival bidder that lost out on the Banesto bid.
Mr. Sevilla of FG Inversiones likes Acerinox, an export-oriented company in stainless steel, and picks out Vidrala, a glass maker that exports bottles to France, as a good bet for this year. Vidrala is expected to post a 40 percent increase in profits this year.
Clive Heathcote of AB Asesores, another brokerage firm, suggests Uralita, a construction supply company, as a good risk/reward stock. But Mr. Smith warns investors to be careful with construction companies that are overdue for profit taking.

HEADLINE: Profile;
Building a Chemical Empire on the Industry's Castoffs

BYLINE: By KATHRYN JONES 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY

 BODY:
WHEN the going gets tough for industrial companies, the Utah billionaire Jon M. Huntsman hops in his jet and goes hunting. Chemicals are his game, and he has built the nation's largest privately held chemical business by snapping up premium properties at low prices when the industry goes into one of its periodic recessions and big corporations unload chemical assets.
These days, he is taking aim at some huge targets. In late April, Mr. Huntsman, chairman and chief executive of the Huntsman Companies, completed the largest and perhaps riskiest deal of his life. He and Kerry Packer, one of Australia's richest men, paid $860 million for Texaco Inc.'s worldwide petrochemical operations. The acquisition will almost double the size of his family business, to about $3.4 billion in annual revenues. 
 Then last week Mr. Huntsman disclosed that he was in talks to acquire at least part of the chemical operations of another American company, which he would not identify.
The timing of these deals -- in the midst of the worst chemical downturn in recent memory -- is vintage Huntsman. He has often gone against conventional wisdom, buying when others are selling and lying low when plants are humming and prices high.
"We think that once again, as we did in the 1980's, we can catch the market upswing, repay our debt and move up," Mr. Huntsman said in his 20th-story office in downtown Salt Lake City, an office filled with mementos from his stint as White House staff secretary for Richard M. Nixon and trips to Britain and the former Soviet Union with his mentor, the late industrialist Armand Hammer. A huge photograph of his nine children and two dozen grandchildren covers a wall.
Mr. Huntsman's scrappiness and habit of watching every penny has deep roots. Born in Blackfoot, Idaho, in the heart of potato country, Mr. Huntsman dug potatoes and did odd jobs to help his father, a music teacher, and his mother make ends meet. He heard stories about two of his great-great-grandfathers, who crossed the mountains on wagon trains with the Mormon visionary Brigham Young in the 1840's and later became astute businessmen in the Utah territory. These stories stuck with him even after the family moved to Palo Alto, Calif., so his father could pursue a doctorate in education at Stanford.
After winning a scholarship from the Crown Zellerbach paper company to the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business, Mr. Huntsman thought his destiny lay in the paper business. But after marrying his childhood sweetheart, Karen, he ended up working at his wife's uncle's egg distribution company -- and scored his first success.
Noticing that the cardboard egg cartons leaked, Mr. Huntsman developed a plastic version. The business took off and was bought by Dow Chemical in 1965, bringing him a nice profit. Mr. Huntsman, who had harbored dreams of being an entrepreneur, formed his own business making plastic packaging, including containers for fast-food products like McDonald's "clamshell" burger box. In 1970 he sold that company and started over, sowing the seeds of his current empire.
Despite his global deal-making, Mr. Huntsman is a reserved, soft-spoken man. His life revolves around his church (he's a devout Mormon), family, business and philanthropy. Four of his six sons work in the company, as do some church members.
Mr. Huntsman has had a brush with mortality recently -- a cancerous prostate was removed in 1992 and he has mouth cancer, which is in remission -- and friends say this has made him more introspective and has driven him to leave something more behind than a business. One of his passions: to find a cure for cancer, which killed both his parents. His family has given $10 million for a cancer research center at the University of Utah, and Mr. Huntsman plans to do more.
Around the end of the decade, Mr. Huntsman vows to cash in his holdings and use a big chunk of the proceeds to create a major charitable foundation in the Ford and Carnegie tradition. All the details have not been worked out, but Mr. Huntsman said he wants it to be run by family members over many generations and focus on areas like cancer research, children's medicine and the homeless.
"To me it's paying dues," Mr. Huntsman said. "I have been blessed with this company."
MR. HUNTSMAN does have a few critics -- on both the philanthropic and the business fronts. When the family gave $60,000 in 1982 to fight the legalization of parimutuel betting on horse races in Utah, a referendum opposed by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, its backers accused the Mormon church and Mr. Huntsman of collusion. In response to such criticism, Mr. Huntsman said: "Nobody has to tell me that I'm opposed to gambling in Utah."
And environmentalists have targeted Huntsman, as well as other chemical companies, for making products that create trash that isn't biodegradable, like polystyrene and other plastic packaging. Huntsman is one of several chemical companies that have formed joint ventures in recent years to recycle polystyrene.
Mr. Huntsman assembled his collection of companies by betting on turnarounds and sticking out tough times. Once he even pledged his house as partial collateral to acquire Shell Oil's polystyrene plant. That 1982 acquisition started the Huntsman Chemical Corporation -- which makes raw materials like polystyrene, polypropylene and other plastics.
A separate company, the Huntsman Packaging Corporation -- whose products include packaging for meat, cheese and produce and plastic bags for frozen food and bread -- has bought businesses from Goodyear, Mobil Chemical and Hoechst-Celanese.
The family owns 60 percent of the chemical company, 80 percent of a specialty chemicals business and all of the packaging operation.
The recently acquired Texaco Chemical Company, which makes a range of products including propylene, ethylene, lubricants and fuel additives and which is now a separate company called the Huntsman Corporation, will give Mr. Huntsman's chemical operations greater diversity and make it one of the largest suppliers of raw materials for products like soaps, detergents, mouthwash and toothpaste.
Yet analysts and even Mr. Huntsman say the latest industry downturn, which began in late 1989, has been deeper and longer than expected because so many companies built new petrochemical plants in the 1980's. Dozens of companies have reshuffled or cut back chemical operations.
When the Texaco acquisition was announced in September, some analysts questioned whether Mr. Huntsman had paid too much, too soon, not sure whether a rebound was imminent.
BUT Mr. Huntsman's timing may be on the money again, analysts say. Mr. Huntsman said he noticed the first price increases on chemical products in March. And analysts say the industry has hit bottom and is on a "slow turn," although they caution that it will take several years to make a sharp turnaround.
Jake Garn, the former Utah Senator, who is a vice chairman of the Huntsman Companies, said Mr. Huntsman seems to have an instinct for timing. "He sees the big picture," Mr. Garn said. "He's not one to say, 'What's the market today or tomorrow or even next year.' "
Since the Huntsman companies are private, they do not disclose earnings. But analysts say Mr. Huntsman has a good record of turning around unprofitable operations like the Texaco unit. His typical strategy is to cut redundant administrative costs, close inefficient plants and fine-tune operations so plants run more efficiently.
"He's going to be more aggressive in running it efficiently," said George J. Krug, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. "He will be a tough competitor."
Mr. Huntsman said $28 million had already been cut from the Texaco unit's costs by cutting redundant jobs, and he said an additional $20 million could be saved on buying raw materials. "Everything Texaco Chemical bought was sold to them by Texaco Inc.," Mr. Huntsman said. "Now we can go into the open market."
Mr. Huntsman surprised some observers with his choice of Mr. Packer as a partner. Mr. Packer, who controls Consolidated Press Holdings from Sydney, has a reputation for flamboyancy and a fondness for gambling and playing polo. The two met when Mr. Huntsman bought half of Consolidated's Chemplex division last year and became fast, if unlikely, friends.
"Kerry Packer and I are, to some extent, strange bedfellows," Mr. Huntsman said, but added, "I would trust him with my life."
The two billionaires originally planned to split the Texaco venture 50-50. Then, at Mr. Huntsman's suggestion, they changed the split to give the Huntsmans 80 percent. That and other factors delayed the scheduled January closing for several months.
As a result, they got caught in the middle of the volatility that saw interest rates climb sharply on high-yield bonds, which Mr. Huntsman used for the first time to finance part of the acquisition. But Texaco agreed to $52 million in discounts over the next two years to offset the higher interest rates.
Mr. Huntsman, who has a reputation for being straightforward in his business dealings and for calling or meeting personally with customers, employees and associates, said he called Mr. Packer shortly after the Texaco acquisition was announced.
"I said, 'Kerry, this is not going to work. You're independent, and so am I,' " Mr. Huntsman recalls. " 'Since this is an industry where we've bet our guns and yours is in mostly newspapers and magazines, I think it would make the partnership stronger if it was an 80-20 relationship.' He said, 'You're absolutely right. You're too old to have someone looking over your shoulder, and so am I.' "
 
Jon M. Huntsman
 
 Born: June 21, 1937; Blackfoot, Idaho.

 Drives: Range Rover.
 
 Family: He and his wife, Karen, have nine children -- ranging in age from 34 to 19 -- and 24 grandchildren.

 Products that launched his career: Plastic egg carton and plastic "clamshell" burger container.
